Title: Quantum gain in photosensitive materials: The domino mechanism
Affiliations: The authors are with University of Tsukuba, Chemistry Department, Sakura-mura, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ebbesen, T.W., The authors are with University of Tsukuba, Chemistry Department, Sakura-mura, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Tokumaru, K., The authors are with University of Tsukuba, Chemistry Department, Sakura-mura, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: It is shown that if a matrix contains a photochemically active molecule whose photoproduct is capable of undergoing energy transfer back to the starting material, high quantum gains may be obtained without further chemical processing. After establishing the equation for quantum gain in solid matrices, the necessary molecular properties and experimental conditions for observing a quantum gain are determined. Obtaining quantum gam with this dry process may be useful in increasing the sensitivity in optical data storage and m photoresist and photographic processes. © 1986 Optical Society of America.
Index Keywords: Chemical industry; Digital storage; Energy transfer; Photoresists; Shotcreting; Active molecules; Chemical processing; Dry process; Experimental conditions; Molecular properties; Photoproducts; Photosensitive materials; Solid matrixes; Optical data storage

Title: A Higher Order Approximation for the Electronic Structure of Hydrogen in Metals
Source title: Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section A Journal of Physical Sciences
Affiliations: Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Germany; IBM Deutschland GmbH, Entwicklung und Forschung, Schünaicher Str. 220, D-7030 Böblingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Göbel, K., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Germany, IBM Deutschland GmbH, Entwicklung und Forschung, Schünaicher Str. 220, D-7030 Böblingen, Germany; Wahl, F., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: A functional energy difference method based on first principles is used to calculate the electronic contribution to the storage energy of hydrogen impurities in metals. That electronic problem is treated in a higher order approximation which means considering the coupling between one-electron wavefunctions and three-particle amplitudes. A formalism is presented to eliminate all higher order correlations and to reduce the whole system to a one-particle Schrodinger equation with the help of a suitable Green's function. The resulting one-electron eigenvalue problem contains some logarithmic singularities due to the fact that there is no gap between occupied and unoccupied electron states in the band structure of a metal. In an electron gas model a convergent theory is reached by an improvement of the Green's function leading to a screening of the long-range Coulomb potentials. The result is a complicated nonlinear algebraic eigenvalue equation which is solved numerically for the special case of a single hydrogen perturbation in a magnesium crystal. The solution shows the influence of higher order electron correlations on the electronic energy eigenvalue of an interstitial hydrogen centre plot as a function of host lattice distortions. © 1986, Verlag der Zeitschrift für Naturforschung. All rights reserved.

Title: Geophysical prediction of fluid flow in sediments
Source title: Geological Society Engineering Geology Special Publication
Affiliations: Department of Geology, University of Nottingham, Nottingham NG7 2RD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lovell, M.A., Department of Geology, University of Nottingham, Nottingham NG7 2RD, United Kingdom
Abstract: The remote assessment of fluid flow by geophysical means relies largely on empirical formulae relating particular geophysical measurements to the permeability for a specific geological situation. This approach has been proved successful by other workers in the field for delineating and quantifying the nature of aquifers. Recently, however, the proposals to store radioactive waste in deep-sea sediments, together with the increasing interest in hydrocarbon formation processes and basin development, have provided further impetus to the study of geophysical-permeability interactions. A series of laboratory experiments involving a wide range of natural and artificial sediments has enabled the relationships between the geophysical characteristics and the fluid flow to be investigated. The results show very clearly the interrelationship between permeability and the geophysical parameters, electrical resistivity and compressional wave velocity, and the capability of predicting the one by measuring the other. In particular, extensive measurements of electrical formation factor and permeability in clean sands show the dominance of particle shape, and hence pore shape, in defining the interaction of these energy transfer processes. In defining a dependence on pore shape the variation of the results effectively identifies differences in the structure of the sediments and hence different distributions of pore geometry. This may in turn be related to depositional environments, and, in extending the results to sedimentary rocks, to the diagenetic and lithification processes involved. Each of these fabrics, however, tends to be anisotropic, and this is borne out by the geophysical measurements. Since the geophysical characteristics are closely linked with permeability then it follows that permeability anisotropy may be reasonably expected also. While this directional dependence may be minimal in surficial marine sediments, it may be considerable at depth in the sediment column, particularly as consolidation progresses. The identification and measurement of anisotropy should help in defining geophysical-fluid flow relationships, especially for fluid flow predictions by remote measurements. Introduction The flow of fluids through the ground is currently of considerable interest to geoscientists and engineers involved in aquifer and hydrocarbon reservoir studies, civil engineering projects, radioactive waste storage, basin dewatering research and geothermal energy projects. In each of these programmes fluid flow concerns movement through large volumes of rock and depends on the solid structure and, moreover, the distribution of interconnecting voids, cracks and fissures. Geophysical techniques are currently employed to evaluate, quantitatively, many physical properties of the ground together with their lateral and vertical variations. Any extension of these geophysical methods to the evaluation of permeability would thus be most welcome. This paper is concerned with the empirical use of electrical resistivity and seismic propagation in evaluating the permeability of sediments. Such techniques have been used before and some examples are detailed below. However, electrical resistivitypermeability results for unconsolidated sediments in the laboratory.

Title: Electron transfer from H2 to N3+ near 0.1 eV a.m.u.-1
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic and Molecular Physics
Affiliations: Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, H.-Y., Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Church, D.A., Physics Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Abstract: The rate coefficient for electron transfer from H2 to N 3+ ions stored in a Penning ion trap has been calculated from measured ion storage time constants and H2 densities. The result is k(N3+,H2)=5.3(3.6)*10-11 cm3 s-1. This measurement is in good agreement with theoretical calculations, in contrast to ion beam cross section measurements at higher energies.

Title: ROLE OF SUBSURFACE GAS STORAGE IN IMPROVING THE INTEGRITY OF THE UNIFIED GAS-SUPPLY SYSTEM.
Authors with affiliations: Furman, I.Ya.
Abstract: The concept of integrity is examined as one of the basic structural properties of large energy systems. It is shown that the presence of subsurface gas storage is an important factor in ensuring the integrity of the Unified Gas-Supply System (UGS). Directions of development are considered together with the siting of subsurface gas storage in the future that will help in increasing the integrity of the UGS.
Index Keywords: ENERGY POLICY - USSR; INDUSTRIAL ECONOMICS - USSR; NATURAL GAS PIPELINES - USSR; STEAM POWER PLANTS - Fuels; LARGE ENERGY SYSTEMS; SUBSURFACE GAS STORAGE; UNIFIED GAS SUPPLY SYSTEM OF THE USSR; GAS STORAGE

Title: Energy storage after photoinduced electron transfer in linked 'triple-decker' molecules
Source title: Journal of the Chemical Society, Faraday Transactions 2: Molecular and Chemical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Manchester, Manchester M13 9PL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Beddard, G.S., Department of Chemistry, University of Manchester, Manchester M13 9PL, United Kingdom
Abstract: A kinetic model, based on non-adiabatic theory of electron transfer, is used to calculate both the energy stored and yields produced, from the final charge-separated species, in the photoinduced electron transfer of 'triple-decker' molecules. These values have been calculated as a function of the reduction potentials of D, A and X, where the molecules have the form D* AX and XD* A, and D* is the photoexcited species. With reasonable potentials, the stored energy and yields are large only over a narrow range of X reduction potentials, and elsewhere are small. This model can therefore be used as an aid in choosing species when synthesising molecules which will maximise both the yield of charge-separated molecules and the fraction of excitation energy stored. The model is also able to explain the overall features of the electron transfer in bacterial reaction centres.

Title: Photoacoustic probing of energy storage and gas exchange in the photosynthesis of leaves
Source title: Journal of the Chemical Society, Faraday Transactions 2: Molecular and Chemical Physics
Affiliations: Biochemistry Department, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Malkin, S., Biochemistry Department, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel
Abstract: The application of the photoacoustic method to the study of photosynthesis in leaves is described, with particular regard to energy storage and gas exchange.

Authors: Stewart M.E., Carter M.R., Casper T.A., Meyer W.H., Perkins D.E., Whitney D.M.
Title: Database tools for enhanced analysis of TMX-U data
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550
Authors with affiliations: Stewart, M.E., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550; Carter, M.R., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550; Casper, T.A., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550; Meyer, W.H., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550; Perkins, D.E., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550; Whitney, D.M., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA 94550
Abstract: A commercial database software package has been used to create several databases and tools that assist and enhance the ability of experimental physicists to analyze data from the Tandem Mirror Experiment-Upgrade (TMX-U) experiment. This software runs on a DEC-20 computer in M-Divisions's User Service Center at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL), where data can be analyzed off line from the main TMX-U acquisition computers. When combined with interactive data analysis programs, these tools provide the capability to do batch-style processing or interactive data analysis on the computers in the USC or the supercomputers of the National Magnetic Fusion Energy Computer Center (NMFECC) in addition to the normal processing done by the TMX-U acquisition system. One database tool provides highly reduced data for searching and correlation analysis of several diagnostic signals within a single shot or over many shots. A second database tool provides retrieval and storage of unreduced data for use in detailed analysis of one or more diagnostic signals. We will show how these database tools form the core of an evolving off-line data analysis environment on the USC computers.

Authors: Ogletree D.F., Somorjai G.A., Katz J.E.
Title: A new system for LEED intensity measurements using a real-time digital video processor
Affiliations: Materials and Molecular Research Division, Department of Chemistry, University of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720; Department of Instrument Science and Engineering, Engineering Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720
Authors with affiliations: Ogletree, D.F., Materials and Molecular Research Division, Department of Chemistry, University of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720; Somorjai, G.A., Materials and Molecular Research Division, Department of Chemistry, University of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720; Katz, J.E., Department of Instrument Science and Engineering, Engineering Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720
Abstract: A new system for low-energy electron diffraction (LEED) intensity measurements has been developed using a video camera and digital processing of the video signal. Complete two-dimensional LEED patterns are digitized in real time with high resolution using a commercial video processor. Intensity-voltage (I-V) data on all beams in complex LEED patterns are collected simultaneously. A microcomputer analysis program automatically tracks the diffraction beams as a function of energy and calculates beam position, size, and integrated intensity, including a local background correction. Using a video tape recorder for intermediate data storage, a complete set of I-V curves can be collected in less than 100 s.

Authors: Lee P.H.Y., Price R.H., Reay J., Pecos J., Seagrave J., McGurn J., Cochrane B., Anderson B.
Title: Optical and UV x-ray imaging diagnostics for imploding plasma experiments
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545
Authors with affiliations: Lee, P.H.Y., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545; Price, R.H., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545; Reay, J., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545; Pecos, J., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545; Seagrave, J., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545; McGurn, J., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545; Cochrane, B., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545; Anderson, B., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545
Abstract: The Trailmaster/Pioneer 1 series of imploding plasma experiments are aimed at using an inductive storage driver to implode an ultrathin aluminum foil with a multimegampere, submicrosecond electrical pulse. The power pulse is produced by an explosive flux compression generator and a fast plasma compression opening switch. The goal is to obtain an intense source of soft x rays from the thermalization of the plasma kinetic energy when pinch occurs on axis. An important target diagnostic is a fast camera which measures the dynamics of foil run-in and implosion symmetry. These measurements are made in the visible, UV, and x-ray portions of the electromagnetic spectrum. UV/x-ray images are first converted to visible light, then transmitted by visible light optics to a framing camera, which is located at a safe distance. For UV/soft x-ray imaging, we mount a disposable pinhole camera with a p-terphenyl-coated converter screen on the target chamber. For soft/hard x-ray imaging, a microchannel plate is used in front of the p-terphenyl-coated screen to boost quantum detection efficiency and signal gain. For faster temporal response the p-terphenyl can be replaced by NE-111 or other fast fluors. Image transmission is accomplished by means of two large mirrors (150-250 mm diam) and a large catadioptric telescope. The framing camera consists of four gated microchannel plates with adjustable gate and interframe times. The framing camera is a versatile and rugged instrument, it has performed satisfactorily for each and every Pioneer shot. Experimental data indicate that this camera, which uses individual gated microchannel plates, is far superior to commercial streak/framing cameras, because it has a dynamic range which is orders of magnitude larger than commercial cameras, each channel can be attenuated separately, further increasing the dynamic range of the imaging system. This makes our framing camera especially suitable for recording sequences of events where the brightness changes by many orders of magnitude. This work was performed under the auspices of U.S. DOE.

Authors: Zucker O., Long J., Lindner K., Giorgi D., Navapanich T.
Title: Inductive energy transfer circuit proof of principle experiment
Affiliations: Energy Compression Research Corporation, 1110 Camino Del Mar, Del Mar, CA 92014, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zucker, O., Energy Compression Research Corporation, 1110 Camino Del Mar, Del Mar, CA 92014, United States; Long, J., Energy Compression Research Corporation, 1110 Camino Del Mar, Del Mar, CA 92014, United States; Lindner, K., Energy Compression Research Corporation, 1110 Camino Del Mar, Del Mar, CA 92014, United States; Giorgi, D., Energy Compression Research Corporation, 1110 Camino Del Mar, Del Mar, CA 92014, United States; Navapanich, T., Energy Compression Research Corporation, 1110 Camino Del Mar, Del Mar, CA 92014, United States
Abstract: For the conventional method of direct transfer of energy between a storage inductor and an uncoupled load inductor, the maximum energy which can be transferred to the load inductor is 25% of the initial stored energy. The Meatgrinder, a novel inductive energy storage and transfer circuit, has been shown to approach 100% energy transfer efficiency. A low-current-level experiment has been performed which has verified the predicted behavior of the inductive transfer circuit and demonstrated an energy transfer efficiency of 47.5%. In order to address the issue of the circuit operation at a higher current level, a second experiment was conducted. The peak current reached was 3.9 kA and the results verified that the current multiplication and energy transfer of the circuit does scale with current.

Title: Time-resolved optical emissions from high-current relativistic electron beams propagating in 150-mTorr air
Affiliations: Physics Department, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hughes, R.H., Physics Department, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Abstract: Results of a time-resolved study of optical emissions from high-current relativistic (6.5 MeV) electron beams propagating in air at a pressure of 150 mTorr are presented. The emissions included N+ lines at λλ4803, 4630, 4552, and 4530 Å. Data were obtained on a single-shot basis by simultaneously recording the temporal history of all four ion lines. For propagating electron beam pulses, each ion line exhibited peak intensity a few microseconds after the passage of the 80-ns-wide electron pulse. This behavior is explained on the basis of inductive (magnetic) energy storage in the return current plasma channel. Spatially integrated plasma temperatures are measured to be in the 20 000-30 000 K range, reaching a maximum when the inductive energy storage has gone to zero.

Abstract: The relative yields of kaons and protons compared with the yield of pions at high pT and polar angles θ away from 90° (in the range from 10° to 45°) are presented for pp, dd, and αα interactions at a centre-of-mass energy {Mathematical expression} GeV per nucleon-nucleon collision. The measured particle ratios depend on the atomic mass number A of the beam particles and on θ. The A dependence of the ratios becomes stronger for larger pT and is more pronounced at smaller polar angles. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Muhlfelder B., Beall J.A., Cromar M.W., Ono R.H.
Title: Very low noise, tightly coupled, dc SQUID amplifiers
Affiliations: National Bureau of Standards, Electromagnetic Technology Division, Boulder, CO 80303, United States
Authors with affiliations: Muhlfelder, B., National Bureau of Standards, Electromagnetic Technology Division, Boulder, CO 80303, United States; Beall, J.A., National Bureau of Standards, Electromagnetic Technology Division, Boulder, CO 80303, United States; Cromar, M.W., National Bureau of Standards, Electromagnetic Technology Division, Boulder, CO 80303, United States; Ono, R.H., National Bureau of Standards, Electromagnetic Technology Division, Boulder, CO 80303, United States
Abstract: We have fabricated and tested thin film, niobium edge junction, double transformer, dc superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUID's) that were stable under room-temperature storage and thermal cycling and that had very good noise performance. The input inductance, approximately 1.7 μH, was large enough to facilitate good matching to many experiments. When the SQUID was operated as a small-signal amplifier, the minimum detectable energy per unit bandwidth (Se) was 5×10-33 J/Hz at 100 kHz, referred to the SQUID loop (uncoupled). The minimum detectable energy per unit bandwidth was 1.8×10-31 J/Hz at 100 kHz, referred to the input coil. The SQUID's had good characteristics for flux-locked operation since the small signal Se was low over a substantial range of bias current and magnetic flux. For operation in a flux-locked feedback circuit, Se was 6×10 -32 J/Hz at 1 kHz.

Title: VOLUME PRODUCTION OF PLASMON OPTICAL DISKS.
Authors with affiliations: Longman, R.J.
Abstract: The production of an optical recording medium based on replicated submicron grating structures or Moth Eye patterns has necessitated the development of simple monitoring techniques which can provide immediate feedback of the profile and depth of structures produced. It has been found that by measuring the zero and first order diffraction energies of the gratings the critical processes of resist development and volume replication can be monitored allowing immediate feedback to the production operators.
Index Keywords: OPTICAL GRATINGS; OPTICAL DISC SYSTEMS; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: BATTERY THERMAL MODELING - THE METHODOLOGY AND APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Johnsee, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Abstract: Mathematical modeling has been an efficient and powerful tool for evaluating thermal behavior of batteries and electrochemical cells. In this paper, the methodology and applications of thermal modeling in various battery systems are reviewed. Potential needs and extensions of battery thermal modeling are discussed. This work is pertinent to electric vehicle propulsion and ability load leveling.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; BATTERY THERMAL MODELING; HEAT GENERATION; THERMAL ENERGY BALANCE; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: MATHEMATICAL MODEL OF A Zn/Br//2 CELL ON CHARGE.
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mader, M.J., Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA; White, R.E., Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, TX, USA
Abstract: A mathematical model of a parallel plate electro-chemical cell with multiple electrode reactions, a separator, and a homogeneous bulk reaction is presented. The model is based on the Zn/Br//2 redox couple and can be used as an aid for the design of an efficient rechargeable storage battery. It is shown that four independent variables exist for the system at a fixed temperature - the effective separator thickness, the residence time, the channel width, and the cell potential. Performance criteria of interest for the Zn/Br//2 battery are defined. Predictions of performance improves as the effective thickness of the separator is increased, despite the associated greater cell resistance. It is also shown that a change in the residence time over the range considered has little effect on cell performance.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Performance; CELL RESISTANCE; CONCENTRATION DISTRIBUTION; CURRENT DENSITY; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; SEPARTOR; ZINC/BROMINE CELL; ELECTROLYTIC CELLS

Authors: Horie Toshio, Ogino Hideharu, Fujiwara Kunihiko, Watakabe Yuichi
Title: ZINC CHLORINE BATTERY WITH NEW CHLORINE STORAGE SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Furukawa Electric Co, Furukawa Electric Co
Authors with affiliations: Horie, Toshio, Furukawa Electric Co, Furukawa Electric Co; Ogino, Hideharu, Furukawa Electric Co, Furukawa Electric Co; Fujiwara, Kunihiko, Furukawa Electric Co, Furukawa Electric Co; Watakabe, Yuichi, Furukawa Electric Co, Furukawa Electric Co
Abstract: Zinc chlorine battery with new chlorine storage system has been developed for the purpose of electric power load leveling. The efficiency of this battery is investigated in this paper. The improvements for increasing of voltaic efficiency and coulombic efficiency are studied. The catalytic treatment is effective for the former and the control of chlorine concentration in electrolyte is effective for the latter. The new chlorine storage system developed for saving the energy has been developed. The 10 KW (80 KWh) battery was made by using these improvements and was operated.
Index Keywords: CHLORINE - Storage; ELECTRIC LOADS; ELECTROLYTES; ENERGY CONSERVATION; CHLORINE STORAGE SYSTEM; ELECTRIC LOAD LEVELING; ZINC CHLORINE BATTERY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: An analogy between information and energy
Affiliations: Inst. fur Didaktik der Phys., Karlsruhe Univ., Germany
Authors with affiliations: Herrmann, F., Inst. fur Didaktik der Phys., Karlsruhe Univ., Germany; Schmid, G.B., Inst. fur Didaktik der Phys., Karlsruhe Univ., Germany
Abstract: The total entropy of an information storage system can be decomposed into independent terms, i.e. into functions which have no independent variables in common. One of these terms represents the information (=entropy) in which the user of a computer is interested. This decomposition corresponds to a break-up of the entire system into non-interacting subsystems and is analogous to the decomposition of the total energy of a system into independent terms commonly referred to as energy forms. In both decompositions, the term usually of interest is many orders of magnitude smaller than the rest.

Title: Production of vibrationally cold ions using a radio-frequency storage ion source
Affiliations: Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; University of Western Ontario, London, N6A 3K7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sen, A., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Mitchell, J.B.A., University of Western Ontario, London, N6A 3K7, Canada
Abstract: A storage ion source has been built for the production of vibrationally cold H+2 and H+3 ions. Using a gas mixture of H2 and rare gases (Ne and He) in the source at high pressure, higher vibrational states of these ions have been effectively depleted by ion-molecule reactions and collisional deactivation. The internal energy of the cold ions was determined by the threshold measurement of collision-induced dissociation. With a mixture of H2 and Ne (ratio 1:5) in the source operated at 80 mTorr, H+2 ions were found to be in v=0 and 1 states only and the H+3 ions were in the ground vibrational state.

Title: A stefan-type problem with void formation and its explicit solution
Source title: IMA Journal of Applied Mathematics (Institute of Mathematics and Its Applications)
Affiliations: Mathematical Sciences Section, Engineering Physics and Mathematics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, D.G., Mathematical Sciences Section, Engineering Physics and Mathematics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, United States; Solomon, A.D., Mathematical Sciences Section, Engineering Physics and Mathematics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831, United States
Abstract: For most materials, the densities of the solid and liquid phases are different. For some materials being considered as potential latent heat thermal energy storage materials, this density change is large. When the solid phase is more dense than the liquid, solidification may result in the formation of vapour bubbles or voids. We have formulated a problem, representing a phase change process with such a void, that has an explicit solution. We examine the solution to gain a further understanding of the thermal and phase change performance of a material in which such voids form. We use the solution to analyse an example problem involving freezing lithium fluoride, a candidate phase-change material with a density change on freezing of about 25 per cent. © 1986 Oxford University Press.

Title: Status of the Kansas State University superconducting linac project
Affiliations: James R. Macdonald Laboratory, Department of Physics, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gray, T.J., James R. Macdonald Laboratory, Department of Physics, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506, United States
Abstract: Funding for the construction of the superconducting linac at Kansas State University was approved by the Department of Energy on May 15, 1985. The project is funded out of the Division of Chemical Sciences, USDOE. Initial design and staff technical training was initiated during 1984-85 with laboratory personnel working at both Florida State University and Argonne National Laboratory. The linac under construction is based upon the Nb split-ring resonator technology developed at Argonne National Laboratory for ATLAS. The linac at Kansas State University will have 14 superconducting resonators with nine low-β (β=0.06) and five high-β (β=0.105) units operating at 97 MHz. Work has progressed on both of the single-resonator cryostats for time bunching and energy rebunching, respectively, with the major cryostat components presently under construction by C. E. Raymond Enterprise Manufacturing, a division of Combustion Engineering, with scheduled delivery of the single resonator cryostat vacuum housings, LN2-cooled heat shields, and LHe Dewars on January 17, 1986. Orders for all Nb-clad Cu resonators have been placed with Argonne National Laboratory and two low-β units are currently under construction. Requests for quotations for a 300-W LHe refrigerator (expandable to 500 W) 1000-l storage Dewar and LHe distribution system have been issued. The building addition which includes a new accelerator/experimental hall (∼6000 ft2 basement structure) and ground-level laboratory support space including additional experimental setup space, additional machine shop space, and mechanical equipment space, is currently under construction with a completion date scheduled for May 1986. Additional personnel training on LHe refrigeration systems is scheduled for January 1986, at the Texas Accelerator Center and at Florida State University.

Labs., Albuquerque, NM, United States; Wilson, J.M., Sandia Nat. Labs., Albuquerque, NM, United States; Vandevender, J.P., Sandia Nat. Labs., Albuquerque, NM, United States
Abstract: PBFA II is a 100 TW pulsed power accelerator constructed at Sandia National Laboratories for use in the light ion fusion program. The objective of PBFA II is to accelerate and focus upon an inertial confinement fusion (ICF) target a lithium beam with sufficient energy, power, and power density to perform ignition scaling experiments. The technologies used in PBFA II include: primary energy storage and compression with 6 MV, low-inductance Marx generators, pulse forming in water-insulated, water-dielectric lines with self-closing water switches, module synchronization using laser-triggered, 6 MV multistage gas switches, voltage addition in vacuum using self-magnetically-insulated biconic transmission lines, inductive energy storage and pulse compression using a fast-opening plasma erosion switch, beam formation using a magnetically- insulated ion diode, and space-charge and current-neutralized beam propagation to the target in a gas-filled cell. The first multimodule shot was on December 11, 1985.

Authors: Clements Jr. T.L., Cook L.A., Stallman R.M., Hunter E.K.
Title: TRANSURANIC WASTE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AND FACILITIES.
Affiliations: EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: Clements Jr., T.L., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Cook, L.A., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Stallman, R.M., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Hunter, E.K., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: A major objective of the Department of Energy (DOE) Nuclear Waste Management Program is the proper management of defense-generated transuranic waste. Strategies have been developed for managing stored and buried transuranic waste at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL). These strategies have been incorporated in the Defense Waste Management Plan and are currently being implemented with logistical coordination of transportation systems and schedules for the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP). The Stored Waste Examination Pilot Plant (SWEPP) is providing nondestructive examination and assay of retrievably stored, contact-handled TRU waste. Construction of the Process Experimental Pilot Plant (PREPP) was recently completed, and PREPP is currently undergoing system checkout. The PREPP will provide processing capabilties for contact-handled waste not meeting WIPP-Waste Acceptance Criteria (WAC). In addition, ongoing studies and technology development efforts for managing the TRU waste such as remote-handled and buried TRU waste are being conducted.
Index Keywords: ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING; INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Treatment; MATERIALS HANDLING; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; IDAHO NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY (INEL); MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES; PROCESS EXPERIMENTAL PILOT PLANT; STORED WASTE EXAMINATION PILOT PLANT; TRANSURANIC WASTE MANAGEMENT; WASTE ISOLATION PILOT PLANT; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: NEED FOR AND FEASIBILITY OF MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE.
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Triplett, M.B., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: The Nuclear Waste Policy Act directs the U. S. Department of Energy to study the need for and feasibility of monitored retrievable storage and to develop a proposal for construction of such a facility. The need for MRS was measured in terms of the relative performance of a system with an MRS facility and a system without an MRS facility. Relative performance was measured in terms of the ease with which all system functions can be developed and implemented, the operating efficiency and reliability of the system, life-cycle cost effects and radiation dose effects. The decision to proceed with the MRS facility involves a tradeoff between improvements in developing and operating the waste management system and an increase in the total cost of the system. Feasibility of MRS was based upon the technical maturity of the design and the level of certainty in the schedule for design, construction and operational testing.
Index Keywords: RADIATION EFFECTS; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Legislation; WASTE DISPOSAL - Economics; MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE; NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY ACT; SYSTEM COATS; WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: NICKEL-HYDROGEN LOW-EARTH-ORBIT TEST PROGRAM.
Affiliations: Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace,, Denver, CO, USA, Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, Denver, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: McDermott, Joseph K., Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace,, Denver, CO, USA, Martin Marietta Denver Aerospace, Denver, CO, USA
Abstract: The incorporation of nickel-hydrogen technology for low-earth-orbit (LEO) spacecraft applications require the establishment of a data base. An extensive test program has been established to provide this data base. This paper outlines the test program and presents preliminary test results.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Testing; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS - Performance; DISCHARGE; ENERGY DENSITY; GEOSYNCHRONOUS; STORAGE BATTERIES; SATELLITES

Title: SIMPLIFIED MATHEMATICAL MODEL OF HEAT AND MASS TRANSFER IN NONSTEADY-STATE PERIODIC PROCESSES IN GREENHOUSES.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Yakubov, Yu.N.
Abstract: A simplified mathematical model is worked out for heat and mass transfer in multispan greenhouses, which is standardized and convenient for solution using a computer. Heat and mass transfer in greenhouses is described by a system of differential equations of motion, mass transfer, continuity, energy, and heat conduction in the ground and walls of the enclosure.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; MASS TRANSFER; SOILS; SOLAR RADIATION - Energy Storage; MULTISPAN SHED GREENHOUSES; GREENHOUSES

Title: ALTERNATE APPROACH TO DIGITAL SYSTEM MODELLING FOR COMPUTER SIMULATION.
Affiliations: Arizona State Univ, Tempe, AZ, USA, Arizona State Univ, Tempe, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Zimmer, Carl R., Arizona State Univ, Tempe, AZ, USA, Arizona State Univ, Tempe, AZ, USA
Abstract: Polynomial models are available in a number of equation-solver and network-simulation programs, such as FORMULA/ONE, PSPICE, and SPICE2. The application of these models to digital logics systems is considered, together with methods of coefficient evaluation to meet differing design specifications. Although the latter process is generally feasible, the extension of the model to multi-input or energy storage situations appears to be difficult.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Polynomials; DIGITAL SYSTEM MODELING; FORMULA/ONE; PSPICE; SPICE2; DIGITAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF HIGH-SPECIFIC-SPEED PUMP-TURBINE SETS FOR SOUTH UKRAINE ENERGY COMPLEX.
Authors with affiliations: Malyshev, A.K.; Evdokimov, A.N.
Abstract: The authors confirmed the possibility of improving the performance of the hydropower equipment installed at pumped-storage hydropower stations, over a range of heads from 80 to 120 meters in principle; proof was demonstrated of the feasibility of designing turbopump flow passages for high specific speed; and the validity applying these approaches in design work was confirmed. Data obtained in the course of investigations also indicate that the basic characteristics of the pump-turbine set (efficiency, cavitation coefficient, level of pressure fluctuations, dynamic components of forces and moments acting on design components) depend in large measured on how carefully designs of all components of the flow passages were worked out.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; FLOW OF FLUIDS - Analysis; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Pumped Storage; PO LENINGRAD METALWORKS; PUMP-TURBINE SETS; PUMPED-STORAGE; SOUTH UKRAINE; PUMPS

Title: ENERGY CRITERIA OF A SYSTEM CONSISTING OF A CHARGING-DISCHARGE CONVERTER AND A CAPACITIVE STORE.
Authors with affiliations: Mikhailo, A.K.
Abstract: A method is proposed for determining the energy characteristics of the system independently of the value of the store capacitance and the charging time. The power and efficiency of capacitive-storage power stations are calculated in relation to the capacitive store voltage. The economies of a capacitive-storage power station and its effect on the power system can be determined e. g. when planned for emergency supply.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Standby Service; CAPACITIVE-STORAGE POWER STATION; CAPACITORS

Title: MECHANICAL HEAT RECOVERY SYSTEMS TO HELP UTILITY PROGRAMS.
Source title: Proceedings, American Institute of Industrial Engineers, Annual Conference and Convention
Affiliations: Georgia Power Co, GA, USA, Georgia Power Co, GA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pucciano, Frank J., Georgia Power Co, GA, USA, Georgia Power Co, GA, USA
Abstract: The effects of mechanical heat recovery systems on industry/utility load profiles, thermal economics and alternative fuel selection are discussed. These systems include applied heat pumps, thermal storage and load control. The discussions will compare these systems to boiler operations and cogeneration. The paper will explain how mechanical heat recovery systems can be integrated into the overall thermal plant of an industry to obtain maximum thermal efficiency, low cost energy and production improvements and/or redundancy. It will also show how existing boiler plants are improved and cogeneration potential is reduced.
Index Keywords: BOILERS - Waste Heat; ENERGY CONSERVATION; FUEL ECONOMY; HEAT RECOVERY SYSTEMS; PRODUCTION IMPROVEMENTS; THERMAL EFFICIENCY; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS

Title: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY ON SOLAR ENERGY STORAGE IN ROCKS.
Affiliations: Kuwait Univ, Kuwait, Kuwait Univ, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Waked, A.M., Kuwait Univ, Kuwait, Kuwait Univ, Kuwait
Abstract: Storage of solar heat has been experimentally studied under outdoor simulated conditions in Kuwait. Air at different inlet temperatures and flow rates, was allowed to pass through the rocks stored in an insulated wooden bin. Various heights were tried for the bin size. The pressure drop across different heights of the rock pile was also measured for the different flow rates. It was found that the heat storage characteristics did not vary significantly with the rock-size. The results indicated that a major portion of the heat stored by rocks may be extracted and utilized for various applications at constant rate. This advantage is due to temperature stratification along the pile height.
Index Keywords: GEOPHYSICS - Rock Properties; ROCK - Thermal Effects; HEAT STORAGE CHARACTERISTICS; SOLAR HEAT; TEMPERATURE STRATIFICATION; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: TMI-2 DEFUELING CANISTERS.
Affiliations: Babcock & Wilcox Co, Lynchburg,, VA, USA, Babcock & Wilcox Co, Lynchburg, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Childress, P.C., Babcock & Wilcox Co, Lynchburg,, VA, USA, Babcock & Wilcox Co, Lynchburg, VA, USA; McGuinn, E.J., Babcock & Wilcox Co, Lynchburg,, VA, USA, Babcock & Wilcox Co, Lynchburg, VA, USA
Abstract: The accident at TMI-2 resulted in a significant portion of the reactor core's being reduced to debris ranging in size from very small fines to partial fuel assemblies. Babcock & Wilcox (B&W) has developed designs for three types of waste package (canisters) that are being used in conjunction with different defueling techniques to encapsulate the core for transportation to and subsequent storage at the Department of Energy's Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL). Currently, canisters are being loaded at TMI-2 with shipment to INEL scheduled in the near future. Analysis and testing, including a series of drop tests, were used to ensure characteristics for operational and faulted conditions that comply with criticality and NRC/ASME Code criteria.
Index Keywords: CONTAINERS; NUCLEAR FUELS - Removal; DEFUELING; DROP TEST; THREE MILE ISLAND; WASTE CANISTERS; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: SOLAR WATER HEATING SYSTEMS, PROCEEDINGS OF THE WORKSHOP.
Abstract: This workshop proceedings contains 28 papers. The main topics discussed are: solar hot water technology; solar radiation; components of solar water heaters; low temperature solar thermal applications; design optimization of collector plates; absorber plate configuration; hot water storage systems; insulation materials for solar heating; painting for solar energy collectors; coatings for photothermal conversion; controls for solar water heating; galvanized steel solar absorber; welding technology; glazing materials for solar collectors; pumps for hot water; heat exchanger optimization, heat transfer in pipes; thermosyphon water heating; industrial experiences with solar water heaters; techno-economics of solar forced flow hybrid hot water systems.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; HEAT TRANSFER - Pipes; SOLAR CELLS - Painting; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; COLLECTOR PLATES; EIREV; SOLAR ABSORBERS; THERMAL INSULATION; THERMOSYPHON WATER HEATING; WATER HEATERS

Authors: Rodgers A.D., Truitt D.J., Logan J.A., Brown R.M.
Title: LOW LEVEL WASTE MANAGEMENT AT THE IDAHO NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY.
Affiliations: EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rodgers, A.D., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Truitt, D.J., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Logan, J.A., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Brown, R.M., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: The Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL) is one of the Department of Energy's principal centers for conducting nuclear energy research and development. This paper presents an overview of selected low level waste (LLW) management operations activities conducted at the INEL. As a prime operating contractor, EG&G Idaho has the major responsibility for the safe and cost-effective management of radioactive wastes. EG&G Idaho has therefore directed its efforts toward developing the improved technologies required to conserve waste disposal space and enhance waste isolation from the biosphere. Activities to be presented include waste generation reduction, waste processing for volume reduction and disposal operations. Enhancements planned to these present waste management practices are also discussed.
Index Keywords: INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Treatment; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; IDAHO NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY; LOW LEVEL WASTE; VOLUME REDUCTION; WASTE GENERATION REDUCTION; WASTE ISOLATION; WASTE PROCESSING; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: MRS, TRANSPORTATION, INTEGRATED SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: US DOE, US DOE
Authors with affiliations: Barrett, Lake H., US DOE, US DOE
Abstract: In addition to requiring development of geologic repositories, the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 (NWPA) directed the Secretary of Energy to perform a detailed study of the need for, and the feasibility of, monitored retrievable storage (MRS) and to submit to Congress a proposal for construction of one or more MRS facilities. The Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM) of the Department of Energy (DOE) was created to manage the overall disposal program. The primary focus of this discussion is the program that OCRWM is developing to ensure the availability of a safe, efficient transportation system for shipping under provisions of the NWPA. In planning the transportation program, two major tasks are recognized. The first is to develop and acquire the equipment and services to support operation of the NWPA transportation system. The second task is to encourage the institutional climate that will allow establishment and operation of the system.
Index Keywords: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION - Legislation; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; TRANSPORTATION - Planning; INTEGRATED SYSTEMS; MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE (MRS); NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY ACT OF 1982; OFFICE OF CIVILIAN RADIOACTIVE WASTE MANAGEMENT; OFFICE OF STORAGE AND TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: V4-275R STIRLING ENGINE IN UNDERWATER APPLICATION.
Affiliations: Sub Power AB, Sub Power AB
Authors with affiliations: Nilsson, H., Sub Power AB, Sub Power AB; Bratt, C., Sub Power AB, Sub Power AB
Abstract: The Stirling power module V4-275R, integrated with a liquid oxygen system, is currently built for the Royal Swedish Navy and for the offshore company Comex in France. Since June 1985 the Stirling engine system for the Swedish Navy has been successfully tested in a full-scale submarine test section for about 400 hours. The next step in this program will be an integration of the Stirling system into an operational Swedish submarine. The French program involves a 500 ton manned diver lock-out submarine, the SAGA 1, which is under final construction at Comex in Marseille. The energy system for the SAGA submarine consists of two V4-275R Stirling engines of maximum 100 kW power each. The oxygen storage, manufactured by AGA Cryo in Gothenburg, consists of two liquid oxygen tanks with a total capability of 10,000 kWh, allowing the submarine to perform missions of up to 14 days submerged.
Index Keywords: SUBMARINES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; STIRLING ENGINES; V4-275R POWER MODULE; AIR ENGINES

Title: 65 Ah RECHARGEABLE LITHIUM MOLYBDENUM DISULFIDE BATTERY.
Affiliations: Moli Energy Ltd, Burnaby, BC, Can, Moli Energy Ltd, Burnaby, BC, Can
Authors with affiliations: Brandt, K., Moli Energy Ltd, Burnaby, BC, Can, Moli Energy Ltd, Burnaby, BC, Can
Abstract: Moli Energy Limited has, during the past seven years, developed rechargeable lithium molybdenum disulfide batteries which have a number of superior performance characteristics which include a high energy density, a high power density, and a long charge retention time. The first cell sizes developed include a 'C' size cell and an 'AA' size cell. Over the last two years, a project to demonstrate the feasibility of the scale up of this technology to a 'BC' size cell with 65 Ah capacity has been undertaken. The objective of the project was to develop, build, and test a . 6 kWh storage battery consisting of 6 'BC' cells in series.
Index Keywords: SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; CYCLE LIFE; ENERGY DENSITY; STORAGE BATTERY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: OPTIMIZATION OF A HYDROGEN-BROMINE SECONDARY BATTERY FOR ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hsueh, K-L., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; Chin, D-T., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA
Abstract: The present work is concerned with a 20MW/200MWH H//2/Br//2 secondary battery for energy storage application. Based on the available data, cost assessment and nonsteady state material and energy analyses, the capacity and capital cost of key equipments of this energy storage system were evaluated. The equipments under the consideration were: cell stack, hydrogen storage, electrolyte storage, pump, heat exchanger and piping. A numerical optimization method was applied to minimize the capital cost (/KWH) of this system. Optimized results indicate that the energy consumed by the electrolyte pump is negligible and the inefficiency is mainly caused by the over-voltage of the battery. A comparison was made between the H//2/Br//2 and H//2/Cl//2 batteries at their optimized operating conditions.
Index Keywords: COST ACCOUNTING; ENERGY STORAGE - Applications; CAPITAL COST EVALUATION; HYDROGEN-BROMINE SECONDARY BATTERY; NUMERICAL OPTIMIZATION METHOD; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: SOLAR ENERGY PROSPECT IN THE ARAB WORLD, SECOND ARAB INTERNATIONAL SOLAR ENERGY CONFERENCE.
Abstract: Proceedings consists of 66 papers on solar energy developments in Arab countries. Topics include: economics, policy and planning; active cooling; solar radiation; flat plate collectors; passive; photovoltaic; wind energy; desalination; concentrating collectors; power plants; and thermal storage. All papers are abstracted and indexed separately.

Title: REDUCTION OF PEAK LOAD BY UTILIZATION OF SOLAR ENERGY.
Affiliations: Univ of Mosul, Mosul, Iraq, Univ of Mosul, Mosul, Iraq
Authors with affiliations: Bashi, S.M.A., Univ of Mosul, Mosul, Iraq, Univ of Mosul, Mosul, Iraq; Al-Hafid, M.S.M., Univ of Mosul, Mosul, Iraq, Univ of Mosul, Mosul, Iraq
Abstract: The peak demand, which occurs in the electric distribution systems, has a great effect on the equipment of the system. The purpose of this study is to investigate the possibility of reducing the peak load by utilizing solar energy. The result of this paper shows successful supply of a fraction of the peak load, and a considerable improvement in the power factor of ac distribution system in a residence area.
Index Keywords: POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Utilization; INVERTER CIRCUIT; LEAD ACID STORAGE BATTERIES; PEAK LOAD REDUCTION; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: THERMAL PERFORMANCE OF ROTATING LATENT HEAT AIR-BASED SOLAR STORAGE SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq, Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq
Authors with affiliations: Al-Karaghouli, A.A., Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq, Solar Energy Research Cent, Baghdad, Iraq
Abstract: Simulation techniques were used for performance comparison between rotation latent heat solar storage and sensible heat solar storage systems. Sun wax p-116 was used as a storage media for the latent heat storage and rockbed was used as a storage media for the sensible heat storage. The comparison shows that the latent heat storage system supplies a higher fraction to the load than the sensible heat storage system. The effects of storage capacity and latent heat were also investigated. It was shown that by using external aluminum fins the system performance improved by 40%.

Title: ELECTRICAL POWER FOR COLUMBUS; AN IMPORTANT CROSS-ELEMENT TASK.
Affiliations: AEG Aktiengesellschaft, Wedel, West Ger, AEG Aktiengesellschaft, Wedel, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Eggers, Gert, AEG Aktiengesellschaft, Wedel, West Ger, AEG Aktiengesellschaft, Wedel, West Ger
Abstract: In order to realize power systems which are larger in size adn simpler in operation, an upgrading of conventional methods and technologies is indispensable. The resulting advanced power supply and distribution hardware for Columbus elements is not designed and developed yet, but in a series of studies, AEG intensively investigated related techniques and technologies. These activities are strongly supported by comprehensive hardware experience from Spacelab, Eureca, Space Telescope and other projects. Subject of this paper is to present the results obtained so far. Subjects covered include the solar array, power conditioning, power distribution, and others.

Title: IMPROVING TECHNICAL SUPPORT TO IAEA SAFEGUARDS.
Affiliations: IAEA, Vienna, Austria, IAEA, Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Rundquist, David, IAEA, Vienna, Austria, IAEA, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: The nuclear industry is entering a phase where more and more emphasis is being placed on cutting fuel fabrication and reprocessing costs. This emphasis, and increasing radiation levels of high burnup plutonium, are leading to increased automation of the associated production processes and facilities, and consequently reduced opportunity for personnel access to key areas of a plant. Fuel assemblies that can be disassembled and reconstructed also are coming into use, and large away-from-reactor spent-fuel storage areas are nearing fruition. In addition, new reactors and bulk-handling facilities with large inventories are being added each year to those already inspected by the IAEA. These changes present new safeguards challenges and require that the entire safeguards process become more efficient, if the Agency is to meet its obligations in a zero growth budget environment.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR ENERGY - International Cooperation; NUCLEAR INDUSTRY; NUCLEAR FUELS

Title: RADIOACTIVE MATERIAL TRANSPORTATION: THE UTILITIES' PERSPECTIVE ON THE LEGAL AND REGULATORY ENVIRONMENT.
Affiliations: LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae,, Washington, DC, USA, LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Buren, Mindy A., LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae,, Washington, DC, USA, LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The respective roles of federal and state governments in regulating the transportation of radioactive materials must be better defined if these materials are to move safely and efficiently. Recent increases in shipments of spent fuel, which will accelerate as the Nuclear Waste Policy Act is implemented by the Department of Energy ('DOE'), has heightened interest in this issue. This paper explains the electric utility industry's perspective on these matters as reflected in the industry's comments on the DOE's Transportation Business Plan and comments in a recent proceeding convened by the Department of Transportation to consider the consistency with federal law of an Illinois law imposing a 1000 per cask fee on shipments of spent fuel through the state. Also discussed are the industry's view on the transportation aspects of the DOE's proposal to include a monitored retrievable storage facility as an integral part of the federal waste management system and the appropriate role of states, localities, and tribal authorities in the regulation of the highway and rail routing of radioactive materials.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION - Legislation; FEDERAL WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM; LEGAL ENVIRONMENT; NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY ACT; REGULATORY ENVIRONMENT; STATE REGULATION; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Source title: Official Proceedings - Annual Conference of the International District Heating Association
Authors with affiliations: Margen, Peter
Abstract: Municipal or private utility companies in the United States have traditionally concentrated on supplying electricity. Lately the additional benefits obtainable by supplying heat and cooling for densely populated areas through cogeneration have been receiving increasing attention. This paper reviews the broader attractive opportunities which are open to 'energy utilities' prepared to supply electricity, heating, and cooling energy, thereby optimizing the benefits of the joint production, storage, and distribution of heating and cooling energy.

Abstract: The Republic of China (ROC) is currently producing nuclear generated electric power and the associated radioactive wastes. At present, disposal of the waste is not being performed until research and development determine the most feasible method. Until such time that disposal operations commence, the ROC Atomic Energy Agency is storing the solid radioactive waste at the Lan-yu facility. Consideration of the facility's design and operation should be included with any storage facilities contemplated for use in the United States.

Abstract: Some problems in the operation of a small electricity supply system for an isolated community are discussed in relation to the application of wind energy. The choice of aerogenerator, the use of load management techniques to balance supply and demand and possible benefits of energy storage systems are examined. The importance of community involvement in load control is stressed and some results given.

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF A GRP CASING COMPONENT AND ITS MANUFACTURE BY THE RESIN INJECTION MOULDING PROCESS.
Affiliations: BP, BP
Authors with affiliations: Potter, K.D., BP, BP
Abstract: For several years British Petroleum (BP) has been developing its Kinetic Energy Storage System (KESS) based on the storage of energy by a rapidly rotating composite flywheel. To develop the entire system has required several parallel development areas. These include the composite rotor itself, safety containment system, lubrication, seals and other mechanical engineering, safety monitor and composite casings. This paper focuses on this last area, the components which form the vacuum chamber and support for the rotor. The casing set consists of three mouldings, the main casing and its end plate, which forms the vacuum housing, and the gearbox adaptor plate, which carries the speed reduction gearbox and oil manifold. The gap between the gearbox adaptor plate and the casing end plate also acts as the system oil sump.

Abstract: An iron-free superconducting quadrupole with a 140 mm coil inner diameter and a field gradient of 70 T/m has been built and tested as a prototype magnet for use in low beta insertions of the TRISTAN Main Ring. The magnet is made from 27 strands of NbTi Rutherford type cable clamped with stainless steel collars. A maximum field gradient of 80 T/m with a peak field of 6. 0 T in the coil was obtained after five quenches. Quench characteristics and field gradient homogeneity of this quadrupole were studied in a vertical cryostat. Mechanical disturbance energies in the coil were also obtained from measurements of the voltages across the coil.

Abstract: This paper reports in condensed form results of the research and development activities carried out during the second testing year of the first Jordanian solar house. In the first testing year it was reported that the thermal load was considerably high and that the storage tank efficiency was low (approx. 58%). Measures were taken to decrease the thermal load and to increase the storage tank efficiency. The results show that the thermal load was reduced to about 46% and that the collector array integrated efficiency was maintained at approximately 22%.

Title: ENERGY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE COOLING AND IN-STORE DRYING OF CEREAL GRAINS IN SRI LANKA.
Affiliations: CSIRO, Aust, CSIRO, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Thorpe, G.R., CSIRO, Aust, CSIRO, Aust
Abstract: Raw climatological data from Colombo and Anuradhapura in Sri Lanka are analyzed to yield statistics on the monthly mean maximum and minimum dry-bulb temperatures, as well as the average dry-bulb temperatures during the coolest 15, 25, and 50 percent of the time, and during the warmest 50 percent of the time. Relative humidity and dew point data are processed to obtain estimates of the absolute humidities of the ambient air during these times. These, in turn, may be used to calculate the heat content of ambient air which is crucial to the calculation of air conditioning requirements for the cooling or drying of grain. The power required to pump air through the grain and the periods required for cooling and drying are also calculated enabling a comprehensive analysis of energy requirements to be made. It is found, for example, that typical energy requirement to cool one ton of grain with a moisture content of 14 percent (wet basis) to 20 degree C is about 2-5 kwh, regardless of initial grain temperature. Cooling is thus a low energy-intensive process compared with ambient air-drying, for example, which requires an order of magnitude of more energy to make damp grain sufficiently dry for long-term storage.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS - Drying; AIR - Drying; AIR CONDITIONING - Energy Utilization; ATMOSPHERIC HUMIDITY; METEOROLOGY - Sri Lanka; AMBIENT DRY-BULB TEMPERATURE; GRAIN COOLING; IN-STORE GRAIN DRYING; PADDY STORAGE; GRAIN

Abstract: The use of resin mixtures for cast blanks in energy technology is distinguished by a number of features resulting from the complex geometrical shape of the castings, their considerable volume and developed thermal centers. The major part of castings with walls more than 60 mm thick are manufactured from steel 15Kh1M1FL, 10Kh18N9TL, 20GSL. The Nevskii Works Production Association (PA) has done a considerable amount of work on increasing the heat resistance of mixtures and reducing the weight portion of the binder with the aim of reducing the gas pores and lowering the cost. A new PFR resin was synthesized on a base of furfuryl alcohol (FA) for the needs of casting manufacture.

Abstract: A distributed control system is presented that includes a control center with a PDP 11/23 PLUS computer, two CRTs, two printers, and 4 remote station that is based on the Intel 8085. The system controls some 1200 digital and 600 analog points, 100 master signals, 200 commands, 64 set-point adjustments, and 64 counters. It provides: automatic start-up and stop; energy consumption optimization; electric maximum demand control; thermal energy storage management; stock management; and preventive maintenance, among other functions.

Title: OPTIMISATION STUDIES OF A HYBRID ELECTRIC CAR.
Affiliations: Univ of Durham, Engl, Univ of Durham, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Bumby, J.R., Univ of Durham, Engl, Univ of Durham, Engl; Forster, I., Univ of Durham, Engl, Univ of Durham, Engl
Abstract: A hybrid vehicle can be defined as a vehicle which utilizes two or more energy storage mediums within its drivetrain, any of which is capable of driving the vehicle when connected to the road wheels. In this paper the hybrid electric vehicle is considered with energy stored in petroleum fuel and a traction battery. To utilize the prime movers, a number of different powertrain configurations are possible but in general fall into one of two basic categories. In the series arrangement the internal combustion engine does not drive the road wheels directly but is connected indirectly through an electric generator and electric traction motor. Introducing a traction battery between the generator and motor buffers the engine output allowing the engine power and speed to be controlled independently of the power and speed demand at the road wheels.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; POWER TRANSMISSION - Control; CONTINUOUS POWER DEMAND; HYBRID ELECTRIC CAR; TRACTION BATTERY; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Authors: Rosen M.A., Scott D.S., Rotenberg Y.
Title: ANALYSIS OF THE EFFICIENCIES OF CURRENT AND ADVANCED PROCESSES FOR ELECTROLYTIC HYDROGEN PRODUCTION.
Affiliations: Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ont, Can, Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Rosen, M.A., Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ont, Can, Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ont, Can; Scott, D.S., Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ont, Can, Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ont, Can; Rotenberg, Y., Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ont, Can, Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ont, Can
Abstract: The efficiencies of processes for producing electrolytic hydrogen, based on current and advanced technologies, and considering several different energy sources, were examined using both energy and exergy analyses. Efficiencies exhibited strong dependences on the energy source considered. The main inefficiencies in these processes were generally shown to be due to internal irreversibilities, and not due to external emissions. The results indicate that exergy analysis, because it provides greater insight into process performance than does energy analysis, should be used when assessing the efficiencies of processes.

Source title: Institution of Chemical Engineers Symposium Series
Affiliations: Politecnico di Torino, Italy, Politecnico di Torino, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Maja, M., Politecnico di Torino, Italy, Politecnico di Torino, Italy; Penazzi, N., Politecnico di Torino, Italy, Politecnico di Torino, Italy; Spinelli, P., Politecnico di Torino, Italy, Politecnico di Torino, Italy; Ginatta, M.V., Politecnico di Torino, Italy, Politecnico di Torino, Italy; Ginatta, U., Politecnico di Torino, Italy, Politecnico di Torino, Italy; Orsello, G., Politecnico di Torino, Italy, Politecnico di Torino, Italy
Abstract: The recovery of lead from spent storage batteries employing an electrochemical process has been investigated and this paper reports the results of the industrial and laboratory tests, which allowed the definition of the technological parameters of an electrolytic plant. During the electrolysis the uncrushed batteries are dissolved in fluoboric electrolyte and pure lead is deposited on the cathodes. The electrolyte purification is not required owing to the electrochemical behaviour of metals present in the bath. The data collected during three years of plant running permit to present detailed energy and mass balances allowing full identification of the economic aspects of the process. The break-even point for the plant has been determined.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; ELECTRODES, ELECTROCHEMICAL; ELECTROLYTIC LEAD RECOVERY; ELECTROWINNING; SPENT BATTERIES; LEAD COMPOUNDS

Title: EFFECT OF GEOMETRY ON STATIC THERMAL STRATIFICATION.

Authors with affiliations: Al-Kandari, A., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait; Moustafa, S., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait; Al-Marafie, A., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait
Abstract: An experimental study of temperature decay in thermally stratified water bodies, was carried out for five thermal storage tanks with height to diameter (L/D) ratios of 1,2,3,4 and 5. The time dependent temperature profiles were measured for various L/D ratios and the composite thermal extraction efficiency was calculated for each tank. The results obtained indicate that the optimum L/D ratio falls between 3 and 4. A one-dimensional, theoretical equation was formulated to study the basic nature of the process by calculating the composite extraction efficiency for each tank as a function of time.

Title: MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE (MRS) FACILITY AND ITS IMPACT ON SPENT FUEL TRANSPORTATION.
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Joy, D.S., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Jolley, R.L., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN,, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: The Department of Energy (DOE) has identified nine potential sites for a repository to permanently dispose of radioactive wastes. The DOE has also released information identifying expected transportation routes between nuclear reactors and these repository sites. More recently, the DOE has announced three potential sites for a Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) Facility in Tennessee. Obviously, if a large portion of the spent fuel should be routed to Tennessee for consolidation and repackaging, there will be significant changes in the projected routes and the number of shipments in the vicinity of the repository will be reduced. The MRS would also result in an increase in the number of spent fuel shipments through eastern Tennessee, while significantly reducing shipments through the central and western parts of the state.

Title: NUCLEAR DATA: SERVING BASIC NEEDS OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY.
Affiliations: IAEA, Vienna, Austria, IAEA, Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Lorenz, Alex, IAEA, Vienna, Austria, IAEA, Vienna, Austria; Schmidt, Joseph J., IAEA, Vienna, Austria, IAEA, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: In today's world, the transfer and spread of information implies the systematic collection, classification, storage, retrieval, and dissemination of knowledge with the essential use of computers. To be able to take best advantage of information technology that has been developing over the last decades, scientific knowledge has to be reduced to concentrated factual statements or data. Today, the volume of information published prevents anyone from being fully informed in his or her own field, not to speak of keeping up with developments in other fields. Consequently, it has become necessary to supplement conventionally published information kept in libraries with condensed information, amenable to computer processing and presented to users in easily accessible and conveniently utilized form. The main topics are demands for more data, IAEA nuclear data centre activities, and nuclear data needs in various fields.

Authors with affiliations: Loughead, J.S.C., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Beers, G.H., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: The Department of Energy Low-Level Waste Management Program has developed an interactive computer model and linked database to be used by state and regional policy makers to evaluate various waste management system configurations and technologies. The computer program resides on an IBM 4341 mainframe host, and was developed and is supported by EG&G Idaho, Inc. Both user access and terminal workstations are provided to regional and state representatives as part of the Low-Level Waste Management Program Information Management System. The analysis model was developed to provide decision support information about regional waste management options for low-level radioactive waste (LLRW) processing, packaging, transportation, storage, and disposal. This model concept represents an extension of several independent analysis programs that were developed as stand-alone planning aids by the Program. Coupled with the computer model is a comprehensive database of default parameters.

Authors: Novick W.M., Wallace H.W., Root K.L., Rozanski D.J., Fuller E.O.
Title: Preservation of donor heart function and high-energy stores by continuous perfusion with synthetic plasma at 22°C
Affiliations: Department of Surgery, Graduate Hospital, Philadelphia, PA 19146, United States
Authors with affiliations: Novick, W.M., Department of Surgery, Graduate Hospital, Philadelphia, PA 19146, United States; Wallace, H.W., Department of Surgery, Graduate Hospital, Philadelphia, PA 19146, United States; Root, K.L., Department of Surgery, Graduate Hospital, Philadelphia, PA 19146, United States; Rozanski, D.J.; Fuller, E.O.
Abstract: We evaluated high-energy phosphate (HEP) levels and the ability to perform work in rat hearts preserved by standard techniques (0.9% NaCl arrest and storage at 4°C) and by continuous coronary perfusion at 22°C, pH 7.25, and 55 mm Hg for 4 or 8 hr with (1) Krebs-Henseleit buffer (KHB), (2) modified Morgan's solution (MCS), or (3) a medium developed in our lab (physiologically complete medium or PCM). Cardiac work was evaluated in the rewarmed hearts with use of a working heart preparation at left atrial pressures of 10, 15, and 20 cm H2O, and by measurement of aortic flow, coronary flow, heart rate, and peak systolic pressure. HEP levels in the hearts continuously perfused were significantly higher (p > .05) than those in the hearts stored at 4°C. The functional recovery of hearts preserved by storage in cold saline for 4 or 8 hr was significantly less (p < .01) than the recovered function of hearts preserved for comparable periods by perfusion at 22°C with either MCS or PCM. The results indicate that continuous perfusion at 22°C with a more physiologic medium is superior to hypothermic arrest and storage at 4°C for the preservation of donor heart function and HEP levels.
Index Keywords: phosphate; animal experiment; cardiovascular system; energy; graft preservation; heart; heart transplantation; hemodynamics; nonhuman; perfusion; priority journal; rat; temperature; therapy; Animals; Blood; Cold; Energy Metabolism; Heart; Heart Arrest, Induced; Heat; Male; Myocardium; Organ Preservation; Perfusion; Phosphates; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Tissue Donors

Title: LIGHTWEIGHT, DIRECT-RADIATING NICKEL HYDROGEN BATTERIES.
Affiliations: Canadian Astronautics Ltd, Ottawa,, Ont, Can, Canadian Astronautics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Metcalfe, John R., Canadian Astronautics Ltd, Ottawa,, Ont, Can, Canadian Astronautics Ltd, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: Two battery module configurations have been developed which, in addition to integrating cylindrical nickel hydrogen (NiH//2) cells into batteries, provide advances in the means of mounting, monitoring and thermal control of these cells. Unlike most conventional nickel-cadmium (NiCd) and NiH//2 batteries, the cells are not tightly packed together; therefore ancilliary heat conducting media to outside radiating areas, and spacecraft deck reinforcements for high mass concentration are not necessary. Testing included electrical characterization and a comprehensive regime of environmental exposures. The designs are flexible with respect to quantity and type of cells, orbit altitude and period, power demand profile, and the extent of cell parameter monitoring. This paper compares the characteristics of the two battery modules and summarizes their performance.
