Title: WASTE CONTAINMENT AND MONITORING SYSTEM FOR THE NIAGARA FALLS STORAGE SITE.
Affiliations: Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jones, M.G., Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Blanke, J.A., Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy has established an interim storage site for low-level radioactive waste, known as the Niagara Falls Storage Site, near Lewiston, New York. The main elements of the waste containment facility at the site are a clay cutoff wall keyed into an underlying clay stratum, a surface dike built on top of the cutoff wall, and a layered cap over the waste. The integrity of the waste containment facility will be monitored using groundwater monitoring wells, periodic topographic surveys, aerial photographic surveys, and walkover surveys. In addition to external monitoring, an internal monitoring system will be installed in the waste containment facility. The principal design restriction for this system is prevention of any direct penetrations of the cap or sidewalls of the containment facility.
Index Keywords: SOIL POLLUTION - Monitoring; WATER POLLUTION - Monitoring; LOW-LEVEL WASTE; MONITORING SYSTEM; STORAGE SITE; WASTE CONTAINMENT; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: FUTURE DEVELOPMENTS IN UNDERGROUND MOBILE EQUIPMENT.
Affiliations: Univ of Queensland, St. Lucia, Aust, Univ of Queensland, St. Lucia, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Grigg, F.W., Univ of Queensland, St. Lucia, Aust, Univ of Queensland, St. Lucia, Aust
Abstract: Turbocharging and the electronic control of fuel pumps and injectors can improve diesel engine performance whilst minimizing exhaust emissions. Ceramic materials promise further improvements in engine efficiency. Electrically powered machines, equipped with trailing cables are expected to find increasing application where there is less need for flexibility and where the cost of ventilation and heating or cooling makes diesel engines unattractive. Voltage to frequency converters and induction motors have a future in mains powered machines. Vehicles employing energy storage in the form of batteries or flywheels will find increasing application. Hydrostatic transmissions having high power density and efficiency are likely to be used more widely. Electronic control systems are likely to be used to simplify jobs and to improve performance and productivity.
Index Keywords: CONTROL EQUIPMENT, MECHANICAL; MINE VENTILATION; MINES AND MINING - Hydraulic Equipment; ENGINE EFFICIENCY; EXHAUST SYSTEMS; UNDERGROUND MOBILE EQUIPMENT; MINING MACHINERY

Title: SIMULATION OF SOLAR ELECTRIC/THERMAL COGENERATORS.
Source title: Paper - American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick NJ, USA, Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ting, K.C., Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick NJ, USA, Rutgers Univ, New Brunswick NJ, USA
Abstract: Computer models were developed to simulate the performance of four different configurations of flat-plate solar electric/thermal cogenerators for agricultural processes. In such solar collectors, photovoltaic panels are used to produce electricity and absorb thermal energy from the sun simultaneously. Any excess amount of electric energy is stored in a battery. The generation efficiencies of electricity and heat were complimentary to each other. The cogenerators could operate without relying on any other external power source. Another model was developed for simulating the output of photovoltaic panels without air heating functions. The modeling algorithm and results of simulation are presented in this paper.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERING; ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; AGRICULTURAL PROCESSES; FLATE PLATE COLLECTORS; PHOTOVOLTAIC PANELS; SOLAR ELECTRIC/THERMAL COGENERATORS; THERMAL ENERGY ABSORPTION; COGENERATION PLANTS

Title: OPTIMAL DESIGN OF PCM STORAGE FOR PASSIVE SOLAR HEATING SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Jawadi, Z.; Winn, C.B.
Abstract: Frequency Domain techniques have proven to be an accurate method for analyzing the thermal performance of passive solar systems with sensible heat storage. In this paper this method is extended for PCM storage. PCM storage has two kinds of non-linearities; (i) Internal: this is due to the moving phase-change boundary and (ii) External: this is due to a switching process from a one-phase state to a two-phase state and vice versa. Linear and piecewise linear models are developed for the above problem.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; FREQUENCY DOMAIN TECHNIQUES; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; THERMAL STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors with affiliations: Vardiashvili, A.B.; Kim, V.D.; Kim, M.D.
Abstract: On the basis of experimental data, hydraulic and heat-exchange characteristics are given for a pebble-filled underground thermal-storage bed in a greenhouse. It is found that for the conditions of a greenhouse, it is necessary to use cobble stones with an average diameter of d//f greater than 0. 27 m and to lay them in the form of a bed with diameter d//T greater than 1. 39 m and length L//T equals 5. 5-6 m.

Title: HIGH-LEVEL WASTE PROGRAM MANAGEMENT: A RATEPAYERS' AND REGULATORY PERSPECTIVE.
Affiliations: Natl Assoc of Regulatory Utility, Commissioners, Lansing, MI, USA, Natl Assoc of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, Lansing, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, Edwyna G., Natl Assoc of Regulatory Utility, Commissioners, Lansing, MI, USA, Natl Assoc of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, Lansing, MI, USA
Abstract: The National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners (NARUC) seeks to investigate and monitor the federal program to provide to the Congress and the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) the NARUC's unique expertise. Recommendations are made for more cost-effective program direction and views on its management are given. Financial control, public input and cost responsibilities for disposal of defense and commercial wastes are separately identified. Needs for the DOE's heightened insight into and development of the monitored retrievable storage proposal to the Congress are described. Finally, with a warning that there exists a limit to ratepayer funding of this effort, the request is made for Congressional cost-control hearings and for expanded dialogue between the Department of Energy and financially responsible parties.

Authors with affiliations: Iskhakov, A.S.; Kuznetsov, G.A.; Pridatkov, A.G.; Tolstov, Yu.G.; Topel'berg, V.V.
Abstract: The stability of a Rectifier unit operating into an inductive store without losses is investigated for instantaneous commutation of the rectifier devices. An effective method is proposed for stabilizing the energy-storage regime through utilization of additional store-voltage feedback. It is shown that it is possible to obtain good dynamic characteristics of the regulation system with the control signals varying widely.

Title: TUTORIAL ON ROLE OF NEODYMIUM MAGNETS IN ACTUATORS FOR COMPUTER PERIPHERALS.

Affiliations: IBM Corp, San Jose, CA, USA, IBM Corp, San Jose, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chai, Hi-Dong, IBM Corp, San Jose, CA, USA, IBM Corp, San Jose, CA, USA
Abstract: In the 1960's and early 70's, the primary concern in the computer industry was to make actuators work according to desired performance specifications. By today's standards, they were big, heavy, energy-inefficient, and expensive. Today with the proliferation of computer peripherals of all kinds and limited natural resources, the designers are faced with multitudes of requirements that need to be met to satisfy their management and their customers. In order to understand these demands, one must look to the technology trends in the computer peripherals -- more specifically, printers and storage devices. The trends are to small package, low power, high efficiency, and low cost. In this tutorial paper, the author examines how some of those demands can be met by the use of neodymium magnets in actuators.

Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to describe the results of a program, performed for the DOE, to evaluate metal cask systems for the packaging, handling, storage, transportation and disposal of spent nuclear fuel. This program has developed tools and demonstrated the methodology for efficient analyses of the economics, radiological, and institutional aspects of very complex nuclear waste management systems. These analyses and the data accumulated in conducting the program provide the DOE with a great deal of insight into the direction that future DOE programs should take.

Title: NOISE REDUCTION IN A SHIP STRUCTURE BY A LIQUID STORAGE TANK.

Authors with affiliations: Shimomura, Yoshihiro, Sumitomo Heavy Industries Ltd, Yokosuka, Jpn, Sumitomo Heavy Industries Ltd, Yokosuka, Jpn; Lyon, Richard H., Sumitomo Heavy Industries Ltd, Yokosuka, Jpn, Sumitomo Heavy Industries Ltd, Yokosuka, Jpn
Abstract: A common ship structure of the aft-bridge and aft-engine type contains a pair of large fuel oil tanks underneath an upper deck between an engine room and the crew's living quarters. From the acoustic point of view, it is important for ship designers to know how these tanks affect noise transmission from the engine room to the living quarters. The experimentally determined vibrational energy level of the upper deck plate located above the liquid storage tank of the model is decreased by filling the tank with water. The reduction of this energy level is about 8 dB at 2 kHz (or 200 Hz in a full scale ship) and decreases as frequency increases. The main reason for the energy level reduction is thought to be the decrease in coupling loss factors between plates due to the liquid loading.

Abstract: An overview of a 1986 Delphi forecast of major trends is presented. Trends discussed include electronics as a fraction of vehicle and component cost and projections of basic vehicle features supported by electronic technology. In addition, basic trends in diagnostics and multiplexing are presented. Several issues in support of automotive electronics are discussed, including the systems approach to vehicle engineering, the importance of developing a proper market strategy, and the continued major role of energy economics. The Delphi forecasting technique and its governing concepts are reviewed as a method to predict the future of automotive technology.

Abstract: This conference contains 5 papers. The subject matter is primarily concerned with control, design and operation of powertrains in vehicles such as automobiles and storage battery vehicles. Title: STATUS OF WASTE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN THE FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF GERMANY.
Affiliations: KFA, Juelich, West Ger, KFA, Juelich, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Merz, E.R., KFA, Juelich, West Ger, KFA, Juelich, West Ger
Abstract: Nuclear power stations in the FRG are owned and operated by the private sector. Consequently, the electricity utilities are obliged to take care of the back-end of the nuclear fuel cycle including waste conditioning. The ultimate storage of wastes, however, stays within the responsibility of the federal government. The German Atomic Energy Act appoints the Federal Agency, Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB) in Braunschweig to undertake the waste disposal on behalf of the federal government. The power plant operators are liable to utilize the radioactive residues, e. g. the spent fuel elements, in such a way that excludes any adverse effects to mankind and the environment. Considerable progress has been made over the past decade within the FRG to develop a national policy and strategy for the management of nuclear wastes. Reference is made to the development work already undertaken and the experience gained to ensure that appropriate treatment, conditioning techniques and facilities are available.

Authors with affiliations: Schoonen, D.H., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Fisher, M.W., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Jensen, M.F., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Mullen, C.K., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: At the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL) include the testing of metal storage casks containing either consolidated or intact spent fuel in inert gas atmospheres. The casks, weighing nearly 100 tons, are fabricated using nodular cast iron or forged carbon steel and contain basket assemblies which provide criticality control and spacing of fuel assemblies in individual cells. Small-scale rod consolidation systems are also being developed. The Test Area North facility located at the INEL was determined to be the appropriate federal facility in which to conduct these activities. These dry storage cask demonstrations support the Department of Energy Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management and NWPA objectives and will establish a data base which can be used for Nuclear Regulatory Commission licensing by generic rule of at-reactor dry storage cask installations.

Title: TWO CO-GENERATION PLANTS IN CALIFORNIA, USA.
Affiliations: Hawker Siddeley Power Engineering, Inc, Hawker Siddeley Power Engineering Inc
Authors with affiliations: Harkins, H.L., Hawker Siddeley Power Engineering, Inc, Hawker Siddeley Power Engineering Inc
Abstract: This paper describes the general economic and technical environment in which were developed two similar cogeneration plants addressing the need for power and refrigeration load at two cold storage facilities in the vicinity of Los Angeles. Each plant comprises a single LM-2500 gas turbine with a dual pressure waste heat boiler generating steam to both an extraction-condensing steam turbine-generator and an absorption refrigeration unit. Included is a description of the cycle together with the factors leading to the choice of the alternative method of financing the projects. Both plants are situated on congested sites in a developed area and consideration of environmental factors is described. The operational characteristics together with the operating regime and staff is considered.

Authors with affiliations: Raju, G.S.N., Defence Research & Development, Organization, Bangalore, India, Defence Research & Development Organization, Bangalore, India; Venkatanarayana, R., Defence Research & Development, Organization, Bangalore, India, Defence Research & Development Organization, Bangalore, India; Rajendran, S., Defence Research & Development, Organization, Bangalore, India, Defence Research & Development Organization, Bangalore, India
Abstract: An all solid state, high power, high voltage, precision dc power supply followed by a hard tube modulator has been developed for a microwave-tube-based coherent radar transmitter. The power supply and modulator of this type offer improved performance from the point of view of spectral purity and reliability. The authors analyze a novel regulation scheme of digital control of the inverter to keep the output voltage constant along with the results obtained. The novel aspects of the scheme are that it not only uses a high-frequency half bridge inverter using SCRs as active switches, but also uses a precision digitally controlled regulation scheme, which keeps the voltage across the energy storage capacitor within 0. 006% of the required value on pulse-to-pulse basis.

Title: COOL STORAGE SYSTEM PERFORMANCE.
Authors with affiliations: Eppelheimer, D.
Abstract: In the past, ice systems were used to reduce the installed tonnage of expensive refrigeration systems that were generally constructed in the field. The advent of the packaged chiller saw the end of ice storage systems in the commercial market. Today we see the seeds of a rejuvenation of ice systems. If the ice systems of today are to succeed, they must embrace the concept of packaging and advanced controls that the commercial HVAC market now enjoys.

Authors: Braakhekke J.P., De Bruin M.I., Stegeman D.F., Wevers R.A., Binkhorst R.A., Joosten E.M.G.
Title: The second wind phenomenon in mcardle's disease
Affiliations: Institutes of Neurology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Nijmegen, Netherlands; Institutes of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Nijmegen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Braakhekke, J.P., Institutes of Neurology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Nijmegen, Netherlands; De Bruin, M.I., Institutes of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Nijmegen, Netherlands; Stegeman, D.F., Institutes of Neurology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Nijmegen, Netherlands; Wevers, R.A., Institutes of Neurology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Nijmegen, Netherlands; Binkhorst, R.A., Institutes of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Nijmegen, Netherlands; Joosten, E.M.G., Institutes of Neurology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Nijmegen, Netherlands
Abstract: Three patients with McArdle's disease exercised for 2 h at 30% VO2max. During exercise two phases occurred During the first 15 min they experienced progressive fatigue and weakness of exercised muscles, with a rapid and complete recovery (adaptation phase). Following this, all 3 patients were able to continue exercise without difficulty ('second wind' phase). During the adaptation phase, patients have to cope with their inability to use muscle glycogen as a fuel Processes occurring during this phase are as follows. (1) An increase in cardiac output. This might be expected to increase muscle blood flow in order to supply exercising muscle with substrates that can substitute for muscle glycogen (free fatty acids (FFA), bloodborne glucose). (2) Changes in the metabolic pathways. These cause a sufficient amount of hexose phosphates to be present to overcome the first 2.5 min of exercise, and FFA and bloodborne glucose to play a major role in energy supply at an earlier stage in exercise than in control subjects. (3) An increase in EMG activity. This is most probably caused by the recruitment of more motor units to compensate for a failure of force generation in the muscle fibres.Central command seems to play an important role in the regulation of cardiovascular processes during the adaptation phase. Despite these compensatory mechanisms, metabolic stress occurs during the adaptation phase During the 'second wind' phase there are no important differences between the metabolism of exercising muscle of patients with McArdle's disease and that of control subjects. © 1986 Oxford University Press.
Index Keywords: fatty acid; adaptation; diagnosis; etiology; exercise; glycogen muscle level; glycogen storage disease type 5; human; major clinical study; muscle; priority journal; Adaptation, Physiological; Adult; Ammonia; Blood Glucose; Cardiac Output; Electromyography; Exertion; Fatigue; Female; Glycogen Storage Disease; Glycogen Storage Disease Type V; Heart Rate; Humans; Lactates; Lactic Acid; Male; Muscles; Potassium

Abstract: Linear restraining spring potential energy storage elements and flexible vibration isolator support systems have been investigated as passive devices to control the highly-nonlinear motion of a planar four-bar mechanical linkage. The design study was based upon the numerical solution in the time domain of the state vector equation for the four-bar mechanical linkage system. The state-vector equation was developed using Lagrange's form of D'Alembert's principle. Frequency responses of the shaft angular velocities, etc. were also obtained using the Fast Fourier Transform of the time domain results. All computer program simulations were written in FORTRAN 77 and performed on an IBM 3033.

Authors: Campbell Lowell F., Coxon Gary D.
Title: NIAGARA FALLS STORAGE SITE REMEDIAL ACTION PROJECT: STATUS UPDATE AND SUMMARY OF SPECIAL FEATURES.
Affiliations: US DOE, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, US DOE, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Campbell, Lowell F., US DOE, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, US DOE, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Coxon, Gary D., US DOE, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, US DOE, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) and its Project Management Contractor, Bechtel National, Inc. are conducting remedial action at the Niagara Falls Storage Site (NFSS) near Lewiston, New York to stabilize low-level radioactive wastes stored at the site and to decontaminate over two dozen contaminated vicinity properties. Over the past 4 years a 10-acre interim waste containment facility has been developed at the site to hold the approximately 250,000 yd**3 of contaminated soil and rubble from the cleanup operations. The residues were dewatered and covered with clay to minimize radon emanation; the tower was demolished and the rubble disposed of in the containment area. Environmental monitoring will continue throughout the interim storage period. In addition, the surface and subsurface condition of the containment structure will be monitored to ensure that undesirable trends are detected in time for corrective action to be taken.

The review includes a discussion of the contents of the Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) Proposal to the Congress, including the findings of the Department's evaluation of the need for and feasibility of MRS. Institutional aspects of the Proposal are also addressed.

Title: LONGTERM PERFORMANCE MODELLING OF A WIND/DIESEL SYSTEM WITH HYDRAULIC ACCUMULATOR STORAGE.

Affiliations: Reading Univ, Engl, Reading Univ, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Slack, G., Reading Univ, Engl, Reading Univ, Engl; Musgrove, P., Reading Univ, Engl, Reading Univ, Engl
Abstract: The use of hydraulic accumulator storage as a small capacity, high power, energy store to improve operation of a wind/diesel system has been validated by tests on a prototype system at Reading. Although measured data has made possible the formulation of a computer model which accurately represents the performance in the short term, assessment of the long term performance and economics causes difficulty due to the large amount of computer time required. This paper describes a fast and flexible method of combining energy buffer performance parameters derived from fast frequency wind data so as to provide an assessment of the long-term performance and economic potential, for a wide variety of system configurations and operating conditions.

Authors with affiliations: Hirling, J., IAEA, Vienna, Austria, IAEA, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) on-going Waste Management Program includes the areas of handling, treatment, conditioning, storage and disposal in land and at sea of various radioactive wastes, the assessment of environmental consequences of radionuclide releases as well as the decontamination and decommissioning of nuclear facilities. The main activities of the IAEA in these fields are: to collect, review and disseminate information, to develop internationally agreed guidelines, to encourage and sponsor research and to provide technical advice and training for Member States upon request. In the last five years about 80 scientific and technical reports have been prepared, ten coordinated research programs were concluded and seven have been initiated. Seventeen developing countries receive technical assistance in the field of waste management.

Title: MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE PROPOSAL IN THE CONTEXT OF THE NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY ACT OF 1982.
Affiliations: Congress of the United States,, Washington, DC, USA, Congress of the United States, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cotton, Thomas A., Congress of the United States,, Washington, DC, USA, Congress of the United States, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The Department of Energy plans to submit to Congress a proposal for an integral monitored retrievable storage (MRS) facility located in the eastern United States to serve as the main waste receiving and packaging facility for the geologic repository. This integral role for the MRS is substantially different from the backup storage role previously discussed for Federal storage facilities. The debate over this proposal offers an opportunity for Congress to address and resolve issues that were not dealt with in passage of NWPA, in a way that will enhance the consensus about the waste program. Compared to the no-action option (the authorized system), approval of the integral MRS would probably increase the front-end political and economic costs of developing the waste management system, but could enhance prospects for success and reduce costs in the long run.
Index Keywords: RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Legislation; WASTE DISPOSAL - Economics; GEOLOGICAL REPOSITORY; MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE; NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY ACT OF 1982; WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: SODIUM-SULFUR BATTERIES FOR SPACECRAFT ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: Aero Propulsion Lab,, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH, USA, Aero Propulsion Lab, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dueber, Ross E., Aero Propulsion Lab,, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH, USA, Aero Propulsion Lab, Wright-Patterson AFB, OH, USA
Abstract: Average lifetimes of nickel-cadmium batteries in LEO run 3-5 years, while lifetimes in GEO average 7-10 years. Nickel-hydrogen batteries are expected to last longer on the average, but still are life-limited by the same nickel electrode used in nickel-cadmium batteries. The sodium-sulfur battery is different in that both the anode and cathode are liquids instead of solids. As such, they do not experience the fatigue and degradation problems associated with the continuous cycling of solid electrodes. Conceivably, the sodium and sulfur could continue to cycle forever in an ideal cell.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Performance; SOLAR CELLS - Design; CELL BYPASS; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; LIFETIME; SOLAR ARRAY; WEIGHT SAVING; SPACECRAFT

Title: 1985 GODDARD SPACE FLIGHT CENTER BATTERY WORKSHOP.
Abstract: This publication contains 32 papers dealing with the latest developments in battery technology with particular emphasis on high reliability operations and aerospace applications. The subjects covered include advanced energy storage, lithium cells technology, nickel-cadmium design evaluation and component testing, simulated orbital cycling and flight experience, as well as nickel-hydrogen technology.
Index Keywords: COMMUNICATION SATELLITES - Electric Power Supplies; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS - Performance; SPACECRAFT - Electric Power Supplies; EIREV; LIFE CYCLE EXTENSION; LITHIUM BATTERIES; NICKEL-CADMIUM; NICKEL-HYDROGEN; STORAGE BATTERIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Hagedorn N.H., Gonzalez-Sanabria O.D., Kohout L.L.
Title: NASA LEWIS EVALUATION OF REGENERATIVE FUEL CELL (RFC) SYSTEMS.

Authors with affiliations: Hagedorn, N.H., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Gonzalez-Sanabria, O.D., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Kohout, L.L., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: At the present time, the primary focus of the Energy Storage Branch at LeRC is the nickel-hydrogen battery, both IPV and bipolar configurations. However, relatively low-level efforts have been initiated recently on two regenerative fuel cell (RFC) systems. The first of these is the 'passive' hydrogen-oxygen RFC, indicating a system capable of operating with no rotating components, such as pumps or compressors. The second RFC being considered is the hydrogen-bromine system. The most promising characteristic of this RFC is that the electrode reactions apparently are reversible, which could result in round-trip energy efficiencies of 75% or more.

Authors with affiliations: van Ommering, G., Ford Aerospace & Communications, Corp, Palo Alto, CA, USA, Ford Aerospace & Communications Corp, Palo Alto, CA, USA
Abstract: The Space Station represents one of the largest space power system applications under serious consideration at this time. This paper provides an overview of the requirements, options, selection criteria and other considerations, and current status with regard to the energy storage subsystem (ESS) for the photovoltaic power system alternative for the Space Station, presented from the perspective of Ford Aerospace as a member of the Rocketdyne team.

Authors: Al-Marafie A., Moustafa S., Al-Kandari A.A.
Title: THERMAL CHARACTERISTIC OF A PARTIALLY CHARGED THERMAL STORAGE.
Affiliations: Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Al-Marafie, A., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait; Moustafa, S., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait; Al-Kandari, A.A., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Safat, Kuwait
Abstract: The thermal storage is a key subsystem in any solar thermal application. It allows for thermal energy storage during periods of high solar irradiance for its reuse during periods of low solar irradiance and during the night. The energy extraction efficiency from the storage is influenced by both design and operational factors such as the state of change of the thermal storage. Under normal conditions, a solar thermal storage is almost always in a partially charged state. This study was aimed at developing and understanding the thermal characteristics of the partially charged thermal with emphasis on the effect of inlet design, storage tank wall material and the presence of fluid dead zone.
Index Keywords: FLUID DEAD ZONES; PARTIALLY CHARGED THERMAL STORAGE; THERMAL EXTRACTION EFFICIENCY; THERMAL STRATIFICATION; WALL MATERIALS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Dymov, G.I.; Bystrov, A.F.; Orlov, A.Yu.
Abstract: On the basis of calculated relationships for changes in the temperature of the heat-transfer medium in a granular fill and its aerodynamic resistance, an interrelation is established between these characteristics, and a procedure is developed for technical-economic evaluation of thermal-storage units with granular fill.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Packed Beds; SOLAR RADIATION - Energy Storage; PACKED-BED THERMAL STORAGE UNITS; HEATING

Title: SURVEY OF SOLAR-DYNAMIC SPACE POWER - THE STIRLING OPTION.
Affiliations: Delft Technical Univ, Delft, Neth, Delft Technical Univ, Delft, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Eshuis, D., Delft Technical Univ, Delft, Neth, Delft Technical Univ, Delft, Neth
Abstract: Using a Stirling-cycle heat-engine in a solar-dynamic space power system to generate electricity can have considerable operational advantages over conventional photovoltaic systems in the case of long-duration, low-Earth-orbit missions such as those of the Space Station or Columbus Platforms. Owing to the high solar-electric efficiency that can be attained, the atmospheric drag produced by the power system is reduced, lessening the need for orbit maintenance. This paper describes an assessment of the feasibility and implications of such a Stirling-cycle space power system by looking at various aspects of the system, its subsystems and components, and presents a reference configuration for preliminary calculations and comparisons. Among the technologies applied would be those of: free-piston Stirling engines, inflatable space-rigidized structures, heat-pipes and thermal energy storage.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; HEAT ENGINES - Efficiency; PROPULSION - Aerospace Applications; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Utilization; SOLAR ELECTRIC PROPULSION SYSTEMS; SPACECRAFT ONBOARD POWER SYSTEMS; STIRLING-CYCLE HEAT ENGINES; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Donley S.W., Matsumoto J.H., Hwang W.C.
Title: SELF-DISCHARGE CHARACTERISTICS OF SPACECRAFT NICKEL-CADMIUM CELLS AT ELEVATED TEMPERATURES.
Affiliations: Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Donley, S.W., Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Matsumoto, J.H., Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA; Hwang, W.C., Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Abstract: The objective of this paper is to relate the effects of heat generation in spacecraft nickel-cadmium (NiCd) cells during high temperature storage on open circuit. When nickel cadmium batteries are open circuited in the charged state, chemical reaction(s) provide a means of self-discharge and heat-generation. Temperatures in the range 80-100 degree C may cause the batteries to become thermally unstable. Additional heating generated by battery self discharge may drive the batteries into catastrophic failure with consequence for the integrity of the spacecraft and its contents.
Index Keywords: SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; AMBIENT EFFECTS; ENERGY LOSS; HEAT GENERATION; THERMAL RUNAWAY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: ARREST OF LONG CRACKS IN STORAGE TANKS.
Authors with affiliations: Willoughby, A.A.; Kawaguchi, Y.
Abstract: To obtain arrest of long, fast running cracks (termed 'long crack arrest') in storage tanks, it is necessary to ensure not only that long brittle cracks will be arrested on entering the parent steel, but also that the arrested crack will subsequently be stable. Test requirements and analyses for these two conditions are discussed. Experiments on a 2 one-half % Ni steel show that it has excellent toughness at -55 degree C, but that ductile tearing under the influence of bulging forces will limit the potential for long crack arrest. Use of a 9% Ni steel is shown to offer little advantage in performance over the 2 one-half % Ni steel.
Index Keywords: FRACTURE MECHANICS; MICROSCOPES, ELECTRON - Applications; STEEL - Fracture; STEEL TESTING - Fracture; DROP WEIGHT TEAR ENERGY; DUCTILE TEARING; ISOTHERMAL TEST; LONG CRACK ARREST; NIL DUCTILITY TRANSITION TEMPERATURE; STORAGE TANK; TANKS

Title: DESIGN OPTIMIZATION OF LARGE WIND POWER PLANTS.
Affiliations: Garyounis Univ, Benghazi, Libya, Garyounis Univ, Benghazi, Libya
Authors with affiliations: Nagrial, M.H., Garyounis Univ, Benghazi, Libya, Garyounis Univ, Benghazi, Libya
Abstract: The design of large wind power plants is formulated as a constrained nonlinear programming problem so as to minimize the cost of energy produced. A horizontal axis wind turbine is assumed but the approach is general enough to be applicable to other designs of wind turbines. Similarly the results presented are restricted to a wind power plant without storage but the design approach can be easily modified to include the cost of storage batteries. A powerful optimization method termed as recursive quadratic programming technique is used to predict the optimum dimensions.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL PROGRAMMING, NONLINEAR; OPTIMIZATION; WIND TURBINES - Design; HORIZONTAL AXIS WIND TURBINE; RECURSIVE QUADRATIC PROGRAMMING; WIND POWER PLANTS; WIND POWER

Title: COMMAND CHARGER FOR LOW-JITTER TRIGGER GENERATOR.
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: LABCOM, US Army Electronics, Technology & Devices Lab, Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA, LABCOM, US Army Electronics Technology & Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wright, William, LABCOM, US Army Electronics, Technology & Devices Lab, Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA, LABCOM, US Army Electronics Technology & Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA; Rohwein, Gerry, LABCOM, US Army Electronics, Technology & Devices Lab, Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA, LABCOM, US Army Electronics Technology & Devices Lab, Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA
Abstract: A command charging circuit capable of delivering a few hundred joules at 30 kV with very good regulation has been developed for operation in a high-noise environment, such as that produced by high-energy spark gaps. The trigger pulse output rose to 125 kV in 2 ns. By pulse-charging the fast storage capacitors, the output trigatron could be operated closer to self-break, thereby reducing jitter; the jitter of the output was less than 1 ns. The immunity of the pulse-charger to extraneous pulses in the presence of a voltage change of tens of megavolts per microsecond was obtained by circuits which blinded the logic to any input during noisy periods. Regulation by the intermediate energy transfer by reducing the reactive power component was 0. 2% for a 10% line variation.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS; ELECTRIC FILTERS; ELECTRIC WAVEFORMS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, TRIGGER; LOGIC CIRCUITS; COMMAND CHARGING CIRCUIT; FAST STORAGE CAPACITORS; LOW-JITTER TRIGGER GENERATOR; PULSE POWER SYSTEMS; SPARK GAPS; PULSE GENERATORS

Authors: Bouriotis V., Santamouris M., Lefas C.C.
Title: ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN: THERMAL PERFORMANCE AND OPERATIONAL STRATEGIES OF A HYBRID SOLAR BUILDING IN ATHENS, GREECE.
Affiliations: DPLG, Athens, Greece, DPLG, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Bouriotis, V., DPLG, Athens, Greece, DPLG, Athens, Greece; Santamouris, M., DPLG, Athens, Greece, DPLG, Athens, Greece; Lefas, C.C., DPLG, Athens, Greece, DPLG, Athens, Greece
Abstract: The architectural design, the thermal performance and the operational strategy of a hybrid solar building in Athens is described. Its total surface is 452m**2 and its total volume is 1990 m**3. The style of the building is characterized as postmodern with neo classical architectural elements. Particular attention is paid to the combination of the passive solar components with the overall aesthetics of the house. Evacuated collectors, greenhouse and direct gain systems are used. Additional storage is provided by a silica gel water tank. The thermal analysis of the system is given. Simulation is used to compute the heating load coverage. Finally the operational strategy, implemented on a dedicated microcomputer is given.
Index Keywords: ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN - Greece; GREENHOUSES; SOLAR ENERGY - Greece; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; WATER TANKS AND TOWERS; DIRECT GAIN SYSTEMS; EVACUATED COLLECTORS; HYBRID SOLAR BUILDING; SILICA GEL WATER TANK; THERMAL PERFORMANCE; BUILDINGS

Title: ENERGY EDUCATION AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY.
Authors with affiliations: Winn, C.B.; Burns, P.J.
Abstract: Energy conversion has been one of six major programs of study in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at Colorado State University for many years. This has been a multidisciplinary program involving electrical, civil, chemical and agricultural engineering, physics, chemistry, and business as well as the Department of Mechanical Engineering. Particular emphasis has been in the areas of solar energy applications, energy conservation in manufacturing facilities, energy conversion, and in applied thermodynamics. Present research programs include (1) energy conservation in manufacturing facilities, (2) off-peak storage of thermal energy, (3) active and passive solar heating and cooling systems, (4) chemical and electric propulsion, and (5) fuels from biomass.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION - Education; SOLAR ENERGY; ENERGY EDUCATION; SOLAR HOUSE; SOLAR VILLAGE; ENGINEERING EDUCATION

Authors with affiliations: Tityukov, Yu.G.; Yakovenko, V.A.
Abstract: A method is suggested for analysis and evaluation of the operation of a charge-storage diode in a high-power upconverter with arbitrary diode parameters and arbitrary excitation level. Relations are derived for calculating the energy and impedance characteristics of the diode in optimal operation. The tables are given of normalized diode characteristics for maximum output power and maximum efficiency operation modes, which can be used for rapid evaluation of diode operation conditions.
Index Keywords: ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, FREQUENCY CONVERTER - Design; CHARGE-STORAGE DIODES (CSD); SIDEBAND UPCONVERTERS; SEMICONDUCTOR DIODES

Title: PASSIVE AND LOW-ENERGY COOLING.
Affiliations: Arizona State Univ, Tempe, AZ, USA, Arizona State Univ, Tempe, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bahadori, M.N., Arizona State Univ, Tempe, AZ, USA, Arizona State Univ, Tempe, AZ, USA
Abstract: This article presents a summary of the author's recent activities in the area of passive and low-energy cooling in hot, arid climates. The studies summarized are: a new design of a wind tower, or Baud-Geer, with improved airflow characteristics and a more effective evaporative cooling process; evaluation of airflow rates through buildings employing domed roofs; reduction of the mean radiant temperature of the internal surfaces of adobe buildings by keeping these surfaces moist and evaporatively cooled; evaluation of the rate of natural ice production in arid regions; production, storage, and utilization of ice in deep underground ponds; and finally, the seasonal storage of coolness in water in aquifers.

The analysis is extended to show constant-current energy delivery to a varying inductive load, e. g. , a constant acceleration EM gun.

Authors with affiliations: Renaud, P., CNRS, Valbonne, Fr, CNRS, Valbonne, Fr; Jaffrin, A., CNRS, Valbonne, Fr, CNRS, Valbonne, Fr
Abstract: Producing fresh water from sea or brackish waters in isolated regions can be achieved using wind energy as the main source of energy and some additional solar heat, by means of a mechanical vapor compression still. It has been shown, on a small prototype, that the distillation process can adapt itself to the fluctuating pattern of a realistic wind energy spectrum and accept intermittent operating modes provided a minimum heat and electric storage is used, which makes the system economically feasible even on a modest scale.

Authors: Isacson Orjan, Ewetz Johan, Lundgren Goran
Title: EFFECTS OF STATE SUPPORT ON INDUSTRY AND ON THE MARKET FOR SOLAR HEATING, HEAT PUMPS AND HEAT STORAGE.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Isacson, Orjan; Ewetz, Johan; Lundgren, Goran
Abstract: A considerable amount of work has been done by industry, the state and other organizations in Sweden since the middle of the 1970s on the development and introduction of solar heating, heat pump and heat storage technology. The objective of this investigation has been to study in detail the effects of state energy-related research, development and demonstration support on industry and on the markets for solar heating, heat pumps and heat stores. Particular attention has been paid to demonstrating effects that have occurred as the direct result of various forms of state energy-related research, development and demonstration support, and to investigating whether it would be possible to achieve better results in future through some modification of the form of this support.

Abstract: The spectral, angular, and polarization properties of the synchrotron radiation of electrons moving in a synchrotron or storage ring are investigated in this paper with allowance for the rectilinear gaps of these facilities. Title: OFF PEAK ICE STORAGE GENERATION.
Authors with affiliations: Davis, R.E.; Cerbo, F.J.
Abstract: Due to the high costs associated with peak demand charges imposed by most electrical companies today, various means of shifting the peak HVAC load have been identified by the industry. This paper discusses the results of a study based upon a building site located in the high desert of the southwestern United States that evaluated ice storage as a mechanism of operating cost reductions. The discussion addresses both the seasonal and the annual cost and energy impacts of an ice storage system when used in place of an air-to-air heat pump system.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION; HVAC; ICE STORAGE; PEAK POWER USE; ICE

Title: CURRENT STATUS OF THE CANADIAN EXPERIMENTAL DRY STORAGE PROGRAM FOR IRRADIATED FUEL.
Affiliations: AECL, AECL
Authors with affiliations: Wasywich, K.M., AECL, AECL; Frost, C.R., AECL, AECL
Abstract: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited and Ontario Hydro are jointly conducting three dry storage experiments in concrete canisters with irradiated fuel bundles from Ontario Hydro's Pickering and Bruce Nuclear Generating Stations. The objective of the work at WNRE near Pinawa, Manitoba, is to assess the behaviour of the bundles under storage conditions representative of those in an interim dry storage or an ultimate disposal facility. The bundles were irradiated at peak outer-element linear power ratings ranging from 22 kW/m to 53 kW/m, and outer-element average burnups of 181 MWh/kg U to 262 MWh/kg U. Prior to canister storage, the bundles were stored in reactor-site water bays for periods ranging between 1. 8 and 8. 8 years.

Abstract: The continuation of activities in the Yugoslav Atomic Energy Programme requires the solution of problems related to disposal in Yugoslavia of radioactive wastes from different sources, such as the Krsko nuclear power plant (in operation since 1982), a series of nuclear power plants to be constructed in Yugoslavia by the end of the year 2010 (4000 MW(e)), nuclear research institutes, industrial applications and hospitals. The first part of the study was concerned with the production of radioactive wastes and spent fuel for three different types of nuclear reactor (PWR, BWR and HWR) and for different nuclear fuel cycle technologies (with and without reprocessing).

The objective of the design is to meet the EPA standards for long-term performance by consolidating the tailings and associated contaminated materials with a system of controls that would last 1000 years where reasonably achievable, and at least for 200 years. Abstract: General Electric is currently about midway in the first major program in the United States for rail transport of commercial spent fuel from nuclear power plants to a licensed receiving and storage facility. The results to date have successfully demonstrated the safety and efficiency of shipping spent fuel by rail. The experience gained in the planning and implementation of the shipping campaigns can serve as a full-scale pilot for later transportation of all the nation's inventory of spent fuel by the U. S. Title: 50kW FLUIDIZED BED HIGH TEMPERATURE SOLAR RECEIVER.
Affiliations: CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr, CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Flamant, G., CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr, CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr; Gauthier, D., CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr, CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr; Flitris, Y., CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr, CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr; Amouroux, M., CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr, CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr; Boudhari, C., CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr, CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr; Robert, J.F., CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr, CNRS, Font-Romeu, Fr
Abstract: This paper deals with the theoretical and experimental study of a 2-dimensional fluidized-bed receiver which was designed and tested at the focus of the 50kW solar furnace in MONTLOUIS. Results presented here are concerned with batch operations, but the receiver can be run continuously, either for heat storage with particulates or for particles processing. Solid circulation has been demonstrated at ambient temperature and will be done at high temperature in the next step.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Fluidized Beds; SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; BATCH OPERATIONS; FLUIDIZED-BED RECEIVER; HIGH TEMPERATURE SOLAR RECEIVER; SOLAR FURNACE; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: MONITORING A SOLAR-ASSISTED HEAT PUMP WITH SEASONAL GROUND COUPLED STORAGE: ANALYSIS OF THE FIRST RESULTS.
Affiliations: Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy, Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Mazzarella, L., Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy, Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy; Pedrocchi, E., Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy, Politecnico di Milano, Milan, Italy
Abstract: This paper outlines the first stage of an extensive research to test solar collectors and seasonal ground storage performances, when these are used as a cold removable source for a heat pump heating system. The heating plants of several buildings, consisting of solar assisted heat pumps with different kinds of ground coupled storage, have been the object of our studies since the beginning of the project in Summer 1982. Essential data have been collected in these years and recently a fully automatic monitoring system has been installed. In this work, first we describe the surrounding environment the physical layout and the different operation modes of the plants. Second we describe the data acquisition system and analyse the data available up to now. We can particularly define the ground storages performance (energy and temperature) and try to make a comparison between horizontal-pipe and vertical-pipe heat storage. We also present a global energy balance for both the plants and define solar collector efficiency and heat pump performance (C. O. P. ) on operating.
Index Keywords: GROUND COUPLED STORAGE; HEAT PUMP PERFORMANCE; HEATING SYSTEM; SOLAR-ASSISTED HEAT PUMP; SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: SYNERGISM OF A COMBINATION SPACE-HEATING/WATER-HEATING APPLIANCE.
Authors with affiliations: Pietsch, Joseph A.
Abstract: Residential storage water heaters are rated in accordance with the Department of Energy (DOE) test procedures (1-3) on the basis of a hot water usage of 64. 3 gallons (244 litres) per day. Most water heaters can provide this requirement in one to two hours of operation per day. For the remainder of the 22 to 23 hours in the day, the water heater operates in a standby mode. Energy must be supplied during standby to maintain the stored water at tank temperature. For a gas water heater, the energy consumed during standby is typically about 30% to 70% of the energy required to provide the daily hot water requirement. The overall efficiency (DOE Energy Factor) of the water heater, taking standby energy consumption into account, is about 60% to 75% of the DOE Recovery Efficiency. If a space-heating load is added to the water-heating load, the overall efficiency of the combination appliance can be increased substantially over the efficiency of the heater when used to heat domestic water only.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION; HEATING; RESIDENTIAL STORAGE WATER HEATERS; SPACE HEATING EFFICIENCY; SPACE HEATING INSTALLATIONS; SUMMER EFFICIENCY; WATER-HEATING EFFICIENCY; WINTER EFFICIENCY; WATER HEATERS

Authors: Korin E., Pasternak D., Rappeport E., Roy A., Wolf D.
Title: NOVEL GREENHOUSE CONCEPT USING PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS IN WALLS AND ROOF.
Affiliations: Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr, Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr
Authors with affiliations: Korin, E., Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr, Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr; Pasternak, D., Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr, Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr; Rappeport, E., Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr, Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr; Roy, A., Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr, Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr; Wolf, D., Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr, Ben-Gurion Univ of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Isr
Abstract: A new type of passive solar greenhouse, for mild winter climate regions, is presented. The surface of the greenhouse (mainly the roof) is made up of modular, double layer transparent panels filled with latent heat energy storage material (LHSM). This paper describes the concept, its basic material components and the main experimental results which were obtained during several seasons of testing.
Index Keywords: MATERIALS - Phase Transitions; PLASTICS PRODUCTS; POLYCARBONATES; LATENT HEAT ENERGY STORAGE MATERIAL; PASSIVE SOLAR GREENHOUSE; ROSE CROPS; SALT-HYDRATES; TRANSPARENT PANEL; GREENHOUSES

Title: UNIQUE HYBRID SOLAR HOME'S ACTUAL AND THEORETICAL THERMAL PERFORMANCE COMPARED.
Affiliations: New Mexico Solar Energy Inst, Las, Cruces, NM, USA, New Mexico Solar Energy Inst, Las Cruces, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Selinfreund, M., New Mexico Solar Energy Inst, Las, Cruces, NM, USA, New Mexico Solar Energy Inst, Las Cruces, NM, USA; Farrer, R., New Mexico Solar Energy Inst, Las, Cruces, NM, USA, New Mexico Solar Energy Inst, Las Cruces, NM, USA
Abstract: Outside the town of Cuba, New Mexico, one of the colder places in the state of New Mexico, an adobe home was constructed. This home is unique in that it incorporates both passive solar design which transfers energy by natural convection throughout the 3,200 square foot house, and also boosts the available passive heat collected with an array of active swimming pool collectors which transfer energy to water storage located in a sunspace. The water storage in the sunspace functions also as a lap pool. An upper story trombe wall provides additional solar heating. Auxiliary heating is provided by thermostatically controlled electric heat and firewood. The residents record daily maximum and minimum temperatures both outdoors and indoors and record also the amount of energy used to supplement the solar heating. The actual house performance is compared to computer simulations.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Solar, Active; COMPUTER SIMULATION; HEAT TRANSFER - Convection; SOLAR RADIATION - Solar Ponds; ACTIVE SWIMMING POOL COLLECTORS; ADOBE HOME; LAP POOL; SUNSPACE; TROMBE WALL; U-VALUES; HOUSES

Authors: Kuwahara E., Kawamura T., Yamazaki M.
Title: SHORTENING THE DEFROST TIME ON A HEAT-PUMP AIR CONDITIONER.
Authors with affiliations: Kuwahara, E.; Kawamura, T.; Yamazaki, M.
Abstract: Methods to shorten the defrost time on a heat pump air conditioner were studied. The experiment was carried out using a one horsepower heat pump, and the energy balance during defrosting was analyzed. We found that the following methods are effective to shorten the defrosting time: (1) increase in power input to the compressor during defrosting, (2) utilization of the compressor for energy storage, and (3) reduction of the water left on the outdoor heat exchanger. A heat pump with the new defrosting system was constructed on an experimental basis. Its defrost time was 1 minute and 55 seconds under the defrost condition of Japanese Industrial Standard. The defrost time of a conventional heat pump is about 4 or 5 minutes.
Index Keywords: REFRIGERATION; DEFROST TIME; DEFROST TIME SHORTENING METHODS; DEFROSTING ENERGY BALANCE; DEFROSTING SYSTEM; HEAT-PUMP AIR CONDITIONER; PRESSURE ENTHALPY DIAGRAM; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: SIMULTANEOUS MEASUREMENT OF DISK VIBRATIONS AND SLIDER BEARING RESPONSE IN AN OPERATING MAGNETIC DISK FILE.
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, L-Y.; Bogy, D.B.
Abstract: The recently developed readback signal modulation (RSM) technique for measuring the spacing variation between the read/write transducer and the magnetic disk is used in conjunction with the laser-Doppler vibrometer (LDV) to measure simultaneously the spacing variation and disk vibrations that result from an impact directly on the disk of an operating disk file. The low-frequency (below 4 kHz) disk vibration modes contain most of the vibrational energy, but some modes are detected at frequencies as high as 18 kHz. The low-frequency disk modes do not excite the air bearing, but those in the 8-18 kHz range, which correspond to the natural frequencies of the air bearing, couple strongly into the air bearing and can easily lead to head crash. The simultaneous measurement technique utilized shows promise for studying the effects on air bearing performance associated with impacts on various system components of the disk file.
Index Keywords: BEARINGS; VIBRATIONS; DISK VIBRATIONS; MAGNETIC DISK FILE; READ/WRITE TRANSDUCER; READBACK SIGNAL MODULATION; SLIDER BEARING RESPONSE; SPACING VARIATION; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Title: CALCULATION OF AIRCRAFT TYRE LOAD CAPACITY.
Affiliations: Shu-Guang Research Inst of Rubber, Industry, Guilin, China, Shu-Guang Research Inst of Rubber Industry, Guilin, China
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Yao-Guang, Shu-Guang Research Inst of Rubber, Industry, Guilin, China, Shu-Guang Research Inst of Rubber Industry, Guilin, China
Abstract: Knowing how to calculate the aircraft tyre load capacity and the energy storage under the load effect accurately is one of the most important criteria for the tyre designers and landing gear engineers. This paper describes a formula and mathematical techniques for accurate calculations and describes experimental results.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES; TIRES - Mechanical Properties; AIRCRAFT TIRE; BOTTOMING DEFLECTION; LOAD CAPACITY CALCULATION; AIRCRAFT

Title: MECHANISM OF REACTIONS AND SIDE REACTIONS OF THE CARBOTHERMIC REDUCTION OF ALPHA-ALUMINA AND SILICA WITH SOLAR ENERGY.
Affiliations: Univ Basel, Basel, West Ger, Univ Basel, Basel, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Eicher, Hp., Univ Basel, Basel, West Ger, Univ Basel, Basel, West Ger; Guentherodt, H.-J., Univ Basel, Basel, West Ger, Univ Basel, Basel, West Ger
Abstract: Up to 8. 5 kWh of energy is released during oxidation of one kg of aluminium or silicon. Both are therefore interesting candidates for chemical energy storage. We have investigated in detail the processes occurring during carbothermic reduction of alumina and silica to aluminium and silicon respectively in our solar furnace Helios 2000. Besides the desired reactions products aluminium and silicon we found several byproducts like siliconcarbide, suboxides of silicon, delta-, gamma- and kappa-alumina, mullite and aluminiumhydrates. The amount of the products depends on the process conditions which will be discussed in this paper.
Index Keywords: ALUMINA - Chemical Reactions; SILICA - Chemical Reactions; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; ALPHA-ALUMINA; CARBOTHERMIC REDUCTION; ELEMENTARY SILICON; REACTIONS AND SIDE REACTIONS; SOLAR FUELS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS

Title: SOLAR THERMAL CENTRAL RECEIVER SYSTEMS, PROCEEDINGS OF THE THIRD INTERNATIONAL WORKSHOP.
Abstract: This workshop proceedings contains 79 papers. Several small Solar Thermal Power Plants have been successfully operated in recent years; their results enable the scientific and technical community to judge on technical viabilities, assess operational characteristics, and evaluate and extrapolate thermal and electrical performance. Summarizing and comparing these experiences was the topic of the first part of the Workshop which dealt with 'Plants'. When solar irradiation is converted into other energetic forms, the transfer from radiative to thermal energy has to be considered thoroughly. This has been performed in a conventional way within the transfer path to electricity. It seems very reasonable, however, to investigate more closely the opportunities for high temperature process heat use, e. g. for endothermic reactions. The chemical problems of these reactions including the technologies of heat exchangers and reactors were examined and developed in the second part of the workshop which dealt with 'Applications'.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS; HEAT TRANSFER; POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; SOLAR ENERGY - Absorption; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; EIREV; SOLAR CENTRAL RECEIVERS; SOLAR CHEMICAL PROCESSES; SOLAR HEAT STORAGE; SOLAR HEAT TRANSFER; SOLAR THERMAL POWER PLANTS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: MAGNETIC TAPE SPEED VARIATIONS: III. TAPE WINDING AND UNWINDING EFFECTS.
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D.P.; Sievers, J.A.
Abstract: Release of stretch energy stored in elastic magnetic tape during unwinding of a tape pack can, under certain circumstances, be discontinuous. This discontinuous energy release process excites longitudinal tape vibrations which can lead to anomalous tape flutter. A theoretical model relating such a process to tape frictional and elastic properties as well as tape tension is presented.
Index Keywords: FRICTION; VIBRATIONS; ELASTIC MAGNETIC TAPE; SPEED VARIATIONS; STRETCH ENERGY; TAPE FLUTTER; TAPE WINDING; UNWINDING; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Title: SOLENOID-TYPE SHIELD COIL FOR SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the International Cryogenic Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oita Univ, Oita, Jpn, Oita Univ, Oita, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ezaki, T., Oita Univ, Oita, Jpn, Oita Univ, Oita, Jpn; Irie, F., Oita Univ, Oita, Jpn, Oita Univ, Oita, Jpn
Abstract: An improved shield coil system for the superconducting energy storage is proposed. The system consists of a solenoid type main shield coil which is located at the inside of a superconducting solenoid coil and a pair of compensation coils which reduce leakage pulse fields from the main shield coil. This system has advantages of a simplicity of magnetic force support and a less quantity of superconductor compared to the system proposed hitherto. A conceptual design for the system of transferring energy of 500 MJ and transferring time of 1 second is made supposing the application to the stabilization of power network system.
Index Keywords: CRYOGENICS; ELECTRIC COILS; SOLENOIDS; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Energy Seminar

Abstract: The proceedings includes 8 papers. The main topics were solar energy conversions, heat transfer, enthalpy radiation, sterilizer, nuclear reactor safety, cooling thermal storage, and comparison between hydrogen and synthetic fuels.

Title: PHOTOVOLTAIC-POWERED VACCINE REFRIGERATOR-FREEZER SYSTEMS FIELD TEST RESULTS.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ratajczak, Anthony F., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The application of vaccination in developing countries has been hampered by the need to provide refrigerated storage and transportation for vaccines. In 1979 the NASA Lewis Research Center in cooperation with the U. S. Centers for Disease Control and the U. S. Department of Energy began a project to develop and field test photovoltaic-powered refrigerator/freezers suitable for vaccine storage. Three different refrigerator/freezers were qualified. Twenty-nine systems containing these refrigerators were subjected to over a year of field testing in 24 countries. This paper describes the project, systems designs, performance, and reliability. The systems are reliable and are capable of maintaining proper vaccine storage temperatures in a range of climatological and user environments.
Index Keywords: REFRIGERATORS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; PERFORMANCE; PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEMS; SOLAR REFRIGERATORS; VACCINATION; VACCINE REFRIGERATORS; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS

Title: ANALYSIS OF INDUSTRIAL LOAD MANAGEMENT.
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Authors with affiliations: Bjork, C.O.; Karlsson, B.G.
Abstract: Industrial Load Management, ILM, has increased the possibilities of changing load profiles and raising load factors. This paper reports on load profile measurements and feasible load management applications that could be implemented in industry e. g. bivalent systems for heating of premises and processes, load priority systems, energy storage and rescheduling processes or parts of processes due to differential electricity rates. Industrial load variations on hourly, daily and seasonal basis are treated as well as the impact by load management on load curves e. g. peak clipping, valley filling and increased off-peak electricity usage.
Index Keywords: INDUSTRIAL PLANTS - Energy Management; IRON AND STEEL PLANTS - Energy Management; INDUSTRIAL LOAD MANAGEMENT; LOAD CURVES; LOAD FACTORS; LOAD PROFILES; THERMAL CAPACITY; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: EFFECT OF FREEZING RATE AND STORAGE TIME ON SHELF-LIFE QUALITY OF HOT BONED AND CONVENTIONALLY BONED GROUND BEEF.
Authors with affiliations: Gapud, V.G.; Schlimme, D.V.
Abstract: Commercially processed, 80% lean, chub packaged ground beef (both conventionally boned and hot boned) was frozen of 0 degree F ( minus 18 degree C) at three rates: 72, 96, and 120 hours before storage at 0 degree F ( minus 18 degree C). The meat was examined after 0, 1. 5, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months storage for the following attributes: pyschrophile and aerobic plate counts, free fatty acid (FFA) and thiobarbituric acid (TBA) values, niacin content, raw and cooked color, moisture, fat and protein contents, and cook shrink and texture of cooked patties.
Index Keywords: REFRIGERATION - Energy Conservation; CONVENTIONALLY BONED GROUND BEEF; ENERGY-SAVING METHODS; FREEZING RATES; MICROBIOLOGICAL ANALYSIS; SHELF-LIFE QUALITY; STORAGE TIME; FOOD PRODUCTS

Authors: Alvaridze G.P., Kalandadze A.M., Garmiza D.I., Bostoganashvili N.I.
Title: DETERMINING THE PROBABILITY OF OCCURRENCE OF ACCIDENTS FROM STATIC ELECTRICAL DISCHARGES.
Authors with affiliations: Alvaridze, G.P.; Kalandadze, A.M.; Garmiza, D.I.; Bostoganashvili, N.I.
Abstract: An increase in the concentration of flammable dusts over the allowable limit, dispersion of dust particles, a decrease in their moisture, or a decrease in atmospheric humidity, favor the appearance of spark discharges from the surface of an electrified material. In this case the energy of the spark discharge is the principal parameter characterizing the ignition probability. The authors present an approximate calculation for determination of the probability of an accident in a technological process when using crushed hard coal (with consideration of certain factors favoring sparking), for example, during its transport and unpackaged storage at a coking plant. The results of calculating the probability indices of the hazard of an accident at various values of several simultaneously acting factors are presented.
Index Keywords: INDUSTRIAL PLANTS - Accident Prevention; RISK STUDIES - Assessment; EXPLOSION PROBABILITY; IGNITION CAPACITY; MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE CONCENTRATION (MAC); SPARK DISCHARGE ENERGY; SPARK FORMATION; COKE PLANTS

Authors: Brunstrom C., Larsson M., Holst P., Zinko H., Hillstrom C.-G.
Title: LYCKEBO PROJECT: A SWEDISH CENTRAL SOLAR HEATING PLANT WITH SEASONAL STORAGE.
Affiliations: Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed, Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Brunstrom, C., Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed, Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed; Larsson, M., Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed, Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed; Holst, P., Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed, Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed; Zinko, H., Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed, Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed; Hillstrom, C.-G., Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed, Swedish State Power Board, Alvkarleby, Swed
Abstract: The main objective of the Lyckebo project is to develop and demonstrate a large-scale solar district heating system with seasonal storage in a rock cavern. Performance data from one year of operation with the plant were measured. An annual collector field heat production of 287 kWh/m**2 at a global collector plane irradiation of 989 kWh/m**2 was obtained, resulting in a collector field efficiency of 29 per cent. The storage heat loss during the year amounted to 3. 14 GWh, corresponding to 26 percent of the heat production. The annual flow-weighted loading and unloading mean temperatures, measured in the interconnecting culvert, were 84 degree C and 64 degree C respectively. The technique with moveable telescope pipes ensured a very good storage temperature stratification. The performance results showed that effective production and storage of solar energy is possible with highly efficient flat plate collectors and rock cavern seasonal storage.
Index Keywords: HEATING - District; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; FLAT PLATE COLLECTORS; LYCKEBO PROJECT; ROCK CAVERN SEASONAL STORAGE; SOLAR DISTRICT HEATING; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: SOLAR THERMAL HIGH TEMPERATURE TECHNOLOGY AND ITS APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor, Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz, Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Kesselring, P., Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor, Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz, Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz
Abstract: In a post-fossil era storage and transportation of energy will, very probably, become decisive issues for any energy system. This is particularly true also for solar energy. Chemistry will be the important discipline, which in connection with solar thermal energy means high temperature process heat applications to produce solar fuels and chemicals. In the long run this technology should have a chance, because highly concentrated solar radiation is a relatively cheap high quality fuel. For the more conventional high temperature processes (e. g. chemical process provided with heat directly from receiver and storage) much can be learned from the experience of solar thermal power plants. Solar energy R plus D will not have a substantial impact on the energy system in this century.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Thermal Effects; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR FUELS AND CHEMICALS; SOLAR HIGH TEMPERATURE TECHNOLOGY; SOLAR THERMAL ELECTRICITY; SOLAR THERMAL TECHNOLOGY; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: MICROELECTRONIC CONTROL OF AN ENERGY-EFFICIENT ELECTRIC VEHICLE.
Affiliations: Univ of Manchester, Engl, Univ of Manchester, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Renfrew, A.C., Univ of Manchester, Engl, Univ of Manchester, Engl; Loh, W.K., Univ of Manchester, Engl, Univ of Manchester, Engl
Abstract: There are two basic ways of increasing the operating range of a given design of electric vehicle: one method is to degrade the vehicle's performance, ultimately to an unacceptable level; the other is to provide specified performance and attempt to find the optimum operating point under all conditions in order to minimise battery drain. With energy efficiency in mind, this article discusses a microelectronic control system for an electric vehicle.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; MICROELECTRONICS; BATTERY DRAIN; MICROPROCESSOR CONTROLLER; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF A COMPOSITE FLYWHEEL ROTOR FOR VEHICLE APPLICATIONS - A STUDY OF THE INTERACTION BETWEEN DESIGN, MATERIALS AND FABRICATION.
Affiliations: BP Research Cent, Sunbury,, Middlesex, Engl, BP Research Cent, Sunbury, Middlesex, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Medlicott, P.A.C., BP Research Cent, Sunbury,, Middlesex, Engl, BP Research Cent, Sunbury, Middlesex, Engl; Potter, K.D., BP Research Cent, Sunbury,, Middlesex, Engl, BP Research Cent, Sunbury, Middlesex, Engl
Abstract: A composite flywheel rotor has been designed and developed, by BP, as part of a programme to develop a total flywheel energy storage system for use in vehicle applications. This paper describes the elements of the flywheel design and analysis, the choices of materials and fabrication route, and the tradeoffs needed to produce the required result. It also describes the testing of rotors to demonstrate their performance characteristics.
