Title: TRIBOACOUSTICS OF NONWOVEN FABRIC FLOPPY DISK DYNAMIC CONTACT.
Authors with affiliations: Tse, Ming-Kai; Lewis, Armand F.
Abstract: Study of the acoustic emission accompanying the rubbing of two surfaces (triboacoustics) has been found to be useful in developing some insights into the dynamics of nonwoven fabrics rubbing against floppy-disk magnetic media surfaces. The triboacoustic response of such a material interface is found to depend upon the contact pressure, rubbing velocity, and type of nonwoven fabric involved. Of importance is the structure and texture of the nonwoven fabric. Using microvideo observation techniques, it was learned that rubbing of a fabric against a solid surface is accompanied by vibration of a fraction of the fiber elements at the interface. In this work, this phenomenon is referred to as fretting. It is found that the percent active fretting area during the fibrous rubbing process is directly proportional to the acoustic energy emitted in the process. The spectral characteristics of the triboacoustic signal are also dependent upon the fibrous material under study and the corresponding percent fretting area. The fibrous wiping of magnetic media produces frictional heating which, in terms of temperature rise, is directly proportional to the product of the kinetic coefficient of friction and the thermal resistance of the fibrous component.
Index Keywords: ACOUSTIC EMISSION TESTING; TRIBOLOGY - Acoustic Wave Effects; DYNAMIC CONTACT; FLOPPY DISK; FRICTIONAL HEATING; NONWOVEN FABRICS; RUBBING VELOCITY; TRIBOACOUSTICS; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Title: SOLAR GASIFICATION OF CARBONACEOUS MATERIAL.
Authors with affiliations: Andujar, J.M.; Romero, M.
Abstract: A fuel enhancement value of 45% and an efficiency for solar power storage ranging between 10-40%, depending on the receiver design, can be achieved when gasification of carbonaceous material is intended. Nevertheless, problems of efficiency loss caused by faults in light transmission through the transparent walls of the gasification furnace have been reported. This paper explores the possibility of using a new concept of concentration and transport of solar power based on optical fibers which can improve the efficiency for solar power storage avoiding the problems found when fluidized bed reactors are used for this purpose.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL EQUIPMENT - Fluidized Beds; HEAT TRANSFER - Transport Properties; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; CARBONACEOUS MATERIAL; FLUIDIZED BED REACTOR; SOLAR GASIFICATION; SOLAR POWER STORAGE; CHEMICAL OPERATIONS

Authors: Durisch W., Frick E., Kesselring P.
Title: HEAT STORAGE IN SOLAR POWER PLANTS USING SOLID BEDS.
Affiliations: Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor, Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz, Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Durisch, W., Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor, Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz, Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz; Frick, E., Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor, Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz, Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz; Kesselring, P., Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor, Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz, Swiss Federal Inst for Reactor Research, Wuerenlingen, Switz
Abstract: A mathematical model has been developed to describe the dynamic behaviour of large scale gas operated solid bed energy stores. In order to solve the system of differential equations the analytical and finite difference method has been applied. To use the model, two computer programs PACKBEDA and PACKBEDN were written. The results of the two solution methods are in excellent agreement. The model can be used with an arbitrary time-varying gas inlet temperature and a non-uniform initial temperature distribution along the bed axis, both for charging and discharging mode. The model is characterized by solving Fourier's equation for all particles along the bed axis individually. The model has been applied to the 500 MWh, 550 degree C air/rock store proposed in a SOTEL power plant study. The model also has been used to study the sensitivity with respect to various bed materials, particle size, air velocity etc. Since for commercial size solid beds no measured data up to high temperatures are available for comparison, experiments are recommended to verify the validity of the model presented in this paper.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Mathematical Models; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; HEAT EXCHANGE MATHEMATICS; HEAT STORAGE; HEAT TRANSPORT MEDIUM; SOLID BED ENERGY STORAGE; SPECIFIC ENERGY DENSITY; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Ikeda N., Tani T., Tanaka T., Horigome T.
Title: CONCEPTURAL DESIGN OF SOLAR THERMAL POWER SYSTEM WITH METALLIC HYDRIDE.
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Lab, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ikeda, N., Electrotechnical Lab, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Jpn; Tani, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Jpn; Tanaka, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Jpn; Horigome, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Jpn
Abstract: The possibility of a solar thermal electric power system with metallic hydride is presented. In the present solar systems, there are problems to be solved such as change of solar insolation, delay time of starting and short generation time of electricity. An application of chemical heat pump system to solar thermal system is considered and we designed conceptually 10 MW//e class solar thermal electric power system with metallic hydride. The system consists of distributed solar reactive collectors, hydrogen transport pipes with no thermal insulation and steam generator with hydrogen reaction like a structure of a nuclear reactor.
Index Keywords: HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS - Design; CHEMICAL PROCESSES; ENERGY STORAGE; METAL HYDRIDE SYSTEMS; SOLAR THERMAL POWER SYSTEM; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Himmel M., Oh K., Tucker M., Rivard C., Grohmann K.
Title: EVALUATION OF SPRAY-DRYING METHODS FOR CELLULASE PRESERVATION.
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Himmel, M., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA; Oh, K., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA; Tucker, M., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA; Rivard, C., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA; Grohmann, K., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Abstract: Spray drying processes are widely used for the large-scale preservation of biological goods. The application of this technology to the enhancement of the storability of cellulases and related enzymes would improve fermentation processes requiring input of specific quantities of enzyme catalyst of known activity. The present study found that very high percentages (90% of original) of filter paper and carboxymethylcellulose hydrolyzing activities can be recovered from conventional spray dryers when operated at inlet air temperatures ranging from 90 to 180 degree C. The beta-glucosidase and beta-xylosidase activity recoveries were somewhat lower and were optimal at temperatures ranging from 120 to 150 degree C. However, the individual performance of the 12 enzyme preparations examined was quite preparation specific. An ultrasonic nozzle adaptation to the Yamato dryer demonstrated the overall feasibility of high energy atomization, inasmuch as the filter paper activity was retained after drying. The more labile beta-xylosidase activity was, however, entirely lost.
Index Keywords: BIOMASS - Saccharification; FOOD PRODUCTS - Storage; SPRAY GUNS - Applications; BETA-GLUCOSIDASE; BETA-XYLOSIDASE; CARBOXYMETHYLCELLULOSE HYDROLYZING ACTIVITIES; CELLULASE; SPRAY DRYING; ULTRASONIC NOZZLE ADAPTATION; ENZYMES

Authors: Aragon Jose M., Segarra Miguel A.
Title: SOLAR HEATING OF GRANULAR SOLIDS.
Affiliations: Univ Complutense de Madrid, Spain, Univ Complutense de Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Aragon, Jose M., Univ Complutense de Madrid, Spain, Univ Complutense de Madrid, Spain; Segarra, Miguel A., Univ Complutense de Madrid, Spain, Univ Complutense de Madrid, Spain
Abstract: Thermal storage can be carried out in the form of heat or latent heat. The disadvantages of latent heat system (contraction phenomena, toxicity of thermal fluid, corrosion and low-heat exchange velocity) are greater than the advantages and in most of the world the system is based on sensible heat. The models could be: two tank model, cold and hot sources, one tank model, with stratification of temperature, fluidized bed. Tank models have been evaluated sufficiently. Fluidized bed models are in the research phase and are discussed.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Fluidized Beds; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; FLUIDIZED BEDS HEAT STORAGE; GRANULAR SOLIDS; SOLAR HEATING; SOLAR RECEIVERS; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: AIR CORE SYSTEMS FOR PASSIVE AND HYBRID ENERGY-CONSERVING BUILDINGS.
Authors with affiliations: Howard, Bion D.
Abstract: This paper reviews generic hollow-core-masonry heat storage system (air-core) designs and discusses an analysis of the measured performance and calculated heat transfer coefficients in one such system. An overview of seasonal performance of the monitored building containing the system is provided. 'Air-core' is a generic term for energy storage systems employing the core voids of concrete masonry units as integral ductwork and heat transfer surface area to store energy indirectly via fan forcing of air. Common energy sources/sinks are collected solar heat, recycled internal generated heat, wood heat, naturally cooled outdoor air, and/or evaporatively cooled outdoor air, supplied under appropriately controlled conditions.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; BUILDING ANALYSIS METHODS; COST CONSTRAINTS; HEAT TRANSFER RATES; HOLLOW-CORE-MASONRY HEAT STORAGE SYSTEM; PASSIVE HEAT STORAGE; BUILDINGS

Title: DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS FOR STABILIZATION OF INACTIVE URANIUM MILL TAILINGS PILES.
Affiliations: Roy F. Weston Inc, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Roy F. Weston Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bone, Michael J., Roy F. Weston Inc, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Roy F. Weston Inc, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) oversees the Uranium Mill Tailings Remedial Action (UMTRA) Project. This involves remedial action work at 24 inactive uranium mill tailings piles in 10 states. The principal objective of the UMTRA Project is to provide engineering designs that ensure the long-term containment and stability requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) standards.
Index Keywords: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION - Standards; RADIOACTIVE WASTES - Storage; INACTIVE TAILINGS PILES; LONG-TERM CONTAINMENT; LONG-TERM STABILITY; US DOE; URANIUM ORE TREATMENT

Title: HIGH-TEMPERATURE DIRECT-CONTACT HEAT EXCHANGE.
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bohn, Mark S., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Abstract: A direct-contact heat exchanger can be used to economically transfer high-temperature heat from a liquid to a gas stream. As a solar thermal application this means that such a heat exchanger would allow using a liquid receiver, with its attendant low cost relative to a gas receiver, to deliver high-temperature gas to an end process. This paper briefly reviews previous economic and performance analyses of direct-contact heat exchange. A detailed heat transfer analysis is then presented in general terms, and results of this analysis are compared with experimental data available in the literature and some recent experimental results from the Solar Energy Research Institute on an air-molten carbonate salt system as would be used for a central receiver application.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; DIRECT HEAT EXCHANGER; DIRECT-CONTACT HEAT EXCHANGE; HIGH TEMPERATURE HEAT STORAGE; LOW TEMPERATURE LOSSES; HEAT EXCHANGERS

Title: GOLD ANALYSER: A TOOL FOR VALUATION AND A MEANS FOR IMPROVED MINING DECISIONS.
Affiliations: Chamber of Mines of South Africa, Research Organization, Chamber of Mines of South Africa Research Organization
Authors with affiliations: Stewart, J.M., Chamber of Mines of South Africa, Research Organization, Chamber of Mines of South Africa Research Organization; Nami, M., Chamber of Mines of South Africa, Research Organization, Chamber of Mines of South Africa Research Organization
Abstract: The erratic values of gold grade in Witwatersrand placer deposits necessitates the collection of large numbers of samples for accurate valuation and ore reserve estimation. Owing to manpower requirements current sampling techniques do not allow for the collection of sufficiently large numbers of samples. A portable gold analyser, which is at an advanced stage of development, is expected to alleviate this problem. It is a lightweight instrument, intended for one-man operation, and is based on energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence principles for determining gold and other mineral concentrations. The instrument is designed for in situ face scanning operations and provides a direct readout and internal storage of the measured gold concentration. The immediate availability of an estimate of gold grade should significantly improve the quality of short-term panel-scale mining decisions.
Index Keywords: GOLD AND ALLOYS - Analysis; GOLD ORE TREATMENT; INSTRUMENTS - Design; MINERALOGY - Analytical Methods; MINES AND MINING - Instruments; GOLD ANALYSER SCHEMATIC; GOLD DISTRIBUTION; WITWATERSRAND GOLD MINES, SOUTH AFRICA; GOLD MINES AND MINING

Authors: Oppel Fred J., Ghajar Afshin J., Moretti Peter M.
Title: NUMERICAL AND EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF STRATIFIED THERMAL STORAGE.
Authors with affiliations: Oppel, Fred J.; Ghajar, Afshin J.; Moretti, Peter M.
Abstract: A one-dimensional, implicit, finite-difference model of a single stratified thermal storage tank has been developed. The model covers variable flow rates for charging or discharging the thermal storage tank and conduction and turbulent mixing within the water for two different inlet configurations. In order to handle variable flow rates, a 'conceptual buffer tank' algorithm was developed. Turbulent mixing occuring in the tank was simulated through thermal eddy conductivity factors, which were determined from experimental data. A decreasing hyperbolic function predicted the best variation of the eddy conductivity factors inside the tank. A general relationship between the inlet eddy conductivity factor and the ratio of Reynolds number over Richardson number was established for the inlets investigated. The simulation model adequately predicted the experimental data. In addition, the model reproduced hydraulic test data better than a recent one-dimensional model found in the literature.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Difference Method; CONVECTION-ONLY MODEL; HYDRAULIC TEST DATA; INLET EDDY CONDUCTIVITY FACTOR; STRATIFIED THERMAL STORAGE; THERMAL ENERGY SYSTEMS; TURBULENT MIXING; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Barber Russell B., Jones Mark G.
Title: MANAGING A MOVING TARGET.
Affiliations: Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Barber, Russell B., Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Jones, Mark G., Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: The Formerly Utilized Sites Remedial Action Program (FUSRAP) is a project of the US Department of Energy (DOE), designed to clean up at selected sites which became contaminated during the 1940s and 1950s primarily as a result of processing and/or storage of natural uranium and thorium. Management problems related to FUSRAP are examined. It is difficult to manage FUSRAP because the scope of work to be performed is not well defined, the schedule is constantly changing, and the yearly budget uncertain. Practices and lessons learned during the first five years of the FUSRAP project are discussed. The use of the rigid cost schedule control system required by DOE for the project is also covered.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ENGINEERING - Project Management; DOE; FUSRAP PROJECT; US DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY; FIELD CONDITION CHANGES; FORMERLY UTILIZED SITES REMEDIAL ACTION PROGRAM (FUSRAP); FUNDING CHANGES; SCHEDULE CHANGES; TYPICAL PROJECT CHANGES; RADIOACTIVE WASTES; MANAGEMENT SCIENCE

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF A WASTE CONTAINMENT STRUCTURE FOR THE NIAGARA FALLS STORAGE SITE.
Affiliations: Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jones, M.G., Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Barber, R.B., Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy established the Niagara Falls Storage Site ner Lewiston, New York, for the short-term (interim) storage of low-level radioactive wastes and residues. This paper describes the development of a containment structure for the waste materials and residues. Also described is the monitoring system that will be used to measure the performance of the containment structure. The interim containment structure can be modified to accommodate the waste materials for an effective design life of 200 to 1,000 years, thus serving as a long-term disposal facility. The means to be used for ultimate disposition of the waste will be announced in the Department of Energy's Record of Decision, which is the culmination of the National Environmental Policy Act process conducted prior to the implementation of any federal action that could have a significant impact on the environment.
Index Keywords: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION - Legislation; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS - New York; LOW LEVEL WASTES; NIAGARA FALLS; WASTE CONTAINMENT STRUCTURE; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: APPLICATION OF LOW INTERSTITIAL CONTENT COLUMBIUM TO RADIO FREQUENCY SUPERCONDUCTING ACCELERATOR DEVICES.
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Padamsee, H., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA
Abstract: Since the 1984 Electron Beam Melting Conference, there has been considerable utilization of columbium specially prepared to fulfill the critical high purity requirements of superconducting radio-frequency technology for application to particle accelerators in the U. S. , Europe and Japan. Progress in further improving the purity of multiple electron beam melted columbium has also been registered. This review will discuss both advances in quality and applications of high purity columbium.

Authors: Neeper Donald A., Hedstrom James C.
Title: SELF-PUMPING VAPOR SYSTEM FOR HYBRID SPACE HEATING.
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Neeper, Donald A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA; Hedstrom, James C., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Abstract: This paper reports investigations of a passive system that transports heat from a solar collector downward. Refrigerant is evaporated in a collector and the vapor transports heat to one or more condensers located at an arbitrary elevation below the collector. The vapor pressure lifts the condensed liquid to an accumulator located near the top of the collector. The results of annual performance calculations are presented for a space heating application in which one or more condensers are located within passive thermal storage units that release heat directly to one or more zones of the building. Simple sizing rules for optimal energy yield are given.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; HEAT TRANSFER; HEATING - Solar; REFRIGERANTS; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; R-11; TRICHLOROMONO FLUOROMETHANE; VAPOR TRANSPORT; BUILDINGS

Title: INVESTIGATION OF A NEW TYPE OF RECHARGEABLE BATTERY, THE NICKEL-HYDRIDE CELL.
Affiliations: Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth, Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Willems, J.J.G., Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth, Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth
Abstract: LaNi//5 and related compounds have been investigated for their usefulness as electrode material in hydrogen-based rechargeable batteries. Although LaNi//5 and LaNi//4Cu give the required rapid absorption and desorption of large amounts of hydrogen, they are not suitable because of the large decay in their storage capacity with repeated charging and discharging. It was found that this capacity loss is due to the conversion of the active material into La(OH)//3, which proceeds more rapidly as the volume changes in the active material caused by repeated charging and discharging become larger. Partial substitution of Co for Ni gives smaller volume changes and hence a more stable electrode material. The stability is further improved by adding small quantities of aluminum or silicon. The capacity of electrodes made from the newly developed La//0//. //8Nd//0//. //2Ni//2//. //5Co//2//. //4Si//0//. //1 was found to have decayed by only 30% after 1000 charge and discharge cycles. The experimental - hermetically sealed - nickel-hydride battery made with this material combines a long life with high energy density and power density, and effective protection from overcharging and overcharging. It also contains no toxic heavy metals such as cadmium.
Index Keywords: ELECTRODES; NICKEL COMPOUNDS; HIGH-RATE CHARGE AND DISCHARGE; NICKEL-HYDRIDE CELL; RECHARGEABLE BATTERY; STABLE ELECTRODE MATERIAL; THOUSAND CYCLES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: COOLING THERMAL STORAGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Energy Seminar
Affiliations: Pennsylvania Electric Co, Johnstown,, PA, USA, Pennsylvania Electric Co, Johnstown, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tremel, Charles L., Pennsylvania Electric Co, Johnstown,, PA, USA, Pennsylvania Electric Co, Johnstown, PA, USA
Abstract: The subject of this discussion is Cooling Thermal Storage. Author has presented here the opportunities for storage of cooling energy for comfort cooling of commercial buildings. These systems involve mainly two storage mediums - chilled water and ice. In the future, cooling thermal storage is going to be a big force in the heating, ventilating and air conditioning (HVAC) industry; and on a lot of projects it already is. Author explains why thermal storage is important, especially focusing on the utilities point of view, some of the system and building design considerations, current methods and equipment used, a short discussion of the cost impact on the HVAC system, and a little of where he thinks thermal storage is headed.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Thermal Load; COMPRESSORS - Applications; ELECTRIC POWER UTILIZATION - Costs; REFRIGERATION - Equipment; BLOCK COOLING LOAD; CHILLED WATER SYSTEMS; COOLING THERMAL STORAGE; MORNING COOL-DOWN PERIOD; PENELEC RATES; RECIPROCATING COMPRESSOR; BUILDINGS

Abstract: For high temperature storage application, proven components of industrial plants exist. In principle they can also be used for solar thermal systems. The design and the proven engineering have to be adapted to the special solar conditions. Moreover there is the possibility of improving the system performance using advanced storage material. The scale up to commercial storage systems is discussed with reference to a 100 KWh high temperature storage test facility, and to a 1 MWh pilot storage experimental unit.

Authors: Gertz C.P., Schoonen D.H., Wakeman B.H.
Title: SPENT FUEL STORAGE AND TRANSPORTATION EXPERIENCE FOR THE IDAHO NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY.
Affiliations: DOE Idaho, ID, USA, DOE Idaho, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gertz, C.P., DOE Idaho, ID, USA, DOE Idaho, ID, USA; Schoonen, D.H., DOE Idaho, ID, USA, DOE Idaho, ID, USA; Wakeman, B.H., DOE Idaho, ID, USA, DOE Idaho, ID, USA
Abstract: Spent fuel research and development demonstrations and associated transportation activities are being performed for DOE's Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM) as a part of the storage cask performance testing programs at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL). These spentfuel programs support the Nuclear Waste Policy Act (NWPA) and Department of Energy objectives for cooperative demonstrations with the utilities, testing at Federal sites, and alternatives for viable transportation systems. The shipment of spent fuel to the INEL from the Surry Power Station and the Nevada Test Site required shipping plans and coordination between DOE, EG&G Idaho, and Virginia Power transportation personnel, as well as extensive communication with the corridor states.

Authors: Chen J.D., Beeley P.A., Taylor R., Hartrick D.G., Pshyshlak N.L., Wasywich K.M., Rochon A., Burns K.I., Frost C.R.
Title: CHARACTERIZATION OF CORROSION DEPOSITS AND THE ASSESSMENT OF FISSION PRODUCTS RELEASED FROM USED CANDU FUEL.
Affiliations: AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can
Authors with affiliations: Chen, J.D., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Beeley, P.A., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Taylor, R., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Hartrick, D.G., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Pshyshlak, N.L., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Wasywich, K.M., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Rochon, A., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Burns, K.I., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Frost, C.R., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can
Abstract: Experiments were carried out to characterize corrosion deposits on used CANDU fuel and to study the release of fission products from intact and intentionally defected fuel bundles stored in air saturated with water vapour. This work is part of a joint Ontario Hydro/Atomic Energy of Canada Limited program to study the long-term behaviour of used CANDU fuel bundles stored in dry and moist air at 150 degree C. Results from the analysis of acid leachates from the sheath of nineteen Pickering and Bruce fuel elements show that the main inactive corrosion product was iron and the major radioisotopes were cesium-137 and strontium-90. Analysis of the water used to provide a moist environment in the stored fuel showed that fission products were leached from the defected fuels and that the major fission product was cesium-137.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR FUELS - Fission; WASTE DISPOSAL - Environmental Impact; WASTE DISPOSAL - Moisture Control; DEFECTED FUEL BUNDLES; DRY/MOIST STORAGE; USED CANDU FUEL; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: DESIGN GUIDE FOR UNDERGROUND HEAT STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: McGill Univ, Ste. Anne de Bellevue,, Que, Can, McGill Univ, Ste. Anne de Bellevue, Que, Can
Authors with affiliations: Coffin, W., McGill Univ, Ste. Anne de Bellevue,, Que, Can, McGill Univ, Ste. Anne de Bellevue, Que, Can; Alward, R., McGill Univ, Ste. Anne de Bellevue,, Que, Can, McGill Univ, Ste. Anne de Bellevue, Que, Can
Abstract: A design guide has been written to assist in the design and construction of underground heat storage systems consisting of an array of air ducts buried horizontally in the soil beneath a greenhouse or floor slab. Recommendations are presented on the design of the various components of these storage systems. Perforated corrugated plastic drainage pipe, 10 cm in diameter, are used as the air ducts. The required length, spacing, depth of placement and number of ducts in a storage system can be estimated from given information. Airflow rate, pressure losses and fan sizing can also be calculated. Construction details and suggestions are given on the layout and installation of these storage systems in new or retrofit situations. Economic aspects, such as construction costs and potential benefits, are also discussed.
Index Keywords: GREENHOUSES - Heating; HEAT EXCHANGERS - Design; HEAT TRANSFER - Underground; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; AIR DUCTS; FLOOR SLAB; SOLAR HEAT STORAGE SYSTEMS; UNDERGROUND HEAT STORAGE SYSTEMS; HEATING

Authors: Kirk James A., Anand Davinder K., Vieira Roger, Jayaraman Chaitanya P.
Title: MODELING AND SIMULATION OF MAGNETIC BEARING FORCES.
Source title: Modeling and Simulation, Proceedings of the Annual Pittsburgh Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD,, USA, Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kirk, James A., Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD,, USA, Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA; Anand, Davinder K., Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD,, USA, Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA; Vieira, Roger, Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD,, USA, Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA; Jayaraman, Chaitanya P., Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD,, USA, Univ of Maryland, College Park, MD, USA
Abstract: Magnetic bearings are attractive for space as well as many other applications since they are capable of long life due to the noncontacting nature of the bearing. Also, they represent excellent choices for energy storage due to the possibility of very high efficiency excursions of input/output power. This feature becomes particularly attractive when coupled with attitude control systems for low earth orbit applications. The analysis reported in this paper, although general, was performed in support of the 'sandwich' configuration magnetically suspended flywheel system currently under development by researchers from the University of Maryland and the Goddard Space Flight Center. The flywheel has its radial dynamics controlled by the magnetic suspension which is biased by four symmetrically located samarium-cobalt permanent magnets and by control windings which compensate the displacement of the flywheel relative to its centered position. To each pair of radially aligned permanent magnets corresponds a closed loop feedback control system which provides active control in each orthogonal direction. In this paper, the magentic forces used for stabilizing the rotor are modeled and validated with exprimental data. The analytical approach in modeling of the magentic forces depends upon the evaluation of the path permeance and operating point of the magnet itself. Several methods, including the Schwartz-Christofell approach of mapping the magnetic field are used to evaluate the magnetic force.
Index Keywords: AEROSPACE ENGINEERING; ELECTRIC TRACTION - Flywheel Propulsion; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELD EFFECTS; ELECTROMAGNETS; MAGNETS; CONFORMAL MAPPING; MAGNETIC BEARING FORCES SIMULATION; MAGNETICALLY SUSPENDED FLYWHEEL SYSTEM; PERMEANCE ANALYSIS; BEARINGS

Title: SAVING ENERGY AND MONEY BY CHILLED WATER STORAGE.
Affiliations: Univ Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belg, Univ Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belg
Authors with affiliations: Roba, H.A., Univ Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belg, Univ Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belg; Noel, G., Univ Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belg, Univ Libre de Bruxelles, Brussels, Belg
Abstract: At the head-office (83,000 m2) of an important insurance company, an expansion area of 42,000 m2 will be added in view, among others, to transfer the renewed computer area. The total peak cooling load of the existing building (3. 6 MW) and of the new building (2. 7 MW) is 6,3 MW. At the existing cooling plant (3 multiplied by 1. 9 MW centrifugal), a new cooling plant (2 multiplied by 0. 65 MW reciprocal) and a chilled water storage of 1. 500 m3 with floating membrane will be added. It is intended to run some chillers during the night. The saving of energy results from the good efficiency of the chillers working at their nominal capacity with good condensing conditions. Money is saved in investment due to lower chiller capacity and in running costs due to lower electrical night tariffs.
Index Keywords: CHILLED WATER STORAGE; COOLING LOAD; ELECTRICITY COSTS; ENERGY SAVINGS; AIR CONDITIONING - Economics; ENERGY CONSERVATION; REFRIGERATION; WATER - Storage; BUILDINGS

Affiliations: Fichtner USA Inc, Fichtner USA Inc
Authors with affiliations: Fichtner, K., Fichtner USA Inc, Fichtner USA Inc; Warde, Ch., Fichtner USA Inc, Fichtner USA Inc
Abstract: The principle of the zinc-chloride couple is well known. Energy Development Associates of Greensboro, North Carolina (EDA) have, in over a decade of research and development, utilized this principle for practical electrical energy storage system applications and have successfully established the feasibility of zinc-chloride batteries for load-leveling, electric vehicles and some other specially applications.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; ENERGY STORAGE; BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE TEST (BEST) FACILITY; FLEXPOWER BATTERY; ZINC-CHLORIDE BATTERY TECHNOLOGY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Boom R.W., Eyssa Y.M., Huang Y., McIntosh G.E.
Title: TWO-LAYER NON-RIPPLED SUPERCONDUCTIVE MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Source title: Proceedings of the International Cryogenic Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Boom, R.W., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA; Eyssa, Y.M., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA; Huang, Y., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA; McIntosh, G.E., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: Two layer superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) solenoid designs are developed for non-rippled coils. The unique advantage of He II cooling for a two-layer coil, as developed for rippled solenoids, is now extended to non-rippled coils. Steady state and transient He II heat transfer of 2 W/cm**2 is indicated for a non-rippled representative design. The structure is simple telescopic segments which slide on each other to reduce cooldown stresses. A 10 minute emergency total energy dump, as actuated with shorting switches and a 5 second helium dump, is included; the switching possibility is another unique advantage of two-layer designs.
Index Keywords: CRYOGENICS; HELIUM; SOLENOIDS; SUPERCONDUCTIVE MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Title: PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER SYSTEM INTERCONNECTED WITH UTILITY.
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Authors with affiliations: Tsukamoto, Kazuyoshi; Tanaka, Kuniho
Abstract: SANYO Electric Company established a 2-kW residential photovoltaic power system in Osaka Prefecture in 1981, and has been operating it through interconnection with a single-phase, 100-V, 60-Hz utility grid since that time. Based on the results of this operation, in this report we explain the system control technology, protection systems, and operation characteristics, and evaluate the energy and cost factors of two different systems: a switching type interconnection system using power storage equipment, and a parallel running interconnection system which operates in parallel with the utility grid without using power storage equipment.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; INTERCONNECTION SYSTEMS; OPERATION CHARACTERISTICS; PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER SYSTEM; PROTECTION SYSTEMS; SANYO ELECTRIC COMPANY; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Barnard J.W., Cameron D.J., Charlewood R.G.
Title: WORKPLACE DECONTAMINATION AND TEMPORARY STORAGE OF RADIOACTIVE SOILS AT A SMALL INDUSTRIAL SITE.
Affiliations: AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can
Authors with affiliations: Barnard, J.W., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Cameron, D.J., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Charlewood, R.G., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can
Abstract: The operation of a small niobium smelter during the early seventies resulted in contamination of an industrial property in Surrey, British Columbia with low-level radioactive waste. In the summer of 1985, the Low-Level Radioactive Waste Management Office of Atomic Energy of Canada Limited decontaminated the work areas of the site by excavating contaminated soils from under and around buildings. Excavated soils were placed in temporary containment, on site, to await final disposal. The project required considerable preplanning in the design stages to minimize the environmental impact of the work and to ensure the radiological safety of the public and workers. Monitoring during the project showed that no contamination was spread from the site during the operation, that workers on the project received no measurable internal dose, and that the maximum external dose to a worker, attributable to the project, was 0. 1 mSv. Additional aspects of the subject are discussed.
Index Keywords: INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Treatment; NIOBIUM ORE TREATMENT - Smelting; RADIOACTIVE WASTES; MONITORING; RADIOACTIVE SOILS; RADIOLOGICAL SAFETY; TEMPORARY STORAGE; WORKPLACE DECONTAMINATION; SOIL POLLUTION

Title: HIGH TEMPERATURE STORAGE FOR SOLAR THERMAL APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: DFVLR, West Ger, DFVLR, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Tamme, R., DFVLR, West Ger, DFVLR, West Ger; Geyer, M., DFVLR, West Ger, DFVLR, West Ger
Abstract: The use of volumetric and advanced direct absorption receivers operating at ambient pressure require a storage system which can accomplish the purpose of thermal storage and of pressure transformation. For buffer storage and overnight storage this complex function can be solved by a storage/regenerator system. For this, solid ceramics and the advanced high temperature salt/ceramic materials - HITESC - can be used as storage media. The potential of chemical heat storage (CHS) is the realization of low-loss high energy density storage systems. Therefore, the application of CHS to long term storage and to the formation of solar thermal fuels seems to be possible. The use of CHS systems includes a closed cycle of the storage material in contrast to a fuel characterized by an open cycle. This has significant consequences to the technical feasible storage density of CHS systems.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; CHEMICAL HEAT STORAGE; DIRECT ABSORPTION RECEIVERS; HIGH TEMPERATURE STORAGE; SOLAR THERMAL APPLICATIONS; SOLAR RADIATION

Authors: Sethu Madhavan R., Amit Kumar, Yardi N.R.
Title: DESIGN, INSTALLATION & PERFORMANCE OF A 10 TR SOLAR POWERED COLD STORAGE IN INDIA.
Affiliations: Jyoti Ltd, Baroda, India, Jyoti Ltd, Baroda, India
Authors with affiliations: Sethu Madhavan, R., Jyoti Ltd, Baroda, India, Jyoti Ltd, Baroda, India; Amit Kumar, Jyoti Ltd, Baroda, India, Jyoti Ltd, Baroda, India; Yardi, N.R., Jyoti Ltd, Baroda, India, Jyoti Ltd, Baroda, India
Abstract: A 10 TR Solar Powered Potato Cold Storage has been installed in a remote village near Baroda, to study its technical feasibility and performance. Solar System, having 152 selectively coated flat plate collectors (nominal area 304 sq. mtr. ) supply hot water at 95 degree C to the aqua-ammonia vapour absorption refrigeration system. The cold storage chamber is designed for storing 75 tons of potatoes at 4 degree C. A part of chamber is made underground and some collectors are placed on its roof - both for reducing the heat gain. A novel 'Product Storage Concept' is tried to store the cooling effect over the non-sunshine hours. The plant has been operated under no-load conditions as well as on fully loaded conditions. The desired storage temperature of 4 degree C could be achieved and maintained throughout the operation period.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS - Cold Storage; REFRIGERANTS - Ammonia; REFRIGERATING MACHINERY - Absorption; SOLAR ENERGY - India; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; FLAT PLATE COLLECTORS; POTATOES; SOLAR POWERED COLD STORAGE; REFRIGERATION

Authors: Morhenna J., Fiebig M., Leipertz A., Leiner W.
Title: LARGE SCALE SOLAR ASSISTED TOBACCO CURING EXPERIENCES AND POTENTIAL.
Affiliations: Ruhr-Univ Bochum, Bochum, West Ger, Ruhr-Univ Bochum, Bochum, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Morhenna, J., Ruhr-Univ Bochum, Bochum, West Ger, Ruhr-Univ Bochum, Bochum, West Ger; Fiebig, M., Ruhr-Univ Bochum, Bochum, West Ger, Ruhr-Univ Bochum, Bochum, West Ger; Leipertz, A., Ruhr-Univ Bochum, Bochum, West Ger, Ruhr-Univ Bochum, Bochum, West Ger; Leiner, W., Ruhr-Univ Bochum, Bochum, West Ger, Ruhr-Univ Bochum, Bochum, West Ger
Abstract: The performance of a 20 ton solar assisted tobacco curing plant was investigated during the drying season of the last 3 years. The solar fraction achieved was measured to be only 35% for good weather conditions because of large leakage losses in the collector field, pebble storage, and dryers By changing the basic curing process within the limits set by quality assurance the solar fraction can be increased to 50%. The results for low and high temperature cycles and combinations are given.
Index Keywords: DRYING - Optimization; SOLAR ENERGY - Agricultural Applications; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; TOBACCO - Drying; FLUE CURED TOBACCO; SOLAR AIR HEATING; SOLAR ASSISTED DRYING; TOBACCO CURING PLANT; DRYERS

Title: UTILIZATION OF INTERNAL HEAT GAINS.
Authors with affiliations: Barakat, S.A.; Sander, D.M.
Abstract: Utilization factors for internal heat gains have been derived from an hour-by-hour computer simulation using actual weather data for 11 Canadian locations. These utilization factors are expressed as a function of the ratio of seasonal total internal gains to seasonal total reference loss for three daily profiles of internal gains and four levels of thermal storage. Curves are presented for conditions of constant room temperature and for allowable temperature rises. For houses with a ratio of internal gains to reference heat loss of less than 0. 4, all internal gains can be utilized to offset thermal losses. In addition, the application of the utilization factor method is extended to calculation of heating energy requirements of other buildings such as apartments, schools, and offices.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; SOLAR RADIATION - Absorption; CANADIAN LOCATIONS; DAILY PROFILES; UTILIZATION FACTOR METHOD; BUILDINGS

Title: THERMOCHEMICAL HYDROGEN PRODUCTION WITH SOLAR HEAT.
Affiliations: RWTH, Aachen, West Ger, RWTH, Aachen, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Knoche, K.F., RWTH, Aachen, West Ger, RWTH, Aachen, West Ger
Abstract: High temperature solar heat sources are very convenient for thermochemical hydrogen production. Though concentration of solar radiation would allow for very high temperatures, the constraint of heat exchanger and other construction materials limit the maximum operation temperature to below 1000 degree C. Thermochemical cycles are attractive for solar hydrogen production, because they allow for an almost optimal adaption of the chemical plant to the solar energy input. Chemical storage is part of the cycle and allows for reasonable storage capacity.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Thermal Effects; SOLAR ENERGY - Industrial Applications; CHEMICAL STORAGE; SOLAR HEAT; THERMOCHEMICAL CYCLES; THERMOCHEMICAL HYDROGEN PRODUCTION; HYDROGEN

Title: OPENSOL: A Dimensional Optimization Software and One for the Control of Complex Heating Systems including Long-term Heat Storage.
Affiliations: Ecole Natl Superieure des Mines de, Paris, Fontainebleau, Fr, Ecole Natl Superieure des Mines de Paris, Fontainebleau, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Lenoir, Y., Ecole Natl Superieure des Mines de, Paris, Fontainebleau, Fr, Ecole Natl Superieure des Mines de Paris, Fontainebleau, Fr; Sneed, C., Ecole Natl Superieure des Mines de, Paris, Fontainebleau, Fr, Ecole Natl Superieure des Mines de Paris, Fontainebleau, Fr
Abstract: OPENSOL is a collection of programs and card indices designed for optimizing heating systems particularly those endowed with interseasonal heat storage. It consists of a pre-existing program OPENSYS and three programs OPENDIM, OPENCOM, and OPENSIM, serving respectively in the areas of dimensional optimization, control, and simulation. Simulation has shown that, at given dimensions, optimal control reduces from 20 to 40%, according to the season, commercial energy consumption relative to traditional regulation.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING - Solar; INTERSEASONAL HEAT STORAGE; OPENCOM; OPENDIM; OPENSIM; OPENSOL; OPENSYS; COMPUTER SOFTWARE

Title: IMPROVEMENT OF THE ENERGY CHARACTERISTICS OF CONSTANT VOLTAGE IMPULSE SUPPLY SYSTEMS FOR IMPULSE LOADS.
Authors with affiliations: Dodotchenko, V.V.; Nikolaev, A.G.
Abstract: The properties of a vacuum-arc break switch to change its own resistance on variation of the magnetic induction produced by its magnetic control coil are used as a basis to develop a method for a high-power impulse load to be supplied with practically constant current on discharge of charged capacitive store into the load through a high-power magnetically controlled nonlinear resistance. For an analytically established ratio of the constant load voltage to the initial store voltage equal to 0. 5, a coefficient for store mass redundancy by the proposed method is less than that in the known case of impulse load supply with practically constant current from a charged impulse forming line by a factor of at least 1. 1-2.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; CONSTANT VOLTAGE IMPULSE SUPPLY SYSTEMS; IMPULSE LOAD; VACUUM-ARC BREAK SWITCH; ELECTRIC SWITCHES

Title: Correlations for the Dimensioning of Latent Heat Storage Panels.
Affiliations: CNRS, Orsay, Fr, CNRS, Orsay, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Gobin, D., CNRS, Orsay, Fr, CNRS, Orsay, Fr; Zanoli, A., CNRS, Orsay, Fr, CNRS, Orsay, Fr
Abstract: Latent heat storage in passive solar panels is of great practical importance. It has been intensively studied in numerous experiments and field tests. However the dimensioning of such panel elements and the modeling of the thermal behavior of phase-changing materials (PCM) have not been considered. This work presents a set of correlations that describe the melting kinetics for PCMs. These correlations have been derived from a simplified description of liquid-phase natural convection. The derivation is based on numerical modeling and precise experimental data.

Title: PREDICTIVE CONTROL OF SEWAGE PUMPS.
Affiliations: Monash Univ, Clayton, Aust, Monash Univ, Clayton, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Tan, P.C., Monash Univ, Clayton, Aust, Monash Univ, Clayton, Aust; Dabke, K.P., Monash Univ, Clayton, Aust, Monash Univ, Clayton, Aust
Abstract: A predictive control strategy is worked out to minimize the pumping costs at a proposed sewage pumping station. A simple model, identified from the exact solution, is used to predict the hydraulic conditions so that the operational constraints are satisfied. Simulations indicate that this pumping strategy, using the storage capacity in the sewer, may lead to considerable savings in energy costs.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS, PREDICTIVE - Applications; ENERGY CONSERVATION; HYDRAULICS; PUMPING PLANTS - Costs; COST MINIMIZATION; OPERATIONAL CONSTRAINTS; PUMPING COSTS; SEWAGE PUMPING PLANTS

Title: DESIGN CONCEPTS AND PERFORMANCE EVALUATION OF A NEW SOLAR SPACE HEATING SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Univ of Melbourne, Aust, Univ of Melbourne, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Chandra, S., Univ of Melbourne, Aust, Univ of Melbourne, Aust
Abstract: A system will be more cost effective if 1) heating and cooling both are provided by the same system, and 2) the components of the building structure itself are utilized to their best advantage to reduce its heating and cooling loads to a minimum. The latter passive concept incorporates solar collection and storage into the building structure and distributes energy by natural means. A hybrid solar heating concept comprising a heat pump system integrated with a Trombe wall (or mass storage wall) is proposed for the present work. A computer model has been developed to evaluate the thermal performance of this combined Trombe wall and heat pump system under Melbourne winter conditions. A fully transient analysis of any heat pump must involve unsteady two phase flow with boiling heat transfer and is not attempted here.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Solar, Passive; COMPUTER SOFTWARE; EVAPORATORS; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Difference Method; HYBRID SOLAR HEATING CONCEPT; MASS STORAGE WALL; TROMBE WALL; HEATING

Title: TECHNICAL AND ECONOMIC FEASIBILITY OF CENTRAL SOLAR HEATING PLANTS WITH SEASONAL STORAGE.
Affiliations: Charles A. Bankston Inc, Washington,, DC, USA, Charles A. Bankston Inc, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bankston, Charles A., Charles A. Bankston Inc, Washington,, DC, USA, Charles A. Bankston Inc, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: A unified analysis and parametric study of central solar heating plants with seasonal storage (CSHPSS) Systems has recently been completed by the participants in the International Energy Agency (IEA) Solar Heating and Cooling Programs Task VII. The study culminated nearly three years of information collection, evaluation, preliminary design and analysis, and system simulation. It included systems with stationary and tracking collector arrays; water tank, rock cavern, water pit, drilled earth and rock fields, and natural aquifers storage subsystems; heat pump and direct coupled loads, and loads representing 50 to 5000 residential units with domestic hot water fractions ranging from 0 to 50%. Each configuration was indenpendently optimized using the Swedish/IEA-developed computer code MINSUN. Results of the unified study indicate that a number of CSHPSS configurations are economically competitive with conventional plants now are clearly economically superior to diurnal solar systems.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER AIDED ANALYSIS; COMPUTER SOFTWARE; ECONOMICS; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; WATER HEATERS - Solar; CENTRAL SOLAR HEATING PLANTS; CSHPSS; INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY (IEA); MINSUN CODE; SEASONAL STORAGE; SOLAR HEATING AND COOLING PROGRAMS TASK VII; BUILDINGS

Title: ON THE APPLICATION OF FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS TO THE OPTIMIZATION OF THE PRODUCTION OF HYDROELECTRIC POWER.
Affiliations: Univ of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta,, Can, Univ of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Can
Authors with affiliations: Christensen, G.S., Univ of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta,, Can, Univ of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Can; Soliman, S.A., Univ of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta,, Can, Univ of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Can
Abstract: This paper presents a new approach used for solving the optimal long-term problem of a hydro power system for maximum expected benefits (benefits from energy generated by a hydro power system over the planning period plus the expected future returns from water left in storage at the end of that period). The problem is formulated as a minimum norm problem in the framework of functional analytic optimization technique. The proposed method takes into account the stochasticity of the water inflows; we assume that their probability properties are pre-estimated from past history. Numerical results are presented for a real system in operation consisting of three rivers; each river has two series reservoirs. The computing time using this approach is small compared to that of other approaches.
Index Keywords: RESERVOIRS; COMPUTING TIME; FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER; MINIMUM NORM PROBLEM; SERIES RESERVOIRS; WATER INFLOWS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: OPERATION OF A PUSHER TYPE ALUMINUM INGOT HOMOGENIZING FURNACE.
Affiliations: Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corp, Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corp
Authors with affiliations: Perrin, Michael E., Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corp, Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corp
Abstract: As part of a 230 million dollar modernization program, Kaiser Aluminum's Trentwood rolling mill recently installed a pusher-type homogenizing and preheat furnace to handle its large electromagnetic cast ingots. The furnace box is approximately 90' L multiplied by 28' W multiplied by 19' H and is designed to hold 32 ingots weighing 40,000 pounds each. The furnace is direct-fired with natural gas at a maximum rate of 63,500 SCFH (approximately 65 multiplied by 10**6 BTU/Hr. ) Extensive material handling equipment at both the entry and exit provide for direct lay-on of the ingot to the hot line with simultaneous load and unload of the furnace. In addition to automatic ingot squaring and centering, the entry equipment provides dynamic storage of five ingots as an operational buffer for ingot delivery. Furnace operation and material handling cycles are completely automatic. The heating practice for each load is downloaded to the furnace control system from a supervisory computer.
Index Keywords: ALUMINUM FOUNDRY PRACTICE - Castings; ALUMINUM PLANTS - Energy Conservation; FURNACES - Control Systems; MATERIALS HANDLING; ALUMINUM INGOT HOMOGENIZING FURNACE; AUTOMATIC INGOT SQUARING; INGOT HANDLING AUTOMATION; FURNACES, HEATING

Authors: Eggert H., Grieger G., Kopplin H., Lipken H.
Title: OPERATING TECHNOLOGY FOR SF//6 PUFFER-BREAKERS. DEVELOPMENT, PRODUCTION AND SERVICE EXPERIENCE.
Source title: International Conference on Large High Voltage Electric Systems
Affiliations: Siemens AG, Berlin, West Ger, Siemens AG, Berlin, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Eggert, H., Siemens AG, Berlin, West Ger, Siemens AG, Berlin, West Ger; Grieger, G., Siemens AG, Berlin, West Ger, Siemens AG, Berlin, West Ger; Kopplin, H., Siemens AG, Berlin, West Ger, Siemens AG, Berlin, West Ger; Lipken, H., Siemens AG, Berlin, West Ger, Siemens AG, Berlin, West Ger
Abstract: The trend of operating technology for SF//6-circuit-breakers is characterized by fulfilling demands such as: increased need of energy for the puffer principle, drive systems for versatile duties and short operating times, and drive systems with high operating reliability and low maintenance costs. As these demands are covered by electrohydraulic drive systems most manufacturers prefer this technology, but also motor-spring storage drives and pneumatic drives are further developed and fulfill essentially most of these requirements. Design and development are supported by advanced calculation methods to optimize the drive system itself and the interactions in the breaker between interrupter-unit and drive. These calculation methods led to reduced cost and time in research and development.
Index Keywords: ELECTROHYDRAULIC OPERATING SYSTEM; INTERRUPTER-UNIT; LOW MAINTENANCE COSTS; PUFFER-BREAKERS; ELECTRIC CIRCUIT BREAKERS

Authors: Loire R., Dunn B., Werth J.
Title: ROPE-STRETCHING ICEBERG ARRESTOR.
Affiliations: Morrison-Knudsen Engineers Inc, San, Francisco, CA, USA, Morrison-Knudsen Engineers Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Loire, R., Morrison-Knudsen Engineers Inc, San, Francisco, CA, USA, Morrison-Knudsen Engineers Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA; Dunn, B., Morrison-Knudsen Engineers Inc, San, Francisco, CA, USA, Morrison-Knudsen Engineers Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA; Werth, J., Morrison-Knudsen Engineers Inc, San, Francisco, CA, USA, Morrison-Knudsen Engineers Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA
Abstract: It is currently planned to produce oil from offshore fields at the Grand Banks east of Newfoundland. Designers of the drilling, production, storage, loading platforms to be commissioned there in a few years time are confronted with the problem of dealing with sizeable vagabond icebergs that occasionally drift southward across the area. They are a threat to navigation and to oil platforms. Two alternate approaches are presently contemplated by the oil companies to ensure survival of production facilities in such 'Iceberg Alleys': Perform development drilling from floating rigs of the semi-submersible kind and produce oil from a FPSO (Floating Production-Storage-Offloading) platform. Use concrete gravity-founded structures (BBS) similar to those operated in the North Sea, but designed to remain unharmed whenever impacted by a berg.
Index Keywords: PRODUCTION PLATFORMS - Protection; STRUCTURAL DESIGN - Impact Resistance; COMPLIANT FENDERING SYSTEM; FLOATING PRODUCTION SYSTEMS; ICEBERG ARRESTOR DESIGN; ICEBERG KINETIC ENERGY; OFFSHORE STRUCTURES

Title: THERMAL MEASUREMENT AND PERFORMANCE OF A SUBMERGED-PHASE CHANGE MATERIAL HEAT EXCHANGER.
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at San Antonio, San, Antonio, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at San Antonio, San Antonio, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Eftekhar, Jahan, Univ of Texas at San Antonio, San, Antonio, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at San Antonio, San Antonio, TX, USA
Abstract: Thermal performance characteristics of a submerged-phase change material heat exchanger using paraffin wax is reported. Two models are introduced which describe the thermal behavior of thermal storage subsystem powered by a liquid type heat transfer fluid. The overall thermal response and effectiveness of this kind of storage system as a function of both coil flow rate and temperature difference between inlet water and tank bulk temperature are presented. This information is useful in designing submerged-PCM heat exchangers for solar or waste heat energy storage units.

Title: High vacuum sputter roll coating. A new large-scale manufacturing technology for transparent conductive ITO layers
Source title: Proceedings, Annual Technical Conference - Society of Vacuum Coaters
Affiliations: Leybold-Heraeus
Authors with affiliations: Mayr, Max, Leybold-Heraeus
Abstract: Energy conservation, information storage, electrophotography, electromagnetic radiation shielding and display technology are only a few of several specific market segments producing a tremendous increase in use of transparent, electrically conductive thin film layers in the near future. Many of these applications are now starting to use plastic film coated with transparent conductive layers. The transparent semiconductor Indium-Tin-Oxide with its high transmission for visible light, its high electrical conductivity and its strong plasma reflection in the near infrared is one of the most common transparent conductive materials. In this paper, some basic physical properties of the material are described, using simplified descriptions for basic understanding. The problems of large scale manufacturing, the general layout of newly developed roll coaters and typical properties of layers produced with large sputter roll coaters are discussed.
Index Keywords: Crystals--Structure; Optical Coatings; Sputtering; Indium Tin Oxide; Large Scale Manufacturing; Sputter Roll Coating; Semiconducting Indium Compounds

Title: 1986 ANNUAL CONFERENCE ON NUCLEAR AND SPACE RADIATION EFFECTS.
Abstract: The following topics are dealt with: basic mechanisms of radiation effects, dosimetry and energy-dependent effects; hardness assurance; silicon-on-insulator/silicon-on-silicon radiation effects; spacecraft charging and space radiation effects; device radiation effects and hardening; integrated circuit radiation effects and hardening; single-event upset phenomena and hardening; electromagnetic penetration phenomena; dose failure and dose rate measurements. 97 papers were presented, all of which are published in full in the present proceedings.

Title: BLOWDOWN WATER CANNON: A NOVEL METHOD FOR POWERING THE CUMULATION NOZZLE.
Source title: Papers Presented at the International Symposium on Jet Cutting Technology
Affiliations: Briggs Technology Inc, Pittsburgh,, PA, USA, Briggs Technology Inc, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pater, Larry L., Briggs Technology Inc, Pittsburgh,, PA, USA, Briggs Technology Inc, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Abstract: A method of providing energetic slugs of water to the cumulation nozzle, to produce a hypervelocity pulsed jet, is described. The method has been successfully demonstrated experimentally and is amenable to automatic and rapidly repetitive operation. The pulse energy and pulse mass are stored via liquid compression within a container, which enables attractively large ratio of pulse energy to machine weight. This in turn leads to the possibility of improved breakage performance vs. tool weight. The theory of operation, apparatus design and development status are presented.
Index Keywords: CONCRETE - Cutting; FLOW OF FLUIDS - Nozzles; ROCK - Cutting; ENERGETIC SLUGS; MASS AND ENERGY STORAGE; WATER CANNON CONCEPT; FLOW OF WATER

Title: MULTI-LEVEL DESIGN STRUCTURE FOR COMPUTER-BASED OPTIMAL DESIGN OF THERMAL ENERGY SYSTEMS.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: San Diego State Univ, San Diego, CA,, USA, San Diego State Univ, San Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Guven, H.M., San Diego State Univ, San Diego, CA,, USA, San Diego State Univ, San Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: In this paper, the mathematical underpinnings and the computational tools necessary for implementing a computer-based design method are described. A method in which any thermal energy system can be described in a way that leads logically to the formulation of a meaningful computer-aided design/optimization problem is presented. For this development, a hierarchial (macro- and micro-level) design structure is proposed. At the macro-level energy source, type of energy conversion and the optimal system configuration are determined. At the micro-level, optimal device sizes and operating conditions are determined. The method is demonstrated using two case studies: a) A passive solar system design, and b) A combined cogeneration and thermal energy storage (ice storage) system design for a hospital.

Abstract: Escom is the electrical utility supplying 93% (120 TWh) of electricity generated in South Africa and 60% of the electrical energy distributed in Africa. Escom presently (Jan 1986) has an installed sent-out capacity of 24 927 Mw at coal-fired, nuclear, conventional hydro, pumped storage, and gas turbine stations. Escom is not interconnected, except for limited imports from Namibia and Cahora Bassa. Emergency resources available to Escom include low frequency operation, maximum generation by coal-fired units, usage of emergency hydro and pumped storage, gas turbines, assistance from major cities with self-generation, and voluntary and compulsory underfrequency load shedding.

Title: CALCULATION OF EXPULSION ENERGY FOR SUPERCRITICAL HELIUM.
Affiliations: Ball Aerospace Systems Div, Boulder,, CO, USA, Ball Aerospace Systems Div, Boulder, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hustvedt, David, Ball Aerospace Systems Div, Boulder,, CO, USA, Ball Aerospace Systems Div, Boulder, CO, USA
Abstract: This paper presents the results of numerical calculations of the total energy required to expel supercritical helium from storage vessels at constant pressure, subject to the constraint of a maximum allowable fluid temperature during the expulsion process. The results were obtained by numerical integration of the specific heat input. Values of the total expulsion energy were calculated for pressures ranging from near the critical pressure to 20 atm and for maximum venting temperatures of 8K to 14K. The calculations show that the total expulsion energy can be maximized by properly selecting the venting pressure. These results can be used to thermodynamically optimize the performance of storage vessels (by minimizing the venting rate) or cryostats (by maximizing the cooling capacity).
Index Keywords: CRYOSTATS - Applications; CRYOGENIC COOLING SYSTEMS; EXPULSION ENERGY; SUPERCRITICAL HELIUM; HELIUM

Abstract: Helium II provides a unique and useful environment for cryogenic cooling of large scale superconducting devices. The heat transfer properties of this peculiar liquid afford enhanced thermal stability for composite conductors, while the low temperatures created ensure the possibility for high current densities in the superconducting material. This report discusses one large scale superconducting device, namely a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) system, and demonstrates the usefulness of He II in providing the stable environment.

Authors: Yuan G.S., Lehmann P., Hartwig K.T.
Title: EFFECT OF PRESTRAIN ON LOW TEMPERATURE FATIGUE INDUCED RESISTIVITY IN PURE ALUMINUM.
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Yuan, G.S., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA; Lehmann, P., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA; Hartwig, K.T., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: Residual resistivity increases are examined in pure aluminum work hardened at room temperature and then cyclically strained at 4. 2 K. The metal studied has an annealed residual resistivity ratio (RRR equals rho //2//7//3//K/ rho 4//. 2K) of 1000, is swagged conventionally to area reductions of between and 82%, and is taken through 3000 cycles of 0. 1, 0. 2 or 0. 3% strain. Fatigue induced resistivity ( DELTA rho ) is found to be dramatically reduced in prestrained metal when compared to the increase seen in annealed metal. Even though the initial residual resistivity of the work hardened aluminum is higher than that for the annealed case, the final resistivity after cycling is lower for the prestrained metal. The results of this study show that prestrain may provide a way to avoid much of the serious resistivity increase in the stabilizer aluminum used in composite superconductors and cryoconductors subjected to cyclic strain during operation.
Index Keywords: METALS TESTING - Fatigue; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS - Design; COMPOSITE SUPERCONDUCTORS; FATIGUE INDUCED RESISTIVITY; LARGE ENERGY STORAGE MAGNETS; ALUMINUM AND ALLOYS

Authors with affiliations: Poz, M.Ya.; Kogan, D.Ya.
Abstract: In determining the optimum dimensions of solar collectors and liquid thermal storage tanks, and the tank operating modes and availability for service, it is necessary to be able to calculate the tank charging time. The full charging time of a thermal-storage tank tau //c//h is determined as the duration of the period during which the temperature in the lower part of the tank reaches a steady-state value close to that of the heat-transfer medium being fed into the upper part of the tank. The authors have developed an algorithm and computer program for calculations. The results of calculations for thermal-storage tanks differing in their capacity (V) and height (H), for various flow rates of the heat-transfer medium being fed through them (G//s).

Abstract: Coal is the major energy source and amounts for 70% of the total energy consumption in China. The annual coal production will increase from 714 Mt to 1. 2 Gt. By the end of this century, the steel production in China will increase considerably. For this steel production, China has to mine plenty of iron ore. The mining, transportation, storage, processing and utilization of coal and iron ore place high requirements on bulk solids handling in China. In order to keep pace with economy, the technology of bulk solids handling has been rapidly developed. This paper introduces and describes the present technology and the tasks of bulk solids handling in China.

Authors: Bisgrove J.M., Lynch J.E., McNulty P.J., Abdel-Kader W.G., Kletnieks V., Kolasinski W.A.
Title: COMPARISON OF SOFT ERRORS INDUCED BY HEAVY IONS AND PROTONS.
Affiliations: Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bisgrove, J.M., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; Lynch, J.E., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; McNulty, P.J., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; Abdel-Kader, W.G., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; Kletnieks, V., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA; Kolasinski, W.A., Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA, Clarkson Univ, Potsdam, NY, USA
Abstract: Measurements of the single-event-upset (SEU) cross section vs. the linear energy transfer (LET) of the incident heavy ion were carried out on a single, Intel 64K dRAM, for which proton SEU data had been recently obtained, in order to test whether a single set of modeling assumptions could provide fits to both data sets. The dRAM exhibited consistent cross-section measurements among devices tested, a high total-dose tolerance, and a proton SEU cross section that was unaffected by accumulated dose, making the device very suited for extended radiation studies. The heavy-ion cross section vs. LET data was used as input to the CUPID code predictions of the proton-upset cross section vs. incident proton energy. Observed agreement is consistent with the hypothesis that proton-induced upsets, even in alpha-sensitive devices, are the result of recoiling nuclear fragments from inelastic nuclear interactions and the same basic mechanism is responsible for both heavy ion and proton-induced upsets.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Random Access; RADIATION EFFECTS - Computer Aided Analysis; HEAVY ION SEU; LINEAR ENERGY TRANSFER; SEMICONDUCTOR MEMORIES; SINGLE-EVENT-UPSET; DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR

Abstract: A solar system based on aquifer seasonal energy storage has been investigated for four cycles at the Yonezawa campus of Yamagata University. The experimental results showed that a recovery factor of 52% was achieved in the fourth cycle for a charge volume of 30,300 m**3 with mean temperature of 27. 4 degree C. Improvements of the well structure to reduce heat losses from the casing pipe were investigated, and a recovery factor of up to 64% was obtained. The possibility of the formation of a colloidal Fe(OH)//3 barrier in aquifer was confirmed. By the method of continuous circulation through the house of the stored lukewarm water, a base temperature of 15 degree C could be maintained all winter. The natural ground water at 13 degree C gave sufficient cooling power in summer.

Abstract: Georgia Power Company's Rocky Mountain Project, located ten miles northwest of Rome, Georgia is a pumped storage facility rated at 800 megawatts of peaking energy. Abstract: Tunnel oxide endurance is studied under conditions of constant-current Fowler-Nordheim injection. After a charge fluence of 10 Ccm** minus **2, the Si-SiO//2 interface state density is found to increase by approximately two orders of magnitude. When the stress current is increased from 10** minus **2 Acm** minus **2 to 10 Acm** minus **2, the charge fluence to 50% cumulative failure decreases from 60 Ccm** minus **2 to 6 Ccm** minus **2. Furthermore, for the temperature range 25 degree C to 250 degree C, the activation energy for oxide breakdown is shown to be 0. 44 eV above 100 degree C, and 0. 2 eV below 100 degree C.

Abstract: Experimental results are presented for latent thermal energy storage using eutectics of sodium hydroxide-sodium nitrite or sodium hydroxide-sodium nitrite molten salts which are promising for application to load-following generation in nuclear power plants (lightly water reactor). The experiment consists of a compatibility study for static corrosion of containment metal materials, and heat transfer and life cycle tests in a storage unit. The static corrosion test showed the best compatibility for carbon steels and Ni steel. A U-tube type latent thermal energy storage unit of 30-kWh scale was constructed for the heat transfer experiment. The unit was also used to conduct material, design, and structural evaluations, as well as optimizations over a number of melting and freezing cycles.

Abstract: This contribution describes the design and the performance of the ARGUS vertex drift chamber. Since spring 1985 it has operated successfully in the high background environment of the DORIS II storage ring. The chamber is filled with pure CO2 at a pressure of 1.5 bar. The spatial resolution, as obtained from Bhabha events, is about 50 μm over a large region of the drift cell. The data from the vertex drift chamber has considerably improved the precision of the measured parameters for charged tracks. Consequently the reconstruction efficiency for secondary vertices from KS0 and Δ decays is greatly enhanced, especially in the region close to the beam line. © 1986.

Abstract: Static RAM (SRAM) cell recovery time following a 140-MeV Krypton strike on a Sandia National Laboratory SRAM is modelled using a two-dimensional transient numerical simulator and circuit code. Strikes at both n- and p-channel 'off' drains are investigated. Four principle results are obtained. The recovery time after a strike is strongly dependent on the drive of the restoring transitor. A struck, off p-channel, drain-to-gate capacitive coupling has a significant effect on recovery in SRAM cells with feedback resistors. Recovery time is approximately linear with linear energy transfer (LET) over LET of around 0. 4 pC/ mu m. Finally, an experimental n-channel single-event upset (SEU) has been observed in a Sandia SRAM without feedback resistors.

Abstract: This paper presents preliminary engineering results for a 50 MW Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) plant for the Alabama Electric Cooperative, Inc. (AEC). The CAES plant would improve AEC's power generation mix in two ways: (a) it would provide needed peaking/intermediate power (otherwise purchased) and (b) it would increase the load factor of economical baseload units. The results of this preliminary engineering effort prove that a CAES plant is a cost effective addition to AEC's installed power generation plants.

Title: THERMODYNAMIC DESCRIPTION OF MIXTURES AND SOLUTIONS.

Authors with affiliations: Ruiter, J.P., NV KEMA, Arnhem, Neth, NV KEMA, Arnhem, Neth
Abstract: A compilation is given of the theories needed for a thermodynamic description of mixtures and solutions. The relation between the Gibbs energy and the pressure, temperature and composition forms the fundamental equation on which this description is based. Three reference systems are described: the perfect-gas model, for which it is assumed that the gas molecules have no volume of their own and do not exert mutual forces; the model of an ideal mixture of liquids, for which it is assumed that the interaction between the molecules of the various components is equal to the mutual interaction between the molecules of each specific component. The model of an ideal diluted solution, for which it is assumed that the molecules or ions of the dissolved component do not mutually interact.

Abstract: Position controllers have to handle kinetic energy exchanges during the acceleration and deceleration of large inertias. However, temporary buffer storage in capacitors is expensive. A system which can manage the power exchange with ease is described: the integrated controlled-current PWM rectifier/controlled current PWM chopper link. Bidirectional power is generated by bidirectional current flow in the dc link for both modulators. The three phase-currents in the rectifier side are nearly sinusoidal at unity power factor. The performance of the system as a position controller in an environment of the sliding-mode strategy is studied. The sliding-mode strategy offers robust characteristics to the controller.

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF REGENERABLE ENERGY STORAGE FOR SPACE MULTIMEGAWATT APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Olszewski, M., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA
Abstract: The author describes a program recently initiated as a part of the US Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI) to develop energy storage technology for space power applications. The energy storage technology considered in the program relate to devices that have a high specific capacity for energy storage, can provide high levels of electric power on demand, and can be recharged with electric power. The devices of principal interest are electrochemical batteries, chemical fuel cells, and electromechanical flywheels. The author focuses on the energy storage element of the Multimegawatt Technology Development Program, describes the rationale for selecting the technology to be developed, and gives an overview of the development effort required.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES; FLYWHEELS; FUEL CELLS; SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; MULTIMEGAWATT APPLICATIONS; REGENERABLE ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: DUAL TEMPERATURE THERMAL STORAGE WITH COMPLEX COMPOUNDS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rocky Research Corp, Boulder City,, NV, USA, Rocky Research Corp, Boulder City, NV, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rockenfeller, Uwe, Rocky Research Corp, Boulder City,, NV, USA, Rocky Research Corp, Boulder City, NV, USA; Martin, James F., Rocky Research Corp, Boulder City,, NV, USA, Rocky Research Corp, Boulder City, NV, USA
Abstract: The storage of thermal energy through the formation or dissociation of complex compounds is described. The solid-vapor reaction of an absorbant, a metal inorganic salt, with an absorbate, the ligand of the complex, provides energy storage for a heat-pump cycle. One system is capable of dual temperature storage, that is, storage of 'cool' for air conditioning and storage of heat for heating. Laboratory experiments that define the material and reaction characteristics of a sodium bromide/ammonia system have been performed. The reaction rates, storage density, and other operating parameters are described in functional form. The performance of a heat-pump storage system is projected from these experimentally determined properties. The resulting system compares favorably with existing cool storage systems and with proposed heat-or-cool storage systems.
Index Keywords: AMMONIA; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; DUAL TEMPERATURE STORAGE; SODIUM BROMIDE; HEATING

Title: NASA SPACE POWER TECHNOLOGY PROGRAM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Washington, DC, USA, NASA, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: VanLandingham, Earl E., NASA, Washington, DC, USA, NASA, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The NASA Space Power Technology Program is driven by missions extending 30 years into the future. The general characteristics of these missions are described insofar as they drive power system requirements. The various elements of the program are presented and put into this mission context. Specific technologies discussed include solar dynamic, nuclear and photovoltaic power generation; electrochemical energy storage; thermal management; and power management and distribution, including environmental interactions and materials.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR ENERGY - Space Applications; SOLAR CELLS; TECHNOLOGICAL FORECASTING; SP-100 STATUS; SPACE REACTOR POWER SYSTEMS; SPACECRAFT

Title: CONCEPTUAL DESIGN AND ECONOMIC EVALUATION OF UTILITY SCALE SMES.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
