Authors with affiliations: Masuda, M., Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Jpn, Natl Lab for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Jpn
Abstract: The author reports the results of current Japanese activities in designing and evaluating the economic feasibility for utilities of superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES). A 5-GWh/1-GW system is proposed as a relevant unit of SMES in the year 2000. More than 20 companies, several universities and two national laboratories joined in a task force to study this technology. After three years' assessment, the conclusion for utility-scale SMES is that there are no unresolvable technological problems and that commercial potential exists.

Authors: Geyer M., Bitterlich W., Werner K.
Title: EVALUATION OF THE DUAL MEDIUM STORAGE TANK AT THE IEA/SSPS PROJECT IN ALMERIA (SPAIN).
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: DFVLR, Inst fuer Technische, Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West Ger, DFVLR, Inst fuer Technische Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Geyer, M., DFVLR, Inst fuer Technische, Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West Ger, DFVLR, Inst fuer Technische Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West Ger; Bitterlich, W., DFVLR, Inst fuer Technische, Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West Ger, DFVLR, Inst fuer Technische Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West Ger; Werner, K., DFVLR, Inst fuer Technische, Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West Ger, DFVLR, Inst fuer Technische Thermodynamik, Stuttgart, West Ger
Abstract: Efficient and reliable thermal storage is the prior condition for replacing conventional power systems with solar thermal facilities. The distributed collector system of the IEA/SSPS Project in Almeria (Spain) contains two different storage systems for the 100 to 295 degree C temperature range: a single-thermocline vessel and a dual-medium storage tank. In the first case thermal oil is used as the energy carrier as well as for energy storage; in the dual-medium concept the storage medium is cast iron, and the oil acts mostly as the heat transfer medium. To assess the potential of this concept for future process heat applications, the performance and operational restrictions of the DMST have been studied systematically over a wide temperature range, verifying and adapting at the same time the existing simulation model. The first results of the 1985 test program are presented.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; TANKS - Energy Storage; DUAL MEDIUM STORAGE TANKS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Title: ENERGY STORAGE IN A SOLAR HOUSE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Nueve, Belg, Univ Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Nueve, Belg
Authors with affiliations: Charlier, Ir M., Univ Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Nueve, Belg, Univ Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Nueve, Belg; Wauters, P., Univ Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Nueve, Belg, Univ Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Nueve, Belg
Abstract: The coupling of a heat pump to solar collectors is considered as an alternative solution for the problem of heating buildings. This approach has been used for a house with a heating installation consisting 63 m**2 of solar collectors, a 7-m**3 tank of water, and a water-air heat pump. The temperatures, flows, and electric consumption have been measured, and a simulation program for the system has been developed. The simulation determined the influence of each part of the installation (collectors, storage tank and heat pump) on its efficiency. In particular, it has been shown that the capacity of the storage cylinder is a very important parameter. These results have been confirmed by measures on the installation without heat storage during the 1985-1986 winter season. The improvements resulting from this study have resulted in an electric energy saving of 20%.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING - Heat Storage; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR HOUSE; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Abstract: The thermal energy in peat is considered. The technology of thermal energy storage is described and a thermal energy storage project in a peat bog in Motala, Sweden is presented.
Index Keywords: PEAT; SEASONAL ENERGY STORAGE; SWEDEN; HEATING

Title: SOLAR ELECTRIC CAR: VEHICLE OF THE FUTURE HERE NOW.
Affiliations: Tokyo Denki Univ, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Denki Univ, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Fujinaka, Masaharu, Tokyo Denki Univ, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Denki Univ, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: A solar electric vehicle system being used by Prof. M. Fujinaka's family is described in some detail. Solar cells are set up on the roof of his home in Hino, a western suburb of Tokyo. The output of an array of photovoltaic cells is used to charge secondary batteries mounted on the electric vehicle, which is driven with the stored electric energy. Fujinaka and his family rely on the electric vehicle for all their daily driving needs, putting as much as 350 Km on the car in August, the peak summer month. The average monthly distance driven was 250 Km.
Index Keywords: SOLAR CELLS - Arrays; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Abstract: Measurements of temperature effects on single-event-upset (SEU) rates have been made on NMOS/resistive-load static RAMs using energetic protons and alphas. Results have indicated that SEU cross sections increase with increasing temperature for these parts. Proton- and alpha-induced nuclear reactions allow upsets to occur below measured linear-energy-transfer (LET) thresholds.

Title: CIRCULATING FLUIDIZED BED COMBUSTOR UTILIZATION WITH COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE PLANTS.

Abstract: This paper presents results of engineering of a Circulating Fluidized Bed Combustor (CFBC) for Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) application. This development allows eliminating the use of premium fuels thus resolving economic as well as institutional issues. The paper summarizes the engineering, performance and cost data for a CFBC and presents comparative technical and economic analyses of a CAES plant with CFBC (burning coal) versus a conventional CAES plant (burning premium fuel).

Title: SOLAR COOLING SYSTEM REDUCES SUMMER UTILITY DEMAND AND HVAC SYSTEM LIFE-CYCLE COST IN COMMERCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL BUILDINGS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: P. C. Gershon Meckler Associates,, New York, NY, USA, P. C. Gershon Meckler Associates, New York, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, G., P. C. Gershon Meckler Associates,, New York, NY, USA, P. C. Gershon Meckler Associates, New York, NY, USA
Abstract: Two large-building applications are described in which a major portion of the summer air-conditioning load is shifted from standard vapor compression refrigeration to desiccant dehumidification. The systems separate dehumidification from sensible cooling, dehumidify with a moisture-absorbing desiccant, and use low-grade solar energy from thermal storage tanks to dry the desiccant. Backup energy for cloudy days is provided by an efficient selective-energy system that incorporates cogeneration and off-peak electric utility energy. The latent heat released by the desiccant absorption process is removed by nonrefrigerated cooling-tower water. Estimated energy and first cost savings, as compared with a traditional VAV HVAC system, are: 30 to 50% in ductwork size and cost; 30% in fan energy; 25% in air handling equipment; 20 to 40% in utility energy for refrigeration; 10 to 20% in refrigeration equipment; and space savings due to smaller ductwork and equipment.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Humidity Control; BUILDINGS - Air Conditioning; WATER TANKS AND TOWERS; DESICCANT DEHUMIDIFICATION; DESICCANT DRYING; OFF-PEAK UTILITY ENERGY; THERMAL STORAGE TANKS; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Kamimoto M., Abe Y., Kanari K., Sawata S., Tani T., Ozawa T.
Title: LATENT THERMAL STORAGE USING PENTAERYTHRITOL SLURRY.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kamimoto, M., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn; Abe, Y., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn; Kanari, K., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn; Sawata, S., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn; Tani, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn; Ozawa, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Jpn
Abstract: Several latent thermal storage systems with pentaerythritol slurry (the transition temperature is 188 degree C) have been evaluated economically and technically. Three candidate systems including passive and active designs have been selected for further R&D. They are an encapsulated-type storage system, a shell and tube storage system with agitation of the slurry, and a slurry-circulation system. Inexpensive encapsulation techniques and fundamental characteristics of these storage systems are presented.
Index Keywords: ENCAPSULATION; ENERGY STORAGE; LATENT THERMAL STORAGE; PENTAERYTHRITOL SLURRY; HEATING

Title: DEVELOPMENT OF ADVANCED WATER-TO-WATER HEAT PUMPS IN THE RANGE OF 200 TO 5000 KW THERMAL OUTPUT: PRESTUDY.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Gilli, P.V.
Abstract: It was the task of this feasibility study carried out for the Swedish Council for, Building Research (BFR) to identify a program of work with the aim of developing heat pumps with a seasonal performance factor (SPF) around 4 when working from a heat storage source of a temperature between 4 and 20 degree C. The output temperature from the heat pump system should be at least 50 degree C. Seasonal energy storage systems designed as bore-hole storage in clay, rock, etc. were to be considered. Solar energy is basically used for the heat input to these storage systems. A brief survey covers the state of art of vertical earth storage systems and gives a description of the results of inquiries regarding design conditions, climatic data, heat sources, heat pumps and collectors in Sweden. A general analysis of the requirements to increase SPF, including an investigation of energetic and exergetic losses of heat pump components shows that the barriers to achieve SPFs of about 4 are high supply temperatures due to combined hot tap water production, increased losses of screw compressors at high pressure differences, the coincidence of minimum heat source temperature and highest demand when using a storage system with recharging. Using actual hourly values of the climate, the dynamic behaviour of systems consisting of a seasonal ground storage with discharging by the heat pump, with and without recharging by solar collectors, one or several water/water heat pumps and a heat distribution system with floating or constant temperatures was simulated by means of the computer program WPSYS3. Finally, a methodology for a large software and hardware project, including detailed studies of different components such as evaporator, compressor, condenser, controls, is developed.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Computer Simulation; HEATING - Heat Storage; HOT WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS - Temperature Control; METEOROLOGY - Climatology; HEAT PUMP COMPONENTS; SEASONAL PERFORMANCE FACTOR; SEASONAL STORAGE SYSTEM; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: WASTE HEAT RECOVERY USING AIR-TO-WATER HEAT PUMP.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Gannon Univ, Erie, PA, USA, Gannon Univ, Erie, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Torab, H., Gannon Univ, Erie, PA, USA, Gannon Univ, Erie, PA, USA
Abstract: Heat pump water heaters have become more attractive in recent years as a part of a growing trend toward residential energy conservation. In this study, a transient simulation procedure representing the performance of a heat pump water-heater coupled with a storage tank is developed. Since the performance of the heat pump is strongly affected by the inlet water temperature to the heat pump and since this inlet water is taken from the storage tank, the performance of the heat pump when coupled with a storage tank is inherently transient. It is assumed that the heat pump uses the energy of exhaust air to heat domestic water. The simulation procedure developed here is verified through comparison with an experimental evaluation of a residential heat pump water heater.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Heat Storage; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; WATER HEATERS - Performance; SIMULATION PROCEDURE; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Authors: Dickinson R.J., Marsh R.D., Silk M.G., McKenzie J., Self B.G.
Title: DEVELOPMENT OF A SAFEGUARDS SEALING SYSTEM FOR MULTI-ELEMENT BOTTLES.
Affiliations: British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl, British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Dickinson, R.J., British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl, British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl; Marsh, R.D., British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl, British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl; Silk, M.G., British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl, British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl; McKenzie, J., British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl, British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl; Self, B.G., British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl, British Nuclear Fuels plc, Warrington, Engl
Abstract: A safeguards sealing system is being developed for containers used by BNFL for transporting spent nuclear fuel, and its subsequent storage in water filled ponds. It is proposed that one or more of the bolts used for fixing the lid of the container to the body will have a unique identifier built into it/them. The unique identifier(s) will be capable of being interrogated by an ultrasonic seal pattern reader (SPAR) unit whilst being stored under several metres of water. The design of the unique identifier is based on the ARC system developed by Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd (AECL). The SPAR system developed by Sandia National Laboratories for use with the ARC system has been modified to take account of decisions to use the top edge of the 'seal' as the reference point for the acquisition of seal data, and to use direct measurements of temperature in the algorithm used to correct the seal signature for temperature effects. The sealing system is undergoing preliminary field trials in one of the spent fuel storage ponds at Sellafield.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; SEALS; ARC SYSTEM; SAFEGUARDS SEALING SYSTEM; ULTRASONIC SEAL PATTERN READER; NUCLEAR FUELS

Title: INTEGRATION OF A COMMERCIAL VEHICLE REGENERATIVE BRAKING DRIVELINE.
Source title: I Mech E Conference Publications (Institution of Mechanical Engineers)
Affiliations: Leyland Vehicles, Preston, Engl, Leyland Vehicles, Preston, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Greenwood, C.J., Leyland Vehicles, Preston, Engl, Leyland Vehicles, Preston, Engl
Abstract: The paper discusses the design options available for the production of a commercial vehicle regenerative braking driveline. It is based on the experience gained during the joint development programme for the Leyland/BP regenerative bus, and, as such, concentrates on mechanical systems using a high-speed flywheel as the energy storage medium. It covers the operational specifications for each of the driveline components and outlines the strategy adopted for their integration into the final system. The operational characteristics of the bus are described, including the mechanically automated 'link' transmission that engages the engine and flywheel.

Title: COMPARISON OF MULTI-MODE MULTI-MEGAWATT SPACE POWER SYSTEMS THAT EMPLOY ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electric Corp, Madison,, PA, USA, Westinghouse Electric Corp, Madison, PA, USA

Abstract: The authors compare and evaluate multimode, multimegawatt space power systems that use energy storage for burst power. Six different candidate concepts have been selected following a preliminary screening. These concepts use inertial, cryogenic, and thermal energy storage systems. The power source concepts are compared in terms of the total system mass and radiator area as well as other factors that may affect their practical application in space power missions.

Authors: Geyer M., Tamme R., Klaiss H.
Title: HIGH TEMPERATURE STORAGE CONCEPTS: A JOINT INVESTIGATION TASK OF THE IEA-SSPS PROJECT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger, DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Geyer, M., DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger, DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger; Tamme, R., DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger, DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger; Klaiss, H., DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger, DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger
Abstract: Solar central receiver systems have the potential to generate high-temperature process heat without polluting the environment. A storage system is necessary to separate the continuous process demand from the intermittent supply of solar radiation. High-temperature thermal energy storage in ceramic regenerators can provide continuous operation and perform the pressure transformation between the receiver and the process. Composite salt/ceramic materials can increase the storage capacity and provide a more constant discharge temperature, making thermal storage competitive with closed-cycle chemical storage concepts. The storage concepts are examined and research activities are described that are being coordinated through the IEA-SSPS (International Energy Agency-small solar power systems) project to demonstrate and evaluate high-temperature solar radiation conversion.
Index Keywords: COMPOSITE MATERIALS; HEAT EXCHANGERS - Regenerators; SMALL SOLAR POWER SYSTEMS (SSPS); THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY

Abstract: The development of a zinc chloride battery for energy storage is discussed. Operation of a prototype 10-kW (80-kWh) battery disclosed that it needed some technical and structural improvements. The main improvements incorporated in a later version are larger electrodes and supporting frames, increased energy efficiency, and a new chlorine storage method. The modifications resulted in a 10% increase in total efficiency and a 60% decrease in the volume of the battery.

Authors: Asper H.K., Grieder T., Riesen H.J., Widmer J., Mosebach H.
Title: INVERTER FED 10 KW ADVANCED RELUCTANCE MACHINE FOR FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS OPERATING FROM 12,000 TO 24,000 RPM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: ETH, Zurich, Switz, ETH, Zurich, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Asper, H.K., ETH, Zurich, Switz, ETH, Zurich, Switz; Grieder, T., ETH, Zurich, Switz, ETH, Zurich, Switz; Riesen, H.J., ETH, Zurich, Switz, ETH, Zurich, Switz; Widmer, J., ETH, Zurich, Switz, ETH, Zurich, Switz; Mosebach, H., ETH, Zurich, Switz, ETH, Zurich, Switz
Abstract: The authors describe an inverter-fed advanced reluctance machine and compare it with a three-phase salient pole reluctance machine. The advanced reluctance machine operates at 3600 rpm and will be adapted for high-speed operation in the flywheel energy storage system of the authors' institution. The machine has no moving windings, and the rotor develops no heat at full operating power, resulting in very low idling losses. The multiphase armature winding of the stator is commutated electronically on a coil-by-coil basis. Depending on the momentary position of the rotor, the coils operate either as a field winding or as an armature winding. The advanced reluctance machine is similar in its electromechanical structure to the induction machine, and hence a similar pricing on a cost-to-weight basis should apply for high-volume production.
Index Keywords: CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES; ELECTRIC INVERTERS; ELECTRIC WINDINGS, MACHINE - Control; FLYWHEELS - Energy Storage; ROTORS; ELECTRONIC COMMUTATION; INVERTER-FED ADVANCED RELUCTANCE MACHINE (ARM); MULTIPHASE ARMATURE WINDING; ELECTRIC MOTORS, RELUCTANCE TYPE

Authors with affiliations: Baev, S.G.; Vessmel'tsev, V.P.; Boldyrev, V.V.; Lomovskii, O.I.; Lushnikiov, A.Ya.
Abstract: The sensitivity of materials containing aminoammonium complex compounds of copper hypophosphite has been studied in connection with thermal writing in a CO//2-laser flying-spot apparatus (10. 6 mu m). The sensitivity (the threshold writing energy) depends linearly on the logarithm of the instability constant of the complex compound. The distribution of absorbed energy in the recording material and the effect of adsorbers have been studied. Threshold writing energy densities of 0. 2-1. 6 J/cm**2 have been attained.

Authors: Bous M.W., Busch J.R., Brockway C.E.
Title: OPTIMAL OPERATING RULES FOR PARALLEL PUMPING PLANTS.
Source title: Paper - American Society of Agricultural Engineers

Authors with affiliations: Bous, M.W., US Bur of Reclamation, Burley, ID,, USA, US Bur of Reclamation, Burley, ID, USA; Busch, J.R., US Bur of Reclamation, Burley, ID,, USA, US Bur of Reclamation, Burley, ID, USA; Brockway, C.E., US Bur of Reclamation, Burley, ID,, USA, US Bur of Reclamation, Burley, ID, USA
Abstract: The objective of this study is to provide a method for determining the minimum energy operating procedure for a pumping plant with parallel pumps. Specifically the method should: provide the flow to be delivered from each pump in the plant and the discharge head at which that flow is delivered for a given flow from the whole plant; require a minimum of computer capabilities. Large amounts of storage and high level problem oriented languages may not be available; utilize data collected during a routine pump test of each pump; adapt easily to minimizing cost instead of energy use; provide a tool for comparing the present pumping plant with a replacement or modified pumping plant. A dynamic programming approach suitable for small computers is used to allocate flow to parallel pumps to minimized the total power requirement. The method proves useful in preparation of operating rules, evaluation of present operation and design of hardware modifications.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL PROGRAMMING, DYNAMIC; SCHEDULING - Optimization; FLOW ALLOCATION; OPTIMAL OPERATING RULES; PARALLEL PUMPING PLANTS; POWER REQUIREMENT MINIMIZATION; IRRIGATION

Title: PERFORMANCE OF A POROUS CONCRETE SOLAR STORAGE WALL.
Source title: Paper - American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Shenyang Agricultural Univ, Shenyang, China, Shenyang Agricultural Univ, Shenyang, China
Authors with affiliations: Ma, Jianxue, Shenyang Agricultural Univ, Shenyang, China, Shenyang Agricultural Univ, Shenyang, China; Schulte, Dennis D., Shenyang Agricultural Univ, Shenyang, China, Shenyang Agricultural Univ, Shenyang, China
Abstract: A porous concrete solar storage wall, constructed from limestone aggregate and portland cement, was used to preheat ventilation air for a swine nursery. The wall and its glazing collected 57. 6 percent of incident solar radiation. Collected energy was equivalent to 107 liters of propane per square meter of collector surface.

Authors: Nitta Tanzo, Shirai Yasuyuki, Okada Takao
Title: POWER SYSTEM CHARACTERISTICS OF SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Kyoto Univ, Jpn, Kyoto Univ, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Nitta, Tanzo, Kyoto Univ, Jpn, Kyoto Univ, Jpn; Shirai, Yasuyuki, Kyoto Univ, Jpn, Kyoto Univ, Jpn; Okada, Takao, Kyoto Univ, Jpn, Kyoto Univ, Jpn
Abstract: The power-system characteristics of superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) with filters to suppress current harmonics is investigated by experiment and simulation. A small magnet is connected to an infinite bus through the double thyristorized converters of the Graetz connection and the transmission line. The passive filters are connected to the terminal of the SMES unit; they suppress the current harmonics and compensate the reactive power. The results are as follows: (1) The active and reactive power of high power-factor are controlled. (2) The current harmonics through the transmission line are reduced. (3) The terminal voltage across the SMES remains almost constant. (4) An increase of nontheoretical harmonics is observed, which may be due to the parallel resonance of the transmission line and the filters. Computer simulation results agree well with those of the experiments.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONVERTERS; ELECTRIC FILTERS; CURRENT HARMONICS SUPPRESSION; DOUBLE TRANSISTORIZED CONVERTERS; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE (SMES); SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Title: THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE FOR ORGANIC RANKINE CYCLE SOLAR DYNAMIC SPACE POWER SYSTEMS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sundstrand Missile & Space Power, Systems, Rockford, IL, USA, Sundstrand Missile & Space Power Systems, Rockford, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Heidenreich, G.R., Sundstrand Missile & Space Power, Systems, Rockford, IL, USA, Sundstrand Missile & Space Power Systems, Rockford, IL, USA; Parekh, M.B., Sundstrand Missile & Space Power, Systems, Rockford, IL, USA, Sundstrand Missile & Space Power Systems, Rockford, IL, USA
Abstract: The organic Rankine cycle (ORC) solar dynamic power system (SDPS) is attractive for space power generation. The ORC-SDPS consists of a concentrator, a radiator, a power conversion unit, and a receiver with thermal energy storage (TEST) subsystem. The TES subsystem must be capable of charging and discharging the energy so that the ORC-SDPS can meet the power demands, including any emergency power requirements, during the orbital insolation and eclipse periods. The criteria used in designing the ORC-TES subsystem are presented and discussed. A brief description of an automated test facility for the TES canister is presented. Additional test results from the deuterium (hydrogen) permeation testing are also presented.
Index Keywords: DEUTERIUM; HYDROGEN; SOLAR ENERGY - Space Applications; THERMODYNAMICS; ORGANIC RANKINE CYCLE; SOLAR DYNAMIC POWER SYSTEMS; HEATING

Title: IMPACT OF OPERATION AND CONTROL STRATEGY ON THE PERFORMANCE OF A THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, CA, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Warren, Mashuri L., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, CA, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, CA, USA
Abstract: The annual performance of a thermal storage system has been simulated on the basis of hourly cooling loads generated with a DOE2 simulation for a typical small office building. The thermal storage system is sized to meet the maximum daily load for the building; the comparable conventional system is sized to meet the typical building peak load. The operation of the thermal storage system in then modeled hour by hour. Results of the simulation analysis show that while chiller priority control achieves the desired peak load reduction, only that part of the cooling load greater than the chiller capacity is shifted to partial-peak or off-peak hours. The chiller runs on, charging storage, through the evening hours. Application of storage priority control shifts a greater portion of the annual cooling from on-peak to partial-peak and off-peak hours. This results in greater cost savings to a utility customer on time-of-day rates.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; CONTROL, THERMAL VARIABLES; CHILLER PRIORITY CONTROL; HEATING

Title: POLYMER ELECTROLYTES.
Affiliations: CNRS, St. -Martin d'Heres, Fr, CNRS, St. -Martin d'Heres, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Armand, Michel B., CNRS, St. -Martin d'Heres, Fr, CNRS, St. -Martin d'Heres, Fr
Abstract: Solvent-free polymer electrolytes are a new class of ionically conductive solids. They have the desirable mechanical properties of thermoplastics or elastomers which are very favorable for maintaining good ionic contact with other solids like intercalation compounds. PEO-based electrolytes have proved the validity of the thin film/low current density concept for reversible energy storage devices. The main drawback of such materials appears to be the lack of selectivity of cation versus anion transport. The review covers the properties and applications of solvent-free polymer electrolytes obtained through direct interaction of a salt and a macromolecule.
Index Keywords: ELECTROCHEMISTRY - Reviews; POLYETHYLENES - Applications; POLYETHYLENE OXIDE (PEO); POLYMER ELECTROLYTES; ELECTROLYTES

Title: NATURAL CONVECTION IN POROUS MEDIA.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Abstract: Natural convection in porous media plays an important role in many geophysical and engineering applications and has received considerable attention in recent years owing to increasing interest in geothermal energy resources - thermally-enhanced oil recovery, high performance building insulation, energy-efficient drying processes, thermal energy storage, packed bed chemical reactors, nuclear reactor containment in the unlikely event of catastrophic failure and nuclear waste disposal, underground spread of pollutants and several other practical problems. This symposium volume contains 16 papers. Both experimental and analytical results are presented covering a broad range of geometrics and applications. The first twelve papers deal with natural convection while the remaining papers deal with mixed convection. Several of these papers consider Brinkman and Forchheimer modifications to the Darcy's equation of motion and attempt to characterize the importance of the viscous diffusion and transport terms. These papers offer a representative cross section of the status of natural and mixed convection in saturated porous media.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF FLUIDS - Porous Materials; MAGNETIC FIELD EFFECTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POROUS MATERIALS - Heat Transfer; BUOYANCY-DRIVEN FLOW; EIREV; MAGNETOCONVECTION; NATURAL CONVECTION; POROUS ANNULUS; HEAT TRANSFER

Title: COMPUTERIZED COST COMPARISON MODEL FOR ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS.

Abstract: A battery power trade study requiring some cost comparisons prompted the authors to develop the BATPAY cost-estimation subprogram for an expert battery data system known as BEBATs (Boeing Expert Battery System). BATPAY makes the derivation and assembly of battery program cost data much easier than a manual assembly of data and holds promise of being a valuable subsection of a larger expert battery program.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Costs; BATTERY PROGRAM; BOEING EXPERT BATTERY SYSTEM (BEBATS); COST COMPARISON MODEL; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Reid R.L., Bedinger A.F.G., Wix S.D.
Title: LESSONS LEARNED FROM A MEMBRANE STRATIFIED THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Reid, R.L., Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA; Bedinger, A.F.G., Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA; Wix, S.D., Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA, Univ of Texas, El Paso, TX, USA
Abstract: The performance of a 64,400-gallon membrane stratified thermal energy storage (TES) system for an elementary school in Roane County, TX, is evaluated. The system was instrumented and monitored over a two-year period. Efficiencies of the order of 40-80% were measured for the storage tanks, so that the concept of membrane stratified thermal energy storage appears to be valid. However, during the study the TES system rarely operated for more than a day or two without human intervention. Indeed, the entire HVAC/TES system was plagued with operational problems. Thus, as presently installed, the system can not operate automatically for long periods of time. For a building of the given size and use patterns, the economic justification for such a system is not obvious.
Index Keywords: MEMBRANES - Energy Storage; MEMBRANE STRATIFIED THERMAL STORAGE; HEATING

Authors: Carotenuto A., Fucci F., La Fianza G., Mele L., Reale F.
Title: VALIDATION OF A CHOICE OF AN AQUIFER FOR SEASONAL THERMAL STORAGE BY NUMERICAL SIMULATION.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Naples, Italy, Univ of Naples, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Carotenuto, A., Univ of Naples, Italy, Univ of Naples, Italy; Fucci, F., Univ of Naples, Italy, Univ of Naples, Italy; La Fianza, G., Univ of Naples, Italy, Univ of Naples, Italy; Mele, L., Univ of Naples, Italy, Univ of Naples, Italy; Reale, F., Univ of Naples, Italy, Univ of Naples, Italy
Abstract: The feasibility of highly efficient energy storage in aquifers coupled to an inverse cycle system for space heating and cooling was studied. The system is to be operated with a number of additional subsystems such as solar collectors and buffer storage. Investigations have been carried out for five sites that have been selected on the basis of their hydrogeological characteristics and the mechanical and thermophysical properties of the rocks. Heat storage in the aquifers at the five sites is evaluated by numerical simulation. The results of the simulation under some simplifying assumptions as well as a preliminary evaluation of the performance of the system are presented.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS - Energy Storage; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Numerical Methods; HYDROGEOLOGY; NUMERICAL SIMULATION; HEATING

Authors: Shiono Noboru, Sakagawa Yoshimitsu, Sekiguchi Masayuki, Sato Kenji, Sugai Isao, Hattori Toshiyuki, Hirao Yasuo
Title: SINGLE EVENT EFFECTS IN HIGH DENSITY CMOS SRAMS.
Affiliations: NTT, Electrical Communications Lab,, Atsugi, Jpn, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab, Atsugi, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Shiono, Noboru, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab,, Atsugi, Jpn, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab, Atsugi, Jpn; Sakagawa, Yoshimitsu, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab,, Atsugi, Jpn, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab, Atsugi, Jpn; Sekiguchi, Masayuki, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab,, Atsugi, Jpn, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab, Atsugi, Jpn; Sato, Kenji, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab,, Atsugi, Jpn, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab, Atsugi, Jpn; Sugai, Isao, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab,, Atsugi, Jpn, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab, Atsugi, Jpn; Hattori, Toshiyuki, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab,, Atsugi, Jpn, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab, Atsugi, Jpn; Hirao, Yasuo, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab,, Atsugi, Jpn, NTT, Electrical Communications Lab, Atsugi, Jpn
Abstract: The effects of epitaxial layer-substrate and a cell power supply layout on heavy-ion induced latch-up for 64K SRAMs are examined by heavy-ion exposure test using a cyclotron. It is shown that epitaxial layer-substrate alone is not sufficient to prevent latch-up. A cell power supply layout technique, that is, power is supplied through the well for MOSFETs in the well, combined with epi-substrate is very effective in preventing latch-up for high-density CMOS/Bulk memories. Soft error cross section and threshold linear energy transfers (LETs) for various CMOS SRAMs are determined by heavy-ion exposure tests. The threshold LET for conventional 64K SRAMs decreases to about one-fifth that of 1K SRAMs.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Random Access; ION BEAMS - Applications; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MOS - Radiation Effects; CMOS STATIC RAMS; HEAVY-ION INDUCED LATCHUP; DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR

Title: ENERGY PLANNING AND ALLOCATION FOR MULTIHUNDRED KILOWATT SPACECRAFT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: TRW, Space & Technology Group,, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Space & Technology Group, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Decker, D.K., TRW, Space & Technology Group,, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Space & Technology Group, Redondo Beach, CA, USA; Vivian, J.M., TRW, Space & Technology Group,, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Space & Technology Group, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: The authors examine various aspects of automation and introduce levels of automation as a method for understanding the application of automation to the space power subsystems. A concept for an expert system approach to energy planning and load management for these large spacecraft is also described. The functional architecture provides dual expert systems: one that is a planner/scheduler for load management and one that functions as the power system monitor. The energy planning function generates load profiles from load status tables for near-term periods up to 24 h and compares these profiles to the available power and energy limits during both sunlight and eclipse periods. Alternate load profiles are generated if peak load limits are exceeded or if the profile leads to a projection of insufficient energy for full system recharge. The load management function includes load bus assignments, peak load management, and emergency load shedding. Once the plans are made and are in effect, the expert system will monitor the performance and health of the power subsystem and serve as a decision aid for dynamic load reapportionment, load shedding, and energy storage recharge.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE - Expert Systems; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; ENERGY MANAGEMENT - Automation; ENERGY PLANNING; MULTIHUNDRED KILOWATT SPACECRAFT; SPACECRAFT

Title: SPACE STATION POWER MANAGEMENT SYSTEM ARCHITECTURE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: TRW, Space & Technology Group,, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Space & Technology Group, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Decker, D.K., TRW, Space & Technology Group,, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Space & Technology Group, Redondo Beach, CA, USA; Campbell, J.F., TRW, Space & Technology Group,, Redondo Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Space & Technology Group, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: The authors describe a distributed, power-management-system architecture for the NASA space station and presents the rationale that was used to derive this configuration. The architecture provides sufficient redundancy to be consistent with space station reliability requirements and provides an interface to the data management system. The architecture consists of redundant load-center controllers, power-source controllers for each energy storage channel, electrical-power-system controllers for overall management of the power subsystem, and parallel databases for the transport medium. A data bus protocol is presented that is consistent with IEEE standards as well as the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) model. Trade study results are presented that identify available microprocessors and define processing requirements. Functional requirements are presented along with rationale for partitioning of man-machine roles.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC POWER DISTRIBUTION; STANDARDS; CONTROLLERS; NASA SPACE STATION; POWER MANAGEMENT; SPACECRAFT

Title: SOLID STATE TRACK RECORDER NEUTRON DOSIMETRY IN A SIMULATED BASALT GEOLOGICAL WASTE REPOSITORY.
Affiliations: Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland,, WA, USA, Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ruddy, F.H., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland,, WA, USA, Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, WA, USA; Roberts, J.H., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland,, WA, USA, Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, WA, USA; Lippincott, E.P., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland,, WA, USA, Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: Solid State Track Recorder (SSTR) techniques have been developed for neutron dosimetry applications related to geological storage of radioactive waste. The neutron irradiation environment of spent fuel stored in a simulated basalt geological waste repository was investigated using SSTR neutron dosimetry capsules which contained low mass deposits of fissionable isotopes in contact with mica SSTRs. After exposure for a period of years, the capsules were recovered and the mica SSTRs were retrieved and analyzed. The measured fission rates and derived neutron energy and fluence information are reported.
Index Keywords: BASALT; GEOLOGY; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; GEOLOGICAL WASTE REPOSITORY; SOLID STATE TRACK RECORDER; NEUTRONS

Title: ATTRACTIVENESS TO THEFT OR DIVERSION AS A CONSIDERATION IN THE PHYSICAL PROTECTION OF SNM.
Affiliations: Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cardwell, R.G., Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Carlson, R.L., Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Erkkila, B.H., Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Heidel, G.M., Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Williams, J.D., Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Martin Marietta Energy Systems Inc, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: There is a growing consensus among personnel responsible for the handling and protection of nuclear materials that certain types and forms of Special Nuclear Materials (SNM) in Department of Energy (DOE) Category I can be moved to a lower category because of their relative unattractiveness for theft or diversion. A collective effort by the authors to create a model based on such an 'attractiveness factor' resulted in a 'decision tree' that will determine a suitable category of protection for each particular group or batch of material. The tree considers (in addition to quantity) such factors as type and condition, self-protecting radiation level, piece size, dispersion or dilution, spacing in storage, and ease of recoverability.
Index Keywords: DECISION THEORY AND ANALYSIS; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Trees; DECISION TREE; SPECIAL NUCLEAR MATERIALS; THEFT PROTECTION; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS

Title: THERMOCHEMICAL ENERGY TRANSPORT FOR A LARGE HEAT UTILITY.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Inst, Solar Energy Research Inst
Authors with affiliations: Nix, R.G., Solar Energy Research Inst, Solar Energy Research Inst; Bergeron, P.W., Solar Energy Research Inst, Solar Energy Research Inst
Abstract: A feasibility study was done on using reversible chemical reactions to transport high-temperature thermal energy from a solar thermal heat source to a distant user. The users were ten equally sized plants clustered in an industrial park, with each user located an average of 0. 8 km (0. 5 mi) from the center. Each user required 26. 2 MW//t (89. 5 MBtu/h) of 4. 14-MPa (600-psig)/400 degree C (750 degree F) superheated steam. The base case for comparison is a central fossil-fuel-fired boiler that transmits steam to the users. The study also considered transmitting high-temperature energy using molten salt as an alternative to thermochemical transport, as well as the effect of long-duration storage on delivered energy costs for some solar thermal cases. The results and conclusions are summarized.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ENERGY STORAGE; SALTS - Fused; STEAM POWER PLANTS; HIGH-TEMPERATURE ENERGY TRANSPORT; LONG-DURATION ENERGY STORAGE; MOLTEN SALT USE; THERMOCHEMICAL ENERGY TRANSPORT; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Kabik C.S., Kuchuk F.J., Hasan A.R.
Title: TRANSIENT ANALYSIS OF ACOUSTICALLY DERIVED PRESSURE AND FLOW RATE DATA.
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers of AIME, (Paper) SPE
Affiliations: Schlumberger Well Services, Schlumberger Well Services
Authors with affiliations: Kabik, C.S., Schlumberger Well Services, Schlumberger Well Services; Kuchuk, F.J., Schlumberger Well Services, Schlumberger Well Services; Hasan, A.R., Schlumberger Well Services, Schlumberger Well Services
Abstract: A pressure buildup test conducted on a sucker-rod pumping well is often distorted by long-duration wellbore storage. In fact, this distortion can be so severe that even a week's shut-in period may not allow a semilog analysis. A longer shut-in period becomes economically discouraging because of lost production. Low energy and low transmissivity in the reservoir, coupled with increased fluid compressibility, contribute to this long-duration storage phenomenon. One way of handling this problem clearly lies in the simultaneous treatment of downhole pressure and flow rate, estimated from rising annular liquid-level data by acoustic well sounding (AWS). Ascertaining the quality of the indirectly measured pressure and rate data constitutes one of the objectives of this study. Interpretation of several transient tests shows that automatic convolved-type-curve or history matching of field data is a powerful tool for reservoir parameter (total mobility, skin, fracture half-length, storage coefficient) estimation.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF FLUIDS - Transients; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Curve Fitting; OIL WELL LOGGING - Acoustic; PRESSURE EFFECTS - Analysis; ACOUSTIC WELL SOUNDING (AWS); FLOW RATE; TRANSIENT ANALYSIS; TYPE-CURVE; OIL WELLS

Abstract: The capacitor's basic function, energy storage, has seen broadened application since the early experiments. This paper is confined to capacitors whose dielectrics are ceramic materials.

Abstract: This paper presents results of engineering development for utilization of thermal energy storage (TES) for Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) plant applications. Presented results include the following: Turbomachinery cycle optimization for TES application; TES systems engineering and optimization; Comparative technical and economic analysis of various CAES plant concepts with TES versus a conventional CAES plant concept. Abstract: On the basis of statistical processing of the data from many years' observations of daily totals of direct solar radiation in Tashkent, calculations are made of parameters of a solar unit and storage devices which will provide for highly reliable operation of communications equipment.

Title: REVIEW OF THE CHARACTERIZATION OF THE MOLTEN NITRATE SALT FOR SOLAR CENTRAL RECEIVER APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Abstract: Over the past several years Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore (SNLL), has been asked by the US Department of Energy to develop thermal energy transfer and storage technologies using advanced single-phase working fluids for solar central receiver (SCR) applications. Particular interest has focused on a mixture of sodium and potassium nitrate (NaNO//3 /KNO//3 ) because of the low melting point (eutectic at 222 degree C), availability of large quantities at low cost, and minimal hazards associated with its use. A comprehensive research program was established by Sandia to address issues relevant to the use of molten nitrates at high temperature (600 degree C). The authors summarize that work, which confirms that the use of molten nitrate salt is technically feasible and a very attractive candidate for advanced SCR systems.

Title: ICE SLURRY SYSTEM FOR LOW TEMPERATURE THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: CBI Industries Inc, Plainfield, IL,, USA, CBI Industries Inc, Plainfield, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Heavener, C.M., CBI Industries Inc, Plainfield, IL,, USA, CBI Industries Inc, Plainfield, IL, USA
Abstract: A thermal energy storage system capable of producing and storing a low-temperature (0 degree F to 25 degree F) ice slurry, or liquid ice, is presented. The system is based on a shell-and-tube exchanger that generates ice crystals continuously within a binary solution. The resulting ice slurry is then pumped to storage for later use against a cooling load. This concept is targeted toward low-temperature cooling loads. A system has been designed, constructed, and operated for two cooling seasons, supplying air conditioning to an office building having a 300-ton peak cooling load. The process concept is described, and its operating advantages and economic benefits are explained. The process flow schematic and equipment used in the 300-ton demonstration plant are discussed. Data collected by the microprocessor-based data acquisition and reduction system installed on the plant are presented and reviewed. The application of the concept in the refrigeration industry is addressed. 2 refs.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS, MICROCOMPUTER; DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; ICE; LOW TEMPERATURE ENGINEERING; ICE SLURRY; HEATING

Title: SOLAR UNIT FOR DRYING FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)

Abstract: The article shows the efficiency of using the suggested system, compared to traditional units. A diagram of the heat-pump drying unit (HPDU) with solar collector which has been developed is shown. The unit consists of a heat exchanger divided into two sections, a unit for mixing part of the recirculated cooling agent with free air, a fan, and a compression heat pump, which includes a compressor, condenser, regenerative heat exchanger regulating valve, evaporator, solar collector, thermal-storage tank, and pumps. The efficiency of using the unit for rice drying is demonstrated.

Authors: Browne Sidney H., Hancock Omar, Block David, Rotundo Louis, Neill Richard, Nelson Earl C., Takahashi Patrick K.
Title: TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT FOR HYDROGEN FROM RENEWABLE ENERGY.
Affiliations: Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI,, USA, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Browne, Sidney H., Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI,, USA, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI, USA; Hancock, Omar, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI,, USA, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI, USA; Block, David, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI,, USA, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI, USA; Rotundo, Louis, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI,, USA, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI, USA; Neill, Richard, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI,, USA, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI, USA; Nelson, Earl C., Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI,, USA, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI, USA; Takahashi, Patrick K., Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI,, USA, Univ of Hawaii Manoa, Honolulu, HI, USA
Abstract: This paper is a preliminary report on an assessment of technologies for hydrogen production from renewable resources, and an investigation of the problems and issues involved in assimilating this hydrogen into the overall energy economy. Hawaii was selected as the ideal laboratory for this purpose. The Hawaiian energy economy is reviewed to establish energy needs, and technologies available for conversion of indigenous resources (geothermal, wind, solar radiation, biomass, and ocean energy), into hydrogen or hydrogen-rich chemicals are assessed. Potential uses of hydrogen energy, for example, to provide transportation fuel or to generate electricity, and the problems of storage and distribution are examined. The assessment was about three-quarters finished at the time of this writing. The final results will be a plan for transition to increased uses of hydrogen, and identification of research and development needs to realize the potential benefits of hydrogen.
Index Keywords: BIOMASS; ENERGY MANAGEMENT - Hawaii; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION; WIND POWER; HYDROGEN FROM RENEWABLE ENERGY; HYDROGEN RICH CHEMICALS; HYDROGEN FUELS

Authors: Goerlich S., Herrmann K.D., Reiners W., Kubalek E.
Title: CAPACITIVE COUPLING VOLTAGE CONTRAST.
Affiliations: Univ Duisburg, Duisburg, West Ger, Univ Duisburg, Duisburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Goerlich, S., Univ Duisburg, Duisburg, West Ger, Univ Duisburg, Duisburg, West Ger; Herrmann, K.D., Univ Duisburg, Duisburg, West Ger, Univ Duisburg, Duisburg, West Ger; Reiners, W., Univ Duisburg, Duisburg, West Ger, Univ Duisburg, Duisburg, West Ger; Kubalek, E., Univ Duisburg, Duisburg, West Ger, Univ Duisburg, Duisburg, West Ger
Abstract: Capacitive coupling voltage contrast (CCVC) allows electron-beam testing of passivated integrated circuits (IC) without radiation damage or prior, time-consuming specimen preparation. This effect occurs when low primary electron energies are used and the electron yield of the passivation layer is greater than 1. Signal changes in the relevant interconnections are transferred to the passivation surface via capacitive coupling, but they vanish there within the storage time due to electron irradiation. A physical model explains the dependence of CCVC on three parameters: electron irradiation, the passivation material and the signals within the IC. Computer simulations based on this model describe the experimentally-obtained dependencies of the storage time with precision and allow predictions to be made for using CCVC in electron beam testing. The requisite modifications to the electron beam testing system are described and the possible uses of CCVC for testing passivated devices, within IC are demonstrated on the basis of examples.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; ELECTRON BEAMS - Applications; CAPACITIVE COUPLING VOLTAGE CONTRAST (CCVC); ELECTRON IRRADIATION; FAST DIGITAL IMAGE ACQUISITION SYSTEM; PASSIVATED INTEGRATED CIRCUITS (IC); STORAGE TIME; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS

Title: COMPARATIVE INVESTIGATION OF THE DEPENDENCE OF THE OPERATING REGIME IN GREENHOUSES ON THEIR DESIGN AND ORIENTATION.
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Yakubov, Yu.N.
Abstract: Different greenhouse designs are investigated from the solar-energy point of view. At present, modular greenhouses of the type design 810-45 are widely used. But their longitudinal axes are parallel to terrestrial meridians. Theoretical calculations and experiments show that, during the heating period, unit inflows of solar radiation, taking into account the probability of clear, sunny days, are significantly smaller for meridional greenhouses than for latitudinal ones, if the greenhouses' longitudinal axes are parallel to terrestrial parallels. Favorable experiences with latitudinal greenhouses are reported.

Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 132 papers. They are arranged as follows: I. Principles and fundamentals: Rock fracture mechanics; Rock characterization; Laboratory measurement; Model analysis; Subsidence; II. Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Imamkulov, A.I.
Abstract: The article reports results of comparative experiments on the storage of solar energy in two models of shed greenhouses by means of forced circulation of air under the soil. When the temperature of air inside the greenhouse is below the norm (18-20 degree C), the air pump automatically turns on, and the reverse process occurs: heat is withdrawn from the ground to the air, the process of discharging the thermal storage.
Index Keywords: AIR; SOILS; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; SOLAR RADIATION - Energy Storage; FORCED CIRCULATION OF AIR; SHED GREENHOUSES; SOLAR GREENHOUSES; GREENHOUSES

Title: MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE OF NUCLEAR WASTE: A POLITICAL PROBLEM REARS ITS HEAD IN TENNESSEE.
Affiliations: Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN,, USA, Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Katz, E.Marcia, Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN,, USA, Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, USA
Abstract: ASME's Congressional Fellows program offers engineering and scientific expertise to United States Senators and Representatives. The existence of ASME's Fellows Program implies that decisions made by our elected officials are based on scientific evidence. This paper presents information concerning an issue that raised political questions: the proposal by the Department of Energy to locate a monitored retrievable storage facility for spent nuclear fuel in Tennessee. Evidence of the non-scientific aspect of the opposition is presented by reviewing election campaigns and newspaper headlines.
Index Keywords: LEGISLATION; NUCLEAR FUELS - Storage; RADIOACTIVE WASTES - Disposal; MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE; NUCLEAR WASTE; POLITICAL PROBLEM; INDUSTRIAL WASTES

Title: INTEGRATED POWER AND ATTITUDE CONTROL SYSTEM (IPACS) TECHNOLOGY.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Oglevie, R.E., Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA; Eisenhaure, D.B., Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA, Rockwell Int, Downey, CA, USA
Abstract: Integrated power and attitude control system (IPACS) studies performed over a decade ago established the feasibility of storing electrical energy in flywheels and utilizing the resulting angular momentum for spacecraft attitude control. Evolving technology pertinent to IPACS is reviewed, and the impact of these advances on its applicability to future space missions is assessed. It is shown that technological advances over the last two decades in composite rotors, motor/generator electronics, and magnetic bearings support the use of IPACS for increasingly sophisticated applications. It is concluded that the concept offers potential performance advantages as well as savings in mass and life-cycle cost.

Abstract: System considerations for a magnetically suspended energy storage system are presented. The key technologies for system success are presented in a technology flowchart. The key areas identified and discussed include the active bearing control system, the back-up touchdown bearings, and the flywheel dynamic performance and balancing. Two possible hardware designs are described that have been identified as having characteristics suitable for energy storage in low-earth-orbit spacecraft. The current progress of inertial energy storage and the direction of future work are shown.

Authors: Otto Roland J., Berdahl Paul, Hunt Arlon J.
Title: ENERGY CONVERSION PROCESSES SUPPORTING ADVANCED THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE TECHNOLOGIES.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Otto, Roland J., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Berdahl, Paul, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA; Hunt, Arlon J., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA,, USA, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA, USA
Abstract: Research progress in two energy conversion processes is summarized and the associated storage technologies described. The two processes are particle-catalyzed solar photodissociation for thermochemical energy conversion and storage, and the controlled emission of thermal radiation using narrow-bandgap semiconductor materials. The thermochemical energy conversion research is focused on the study of endothermic dissociation of SO//3 through direct irradiation by concentrated sunlight. The reaction products, SO//2 and O//2 , are recombined to produce high temperatures for driving thermal processes. Research on narrow-bandgap semiconductor materials is being pursued for the development of a solid-state radiative heat pump. This work takes a fundamental approach to developing a solid-state technology having the potential for exceeding the COP of a vapor compression heat pump while providing unique capabilities for energy storage systems.

Abstract: The authors describe the further development of a woven-ribbon winding process for low-cost flywheel manufacturing. The first flywheels manufactured with this technique had an energy content of about 100 Wh, which is too low for large-scale flywheel energy storage systems. The scaling up of the process has been studied. A 200-Wh stacked flywheel has been built, and a 4. 5-kWh flywheel has been designed. Stacked and unstacked flywheel disks have been analyzed by modal analysis, and the results are presented.

Abstract: The paper undertakes the study of heat storage from solar source or other sources in accumulator-type heat exchangers with heat transfer surface, without phase change. Calculation bases are presented under the circumstances when the thermal regime is influenced by many factors: heat flux, primary agent flow and its mass in the system, secondary agent mass, overall heat transfer coefficient, initial temperatures of the fluids. The results of the experimental tests are in good agreement with the theory. The study aims to obtain, at design stage, data which should lead to optimizing heat storage installations and particularly those belonging to low temperature absorption refrigerating systems.

Title: FINAL DESIGN AND EVALUATION OF A 500 KW BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM FOR 1-HOUR PEAK SHAVING APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: GNB Inc, Langhorne, PA, USA, GNB Inc, Langhorne, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Deshpande, Sanjay, GNB Inc, Langhorne, PA, USA, GNB Inc, Langhorne, PA, USA; McClellan, Robert, GNB Inc, Langhorne, PA, USA, GNB Inc, Langhorne, PA, USA; Mills, John, GNB Inc, Langhorne, PA, USA, GNB Inc, Langhorne, PA, USA; Spindler, William, GNB Inc, Langhorne, PA, USA, GNB Inc, Langhorne, PA, USA
Abstract: To confirm the technical viability of large-scale lead-acid battery energy storage, a 500-kW battery and ac/dc converter have been evaluated by Public Service Electric & Gas Company. System design characteristics are emphasized in this review of the operating experiences. The battery has 324 cells contained in 54 6-cell modules. The energy storage is 500 kWh at the 1-h discharge rate, and 1. 2 MWh for a 5-h discharge. The battery has been tested in a series string of nominal 750 V and in three parallel strings of 250 V. The converter is a line-commutated 12-pulse module assembled from two 3-phase, 6-pulse bridge circuits connected to the utility through a 480-V/13. 8-kV transformer. Over 80 MWh of energy was delivered by the system in all the discharge profiles, for the equivalent of about 160 full cycles.

Abstract: A compact system that evaluates radioactive materials can furnish a big savings to taxpayers by ensuring that only properly identified nuclear waste is sent to a Department of Energy (DOE) radioactive waste storage area. The Los Alamos National Laboratory's Advanced Nuclear Technology Group has developed and field tested two easily transportable, self-contained modules: one x-rays the contents of special 208-l shipment containers, the other assays the contents. The assay and evaluation system is a simple, portable solution to a complex problem that ensures that only properly packaged transuranic (TRU) waste is shipped to the Department of Energy's Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) near Carlsbad, New Mexico.
Index Keywords: NONDESTRUCTIVE EXAMINATION; NDE MODULE; NONDESTRUCTIVE ASSAY SYSTEM; WASTE ISOLATION PILOT PLANT; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Title: DESIGN OF A SOLAR POWER PLANT FOR FREEZE DESALINATION.
Affiliations: Foster-Miller Inc, Foster-Miller Inc
Authors with affiliations: Krepchin, Ira, Foster-Miller Inc, Foster-Miller Inc; Torbin, Robert, Foster-Miller Inc, Foster-Miller Inc
Abstract: A solar-powered seawater desalination plant recently began operating in Yanbu, Saudi Arabia. Design and construction were funded by SOLERAS, a joint effort by the United States and Saudi Arabia to further the development and commercialization of solar energy. The plant consists of 18 parabolic dish solar collectors with a total reflective surface of 1,445 m**2 and a thermal output of over 1 MW. Its rated output is 200 m**3 per day of fresh water. The collectors heat a synthetic heat transfer fluid, Syltherm(TRADE MARK) 800. The heated fluid, in turn, charges a molten salt buffer system. On demand, the molten salt is pumped from a two tank storage system through a steam generator, producing superheated steam. The steam is expanded through a steam engine which provides the shaft power that drives the compressors of the desalination system. This paper will describe the solar plant and some of the trade-off studies that led to the final configuration.
Index Keywords: DESALINATION; SEAWATER - Salt Removal; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; FREEZE DESALINATION; PARABOLIC DISH; TRADE-OFF STUDIES; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Source title: I Mech E Conference Publications (Institution of Mechanical Engineers)
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: 16 papers were presented at this conference on integrated engine transmission Systems. The papers presented investigate among other things different integrations of individual components like engine, gear box, clutch and driveline. Engine transmission matching, the use of automatic or semi- automatic gear boxes in heavy goods vehicles and the difference between hydrostatic continuously variable transmission and a stepped ratio transmission are some of the aspects studied. The vehicles considered include buses, trucks, rail vehicles, and military tanks.

Title: BATTERY REQUIREMENTS FOR URBAN ELECTRIC VANS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: US DOE, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Patil, P.G., US DOE, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA; Walsh, W.J., US DOE, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The US Department of Energy has carried out an intensive study of battery requirements for electric vans and developed a mission-directed goals package for each of the principal battery contenders for this application. A light-weight, low-rolling-resistance van with an improved version of the ac powertrain was chosen as the hypothetical baseline vehicle. A modified FUDS cycle was selected along with assumptions of 3 m**2 frontal area, 0. 37 drag coefficient, and 0. 008 rolling resistance. State-of-art characteristics and design interrelationships were developed for each battery technology, and the degree of advance expected by 1995 was projected. For each battery candidate, a least-cost combination of performance and operating characteristics was determined. The resultant R&D goals for the electric van battery are presented, including early-in-life and end-of-life energy over the drive cycle, peak power, battery weight and volume, battery life, costs, and allowable frequency of repair.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Costs; DUAL SHAFT ELECTRIC PROPULSION (DSEP); EARLY-VS END-OF-LIFE BATTERY CAPABILITY; URBAN ELECTRIC VANS; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Title: MATERIALS HANDLING.
Source title: Proceedings of the International Centre for Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Twente Univ of Technology, Enschede, Neth, Twente Univ of Technology, Enschede, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Rademacher, F.J.C., Twente Univ of Technology, Enschede, Neth, Twente Univ of Technology, Enschede, Neth; Haaker, G., Twente Univ of Technology, Enschede, Neth, Twente Univ of Technology, Enschede, Neth
Abstract: The current world energy situation has focused attention on the dwindling supplies of fuel oil and consequently considerable attention is being given to the increased use of coal as a source of fuel. From the literature it appears that the process of feeding coal into a fluid bed combustor is still not without its problems and certainly not optimised. Although the great diffusion that exists inside the bed of this type of combustor is claimed to be a major advantage, it has its natural limitations. In order to gain both an equally distributed thermal load throughout the bed and a good combustion efficiency, it is desirable to distribute the incoming coal as uniformly as possible over the bed area.
Index Keywords: COMBUSTION - Fluidized Beds; MATERIALS HANDLING; ATMOSPHERIC FLUIDIZED BED COMBUSTORS; BULK SOLIDS HANDLING FEEDERS; BULK SOLIDS STORAGE; COAL SPREADER; COAL COMBUSTION

Authors: Phillips Wayne M., Stearns John W.
Title: ALKALI METAL/HALIDE THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS PERFORMANCE EVALUATION.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, Wayne M., JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA; Stearns, John W., JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA, JPL, Pasadena, CA, USA
Abstract: Materials compatibility and durability of advanced salt/alkali metal slurry thermal energy storage systems has been demonstrated. Understanding of the mechanism of both micro and macro stratification of the slurry is necessary to fully predict system performance as a function of gravity and system geometry. It can be shown that gravity stratification effects are secondary to a combination of: 1) adhesion (wetting) of liquid-metal film to the heat exchange surfaces and solidified salt particles, 2) solubility of alkali metal in the salt-rich phase, and 3) stirring produced by liquid-to-vapor conversion of the alkali metal, then system geometry limitations are greatly relaxed for space application. The performance testing was accomplished using a sodium heat pipe to transfer heat from the slurry canister to a gas-gap calorimeter. Testing was accomplished with the heat pipe installed only in the vapor space above the alkali metal/salt slurry. This testing conclusively demonstrated the effectiveness of the pseudo-heat-pipe type of heat transfer mechanism in the slurry system operating under terrestrial conditions.
Index Keywords: HEAT PIPES; HEAT TRANSFER; LIQUID METALS; SALTS; SODIUM AND ALLOYS; ALKALI METAL/SALT SLURRY; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Title: ADVANCES IN FLYWHEEL TECHNOLOGY FOR SPACE POWER APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Olszewski, M., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA; O'Kain, D.U., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Natl Lab, TN, USA
Abstract: A high-performance flywheel energy storage system is described that has demonstrated high-speed capability using carbon-composite flywheel rims. A burst speed of 1405 m/s was achieved with a 7. 28 MJ flywheel demonstration unit. The specific energy of the rim in this unit was 878 kJ/kg (244 Wh/kg). The aim is to develop a high-performance flywheel energy storage module with a total stored energy of 1 GJ; anticipated operating speed is in the range of 1100-1200 m/s.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; CARBON-COMPOSITE FLYWHEEL RIMS; FLYWHEELS

Authors: Pidcoke L.H., Gay R.L., Lee W.T.
Title: THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE EXPERIMENTS FOR SPACE APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Int Corp, Rockwell Int Corp
Authors with affiliations: Pidcoke, L.H., Rockwell Int Corp, Rockwell Int Corp; Gay, R.L., Rockwell Int Corp, Rockwell Int Corp; Lee, W.T., Rockwell Int Corp, Rockwell Int Corp
Abstract: The authors have conducted a series of tests to investigate phase change materials (PCMs) for thermal energy storage for space applications. The thermal energy storage subsystem provides energy to a solar dynamic heat engine during the eclipse portion of an earth orbit and absorbs heat during the sunlit portion of each orbit. The first series of experiments that were conducted with LiOH salt is described. Laboratory measurements of heating and cooling profiles have been used to verify a computer model used for the subsequent thermal energy storage vessel design. Laboratory thermal cycling tests of sealed canisters of thermal energy storage salt have been conducted to determine canister integrity and corrosion under thermal cycling conditions. On the basis of the tests, a thermal energy storage vessel containing 37 canisters has been built and tested in a pilot-scale pumped-liquid-sodium thermal tests facility. The experiment was successful and formed the basis for the design of a 117-canister thermal energy storage vessel which in turn has been tested and shown to provide a basis for future thermal storage designs.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; HEAT ENGINES; SOLAR ENERGY - Space Applications; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Title: OPTIMIZATION OF A PACKED BED OF ENCAPSULATED PHASE-CHANGE MATERIAL FOR THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Abstract: A simple search method is used to find the optimal geometry and particle diameter of a packed bed of phase-change material for thermal energy storage. For a given bed volume and fluid flow rate, and a total charging time, a length of the bed and a particle diameter that maximize the ratio of total availability to total pumping energy are shown to exist, and a method is demonstrated to find the appropriate values.

Abstract: Condensed-phase explosives are an extremely compact form of energy storage characterized by a high rate of release. The conversion of chemical energy of explosives to electrical pulse energy is considered and discussed, with particular regard to explosive magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) generators. The conversion efficiency of these devices is low, with demonstrated values of less than 10%. However, the power density is very high. The devices continue to be a significant part of the pulsed-power program in the Soviet Union.

Abstract: The economic potential of biomass plantations is being evaluated by the School of Forest Resources at Pennsylvania State University in cooperation with the US Department of Energy. The project has provided growth and yield information on a Populus hybrid grown under four production strategies on two dissimilar sites as well as financial and energy analyses of the production strategies. The production alternatives were further analyzed in tandem with harvesting and storage options to determine the least-cost configuration for an integrated biomass supply system. The authors identify the technical parameters and costs for alternate biomass supply systems and present a comparison of their unit-biomass costs within the conversion requirements of electrical generation and ethanol production.

Abstract: Methods are described for real-time control of the energy applied to loading using a thyristor-diode commutator. Calculated and experimental data about the staged change in energy from 250 to 500 J with a change in the control pulse duration from 30 to 200 mu sec are presented.

Abstract: The Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) in New Mexico is being developed by the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) to demonstrate the safe storage of defense-related radioactive wastes in bedded salt. Pretest 3-D finite element creep calculations of the wedge pillar experiment have been performed. The calculation shows that the horizontal closure of the drifts on either side of the wedge pillar increase with distance from the tip of the wedge. Vertical closure is greatest at the tip of the wedge.

Title: BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM FOR THE BERLIN (WEST) INSULAR SUPPLY SYSTEM.

Abstract: The electric supply system of West Berlin has been running as an insular system since 1952. In order to maintain sufficient power for load frequency control and instantaneous reserve, a battery energy storage plant has been put into service. Its nominal power is plus or minus 8. 5 MW for load frequency control and 8. 5 MW/30-min for instantaneous reserves; the latter can be increased to 17 MW/10 min. The decision to install this plant is based on experience from the five-year operation of a test facility where an advanced lead-acid battery was tested to determine service life, efficiency, and operational behavior.

Authors with affiliations: Bilgen, E., Ecole Polytechnique, Montreal, Que,, Can, Ecole Polytechnique, Montreal, Que, Can
Abstract: A chemical energy storage and transportation system is conceived that is based on sulfuric acid decomposition and synthesis processes using hot oxygen as a vector. A thermodynamic assessment is carried out to determine the thermal performance of the process. It is found that the energy storage density is about 0. 58 GJ/m**3 for 365 cycles per year operation, the overall thermal energy storage efficiency is about 62%, the energy transportation efficiency is about 29%, and the thermal-to-mechanical energy conversion efficiency is about 25%.

Title: HIGH SPEED, SNUBBERLESS OPERATION OF GTO'S USING A NEW GATE DRIVE TECHNIQUE.
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Allen-Bradley, Milwaukee, WI, USA, Allen-Bradley, Milwaukee, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wirth, W.Frederick, Allen-Bradley, Milwaukee, WI, USA, Allen-Bradley, Milwaukee, WI, USA
Abstract: GTOs can be operated at currents well beyond the rated I//t//c//s//m m without turn-off snubbers by use of a gate drive circuit that is capable of very high rates of rise of reverse gate current. This results in a large rectangular unsnubbed reverse biased safe operating area (RBSOA) that extends to the V//d//r//x//m on the voltage axis and beyond the I//t//c//s//m on the current axis. Storage time is reduced to a few tenths of a microsecond and the inductance required for paralleling is reduced by an order of magnitude. Elimination of the turn-off snubber capacitors allows protective circuit trip levels to be set closer to the device ratings and reduces the energy loss in the turn-on snubber. The size of the turn-on snubber inductor can be significantly reduced. High-frequency operation of GTOs becomes practical with this technique due to the short storage times and low external snubber losses.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC SWITCHES, SEMICONDUCTOR; GTO THYRISTORS; REVERSE BIASED SAFE OPERATING AREA; SNUBBERLESS OPERATION; TURN-ON SNUBBER INDUCTOR; THYRISTORS

Title: V4-275R STIRLING ENGINE IN UNDERWATER APPLICATION.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sub Power AB, Sub Power AB
Authors with affiliations: Nilsson, H., Sub Power AB, Sub Power AB; Bratt, C., Sub Power AB, Sub Power AB
Abstract: The Stirling power module V4-275R, integrated with a liquid oxygen system, is currently being built for the Royal Swedish Navy and for the offshore company Comex in France. The Stirling engine system for the Swedish Navy has been successfully tested in a full-scale submarine test section for about 400 h. The next step in this program will be an integration of the Stirling system into an operational Swedish submarine. The French program involves a 500-ton, manned diver lockout submarine, the SAGA 1, which is under final construction. The energy system for the submarine consists of two V4-275R Stirling engines of maximum 100-kW power each. The oxygen storage consists of two liquid oxygen tanks with a total capability of 10,000 kWh, allowing the submarine to perform missions of up to 14 days submerged.
