Title: ELECTRON SHIELD CURRENTS FOLLOWING FORCED DECLINE OF VACUUM ARC CURRENT.
Affiliations: Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Neth, Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Neth
Authors with affiliations: Smeets, R.P.P., Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Neth, Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Neth
Abstract: When ramping down a vacuum arc current with a sufficiently high di/dt, a grounded vapor shield can temporarily act as an anode. This is due to an inductive shift of plasma potential relative to shield potential. As a result a small amount of magnetic energy is stored at zero circuit current in the parasitic inductances formed by the cathode support and the shield to ground connection. This energy can sustain cathode spot emission for several hundred ns after circuit current reaches zero. Such a postzero emission can postpone the onset of vacuum gap recovery, as shown by recovery experiments probing the gap with HV pulses and measuring the breakdown voltages at a number of times during the first microsecond following current zero. By varying HV pulse polarity and shield potential, recovery was studied during this period. Electron shield currents could also be detected as a result of high di/dt caused by spontaneous instabilities in low current vacuum arcs.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC MEASUREMENTS - Current; ELECTRIC SHIELDING - Electronic Properties; ELECTRODES - Energy Storage; BREAKDOWN VOLTAGE; CATHODE SPOT EMISSION; ELECTRON SHIELD CURRENT; VACUUM ARC CURRENT FORCED DECLINE; VACUUM GAP RECOVERY; ELECTRIC ARCS

Authors with affiliations: Cartier, E., Brown Boveri Research Cent, Baden, Switz, Brown Boveri Research Cent, Baden, Switz; Pfluger, P., Brown Boveri Research Cent, Baden, Switz, Brown Boveri Research Cent, Baden, Switz
Abstract: The authors present experimental evidence for hot-electron-induced chemical damage as a cause of dielectric aging. They have studied hot-electron-induced electron traps in thin films using a combination of the IPTA (internal photoemission for transport analysis) method and standard techniques usually called TSEE and OSEE (thermally and Optically Stimulated Exoelectron Emission). The authors also present experimental results on as-grown films and data on hot-electron-induced electron traps in the linear hydrocarbon n-C//3 //6 H//7 //4 , which they as a model for polyethylene. The results show that charge storage and chemical damage can be investigated by the experimental procedure described and that it should be possible to determine damage rates as a function of dose and energy of hot electrons.
Index Keywords: CHARGE STORAGE; THIN DIELECTRIC FILMS; RADIATION DAMAGE - Microscopic Examination; SPECTROSCOPY, ELECTRON; DIELECTRIC MATERIALS

Title: STRUCTURAL DESIGN OF A UTILITY SCALE SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE PLANT.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Bechtel Group Inc, San Francisco,, CA, USA, Bechtel Group Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Loyd, R.J., Bechtel Group Inc, San Francisco,, CA, USA, Bechtel Group Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA; Schoenung, S.M., Bechtel Group Inc, San Francisco,, CA, USA, Bechtel Group Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA; Nakamura, T., Bechtel Group Inc, San Francisco,, CA, USA, Bechtel Group Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA
Abstract: Recent developments in the conceptual design of a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) plant for utility load-leveling application have advanced the technology to a level where demonstration on a small scale would be an appropriate next step. A design concept is described that resolves the structural difficulty of accommodating high operating stresses. This, in addition to recent developments in conductor design and coil protection, result in a technically feasible design. The cost of a 5000-MWh plant is shown to be economically competitive with other energy storage options.

Authors: Petri Randy J., Ong Estella T., Martin James
Title: HIGH TEMPERATURE COMPOSITE THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE (TES) SYSTEMS FOR INDUSTRIAL APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL,, USA, Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Petri, Randy J., Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL,, USA, Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL, USA; Ong, Estella T., Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL,, USA, Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL, USA; Martin, James, Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL,, USA, Inst of Gas Technology, Chicago, IL, USA
Abstract: An advanced thermal energy storage (TES) subsystem is being developed that uses a family of composite phase change material (PCM)/sensible heat media (CompPhase). The basic and engineering research efforts have focused on the development of these media for low (400 degree F) and high (900 to 2500 degree F) temperature regimes. As such, the subsystem is amenable to high-temperature storage applications such as industrial reject/process heat recovery and utilization, off-peak utility, solar thermal, solar chemical and fuels, and space solar dynamic power systems. The concept allows direct contact heat exchange between the latent/sensible storage media and compatible working fluids, with a number of potentially significant performance and cost advantages over conventionally tube-intensive indirect-contact storage systems based on molten-salt latent heat. A flexible composite heat transfer model has been developed and enhanced to simulate the thermal cyclic environment of a typical brick ceramic plant, for which simulation results are presented.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER; HIGH TEMPERATURE ENGINEERING; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Title: DESIGN FEATURES AND COMMERCIAL POTENTIAL OF SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE FOR ELECTRIC UTILITY APPLICATION.
Affiliations: Bechtel Natl Inc, San Francisco, CA,, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Loyd, Robert J., Bechtel Natl Inc, San Francisco, CA,, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA; Schoenung, Susan, Bechtel Natl Inc, San Francisco, CA,, USA, Bechtel Natl Inc, San Francisco, CA, USA
Abstract: Today's declining load factors, increasing base load generation, and large fuel price differentials point to the need for increased use of energy storage by electric utilities. Historically, energy storage in the United States has been provided by a few pumped hydroelectric plants, but siting constraints and high cost severely limit the use of this option. Two other options which will soon be in use are batteries and compressed air energy storage. A fourth option, currently being developed for load leveling is Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES). This paper reports the design features and estimated costs of utility scale SMES plants. For moderate discharge duration, SMES is projected to have substantially lower revenue requirements and better availability than other load leveling options. The Electric Power Research Institute has prepared a plan for commercialization which could, if aggressively pursued, lead to a demonstrated SMES technology that is available for utility commitment by the late 1990's.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Energy Storage; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; BASE LOAD GENERATION; LOAD FACTORS; LOAD LEVELING; SMES; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Title: FIELD EXPERIMENTS OF THE SOLAR ENERGY COLLECTION AND AQUIFER SEASONAL STORAGE IN THE SNOW-MELTING SYSTEM ON THE ROOF.

Affiliations: JNR, Tokyo, Jpn, JNR, Tokyo, Jpn

Abstract: Field experiments were conducted to collect solar energy and to store the energy in an aquifer using a novel snow-melting system of melting snow on the roof. Solar energy of 158 GJ was collected by sprinkling water on the roof, measuring 2500 m**2 , during 45 days during the summer of 1984. In this period, a volume of water 10,300 m**3 that had been heated to 30 degree C by a boiler was charged into a well whose depth was 194 m. During winter, 38% of the total amount of energy charged into the well was recovered. The performance coefficient was 5. 64 for solar energy collection and 1. 76 for snow melting in the solar collection area.

Authors: Stout R.D., Tarby S.K., Wiersma S.J.
Title: FRACTURE TOUGHNESS OF MODERN 9% NICKEL CRYOGENIC STEELS.
Affiliations: Lehigh Univ, USA, Lehigh Univ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Stout, R.D., Lehigh Univ, USA, Lehigh Univ, USA; Tarby, S.K., Lehigh Univ, USA, Lehigh Univ, USA; Wiersma, S.J., Lehigh Univ, USA, Lehigh Univ, USA
Abstract: Storage tanks for liquefied natural gas must contain a highly flammable gas at minus 162 degree C ( minus 260 degree F) with an ample margin of safety. The 9% nickel steels have served in more than 50 LNG tanks without failure for over a decade. An important ingredient of crack-arrest is the large energy absorption by the surface layers of these relatively thin storage tank gages. While welding planar flaws and property alteration in the weld heat-affected zone may have adverse effects on welded joints, the excellent fracture toughness of the austenitic weld metal used in tanks compensates for these effects.

Authors with affiliations: Vaughan, N.D., Univ of Bath, Avon, Engl, Univ of Bath, Avon, Engl; Dorey, R.E., Univ of Bath, Avon, Engl, Univ of Bath, Avon, Engl
Abstract: This paper is concerned with the sizing and selection of an hydraulic accumulator system for regenerative braking in a city bus and with an evaluation by computer simulation of alternatives for its integration in the vehicle driveline. The paper builds upon earlier work published by the authors which has considered typical duty cycle and performance data for the bus. This is reviewed and used to justify the choice of accumulator system. Here the accumulator system is considered in conjunction with both conventional and hydrostatic split power transmissions, and the effect upon bus performance determined for operation over a typical route.

Abstract: More than 20 14-kWh/21-kW sodium/sulfur batteries have been produced and tested. Bench testing yielded a specific power of 105 W/kg at 2/3 OCV, a specific energy of 70 Wh/kg at 2 hours discharge time, and a life of 300 cycles. On-vehicle tests resulted in considerably improved drive characteristics compared to lead-acid batteries. A larger battery with higher power (34 kW) and energy (21 kWh) leading to about a 15% higher specific power and energy has also been developed and is being tested.

Abstract: Zinc chloride battery technology is the leading candidate for utility energy storage. The authors describe the successful test of a 500-kWh, 100-kW zinc chloride battery system at the Battery Energy Storage Test (BEST) Facility. The present status of commercial hardware (2-MW FLEXPOWER units for utility and customer-side-of-the-meter peak shaving) is presented, and the design, assembly, and testing of a 125-kW stack/sump module (the repeating unit of FLEXPOWER) in a complete system are described.

Title: THERMAL-ENERGY STORAGE IN A DEEP SANDSTONE AQUIFER IN MINNESOTA: FIELD OBSERVATIONS AND THERMAL ENERGY-TRANSPORT MODELING.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: US Geological Survey, St. Paul, MN,, USA, US Geological Survey, St. Paul, MN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Miller, R.T., US Geological Survey, St. Paul, MN,, USA, US Geological Survey, St. Paul, MN, USA
Abstract: A study of the feasibility of storing heated water in a deep sandstone aquifer in Minnesota is described. The aquifer consists of four hydraulic zones that are areally anisotropic and have average hydraulic conductivities that range from 0. 03 to 1. 2 meters per day. A preliminary axially symmetric, nonisothermal, isotropic, single-phase, radial-flow, thermal-energy-transport model was constructed to investigate the sensitivity of model simulation to various hydraulic and thermal properties of the aquifer. A three-dimensional flow and thermal-energy transport model was constructed to incorporate the areal anisotropy of the aquifer. Analytical solutions of equations describing areally anisotropic groundwater flow around a doublet-well system were used to specify model boundary conditions for simulation of heat injection. The entire heat-injection-testing period of approximately 400 days was simulated. Model-computed temperatures compared favorably with field-recorded temperatures, with differences of no more than plus or minus 8 degree C. For each test cycle, model-computed aquifer thermal efficiency, defined as total heat withdrawn divided by total heat injected, was within plus or minus 2% of the field-calculated values.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS; COMPUTER PROGRAMMING; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Boundary Value Problems; DEEP-SANDSTONE AQUIFERS; ENERGY TRANSPORT MODELING; HEATING

Title: HUNTSMAN AND WEST ENGELLAND FIELDS, CHEYENNE COUNTY, NEBRASKA: A CASE HISTORY OF TECHNICAL LESSONS FROM A LEGAL CONFLICT.

Authors with affiliations: Tek, M.R., Univ of New South Wales, Aust, Univ of New South Wales, Aust; Coleman, D.D., Univ of New South Wales, Aust, Univ of New South Wales, Aust; Parker, J.M., Univ of New South Wales, Aust, Univ of New South Wales, Aust
Abstract: During the years 1982-85, a lengthy litigation took place between KN Energy and Marathon Oil Corp. The case involved performance of two fields on structures adjacent to a common saddle and suspected migration of storage gas into the gas cap of a producing oil field. After some 3 years of extensive study, discovery proceedings and preparations, the case came to trial in U. S. District Court in Lincoln, Nebraska, 8 July 1985. After nearly a month in court, agreement was reached between the parties to settle the case on 6 August 1985. The purpose of this paper is not to redress and reargue the legal controversy. Rather, it is to share the technical forum of gas technology, the lessons learned from the synergistic study leading to a forensic conclusion. Application and calculations involving inventory verification methods, production-pressure trends, study of well records, gas-water, gas-oil contacts, computer simulation by finite element method, and identification of resident gas by isotope chemistry are among areas highlighted by specific examples.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; GEOCHEMISTRY - Groundwater; LEGISLATION; PETROLEUM GEOLOGY; CASE HISTORY; LEGAL CONFLICT; MIGRATION; TECHNICAL LESSONS; PETROLEUM RESERVOIR ENGINEERING

Abstract: Increasing the firing percent solids of black liquor to a Tomlinson recovery furnace represents energy and capacity opportunities at existing installations. Analysis of high solids evaporation technologies indicates that storage, handling and firing of high solids liquor and capital cost are key factors controlling the practicality and economic feasibility of pushing higher solids firing.

Abstract: Thermodynamics and heat transfer pertinent to waste heat recovery are introduced together with the selection of optimum working fluids. Effective means of waste heat recovery are presented for the high, moderate and low temperature levels of the effluents. They are the liquid-liquid direct-contact method, adsorbing-regenerating fluidized beds, and heat-pipe operated heat exchangers for low-level thermal energy; heat storage by thermochemical cycle and latent heat technique for moderate level; and enthalpy-radiation energy conversion method and radiation plate method for high level.

Abstract: Chernobyl has pushed waste disposal into second place as the aspect of nuclear energy that most concerns the public. Nevertheless if there is to be a second nuclear era, the issue of waste disposal must be resolved. This paper proposes solutions to the nuclear waste disposal problem.

Title: AUTOMATIC ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM BASED ON GENERATOR SCHEDULING AND MEDIUM TERM PLANNING.

Authors with affiliations: Brugger, H., Siemens AG Oesterreich, Austria, Siemens AG Oesterreich, Austria; Giddey, M.C., Siemens AG Oesterreich, Austria, Siemens AG Oesterreich, Austria
Abstract: An automatic energy management system based on generator scheduling and medium-term planning was realized for an electric company including a SCADA system. The schedules, delivered by the planning programs, are executed directly without connecting link. In a closed loop the load fluctuations and the deviations from the forecast are automatically detected and immediately adapted to the new status by initiating a new calculation. Preliminary postulates for a reliable operating closed loop are accurate and appropriate models of the power plant and the hydro storage. The exact adaptation of the parameters of the models is possible by the closed loop.
Index Keywords: ENERGY MANAGEMENT - Automation; CLOSED LOOP; GENERATOR SCHEDULING; LOAD CURVES; LOAD FLUCTUATIONS; MEDIUM TERM PLANNING; SCADA SYSTEM; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Abstract: This paper presents solutions to the extensive corrosion problems affecting recuperators in Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) applications. Two advanced designs for a 50 MW CAES plant were engineered: (a) a two-section counterflow arrangement with a replaceable cold end section which operates with tube wall temperatures below the exhaust gas dew point temperature, (b) a three-section design with a flow arrangement which eliminates tube wall temperatures below the exhaust gas dew point temperature. Presented in this paper are a general description, design specifics, performance and cost data for these two conceptual designs. Technical and economic analyses were performed to determine the most practical and economic design.

Abstract: Thermal performance characteristics of a submerged-phase change material cell using paraffin wax are reported. Two models are introduced which describe the thermal behavior of a thermal storage subsystem powered by a liquid type heat transfer fluid. The overall thermal response and effectiveness of this kind of storage system as a function of both coil flow rate and temperature difference between inlet water and tank bulk temperature are presented. This information is very useful in designing submerged-PCM heat exchangers for waste heat recovery systems.

Abstract: This paper outlines the consideration of alternative energy storage application for a modern Public Service Vehicle leading to the fitment of the Volvo Cumulo system to a Volvo underfloor engined 'Citybus'. Test results are included indicating the degree of savings experienced on different types of routes showing that this system cannot be justified on a universal basis. Only service operation will determine the maintenance level required for the system which is now to be obtained.

Authors: Cha Gueesoo, Hahn Songyop, Won Jongsoo
Title: ASYMMETRICALLY CONTROLLED 6-PULSE CONVERTER FOR SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNET ENERGY STORAGE (SMES).
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Seoul Natl Univ, Seoul, South Korea, Seoul Natl Univ, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Cha, Gueesoo, Seoul Natl Univ, Seoul, South Korea, Seoul Natl Univ, Seoul, South Korea; Hahn, Songyop, Seoul Natl Univ, Seoul, South Korea, Seoul Natl Univ, Seoul, South Korea; Won, Jongsoo, Seoul Natl Univ, Seoul, South Korea, Seoul Natl Univ, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: It is shown that a six-pulse converter instead of a 12-pulse converter can be used for the control of superconducting magnet energy storage (SMES) to improve the stability and to suppress the voltage fluctuation of a power system. An asymmetrically controlled six-pulse converter has been used to simultaneously control the real power and the reactive power. In order to prevent commutation failure which may arise from asymmetrical control, a stable control region is identified by analyzing the commutation phenomena at critical points which distinguish the stable control region from the unstable control region. Harmonic components of line current and output voltage are calculated. Computer simulation of power system stabilization has been presented to show the effectiveness of the proposed method. According to the computation results, SMES controlled by the six-pulse converter is an effective measure in reducing the oscillation and the transient instability of the power system.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC COMMUTATION; ENERGY STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS; ASYMMETRIC CONTROL; HARMONIC COMPONENTS; POWER CONVERSION HARMONICS; SIX-PULSE CONVERTER; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNET ENERGY STORAGE (SMES); ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE

Authors: Schubert F.H., Hoberecht M.A., Le M.

Affiliations: Life Systems, Life Systems
Authors with affiliations: Schubert, F.H., Life Systems, Life Systems; Hoberecht, M.A., Life Systems, Life Systems; Le, M., Life Systems, Life Systems
Abstract: A regenerative fuel cell system concept is described that consists of a dedicated water electrolysis subsystem, a fuel cell subsystem, reactant oxygen, hydrogen, and water storage assemblies and controls This design is a major candidate for the space station ESS (energy storage system) on the basis of projected launch weight, efficiency, volume, flexibility (i. e. , peak power and contingencies), adaptability to cyclic operation, and the existence of a strong technology base on which to build. The authors present the results of the technology development efforts to date and use them to make projections for the space station ESS sizing.

Abstract: Recent activities and results in a zinc-bromine battery development program are presented. Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Authors with affiliations: Vardiashvili, A.B.; Kim, V.D.
Abstract: Heat exchange in thermal-storage channels is determined by the temperature-humidity regime in a solar greenhouse and occurs on account of natural convection and the change in moisture content of air in the channels. In the daytime, during charging, condensate forms on walls of the channel; at night, during discharging, evaporation of moisture from the surface of channel walls is observed. A dimensionless dependence is illustrated, which characterizes heat exchange with natural convection in inclined channels.
Index Keywords: EVAPORATION; HEATING - Solar; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; SOLAR RADIATION - Energy Storage; MOISTURE; NATURAL CONVECTION; SOLAR GREENHOUSES; TEMPERATURE-HUMIDITY REGIME; THERMAL-STORAGE CHANNELS; GREENHOUSES

Title: WIND POWER FOR WATER PUMPING.
Authors with affiliations: Mueller, A.M.; Jansen, W.A.M.
Abstract: The Consultancy Services Wind Energy Developing Countries (CWD) of the Netherlands promotes the interest in wind energy in developing countries and aims to help governments, institutions, and private parties in the Third World with their efforts to utilize wind energy. The CWD has developed a number of standard wind pump models and special versions to suit various purposes. The design process is determined by CWD's aim to enable local production in developing countries. An analysis permits a quick, economic comparison of wind pumps combined with storage tanks and Diesel pumps intended for use in small-scale irrigation. Some general conclusions reached during the course of the study are presented.
Index Keywords: DIESEL ENGINES; WELL PUMPS; WIND TURBINES; CONSULTANCY SERVICES WIND ENERGY DEVELOPING COUNTRIES (CWD); WIND POWER

Authors: Wilkins B.J., Liner Y., Rigby G.L.
Title: ESTIMATIONS OF CHANGES IN MICROCRACK-POPULATION, ELASTIC MODULUS, AND PERMEABILITY, DUE TO DIFFERENTIAL-THERMAL EXPANSION IN PLUTONIC ROCK SURROUNDING A NUCLEAR FUEL WASTE DISPOSAL VAULT.
Affiliations: AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can
Authors with affiliations: Wilkins, B.J., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Liner, Y., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can; Rigby, G.L., AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can, AECL, Pinawa, Manit, Can
Abstract: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited is studying the disposal of nuclear-fuel-waste in a vault in plutonic rock. An important part of this study is to develop models to assess the rate of escape of waste components to the biosphere. In these models time-dependent changes in the system are important. This paper describes the model devised to estimate the extent of microcracking in rock surrounding a vault, and the anticipated changes in rock elastic modulus and permeability. The model is applied to a possible vault, located at various depths in plutonic rock typical and the Canadian Shield. It estimates the dimensions of an envelope outside of which the influence of the vault on microcracking will be negligible.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR ENERGY - Canada; NUCLEAR FUELS - Storage; ROCK - Crystalline; MICROCRACK POPULATION; NUCLEAR FUEL WASTE DISPOSAL VAULT; PLUTONIC ROCK; TIME DEPENDENT CHANGES; RADIOACTIVE WASTES

Abstract: The work presented in this paper covers the design and construction of a magnetic bearing assembly for flywheel energy storage applications. A pancake magnetic bearing is described and the geometry of the bearing, which governs the radial weight carrying capacity and the size of permanent and electromagnets, is presented. A design model for magnetic force computation is developed, based on the use of an equivalent electric circuit for the magnetic system, and results of applying the model are presented. The bearing control system is analyzed by simulating its response to perturbations.

Affiliations: Snamprogetti SpA, San Donato Milanese, Italy, Snamprogetti SpA, San Donato Milanese, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Ercolani, D., Snamprogetti SpA, San Donato Milanese, Italy, Snamprogetti SpA, San Donato Milanese, Italy; Grinzi, F., Snamprogetti SpA, San Donato Milanese, Italy, Snamprogetti SpA, San Donato Milanese, Italy; Romani, G., Snamprogetti SpA, San Donato Milanese, Italy, Snamprogetti SpA, San Donato Milanese, Italy
Abstract: Snamprogetti technology for coal-water slurries has expanded very rapidly in the past two years and it can be said that there are no technical obstacles today to the commercial development of slurry fuels with our Reocarb technology. The main target is an optimum use of coal according to its type, quality and location, and this can be achieved with an accurate balance of CWM production requirements, transportation and storage constraints, utilization specifications and, obviously, an overall economic evaluation. Reocarb, the coal-water fuel prepared according to the Snamprogetti process has been produced on a continuous basis; the slurry has been successfully pumped, shipped and stored on a long term basis and have also demonstrated that it can be burned with high carbon conversion, even in oil designed boilers.

Abstract: The storage and disposal of nuclear waste requires effective quality assurance of the immobilisation process. It is proposed that Intermediate Level Wastes (ILW) are mixed with concrete or other binding materials and cast into steel drums. Various methods of nondestructive examination have been considered. One technique which emerged as an effective and suitable procedure was high energy radioscopy. This paper describes the development of this technique into an effective inspection system for ILW monoliths.

Authors: Morimoto Y., Hayashi T., Maeda Y.
Title: MOBILE SOLAR ENERGY HYDROGEN GENERATING SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Hoxan Corp, Sapporo, Jpn, Hoxan Corp, Sapporo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Morimoto, Y., Hoxan Corp, Sapporo, Jpn, Hoxan Corp, Sapporo, Jpn; Hayashi, T., Hoxan Corp, Sapporo, Jpn, Hoxan Corp, Sapporo, Jpn; Maeda, Y., Hoxan Corp, Sapporo, Jpn, Hoxan Corp, Sapporo, Jpn
Abstract: A mobile hydrogen generating system powered by photovoltaic energy has recently been developed. This system consists of a 10-kW photovoltaic system, solid polymer electrolyte, water tank, and hydrogen and oxygen gas storage tanks. Electricity generated from the PV system is fed directly to the solid polymer electrolyte, and water is electrolyzed, thus creating hydrogen and oxygen. This system is installed on a trailer chassis. The PV array collapses onto the trailer when being moved. The wings of the PV array can be spread spent so as to be able to face the sun or meet the latitude; thus gases can be generated anywhere. With this system, an average of 7 m**3 /day of hydrogen can be generated.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN - Production; WATER - Electrolysis; 10-KW PHOTOVOLTAIC ARRAY; MOBILE HYDROGEN GENERATING SYSTEM; PHOTOVOLTAIC ENERGY-POWERED SYSTEM; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: MATERIALS COMPATIBILITY ISSUES RELATED TO THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE FOR A SPACE SOLAR DYNAMIC POWER SYSTEM.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent,, Houston, TX, USA, NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, Houston, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Faget, Nanette M., NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent,, Houston, TX, USA, NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Cent, Houston, TX, USA
Abstract: Increasing electrical power requirements have made a solar dynamic power system (SDPS) a serious contender for the electrical power generating system for the NASA space station because of its potential advantages over a photovoltaic power system at higher power levels. An SDPS converts solar energy into electricity by utilizing rotating heat engines. A thermal energy storage (TES) system is required to supply the heat energy during the eclipsed portion of a low earth orbit. The TES system is considered to be the weakest link in the SDPS, largely because long-term (5-10 years) compatibility between the TES phase change material and its container has yet to be proved. The ongoing test program to establish material compatibility is described, and preliminary results and conclusions are presented.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; MATERIALS - Phase Transitions; SOLAR ENERGY - Space Applications; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; SOLAR DYNAMIC POWER SYSTEMS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Title: AQUIFER THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE EXPERIMENTS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA, ST. PAUL, MINNESOTA, U. S. A.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Minnesota, Minnesota, Geological Survey, St. Paul, MN, USA, Univ of Minnesota, Minnesota Geological Survey, St. Paul, MN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hoyer, Marcus C., Univ of Minnesota, Minnesota, Geological Survey, St. Paul, MN, USA, Univ of Minnesota, Minnesota Geological Survey, St. Paul, MN, USA; Walton, Matt, Univ of Minnesota, Minnesota, Geological Survey, St. Paul, MN, USA, Univ of Minnesota, Minnesota Geological Survey, St. Paul, MN, USA
Abstract: Four short-term and one long-term aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) experiments to examine the feasibility of storing water heated to temperatures from 100 degree to 150 degree C in a confined aquifer have been conducted. The facility uses a well doublet for supplying, storing, and recovering the heated ground water. Heat was supplied by a steam heating plant. Energy recovering during the four short-term cycles was 59, 46, 62, and 58%, respectively, of the energy added to the ground water during each cycle. Energy recovery during the long-term cycle was 62% of the energy added to the ground water during that cycle. The ground water is a calcium-magnesium bicarbonate water having a hardness of about 12 grains. For the short-term cycles a precipitator was successfully used to prevent scaling in the storage well. An ion-exchange water softener was used for the long-term cycle. Water recovered from storage had approximately reached equilibrium with respect to calcium carbonate and quartz.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS; ENERGY STORAGE; ION EXCHANGE; CALCIUM CARBONATE; HEATING

Title: EVALUATION AND POSSIBILITIES OF DIFFERENT CHEMICAL SYSTEMS AT MEDIUM AND HIGH TEMPERATURES FOR SEASONAL STORAGE.

Affiliations: Plataforma Solar de Almeria,, JEN-IER, Tabernas, Spain, Plataforma Solar de Almeria, JEN-IER, Tabernas, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Andujar, Peral, Plataforma Solar de Almeria,, JEN-IER, Tabernas, Spain, Plataforma Solar de Almeria, JEN-IER, Tabernas, Spain
Abstract: Some chemical systems, viewed as heat carriers, have been considered for seasonal storage. Some of them have been found to be economically competitive with electrical transport of heat, but is is shown that none can compete with the concept of a hybrid plant in which the heat in the period of low insolation is supplemented by the energy delivered by a fossil fuel.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS; INSOLATION; SEASONAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Authors: Hillstroem C-G, Brunstroem C., Larsson M.
Title: LYCKEBO PROJECT - ECONOMY AND MEASURED PERFORMANCE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: VIAK AB, Falun, Swed, VIAK AB, Falun, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Hillstroem, C-G, VIAK AB, Falun, Swed, VIAK AB, Falun, Swed; Brunstroem, C., VIAK AB, Falun, Swed, VIAK AB, Falun, Swed; Larsson, M., VIAK AB, Falun, Swed, VIAK AB, Falun, Swed
Abstract: Measured results from two years of operation of the Lyckebo solar district-heating plant with rock cavern seasonal storage are summarized. The original investment costs are presented, and the present and future economies of this type of system is discussed. During two years of operation 100% availability was obtained for energy distribution. Unexpectedly high losses are partly explained by heat losses from shafts and from a tunnel surrounding the cavern and by water leakage. The heat production of the collector field during 1985 was 294 KWh/m**2 at a mean delivery temperature of 81 degree C. Relatively high investment was needed, 4. 9 SEK/kWh-y and 10. 4 SEK/kWh-y for the built system and for the corresponding system with 100% collectors, based on costs when the Lyckebo system was constructed during 1982 and 1983. Significant cost reductions have, however, taken place during the past few years, and a number of ways to improve the cost/benefit ratio are indicated.

The heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) design for the building includes an option for the use of aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) on a seasonal basis. Abstract: This paper deals with magnets for high-energy-physics. Special consideration is given to the fabrication and testing of such magnets; examples of magnets actually fabricated for physical experiments are demonstrated. In particular, the manufacture of the B280 magnet for the CERN electron positron storage ring (LEP) is described.

Abstract: A zinc bromide battery of the circulating electrolyte type currently under development is described. In addition to abundant availability of active materials, high energy density and high power density, this battery has the following features: (1) operation at ambient temperature with easy maintenance and control; (2) conductive carbon-plastic electrodes suitable for mass production at low cost and for large-capacity applications; and (3) compact design based on a simple battery reaction, so that the battery can easily be composed and assembled. Test results and construction of the battery are discussed.

Title: DEVELOPMENT AND TESTING OF A REGENERATIVE DIESEL-HYDRAULIC POWER TRAIN FOR THE URBAN BUS.
Authors with affiliations: Heggie, W.S.; Davies, A.S.
Abstract: A retrofit package to hybridise the urban bus comprising hydro-pneumatic energy storage and controlled by a custom designed electronic processor control system is constructed and tested under average city operating conditions. The optimum accumular design in terms of stored energy per unit volume is shown to be less than ideal when considering the complete system. When this is compromised a well developed flow and control philosophy is shown to be capable of approximating theoretical predictions of improved fuel mileage, etc. with good drivability.

Title: Ecophysiology of Zigadenus nuttallii, a toxic spring ephemeral in a warm season grassland: effect of defoliation and fire
Affiliations: Division of Biology, Kansas State University, Manhattan, 66506, KS, United States
Authors with affiliations: Knapp, A.K., Division of Biology, Kansas State University, Manhattan, 66506, KS, United States
Abstract: Zigadenus nuttallii, a highly toxic spring ephemeral in tallgrass prairie, was studied in 1985 to ascertain: 1) several ecophysiological characteristics of the species, 2) seasonal patterns of biomass accumulation, and 3) its response to defoliation and fire. The maximum photosynthetic rate of Z. nuttallii measured in unburned prairie was 13.2 μmoles CO2 m-2 s-1 which occurred at 24-28° C and an incident quantum flux of 0.8-1.0 mmoles m-2 s-1. Maximum stomatal conductance measured was 5.4 mm s-1. Early in the season, belowground storage organs (bulbs) decreased in mass and supplied much of the energy for growth of leaves, even though CO2 uptake was possible. Buld mass did not increase until about 6 weeks after shoot emergence implying that, at this time, leaves had become a source rather than a sink for carbohydrates. The result of a single, severe defoliation event was a decrease in biomass of bulbs, leaves and reproductive structures in Z. nuttallii. Intrinsic compensatory mechanisms were not detected. In contrast, fire, which also defoliated plants, did not result in any biomass decrease at the end of the season. Improved post-fire microclimate and increased nutrient supply (extrinsic factors) may have contributed to higher photosynthetic rates and led to biomass compensation in burned prairie. These data support arguments that intrinsic compensatory mechanisms have evolved in response to chronic herbivory. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Carbon storage; Fire; Herbivory; Photosynthesis; Zigadenus

Authors: Isacson Orjan, Ewetz Johan, Lundgren Goran
Title: EFFECTS OF STATE SUPPORT ON INDUSTRY AND ON THE MARKET FOR SOLAR HEATING, HEAT PUMPS AND HEAT STORAGE.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Isacson, Orjan; Ewetz, Johan; Lundgren, Goran
Abstract: A considerable amount of work has been done by industry, the state and other organizations in Sweden since the middle of the 1970s on the development and introduction of solar heating, heat pump and heat storage technology. The objective of this investigation has been to study in detail the effects of state energy-related research, development and demonstration support on industry and on the markets for solar heating, heat pumps and heat stores. Particular attention has been paid to demonstrating effects that have occurred as the direct result of various forms of state energy-related research, development and demonstration support, and to investigating whether it would be possible to achieve better results in future through some modification of the form of this support.

Authors: Huther M., Anslot P., Zehri M.
Title: RELIABILITY AND SAFETY VERIFICATION OF MEMBRANE CONTAINMENTS.

Abstract: Gas has become an alternative source of energy to oil in most industrial countries. One of the major disadvantages is that production areas tend to be far from the consumers which means transportation over long distances. Taking into account its 20 years experience in gas carrier classification and survey in service (40% of the LNG tankers of the world were built under BV class), Bureau Veritas has developed a particular rational classification procedure which is applicable to all these kinds of ships. This procedure integrates the results of practical experience, with research and development programmes. To illustrate this procedure, the paper presents its application to membrane LNG carriers, but it has also been applied to SPB and spherical type B systems.

Title: The room temperature stability of amorphous Mg-Zn alloys
Source title: Journal of Physics F: Metal Physics
Affiliations: Dept. of Solid State Phys., Australian Nat. Univ., Canberra, ACT, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Calka, A., Dept. of Solid State Phys., Australian Nat. Univ., Canberra, ACT, Australia
Abstract: Mg-Zn metallic glasses, characterised by low crystallisation temperatures, are useful alloys for investigating the room temperature stability of the amorphous metallic state. In this paper the structural stability of Mg-Zn metallic glasses is discussed. As-quenched ribbons and the same ribbons after storage for six years at room temperature were investigated through differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), X-ray diffraction and optical microscopy. The fully amorphous structure was found only for Mg65Zn35 composition. An Mg68Zn32 alloy exhibited an amorphous structure with precipitated Mg on the ribbon surface. Mg75Zn 25, Mg72Zn28 and Mg70Zn30 showed a mixture of crystalline phases with a decreasing amount of amorphous phase on the Mg-rich side of the peritectic. The structure of the crystalline phases and the quantity of the remaining amorphous phase was determined. Thermal analysis of aged samples indicated two values of activation energy for crystallisation-lower for the Mg-rich side of the peritectic (including the peritectic composition) and higher for Zn-rich alloys. Additionally, for Zn-rich alloys thermal effects related to the structural relaxation of the amorphous phase were observed.
Index Keywords: GLASS, METALLIC - Thermal Effects; RELAXATION PROCESSES; ACTIVATION ENERGY; STRUCTURAL STABILITY; MAGNESIUM ZINC ALLOYS

Authors: Jonscher A.K., Pickup C., Zaidi S.H.
Title: Dielectric spectroscopy of semi-insulating gallium arsenide
Affiliations: King's Coll., London Univ., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jonscher, A.K., King's Coll., London Univ., United Kingdom; Pickup, C., King's Coll., London Univ., United Kingdom; Zaidi, S.H., King's Coll., London Univ., United Kingdom
Abstract: Dielectric spectroscopy of semiconductors (DSS) employs dielectric measuring techniques to study delayed electronic transitions in and out of localised energy levels in the forbidden gap. 'Horizontal' transitions between levels normally take place in the volume of the material and involve relatively small changes of energy. 'Vertical' transitions between deep levels and the free bands involve energy changes of the order of half the band gap and take place mainly in interfacial space-charge regions and at semiconductor-metal interfaces. DSS is uniquely able to resolve the spectra of these delayed transitions and measurements on semiinsulating (SI) GaAs in the frequency range 10-2-104 Hz and between 90 and 380K show that none of them conform to the expected exponential time dependence. The various transitions are found to have well recognisable spectral 'signatures' involving fractional power-law dependences on frequency and hence on time. The exponents are sensitive to the nature of the transitions and to the types of impurities, and may also depend on the crystalline order. The authors report for the first time in the context of single-crystal SI GaAs the phenomena of low-frequency dispersion both in the volume and in interfacial transitions, and also of negative capacitance, all of which involve some structural instabilities and the likelihood of electrochemical energy storage. They also show the existence of electronic phase transitions involving subtle reversible changes of electron-lattice interactions as well defined temperatures. They associate the power laws with many-body interactions affecting the transitions in the localised levels, which are not well understood probably on account hitherto of lack of experimental evidence. This shows the usefulness of DSS as a unique technique for studies of semiconductor transitions.
Index Keywords: SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS - Dielectric Properties; DIELECTRIC SPECTROSCOPY; ELECTRONIC TRANSITIONS; ENERGY LEVELS; HORIZONTAL TRANSITIONS; VERTICAL TRANSITIONS; SEMICONDUCTING GALLIUM ARSENIDE

Title: Fourier transform mechanical spectroscopy
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: H.H. Wills Phys. Lab., Bristol Univ., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Arridge, R.G.C., H.H. Wills Phys. Lab., Bristol Univ., United Kingdom; Barham, P.J., H.H. Wills Phys. Lab., Bristol Univ., United Kingdom
Abstract: A powerful new experimental method of determining the dynamic mechanical behaviour of viscoelastic materials is described. The method, Fourier transform mechanical spectroscopy (FTMS), consists of superposing and deconvoluting discrete Fourier transforms obtained from a single stress relaxation experiment using a novel sampling scheme. The theory of the sampling scheme and the superposition of the transforms is described elsewhere. In this paper the authors present the results of using the new method on Nylon over the frequency range 5*10-4 to 20 Hz and temperatures from 25 to 110 degrees C. There is good agreement between the values of storage and loss moduli, obtained by means of the transform method, and those obtained by conventional means. An activation energy of 143 kcal mol-1 is obtained for the relaxation in this temperature range. The new method has considerable potential for the rapid determination of the mechanical properties of novel polymers and composites.
Index Keywords: MATERIALS - Mechanical Properties; MATHEMATICAL TRANSFORMATIONS - Fourier Transforms; SPECTROSCOPY - Applications; DYNAMIC MECHANICAL BEHAVIOR; FOURIER TRANSFORM MECHANICAL SPECTROSCOPY (FTMS); VISCOELASTIC MAATERIALS; VISCOELASTICITY

Authors: Van Der Poel C.J., Gravesteijn D.J., Rippens W.G.V.M., Stockx H.T.L.P., Van Uijen C.M.J.
Title: Phase-change optical recording in TeSeSb alloys
Affiliations: Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Der Poel, C.J., Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Gravesteijn, D.J., Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Rippens, W.G.V.M., Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Stockx, H.T.L.P., Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Van Uijen, C.M.J., Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: Some characteristics of reversible phase-change optical data storage in TeSeSb alloys are given. High signal-to-noise ratios are reached at low recording energies. Upon passage of an oblong scanning laser spot, erasure occurs by growth from the crystalline surroundings of the amorphous effects at growth velocities of up to 5 cm/s. Isothermal transformation appears to be dominated by phase separation and diffusion processes. The tradeoff between long-term stability and erasure time varies with alloy composition and, for some alloys, attractive properties with respect to data retention and erasure times are found.

Authors: Yafet Y., Gyorgy E.M., Walker L.R.
Title: Directional dependence of the demagnetizing energy in imperfect thin magnetic films
Affiliations: AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Old Farm Lane, Bedminster, NJ 07921, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yafet, Y., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Gyorgy, E.M., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Walker, L.R., Old Farm Lane, Bedminster, NJ 07921, United States
Abstract: The magnetostatic energy of imperfect films having a two-dimensional square-lattice structure with voids between square islands of magnetic material is calculated for arbitrary ratios of thickness and island size to the period of the lattice. These calculations are relevant to the understanding of the uniaxial anisotropy observed in many thin films used as magnetic-storage media.

Authors: Miyazaki K., Hasama T., Yamada K., Fukatsu T., Eura T., Sato T.
Title: Efficiency of a capacitor-transfer-type discharge excimer laser with automatic preionization
Affiliations: Laser Research Section, Radio- and Opto-Electronics Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba Science City, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyazaki, K., Laser Research Section, Radio- and Opto-Electronics Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba Science City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Hasama, T., Laser Research Section, Radio- and Opto-Electronics Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba Science City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yamada, K., Laser Research Section, Radio- and Opto-Electronics Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba Science City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Fukatsu, T., Laser Research Section, Radio- and Opto-Electronics Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba Science City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Eura, T., Laser Research Section, Radio- and Opto-Electronics Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba Science City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Sato, T., Laser Research Section, Radio- and Opto-Electronics Division, Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tsukuba Science City, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Abstract: Energy transfer aspects in a capacitor-transfer-type discharge excimer laser with automatic preionization (API) have been studied to improve the laser efficiency. Detailed measurements on the discharge and output characteristics of the XeCl laser show that efficient energy transfer from the storage capacitor to the discharge capacitor is essential for improvement in the overall efficiency. The circuit analysis based on the measurements suggests that the API discharge excimer laser could be operated with an electrical efficiency of about 4%. The overall efficiencies of 2.9, 2.8, and 1.3% have been obtained with the XeCl, KrF, and ArF lasers, respectively.

Title: Heavy quark physics
Affiliations: Lab. of Nucl. Studies, Cornell Univ., Ithaca, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Berkelman, K., Lab. of Nucl. Studies, Cornell Univ., Ithaca, NY, United States
Abstract: The author discusses the physics of the hadrons containing charmed, bottom and top quarks. The emphasis is on the most recent experimental results from the e+e- storage rings in the 3-12 GeV range of centre-of-mass energy: SPEAR at SLAC, DORIS at DESY, and the Cornell Electron Storage Ring CESR. The reader can find more details of earlier work covered in summaries presented at annual high-energy or lepton-photon conferences and in several review articles.

Abstract: The method of resonance depolarization has been used for the absolute energy calibration of storage ring VEPP-4. The beam polarization was measured by the up-down asymmetry of the synchrotron radiation back-scattered on the colliding beam. By scanning the Υ{hooked} resonance with the MD-1 detector, we obtained a mass M=9460.59 ±0.12 MeV. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Metal cluster ion chemistry
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY, 11794 -3400, United States

Abstract: An instrument for the study of the chemistry and photodissociation spectroscopy of metal cluster ions has been constructed. The instrument incorporates a source using either laser, ion, or fast atom sputtering to generate cluster ions of nearly any material. Radio-frequency ion guides are used to collect, transport, and store the clusters; storage in a buffer gas is used to thermalize hot clusters produced in the source. Studies of the chemistry of aluminum and cobalt clusters are used to illustrate the operation of the instrument. © 1986 SPIE.

Authors: Krajcar-Bronić I., Obelić B., Srdoč D.
Title: The simultaneous measurement of tritium activity and the background count rate in a proportional counter by the povinec method: Three years experience at the Rudjer Bošković Institute
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Rudjer Bošković Institute, Zagreb
Authors with affiliations: Krajcar-Bronić, I., Rudjer Bošković Institute, Zagreb; Obelić, B., Rudjer Bošković Institute, Zagreb; Srdoč, D., Rudjer Bošković Institute, Zagreb
Abstract: Tritium activity in water samples has been measured by means of a proportional counter. The energy interval was set between 1.1 keV and 9.7 keV to obtain optimal efficiency (the best figure of merit). The background count rate in the energy interval above 20 keV was measured simultaneously. A very good correlation between background count rates in both energy intervals has been observed. The counting gas quality has been checked by measuring the 55Fe spectral line (5.89 keV). A good correlation between the count rate above 20 keV and the spectral resolution has been obtained enabling gas quality control during the measurement. A constant monitoring of the count rate above 20 keV has revealed radon contamination of several groundwater samples. Repeated measurement after 15 days storage gave more accurate tritium activity. © 1986.
Index Keywords: PROPORTIONAL COUNTERS; BACKGROUND COUNT RATE; RESOLUTION; TRITIUM ACTIVITY; TRITIUM

Title: SHORT-CIRCUIT PROTECTION FOR CAPACITIVE STORAGE DEVICES WITH THYRISTOR COMMUTATORS.

Abstract: Two protective circuits for capacitive storage devices with thyristor commutators are described, one of which is a linear LC network while the other is a transformer with bucking windings. The effect of an actual transformer on the current under operating i and overload i prime conditions is analyzed. It is shown that, under overload conditions, the current exceeds the working value by only about 20% and (di prime /dt)/(di/dt) less than equivalent to 3. Elements are developed and recommendations for selection of their values are given.

Title: 3RD SYMPOSIUM ON ELECTROMAGNETIC LAUNCH TECHNOLOGY 1986.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The following topics are dealt with: electromagnetic rail guns; rail and insulator erosion in rail guns; homopolar generators; railgun armatures; railgun projectiles; simulation of electromagnetic railgun barrels; current carrying plasmas in railguns; MHD generator-powered railgun; plasma coaxial railguns; metal armature and sabots for railguns; high-current meatgrinder; railgun insulator materials; thermal hypervelocity launcher technology; capacitor-powered railguns; plasma-pulse-accelerators; and the physics of railgun plasma armatures. 90 papers were presented, all of which are published in full in the present proceedings. Abstracts of individual papers can be found under the relevant classification code in this or other issues.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; ELECTROMAGNETS; MILITARY ENGINEERING; PLASMA DEVICES; EIREV; HOMOPOLAR GENERATORS; HYPERVELOCITY LAUNCHERS; PLASMA ARMATURES; RAILGUNS; ROCKETS AND MISSILES

Authors: Dolce James L., Faymon Karl A.
Title: AUTOMATING THE U. S. SPACE STATION'S ELECTRICAL POWER SYSTEM.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Dolce, James L., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Faymon, Karl A., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: NASA has undertaken the design of a manned space station. To decrease both airborne and ground support costs, subsystem designers are encouraged to automate activities ordinarily performed by humans. The Lewis Research Center has been charged with developing a highly automated system for generation, storage, and distribution of electrical energy aboard the Space Station. Conventional algorithms enhanced by expert systems are proposed for this task. An autonomous power system will require the intelligence to schedule power, allocate energy, diagnose failure causes, propose goals, prepare plans, evaluate consequences, and select the best plan for execution. Crew-interactive, expert systems can be ready for automating the initial space station, but complete system autonomy will need more development time.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE - Expert Systems; FAILURE ANALYSIS; ROBOTS, INDUSTRIAL; SCHEDULING; SPACE RESEARCH; RESOURCE ALLOCATION; SPACE STATION; STATE ESTIMATION; SPACE PLATFORMS

Title: PRIORITY SERVICE: UNBUNDLING THE QUALITY ATTRIBUTES OF ELECTRIC POWER.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EA
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: In an increasingly competitive environment, utilities are seeking cost-effective ways to respond to new and diverse consumer needs. This exploration of a concept in which customers select different levels of service to match their requirements is a first step in an EPRI effort to develop practical new service options from which both utilities and their customers can benefit. Utilities could offer priority service through combinations of technical alternatives including load-shedding controls, backup generators, fuel cells, local energy storage, uninterrupted power supply, and multiple feeders. Utilities could implement priority service through a variety of mechanisms such as demand subscription service, priority insurance, and priority points. This report - a preliminary look at the economic theory behind priority service and an assessment of its feasibility for utilities - discusses incentives and market structures, priority service menus, priority classes, and priority insurance. In six appendixes of interest particularly to engineers and analysts, it details mathematical models for various analyses.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ELECTRIC POWER DISTRIBUTION; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; ENERGY STORAGE; FUEL CELLS; BACKUP GENERATORS; INCENTIVES; LOAD-SHEDDING; MARKET STRUCTURES; PRIORITY SERVICE; ELECTRIC UTILITIES

Authors: Sutton A.L., Jones D.D., Kelly D.T., Bache D.H.
Title: TWO TYPES OF RUNOFF CONTROL SYSTEMS FOR OPEN CONCRETE SWINE FEEDLOTS.
Affiliations: Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sutton, A.L., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Jones, D.D., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Kelly, D.T., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Bache, D.H., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA
Abstract: At one location, infiltration channel-vegetative filter system was used on a silty loam soil for infiltration of treated runoff. At the second location, a detention pond for runoff storage was used due to a heavy textured, poorly drained silty clay loam soil. Concrete settling basins were used to treat runoff before disposal. Nutrient accumulation in the soil and soil solution suggested that increasing the slope above 1% and widening the area more than 0. 9 m would provide a more uniform absorption of runoff. A labor and energy cost analysis indicated that the major cost of the manure management system with the open lot was scraping and hauling solid manure. Detention pond storage with irrigation application increased some labor and energy costs; however, nutrients from the effluent would recover the additional cost if utilized as a fertilizer resource.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERING; RUNOFF - Control; WASTEWATER - Treatment; SWINE FEEDLOTS; AGRICULTURAL WASTES

Authors: Harasawa Hideaki, Kobayashi Hisayasu, Yasuoka Toshiki, Matsumoto Kazuaki, Shiokawa Yukio, Harigayo Shoji
Title: DEVELOPMENT OF WELDING PROCEDURES FOR ARCTIC STRUCTURES AND OFFSHORE PLATFORMS.
Affiliations: Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Harasawa, Hideaki, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn; Kobayashi, Hisayasu, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn; Yasuoka, Toshiki, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn; Matsumoto, Kazuaki, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn; Shiokawa, Yukio, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn; Harigayo, Shoji, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn, Nippon Kokan KK, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: In order to improve low temperature toughness and to reduce hardenability of welded joints in fabricating arctic structures and offshore platforms, optimum welding procedures have been developed and applied, by utilizing the steel plates with a yield strength of up to 415MPa, produced by the OLAC (On-Line Accelerated Cooling) after controlled rolling. In the fabrication of Super CIDS (Concrete Island Drilling System) for arctic use, Charpy absorbed energies at minus 60 degree C of welded joints have been obtained sufficiently, even for high heat input procedures (10-15kJ/mm). For large offshore platforms, the welded joints of heavier thickness plates (up to 100 mm) have shown the sufficient weld metal and HAZ COD values at minus 10 degree C and lower hardenability compared with conventional normalized plates in examining the advanced welding procedures of Narrow Gap weldings, and the conventionial multi-pass SAW.
Index Keywords: OPTIMIZATION; STEEL - Mechanical Properties; STEEL TESTING - Impact; WELDED STEEL STRUCTURES; WELDING, ELECTRIC ARC - Submerged Arc; ARCTIC STRUCTURES WELDING; CONCRETE ISLAND DRILLING SYSTEM; LOW TEMPERATURE TOUGHNESS OF WELDED JOINTS; STEEL DECK STORAGE BARGE; WELD HEAT AFFECTED ZONE; MARINE PLATFORMS

Title: NEW HIGH TEMPERATURE CERAMIC FIBER BLANKET PROVIDING HIGH STRENGTH AND LOW SHRINKAGE IN KILN OPERATION.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: A new high temperature ceramic fiber insulation blanket developed by Standard Oil Engineered Materials Co. (Carborundum), Niagara Falls, N. Y. , has demonstrated its high strength and low shrinkage properties as well as energy savings benefit in applications above 2000 degree F. This insulation's unique chemical composition of high purity alumina, zirconia and silica in combination with a unique manufacturing process contributes to its performance in medium to high temperature uses. The superior handling strength of this insulation (Fiberfrax Durablanket 2600), five times that of conventional blankets, is the result of a proprietary manufacturing process where ceramic fibers are cross-locked and needled to produce a high strength blanket without organic binders. The ceramic fiber blanket has low thermal conductivity, low heat storage, light weight, thermal shock resistance, high heat reflectance and good sound absorption. Application trials in a kiln are described.
Index Keywords: ALUMINA; CERAMIC MATERIALS - Fibers; HEAT INSULATING MATERIALS - Energy Conservation; REFRACTORY MATERIALS - Zirconia; SILICA; CERAMIC FIBER BLANKET; HIGH TEMPERATURE; KILNS

Title: CALSEM - SEWAGE TREATMENT WITH LOAD SMOOTHING.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Portsmouth Polytechnic is now able to offer full-scale application of the computer controlled process for activated sludge treatment plants. CALSEM -- Computer Aided Load Smoothing with Energy Management -- is a system for controlling the erratic variations which occur in flow to sewage treatment plants, in order to improve the performance of conventional activated sludge installations, so that quality of effluent is improved and is less variable, energy is saved, and energy costs are reduced. There is also considerable scope for reducing labour costs. The system works by diverting flow, and hence load, to a balance tank during times of high flow or strong flow to the works, and returning flow and load back from the balance tank when flows are low or weak. The goal is to reduce the variability in the feed to treatment, as measured by difference between consecutive mean flows and loads. Frequent measurement of flow and strength of sewage is required at several points in the treatment system. Alternatively, storage using the sewer system may be mobilised in suitable locations in place of storage in tanks.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SOFTWARE - Applications; ENERGY CONSERVATION; FLOW OF FLUIDS - Computer Applications; ACTIVATED SLUDGE; CALSEM; COMPUTER AIDED LOAD SMOOTHING WITH ENERGY MANAGEMENT; SEWAGE TREATMENT

Authors: Saito Akio, Utaka Yoshio, Okawa Seiji, Katayama Kozo
Title: STUDY ON THE HEAT TRANSFER OF LATENT HEAT THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE (4TH REPORT: THERMAL CHARACTERISTICS OF VERTICAL TYPE CAPSULE IN STORAGE PROCESS).
Affiliations: Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Saito, Akio, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn; Utaka, Yoshio, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn; Okawa, Seiji, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn; Katayama, Kozo, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: Concerning a vertical type latent heat TES (thermal energy storage) capsule having the vertical axis, experiments and analyses were performed to discuss the heat transfer mechanisms in the heat storage process. The time dependency of the local heat flux across the capsule wall was measured and the natural convection flow within the capsule was observed, varying the height of the phase change material (PCM). The finite difference analyses considering the natural convection flow were also done.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Difference Method; LATENT HEAT THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; VERTICAL CAPSULE; HEAT TRANSFER

Title: INTRODUCTION TO THE CRANE.
Affiliations: Harnischfeger Corp, Milwaukee, WI,, USA, Harnischfeger Corp, Milwaukee, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Greniewicki, Daniel W., Harnischfeger Corp, Milwaukee, WI,, USA, Harnischfeger Corp, Milwaukee, WI, USA
Abstract: Waste-to-energy plants are among the harshest environments for any piece of machinery - including cranes. Duty cycles are continuous, temperatures high, atmospheres abrasive and corrosive. And much is required of a refuse-handling crane. Beyond merely raising and lowering material, it must process, rehandle, and mix refuse that has been deposited into the plant's receiving and storage pit. In many cases, it must do this job around the clock! From the foregoing, a properly specified refuse-handling crane is obviously a must - because the wrong specification can lead to a key component that is a source of headaches for years. While the refuse processing and firing may occur elsewhere in the plant, the crane is an integral, built-in component of that facility - something that will perform for 20 years or more. Proper specifications, engineering, manufacturing, and installation, operation, the service will ensure maximum return on investment.
Index Keywords: CRANES - Performance; ENGINEERING WRITING - Control; MACHINERY - Reliability; GRAPPLE CRANES; WASTE-TO-ENERGY PLANTS; REFUSE DISPOSAL

Authors: Okazaki S., Higuchi S., Nakamura O., Takahashi S.
Title: Influence of superimposed alternating current on capacity and cycle life for lead-acid batteries
Affiliations: Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka Midorigaoka 1, Ikeda, Osaka, 563, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Okazaki, S., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka Midorigaoka 1, Ikeda, Osaka, 563, Japan; Higuchi, S., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka Midorigaoka 1, Ikeda, Osaka, 563, Japan; Nakamura, O., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka Midorigaoka 1, Ikeda, Osaka, 563, Japan; Takahashi, S., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka Midorigaoka 1, Ikeda, Osaka, 563, Japan
Abstract: Capacity and cycle life have been measured for commercially available lead-acid batteries by superimposing an a.c. upon the charge and discharge d.c. to clarify the influence of an a.c. invasion into the d.c. system on battery performance in an electric power storage system. The current was controlled to be I=I0(1+sinωt) in all the experiments. The value of I0 corresponded to 5 or 8 HR and the frequency range was 0.1 to 4000 Hz. No capacity change was observed for the a.c. superimposition on the charge current in this frequency range. When an a.c. was superimposed upon the discharge current the capacity of the battery increased by less than 1%. No effect on the cycle life caused by the a.c. superimposition on the charge and the discharge current was observed, as the inherent distribution of the cycle life of the batteries used was much greater than the change caused by the a.c. superimposition. Thus, it was clarified that the influence of the a.c. superimposition on battery capacity and cycle life is practically negligible for lead-acid batteries. © 1986 Chapman and Hall Ltd.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; ENERGY STORAGE - Equipment; CYCLE LIFE; LEAD-ACID BATTERIES; SUPERIMPOSED ALTERNATING CURRENT; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Authors: Welty D.L., Sutton A.L., Jones D.D., Nye J.C.
Title: LABOR, EQUIPMENT AND ENERGY REQUIREMENTS FOR HANDLING SWINE AND DAIRY MANURE WITH AN ABOVE-GROUND LIQUID MANURE STORAGE SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Welty, D.L., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Sutton, A.L., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Jones, D.D., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Nye, J.C., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA
Abstract: Frequency of manure collection and transfer into storage was dependent upon weather conditions, manure volume and moisture of the manure on the open lot facilities. For the three dairies, manure collection activities were more costly than removal activities with 55 to 77% of the operating costs due to energy and labor. For both collection and removal, labor was the greatest expense. Between 58 to 75% of the total fuel usage of all manure system activities was required for manure removal with agitation requiring more fuel than hauling and land application. Distance to the application site was the most important variable in manure removal and a major influence on both time requirements and costs.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS - Analysis; ENERGY UTILIZATION; MATERIALS HANDLING - Equipment; DAIRY MANURE; LIQUID MANURE STORAGE SYSTEM; AGRICULTURAL WASTES

Authors: Karolczak S., Hodyr K., Łubis R., Kroh J.
Title: Pulse radiolysis system based on ELU-6E LINAC
Source title: Journal of Radioanalytical and Nuclear Chemistry Articles
Affiliations: Institute of Applied Radiation Chemistry, Technical University (Politechnika), Wróblewskiego 15, Łódź, 93-590, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Karolczak, S., Institute of Applied Radiation Chemistry, Technical University (Politechnika), Wróblewskiego 15, Łódź, 93-590, Poland; Hodyr, K., Institute of Applied Radiation Chemistry, Technical University (Politechnika), Wróblewskiego 15, Łódź, 93-590, Poland; Łubis, R., Institute of Applied Radiation Chemistry, Technical University (Politechnika), Wróblewskiego 15, Łódź, 93-590, Poland; Kroh, J., Institute of Applied Radiation Chemistry, Technical University (Politechnika), Wróblewskiego 15, Łódź, 93-590, Poland
Abstract: Basic parameters and operating characteristics of the linear microwave accelerator ELU-6 and pulse radiolysis system are given. LINAC can operate in single pulse mode or with repetition of 10 to 200 pps. In nanosecond mode electron pulses of 7, 10 and 17 ns, beam currents≧10 A and an energy of 8 MeV are generated. In microsecond mode, duration of pulses can be varied from 0.3 to 4.5 μs, beam current up to 1.2 A and energy not less than 5 MeV are available. Versatile pulse radiolysis system enables routine optical measurements in the range from 350 to 2500 nm on the time scale from 10 ns to a few seconds. Transient signals are recorded by a 400 MHz storage Tektronix oscilloscope or by an IWATSU TS8123 digital oscilloscope linked to an Apple II microcomputer incorporated into the Institute computer system. A set up for pulse conductivity measurements with μs resolution time is also available. © 1986 Akadémiai Kiadó.

Authors: Malyshenko S.P., Nazarova O.V., Sarumov Yu.A.
Title: THERMODYNAMIC ASPECTS OF THE USE OF HYDROGEN FOR SOLVING CERTAIN PROBLEMS FACING THE POWER INDUSTRY.
Authors with affiliations: Malyshenko, S.P.; Nazarova, O.V.; Sarumov, Yu.A.
Abstract: The authors consider the effectiveness of using hydrogen for superheating steam in steam power plants using a simplified example. In conclusion they emphasize that as an energy carrier, hydrogen possesses unique properties which enable the heat of its combustion to be transformed into work with an efficiency superior to that of land and transport power plants using conventional fuels. However, direct replacement by hydrogen of the natural fuels used today for power plants in the majority of cases (for instance, in gas turbine plants or in steam boiler furnaces) cannot be sufficiently effective since not all of the advantages of hydrogen are realised as a rule, and the costs of producing it from water are higher than the costs of natural gas and oil fuels. The advantages of hydrogen as an energy carrier will only be realised fully if new technology specially suited to operation on hydrogen is developed.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; STEAM POWER PLANTS; SUPERHEATERS; EFFICIENCY; POWER COSTS; SUBSTITUTION; HYDROGEN FUELS

Authors: Goel R.C., Srivastava G.S., Khan A.M.
Title: CENTRAL RECEIVER SOLAR POWER SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering, Coll, Gorakhpur, India, Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering Coll, Gorakhpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Goel, R.C., Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering, Coll, Gorakhpur, India, Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering Coll, Gorakhpur, India; Srivastava, G.S., Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering, Coll, Gorakhpur, India, Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering Coll, Gorakhpur, India; Khan, A.M., Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering, Coll, Gorakhpur, India, Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering Coll, Gorakhpur, India
Abstract: Existing technology on heat transfer salt systems and steam power conversion can be combined with solar equipment under development to produce a multipurpose solar power plant with attractive performance characteristics. Full utilization of the collected energy is important to system economics and is enhanced with the provision of modular thermal storage at both high and low temperature. Earliest economic viability may occur for rural sites isolated from an electric grid. The purpose of this paper is to summarize the state of knowledge relating to 'Central Reciever Solar Power System' in a manner useful to engineers in understanding this system and to collect full information of work done about the system as far as possible.
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; STEAM POWER PLANTS; THERMODYNAMICS; CENTRAL RECEIVER SOLAR POWER SYSTEM; HIGH-TEMPERATURE RANKINE CYCLE; SOLAR CONCENTRATING COLLECTORS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Mitani Yasunori, Tsuji Kiichiro, Marakami Yoshishige
Title: APPLICATION OF SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNET ENERGY STORAGE TO POWER SYSTEM STABILIZING CONTROL.
Source title: Technology Reports of the Osaka University
Affiliations: Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Mitani, Yasunori, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn; Tsuji, Kiichiro, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn; Marakami, Yoshishige, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn, Osaka Univ, Suita, Jpn
Abstract: The application of Superconducting Magnet Energy Storage (SMES) to the stabilizing control of power systems with a long-distance bulk power transmission line and with longitudinal interconnect structure is presented. Control schemes for stabilization using an SMES is proposed and the effective locations of SMES in these power systems are discussed in detail. Results of eigenvalue analysis and computer simulations demonstrate the significant effect of the control by SMES on power systems stabilization. From the results of simulations necessary capacities of SMES for stabilization are evaluated.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Stability; ELECTRIC POWER TRANSMISSION; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEM STABILIZATION; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Title: ACTUAL COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE TECHNOLOGY IN EUROPE.
Affiliations: Soc Electrique de l'Our SA, Luxemb, Soc Electrique de l'Our SA, Luxemb
Authors with affiliations: Pellin, J., Soc Electrique de l'Our SA, Luxemb, Soc Electrique de l'Our SA, Luxemb
Abstract: This paper presents a storage system becoming more and more attractive, i. e. the compressed air storage plant. Exploited to the full of its limited potential, most of the disadvantages of pumped hydro can be eliminated by this new principle and, at the same time, C. A. E. S. is a generating unit and a storage device. It comes out that air storage is applicable to any power system over a certain minimum size and in any climate. Different storage facilities are compared with particular emphasis upon the constant pressure storage system, less related to site selections. Further developments and investigations are pointed out with special stress on the airlift effect phenomenon and its experimental analyses.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; AIRLIFT EFFECT PHENOMENON; C. A. E. S. COMPRESSED AIR GENERATING AND STORAGE FACILITY; COMPRESSED AIR

Authors: Giordano N., Cacciola G., Parmaliana A.
Title: ENERGY STORAGE AND TRANSMISSION: PLATINUM CATALYSES CHEMICAL CLOSED-LOOP SYSTEM.
Affiliations: CNR, Messina, Italy, CNR, Messina, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Giordano, N., CNR, Messina, Italy, CNR, Messina, Italy; Cacciola, G., CNR, Messina, Italy, CNR, Messina, Italy; Parmaliana, A., CNR, Messina, Italy, CNR, Messina, Italy
Abstract: Hydrogen produced by any convenient means is used as a medium for energy storage and transmission. Close to its production site the hydrogen is catalytically reacted with toluene to yield methylcyclohexane; this is transferred by pipeline or container to the point of energy requirement where it is catalytically dehydrogenated. The hydrogen released is then available for use in a variety of ways while the toluene is returned to the source for further hydrogenation and the cycle is repeated.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Hydrogenation; HYDROGEN - Energy Storage; TOLUENE; METHYLCYCLOHEXANE; CATALYSTS

Title: DYNAMIC OPERATING BENEFITS OF ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, Advanced Power Systems Division, (Report) EPRI AP
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Energy storage plants offer utilities relief from the increasingly urgent pressures for operating flexibility imposed by excess baseload capacity, aging facilities, and worsening daily load factors. Case studies at three utilities identified substantial operating savings - typically overlooked in technology evaluations - that could greatly increase the economic appeal of these units.
