Title: TECHNICAL FLOW PROBLEMS AND SAFETY RISKS CONNECTED WITH PEAT HANDLING.
Affiliations: Technical Research Cent of Finland, Espoo, Finl, Technical Research Cent of Finland, Espoo, Finl
Authors with affiliations: Thun, R., Technical Research Cent of Finland, Espoo, Finl, Technical Research Cent of Finland, Espoo, Finl; Rautalin, A., Technical Research Cent of Finland, Espoo, Finl, Technical Research Cent of Finland, Espoo, Finl
Abstract: In Finland, milled peat is used as fuel for electricity and heat generation. Although only about 4% of the total energy production is met with peat, its use is regionally significant and feasible. Peat handling and related safety techniques have been studied at the Technical Research Centre of Finland (VTT) since 1978. In this article, difficulties involved in peat handling and storage, experiments carried out at VTT and the latest handling technology and silo storage systems for milled peat are introduced. The systems are mainly based on empirical know-how of peat behavior, in part also on research results concerning the flow and dust explosion properties of milled peat.
Index Keywords: FUELS - Storage; SILOS; FLOW PROPERTIES; SAFETY RISKS; PEAT

Title: Dynamic Mechanical Study of the α-Relaxation in Poly(oxymethylene)
Affiliations: Central Research and Development Department, Experimental Station, E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company, Wilmington, Delaware 19898, United States
Authors with affiliations: Starkweather, H.W., Jr., Central Research and Development Department, Experimental Station, E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company, Wilmington, Delaware 19898, United States
Abstract: The dynamic mechanical properties of poly(oxymethylene) were measured in the region of the a-relaxation at frequencies from 0.033 to 90 Hz. Isothermal data were taken at temperatures from 100 to 150 °C to form master curves of the dependence of tan δ, the storage modulus (E‘), and the loss modulus (E“) on frequency. The frequency-temperature shifts corresponded to an activation energy of 22 ± 1 kcal/mol, in agreement with the findings of Gray for temperatures below 70 °C. A two-dimensional shift was required for the modulus functions. The activation entropy of this relaxation is close to zero, suggesting that the internal motion has little cooperative character. © 1986, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Abstract: A review of the performance of the barrel calorimeter system of the high resolution spectrometer (HRS) is given. The system has been in operation for several years at the PEP e+e- storage ring. The barrel calorimeter, consisting of Pb-scintillator sandwiches and proportional wire tubes with charge-division readout, measures the energies and production angles of electromagnetic showers and also provides time-of-flight for particles produced in e+e- collisions. © 1986.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; PARTICLE DETECTORS; PHYSICS - High Energy; SPECTROMETERS; BARREL CALORIMETER; HIGH RESOLUTION SPECTROMETER; CALORIMETERS

Authors: Preger M., Spataro B., Bernabei R., de Pascale M.P., Schaerf C.
Title: Monochromatic and polarized tagged ladon gamma ray beams
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: INFN - Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Frascati, Italy; Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università di Roma, INFN - Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Preger, M., INFN - Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Frascati, Italy; Spataro, B., INFN - Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Frascati, Italy; Bernabei, R., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università di Roma, INFN - Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy; de Pascale, M.P., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università di Roma, INFN - Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy; Schaerf, C., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università di Roma, INFN - Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy
Abstract: We discuss the production of monochromatic and polarized gamma ray beams by backward Compton scattering of laser light against the high energy electrons circulating in a storage ring. The gamma ray energy resolution obtainable by photon collimation is compared to that obtainable by tagging the scattered electrons. A complete model of the tagged electron technique is developed in the linear theory of electron optics. The formulas are applied to the proposed 5 GeV European synchrotron radiation facility (ESRP 27/3). The results appear very promising, indicating an energy resolution better than 4 MeV at 780 MeV. © 1986.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; ELECTRONS; LASER BEAMS - Effects; COMPTON SCATTERING; TAGGING; X-RAY AND GAMMA RAY PRODUCTION

Authors: Wojtczak L., Zółkiewska A., Duszyński J.
Title: Energy-storage capacity of the mitochondrial proton-motive force
Affiliations: Department of Cellular Biochemistry, Nencki Institute of Experimental Biololgy, Pasteura 3, 02-093 Warsaw, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Wojtczak, L., Department of Cellular Biochemistry, Nencki Institute of Experimental Biololgy, Pasteura 3, 02-093 Warsaw, Poland; Zółkiewska, A., Department of Cellular Biochemistry, Nencki Institute of Experimental Biololgy, Pasteura 3, 02-093 Warsaw, Poland; Duszyński, J., Department of Cellular Biochemistry, Nencki Institute of Experimental Biololgy, Pasteura 3, 02-093 Warsaw, Poland
Abstract: Resting state respiration of rat-liver mitochondria in the presence of oligomycin was rapidly blocked with cyanide and the dissipation of the membrane potential was followed with a tetraphenylphosphonium-sensitive electrode. From the rate of this dissipation and the electric capacitance of the mitochondrial membrane the energy stored in form of the membrane potential was calculated as about 7 μJ/mg protein. In the absence of oligomycin, dissipation of the membrane potential was slower, as it was partly compensated by proton ejection by mitochondrial ATPase hydrolyzing endogenous ATP. This allowed to calculate the total energy storage capacity of the proton-motive force. It amounted to the equivalence of 3.3 nmol ATP/mg protein or about 130 μJ/mg protein. The stoichiometry of proton-pumping ATPase utilizing endogenous ATP was estimated as three protons per molecule ATP. © 1986.
Author Keywords: (Rat liver); Energy-storage capacity; Membrane potential; Proton-motive force; Respiration
Index Keywords: animal cell; energy conservation; liver; membrane potential; mitochondrion; nonhuman; oxidative phosphorylation; priority journal; rat; Adenine Nucleotides; Animal; Cyanides; Electron Transport; Energy Metabolism; Hydrogen-Ion Concentration; Membrane Potentials; Mitochondria, Liver; Oligomycins; Rats

Authors: Reisfeld R., Eyal M., Jørgensen C.K., Jacoboni C.
Title: Energy transfer between manganese(II) and neodymium(III) in transition-metal fluoride glasses
Affiliations: Department of Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry, The Hebrew University, 91904 Jerusalem, Israel; Département de Chimie Minérale, Analytique et Appliquée, Université de Genève, CH-1211 Geneva 4, Switzerland; Laboratoire des Fluorures VA (CNRS) 449, Université de Maine, 72017 Le Mans Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Reisfeld, R., Department of Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry, The Hebrew University, 91904 Jerusalem, Israel; Eyal, M., Department of Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry, The Hebrew University, 91904 Jerusalem, Israel; Jørgensen, C.K., Département de Chimie Minérale, Analytique et Appliquée, Université de Genève, CH-1211 Geneva 4, Switzerland; Jacoboni, C., Laboratoire des Fluorures VA (CNRS) 449, Université de Maine, 72017 Le Mans Cedex, France
Abstract: Energy transfer between Mn(II) and Nd(in) in glasses of composition: 36 PbF2, 24 ZnF2, 35 GaF3, 2 AlF3, 3 YF3, 4 LaF3 in which manganese may replace all the zinc, and neodymium some lanthanum, is studied by dynamic and static methods. Both methods arrive at the same results indicating linear dependence of transfer probability on donor concentration. These results also demonstrate energy storage in the manganese-neodymium system having applications in Nd lasers. © 1986.

Authors: Nardone V.C., Kimmerle W.L., Tien J.K.
Title: Cyclic creep and anelastic relaxation analysis of an ODS superalloy
Affiliations: United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, 06108, CT, United States; Henry Krumb School of Mines, Columbia University, New York, 10027, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nardone, V.C., United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, 06108, CT, United States; Kimmerle, W.L., Henry Krumb School of Mines, Columbia University, New York, 10027, NY, United States; Tien, J.K., Henry Krumb School of Mines, Columbia University, New York, 10027, NY, United States
Abstract: This paper documents the effect of stress and temperature on the cyclic minimum strain rate at two different loading frequencies for the oxide dispersion strengthened (ODS) superalloy, INCONEL* MA 6000. The apparent stress exponent and activation energy for cyclic creep at both frequencies studied are shown to be greater than values observed for static creep. The large values of the stress exponent and activation energy for cyclic creep are proposed to result from anelastic strain storage delaying nonrecoverable creep during the on-load portion of the cyclic creep loading, such that the "effective stress" driving nonrecoverable creep is only a small fraction of the applied stress. In addition, the temperature dependence of the anelastic relaxation that occurs during the off-load portion of the cyclic creep loading is determined. The activation energy found for the relaxation process is equal to about one-half that for self-diffusion in nickel. A mechanism of localized climb of dislocations over the oxide dispersoids present in INCONEL MA 6000 is postulated to account for the observed activation energy of the relaxation process. © 1986 The Metallurgical of Society of AIME.

Authors: Tang C.-M., Sprangle P., Penner S., Kincaid B.M., Freeman R.R.
Title: Proposal for FEL experiments driven by the National Bureau of Standards' CW microtron
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States; Center for Radiation Research, National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tang, C.-M., Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States; Sprangle, P., Plasma Physics Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375-5000, United States; Penner, S., Center for Radiation Research, National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Kincaid, B.M., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Freeman, R.R., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Abstract: We propose FEL experiments driven by the race-track microtron (RTM), which is under development at the National Bureau of Standards (NBS). The design of the NBS RTM has many exceptional properties: (i) normalized transverse emittance of 10 mm mrad, comparable to a storage ring, (ii) axial emittance <30 keV-degree, much superior to rf linacs, (iii) electron energy tunable from 20 to approximately 200 MeV, (iv) CW operation, (v) energy stability, (vi) compactness, and (vii) high power-conversion efficiency. We propose accelerator up-grades to increase the peak current and to recover a significant part of the electron beam energy. It seems possible to obtain peak current of Ip = 5-10 A, for electron pulse length of leb ≳ 1.2 mm. We have made conservative estimates based on Ip = 1.0 A in estimating the performance of the FELs to be used with the RTM. Low gain calculations indicate that the FEL can oscillate at the fundamental wavelength ranging from 0.15 to 100 μm. Furthermore, we will outline experiments to generate harmonics in the XUV. © 1986.

Title: Thermal dynamics of a block-filled underground hot water store
Affiliations: The Swedish State Power Board, Vällingby, S-162 87, Sweden; The Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, S-100 44, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Rehbinder, G., The Swedish State Power Board, Vällingby, S-162 87, Sweden; Eriksson, H., The Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, S-100 44, Sweden
Abstract: One of the best methods for seasonal storage of solar heat is the storage of hot water in large unlined rock caverns. A safe method to build self stabilizing very large caverns is to excavate them partially, i.e. to leave a considerable amount of the blasted rock in the cavern. The remaining rock in such a hot water store represents an undesired thermal inertia and it is of great practical interest to estimate how the remaining blocks influence the performance of the store. If the cavity is assumed to be spherical, the remaining blocks spherical as well, the heat diffusitivity of the solid matter constant and the water well stirred, the temperature of the water can rather easily be calculated. In the present paper it is shown that the coupled system of partial differential equations and one ordinary differential equation can be reduced to a Volterra integral equation. The calculations show how the porosity and the size of the remaining blocks influence the water temperature if an arbitrary power is added to or extracted from the cavern. © 1986 Martinus Nijhoff Publishers.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Differential Equations; THERMAL DYNAMICS; UNDERGROUND HOT WATER STORE; VOLTERRA INTEGRAL EQUATION; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Saturated permeability measurements on pumice and welded-tuffaceous materials
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, 87185, New Mexico, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reda, D.C., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, 87185, New Mexico, United States; Hadley, G.R., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, 87185, New Mexico, United States
Abstract: Fluid flows in consolidated porous media of volcanic origin are being investigated to support such diverse efforts as the modeling of thermal/outgassing phenomena at Mount St. Helens and the hydrological modeling of tuffaceous rocks in support of the Department of Energy's (DOE) Nevada Nuclear Waste Storage Investigations Project An experimental apparatus was designed and built to allow water-saturated permeabilities as low as 10-18 m2 to be measured on cores of diameter 5 cm and length 10 cm under steady-state flow conditions. This same apparatus can also be utilized in a transient (pressure-decay) mode in order to measure permeabilities several orders of magnitude lower than the steady-state limit. Tests were conducted on samples of pumice, fractured welded tuff, and welded tuff, representing a permeability range of seven orders of magnitude Pumice was found to have a permeability of ∼3×10-12 m2, sufficiently high to allow the complete Darcy-to-Ergun regime to be investigated Welded (unfractured) tuff was tested in the transient mode, yielding a permeability of ∼5×10-19 m2. Two, long-time-scale, steady-flow experiments were conducted on a core of welded tuff containing a single, through-going fracture. For the first experiment, the core was an integral cylinder containing a naturally occurring fracture. For the second experiment, the core was separated into two pieces along the existing fracture plane, then rejoined. Effects of essentially constant, as well as rapidly varied, circumferential stress were studied in both tests. Results showed core permeability to decay to 2×10-18 m2 in both cases, independent of the initial fracture state (closed versus open). With a naturally occurring fracture, core permeability decreased by a factor of 2 over a 200-h test period. With an initially open fracture, core permeability decreased by a factor of 4 under the influence of a comparable 200-h load-time history, after 700 h of testing, core permeability was reduced by an order of magnitude from its initial level. Final effective hydraulic fracture aperture was calculated to be 10-6 m, corresponding to a calculated effective fracture permeability of 10-13 m2 Fracture flow was thus estimated to account for 80% of the total flow rate through this core under final test conditions. © 1986 Springer-Verlag New York Inc.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF FLUIDS - Porous Materials; PRESSURE-DECAY FLOW; PUMICE; STEADY-STATE FLOW; TUFF; SOILS

Title: Suburban-rural energy balance comparisons in summer for Vancouver, B.C.
Affiliations: Department of Geography, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, B.C., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Cleugh, H.A., Department of Geography, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, B.C., Canada; Oke, T.R., Department of Geography, The University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, B.C., Canada
Abstract: Simultaneous energy balance observations at a rural and a suburban site in Vancouver, B.C. during the summer of 1983 are presented. The study is a follow-up to that conducted in 1980. Many of the 1980 results were unexpected and the present study seeks to assess their representativeness. The net radiant, turbulent sensible, and rural soil heat flux densities were measured directly. The suburban heat storage was parameterized and the turbulent latent heat flux densities were resolved as residuals in the energy balances. The 1983 average diurnal energy partitioning for both sites was typical of those quoted in the literature, suggesting that the 1980 results represent an extreme case. Suburban-rural differences showed the suburban area to have a 4% increase in net radiation, a 51% increase in turbulent sensible heat, and a 46% decrease in turbulent latent heat flux density. The values of the average daytime Bowen ratio were 0.46 and 1.28 for the rural and suburban areas, respectively. The sensible heat flux density exhibited relatively large values in the late afternoon and remained directed upward on many summer evenings. Large day-to-day variability in the relative magnitude of the suburban turbulent fluxes may have been due to synoptic influences. In this environment, the turbulent surface and mixed layers are closely coupled because of the low aerodynamic resistance over the rough surface. © 1986 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Authors: Amelin G.P., Bludov A.I., Guesl'nikov V.I., Kolyadin N.M., Kuroedov Yu.D., Mashchenko A.I.
Title: CRYOGENIC EXPLODING-WIRE BREAKER.
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Amelin, G.P., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR; Bludov, A.I., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR; Guesl'nikov, V.I., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR; Kolyadin, N.M., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR; Kuroedov, Yu.D., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR; Mashchenko, A.I., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR
Abstract: An exploding-wire breaker that operates in the temperature range of 77-4. 2 degree K is described. Spent wires can be replaced without warming of the cryostat. The breaker is tested in a circuit with a pulsed inductive storage device and a synchronized control supply. When a quasiconstant current of 3 kA with a density of 5 multiplied by (times) 10**5 A/cm**2 is switched, 40 kV is obtained in the wires with an average electric strength in the explosion channels of less than 8 kV/cm.
Index Keywords: CRYOSTATS; ENERGY STORAGE; EXPLODING WIRES; EXPLODING-WIRE BREAKER; INDUCTIVE STORAGE DEVICES; ELECTRIC CIRCUIT BREAKERS

Authors: Amelin G.P., Bludov A.I., Gusel'nikov V.I., Mashchenko A.I.
Title: HIGH-SPEED SUPERCONDUCTING FOIL BREAKERS.
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York

Authors with affiliations: Amelin, G.P., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR; Bludov, A.I., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR; Gusel'nikov, V.I., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR; Mashchenko, A.I., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR, Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, USSR
Abstract: The design, fabrication technology, and switching characteristics of superconducting foil breakers controlled by current pulses are described. The breakers have working currents of 800-1200 A, working voltages of up to 100 kV, and cutoff times of a few microseconds. A precharged capacitor is discharged to produce the control current.

Title: SPREADING THE LOAD FOR AIR CONDITIONING.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Thermal storage is shifting the energy load for cooling into off-peak hours and flattening maximum demand curves. Early efforts in stored cooling centered on chilled water storage, as a logical and seemingly simple extension of widely used chilled water system technology. However, the practice of chilled water storage has proved much more difficult than the theory. Baltimore Aircoil believes that cooling systems using ice storage can be designed with less connected load, less energy consumption and on occasions lower capital cost than conventional systems.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Thermal Load; ECONOMICS; REFRIGERATION - Applications; COOLING LOAD; LOAD SPREADING; THERMAL STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: FUEL REPROCESSING: FIZZLES IN U. S. BUT SIZZLES IN EUROPE.
Affiliations: McGraw-Hill World News, Washington,, DC, USA, McGraw-Hill World News, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bradford, Hazel, McGraw-Hill World News, Washington,, DC, USA, McGraw-Hill World News, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: While the U. S. chooses storage and permanent disposal of spent nuclear fuel, Europe continues to build reprocessing capacity in an atmosphere of economic and political debate. The article reviews existing as well as new spent nuclear fuel reprocessing facilities in France, the United Kingdom, West Germany, and Japan. Some economic considerations are also discussed. Reprocessing does seem to make economic sense, particularly for a country seeking energy self-sufficiency. The recovered uranium and plutonium from spent fuel can reduce a reactor's requirement for new, natural uranium by about 35%, and the need for uranium enrichment services by about 25%.
Index Keywords: INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Radioactive Materials; NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; RADIOACTIVE WASTES - Disposal; SPENT FUEL REPROCESSING PLANTS; SPENT NUCLEAR FUELS; NUCLEAR FUELS

Title: COMPACT REGULATED 5-kW POWER SUPPLY FOR PULSED GAS LASERS.
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Novosibirsk, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Novosibirsk, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Krasnikov, Yu.I., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Novosibirsk, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Novosibirsk, USSR; Malov, A.N., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Novosibirsk, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Novosibirsk, USSR
Abstract: A power supply for a pulsed laser is described that produces a regulated high voltage on the storage capacitors of the high-voltage generators for periodic operation. The supply charges the storage unit with one pulse produced by two-stage charge transfer through pulse transformers. The output voltage is controlled and regulated in a low-voltage circuit by a transistor switching regulator that operates from a three-phase 380-V line. The pulse energy is less than equivalent to 64 J, the repetition frequency is 1-1000 Hz, and the average power reaches 5 kW. The relative amplitude spread of the high-voltage pulses is less than 2%.
Index Keywords: LASER PULSES; LASERS, GAS - Components; PULSE GENERATORS; VOLTAGE-PULSE GENERATORS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, POWER SUPPLY

Title: HEAT RECOVERY FOR RESTAURANTS.
Authors with affiliations: Cohen, Jon
Abstract: Tens of thousands of U. S. restaurants could lower their energy bills by recovering heat rejected from air conditioners and using it to heat water. Information and tools are now available to help utilities promote heat recovery systems for this growing segment of their service areas. An easily installed heat recovery system, consisting of a heat exchanger, conventional pump and piping, and a water storage tank, should pay for itself within one to three years.
Index Keywords: WATER HEATERS; COST-EFFECTIVENESS; HEAT RECOVERY; RESTAURANTS; AIR CONDITIONING

Authors: Stahl Tilo, Fischer James R., Harris F.D.
Title: THERMAL ENERGY COMPONENT TO BIOGAS COGENERATION.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Mercedes-Benz Co, West Ger, Mercedes-Benz Co, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Stahl, Tilo, Mercedes-Benz Co, West Ger, Mercedes-Benz Co, West Ger; Fischer, James R., Mercedes-Benz Co, West Ger, Mercedes-Benz Co, West Ger; Harris, F.D., Mercedes-Benz Co, West Ger, Mercedes-Benz Co, West Ger
Abstract: The University of Missouri Integrated Energy Farm Project is an energy conversion system designed for maximum utilization of selected on-form energy resources. A subsystem is an engine/generator fueled with biogas whereby chemical energy is converted to electrical and thermal energy. This paper presents an analysis of the thermal energy component of this cogeneration process and a simple approach to thermal energy storage.
Index Keywords: BIOGAS - Analysis; ENERGY STORAGE; FARMS - Energy Utilization; BIOGAS COGENERATION; THERMAL ENERGY; COGENERATION PLANTS

Authors: Thoreson B.P., Alcock R., Christianson L.L.
Title: ELECTRIC CHOREMASTER I: TEST PROCEDURES AND RESULTS.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: South Dakota State Univ, Brookings,, SD, USA, South Dakota State Univ, Brookings, SD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thoreson, B.P., South Dakota State Univ, Brookings,, SD, USA, South Dakota State Univ, Brookings, SD, USA; Alcock, R., South Dakota State Univ, Brookings,, SD, USA, South Dakota State Univ, Brookings, SD, USA; Christianson, L.L., South Dakota State Univ, Brookings,, SD, USA, South Dakota State Univ, Brookings, SD, USA
Abstract: Test procedures and results for a battery powered chore tractor, the Electric Choremaster I, are presented. Maximum continuous power-take-off and drawbar power outputs were 12. 2 and 34. 7 kW, respectively. A model developed to predict energy requirements for standard test segments on an asphalt surface was developed. The accuracy of the model, when compared to an independent data set, was plus or minus 10 percent for standard cycles on a hard surface.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY - Testing; ENERGY UTILIZATION - Mathematical Models; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; ELECTRIC CHOREMASTER I; TRACTORS

Title: NEARLY ISOTROPIC PROPAGATION OF 0. 5 MICROMETER BUBBLES IN CONTIGUOUS DISK DEVICES.
Affiliations: Carnegie-Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh,, PA, USA, Carnegie-Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jo, Soonchul, Carnegie-Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh,, PA, USA, Carnegie-Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, PA, USA; Kryder, M.H., Carnegie-Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh,, PA, USA, Carnegie-Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
Abstract: 'Good' and 'bad' ion implanted bubble propagation tracks of variously shaped patterns (snake, diamond, circular and triangular shapes) were fabricated on garnet films for 0. 5 mu m bubbles with nearly isotropic magnetostriction. Quasistatic bias margin measurements show great improvement for bad track margins for all pattern shapes. The best overlapping bias margins were obtained from 2. 5- mu m period diamond-shaped patterns, which show a minimum drive field and 78-Oe margin width at 50-Oe drive. Snake patterns exhibit the best 'good' track margin with a minimum drive of 25 Oe and a margin width of 78 Oe at 50-Oe drive, but show somewhat inferior 'bad' track margins. It was found that 'bad' track margins of snake patterns are especially sensitive to ion implantation conditions and the propagation pattern cusp shape. By carefully adjusting ion implantation conditions (implantation energy and dosage) and the pattern cusp shape, nearly isotropic propagation was achieved for all propagation pattern shapes tested.
Index Keywords: MAGNETIC MATERIALS - Bubbles; MAGNETOSTRICTION; MAGNETIC BUBBLE MEMORIES; MAGNETIC DISK RECORDING; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Title: IR LAMP MODIFIED FOR VERTICAL BURN.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This article describes an infrared (IR) lamp modified for vertical burn. The glass of the lamp is dimpled to retain the supports in their desired position, thereby eliminating support shifting and stretching of filament and distortion. In diskette manufacturing equipment a vertical burning lamp is used to thermally set the side folds of diskettes. Focal point band variations after an IR lamp heats up during use can cause the energy level to drop and result in inadequate thermal setting of diskette cartridge folds. The arrangement disclosed eliminates this effect.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC - Disk; ELECTRIC LAMPS - Performance; IR LAMP; VERTICAL BURN; INFRARED DEVICES

Authors: Tagawa Hisatoshi, Matsui Kazuyuki, Izawa Tohru, Watanabe Itaru, Suzuki Motoaki, Tokunaga Takanobu
Title: NINE-PERCENT Ni STEEL PLATES MANUFACTURED BY THE DIRECT-QUENCHING AND TEMPERING PROCESS.

Abstract: Nine-percent Ni steel plates have many records of application to liquefied natural gas storage tanks, particularly to above-ground tanks. It is expected that these plates will enjoy a growing demand, but with more strict requirements for safety in the future. To cope with these requirements, NKK has been making earnest researches. As a result, it was found that, with the direct-quenching and tempering process after controlled rolling in which ultrapure CC slabs are used, not only energy-savings but also production of nine-percent Ni steel plates having more excellent material characteristics and brittle fracture arrestability could be realized.
Index Keywords: NATURAL GAS, LIQUEFIED - Heat Treatment; NICKEL AND ALLOYS - Storage; NICKEL METALLOGRAPHY - Microstructures; PLATES - Manufacture; INFLUENCE OF COOLING RATE; NICKEL STEEL PLATES; TANKS

Title: RHOMB-SHAPED CHECKERWORK - A NEW CONCEPT IN REGENERATOR LINING.
Affiliations: VGT-DYKO Industriekeramik Vertriebs, GmbH, Duesseldorf, West Ger, VGT-DYKO Industriekeramik Vertriebs GmbH, Duesseldorf, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Kuchta, H.D., VGT-DYKO Industriekeramik Vertriebs, GmbH, Duesseldorf, West Ger, VGT-DYKO Industriekeramik Vertriebs GmbH, Duesseldorf, West Ger
Abstract: A consideration of simple pyrometric relationships has resulted in the generation of some basic facts for the design and optimisation of a new shaped-brick system for regenerator lining. This article lists the characteristic features of rhomb-shaped checker work and explains its construction as well as the improvement in the heat transfer. The technical data are included in a Table. Pyrometric, static and structural advantages are highlighted and particular reference is made to energy saving. The article also contains a brief reference to costs and operating experience. Different lining systems, consisting of rectangular bricks with a thickness of 64mm and 76mm, respectively, are employed for the lining of glass furnace regenerators.
Index Keywords: BRICK - Design; FURNACES - Lining; HEAT TRANSFER - Optimization; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; HEAT EXCHANGE SURFACES; HEAT STORAGE CAPACITY; GLASS FURNACES

Title: Enhancing productivity with modular storage cabinets.
Authors with affiliations: Baker, R.; Montgomery, W.G.
Abstract: Several years before the advent of Medicare's prospective payment system and DRGs, which have caused many other hospitals to focus attention on cost reduction and central inventory control for the first time, St. Mary's had adopted central material management techniques. In recognizing that the cost of overhead materials cannot be passed along to the patients, the hospital took steps to keep these costs under control. Modular storage drawer cabinets are being used at the medical center to implement established policies because they proved to be more efficient than other material storage systems, including tote boxes, open shelving and wire-tray carts. As a capital equipment expenditure, the return-on-investment for these cabinets can be justified in terms of space savings estimated at 50% in the case of CSS. The flexibility, modularity and space efficiency of modular storage drawer cabinets meet St. Mary's desire to save time, energy and money.
Index Keywords: article; construction work and architectural phenomena; furniture; hospital bed capacity; hospital purchasing; productivity; standard; United States; Central Supply, Hospital; Efficiency; Facility Design and Construction; Hospital Bed Capacity, 500 and over; Interior Design and Furnishings; Tennessee

Title: USE OF PERIODICALLY LAYERED COMPOSITES AS A MECHANICAL NOTCH FILTER TO ISOLATE SELECTED HIGH FREQUENCY VIBRATION IN DATA RECORDING DISK FILES.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: In order to improve the track misregistration values of data recording disk files, it is necessary to effectively isolate sources of vibration, such as those which occur between the actuator assembly for moving the read/write transducers and the base plate for the drive motor for rotating the recording disks. A periodically layered stack of alternating materials which have wide differences in density and stiffness are located between the actuator mount and the base plate. Such periodic layers create a large impedance mismatch. Large differences in impedance result in rapid attenuation of an input wave for certain frequency ranges. This results in a mechanical filter which acts only in a specific frequency band to reduce the vibratory energy of the narrow band excitation. At other frequencies, the composite structure will transmit the vibratory energy unmodified, thus acting as a mechanical notch filter.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC - Disk; DATA RECORDING DISK FILES; HIGH FREQUENCY VIBRATIONS; MISREGISTRATION; NOTCH FILTER; PERIODICALLY LAYERED COMPOSITES; ELECTRIC FILTERS, ELECTROMECHANICAL

Title: POWER IS THE KEYSTONE.
Affiliations: NASA-Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA, NASA-Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, Ronald L., NASA-Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland,, OH, USA, NASA-Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The dominant feature of the space station is its electric power system, which also significantly affects station mass, stability and control, and cost. The large size, many uses, and evolutionary nature of the space station impose requirements like those on no other space power system. Besides being big and user-friendly, the system must be able to adapt readily to ever-changing demands; hence it is more like a terrestrial utility power plant than the typical fixed-purpose spacecraft system. A variety of options to meet these circumstances were evaluated. Major candidates were photovoltaic generation with electrochemical storage, solar dynamic generation with thermal energy storage, or a hybrid of both. Frequency, voltage, and architecture for the power management and distribution sub-system also received careful evaluation.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; SOLAR POWER PLANTS - Orbiting; SPACECRAFT

Title: DEMONSTRATION TEST OF A 500-KW PEAK-SHAVING LEAD-ACID BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM.

Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: In performance testing at the BEST Facility, a 500-kW peak-shaving battery energy storage plant met the requirements of a variety of typical utility- and customer-load-demand profiles with 65-75% energy storage efficiency. The system - whose major components are commercially available - is ready for trial use by utilities and their customers.

Title: Impaired monocyte function in glycogen storage disease type Ib
Affiliations: Department of Pediatrics, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, North 15, West 7, Saporo, 060, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ueno, N., Department of Pediatrics, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, North 15, West 7, Saporo, 060, Japan; Tomita, M., Department of Pediatrics, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, North 15, West 7, Saporo, 060, Japan; Ariga, T., Department of Pediatrics, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, North 15, West 7, Saporo, 060, Japan; Ohkawa, M., Department of Pediatrics, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, North 15, West 7, Saporo, 060, Japan; Nagano, S., Department of Pediatrics, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, North 15, West 7, Saporo, 060, Japan; Takahashi, Y., Department of Pediatrics, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, North 15, West 7, Saporo, 060, Japan; Arashima, S., Department of Pediatrics, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, North 15, West 7, Saporo, 060, Japan; Matsumoto, S., Department of Pediatrics, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, North 15, West 7, Saporo, 060, Japan
Abstract: Phagocyte (neutrophil and monocyte) function was evaluated in a boy with glycogen storage disease type Ib. Neutrophils were found to be defective in motility and respiratory burst and monocytes showed a defect in respiratory burst but not in motility. These results suggested that the glucose-6-phosphate transport system plays a role in the function of neutrophils and monocytes and that these two phagocytes are different from each other in their energy metabolism for motility. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Redox properties of zinc(II) tetra-N-methyl-2,3-pyridinoporphyrazine in aqueous solution
Affiliations: Chemical Kinetics Division, National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Davy Faraday Research Laboratory, The Royal Institution, 21 Albemarle Street, London, W1X 4BS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Richoux, M.-C., Chemical Kinetics Division, National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Abou-Gamra, Z.M., Davy Faraday Research Laboratory, The Royal Institution, 21 Albemarle Street, London, W1X 4BS, United Kingdom
Abstract: ZnTMPz4+ was studied in order to decide if the compound, or its close analogues had any real application in photoredox reactions capable of the storage of solar energy. The compound is reduced easily (E1/2 = tau; 0.02 V vs. NHE). The resultant piradical anion undergoes rapid disproportionation in neutral aqueous solution. Oxidation of the compound was very difficult, both electrochemically (E1 2 =>1.55 V vs. NHE) and with conventional oxidants. Altogether, such compounds seem to have little application in solar energy storage devices. © 1986.

Title: Experimental studies of photon-surface interaction dynamics in the alkali halides
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Astronomy Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, 37235, United States
Authors with affiliations: Haglund, R.F., Jr., Department of Physics and Astronomy Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, 37235, United States; Tolk, N.H., Department of Physics and Astronomy Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, 37235, United States
Abstract: We describe recent measurements which have provided, in unprecedented detail, insights into the electronic mechanisms through which energy carried into a material by photon irradiation is absorbed, localized and rechanneled to produce desorption, surface modification, erosion and damage. The specific object of these studies has been desorption induced by electronic transitions in alkali halide crystals, with particular emphasis on the dynamics of changes in the surface and near-surface regions. In our experiments, the irradiating ultraviolet photons are provided by a synchrotron storage ring, and the dynamical information about desorption products is obtained from optical measurements of the quantum states, yields and velocity distributions of neutral ground-state and excited-state atoms ejected from the surface of the irradiating material. These studies have shown that the dominant exit channels in photon-induced particle emission are those producing ground-state and excited-state neutral atoms. Using dynamical information about these desorbing neutral species, obtained, for example, by laser-induced fluorescence and laser Doppler spectroscopy, we are generating an increasingly comprehensive picture of the dynamics of electronic energy flow into and out of pure crystalline surfaces in these prototypical dielectrics. We are also beginning to be able to relate desorption dynamics to specific materials properties, and to discriminate between pure surface and near-surface effects in these materials. Applications of these techniques to the problem of photon-induced surface damage and to analysis of surface dynamics in dielectric materials are discussed, and the relationships between these nearly ideal model materials and the non-crystalline, covalently bonded materials more typical of real optical elements are pointed out. © 1986 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Alkali halides; Crystalline materials; Desorption; Dielectric materials; Dynamics; Excited states; Ground state; Optical data processing; Photons; X rays; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Storage Rings; CRYSTALS; DESORPTION; ELECTRONS - Transitions; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; Alkali-halide crystals; Crystalline surfaces; Desorption induced by electronic transitions; Electronic mechanisms; Laser induced fluorescence; Laser-Doppler spectroscopy; Surface interactions; Synchrotron storage ring; Materials properties; PHOTONS; ALKALI HALIDES; ELECTRONIC MECHANISMS; ELECTRONIC TRANSITIONS; PHOTON IRRADIATION; PHOTON-SURFACE INTERACTION DYNAMICS

Title: Energy budgets can explain body size relations
Affiliations: TNO Division, Technology for Society, P.O. Box 217, 2600 AE Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kooijman, S.A.L.M., TNO Division, Technology for Society, P.O. Box 217, 2600 AE Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: The size-dependence of some 20 physiological variables has been derived from a rather simple model for energy budgets. This nine parameter model is based on detailed observations on the growth and reproduction at varying food densities, and has the state variables size and storage. The size-dependence of some variables works out to be different for animals of the same species as opposed to animals of different species. The reproductive rate, for instance, tends to increase with size for animals of the same species, but to decrease with size for animals of different species. This is because the parameter values are constants within a species, but vary in a size dependent manner for animals of different species. Although growth at constant food density is assumed to be of the von Bertalanffy type, and routine metabolism to be proportional to size, respiration turns out to be about proportional to size to the power 3/4, both within and between species. The value of about 3/4 has frequently been found, but it has always been thought to be incompatible with von Bertalanffy growth. © 1986 Academic Press Inc. (London) Ltd.

Title: High temperature grain growth during slab reheating of oriented 3 pct Si-Fe made using continuous casting
Affiliations: Research and Technology, Armco Inc., Middletown, 45043, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schoen, J.W., Research and Technology, Armco Inc., Middletown, 45043, OH, United States
Abstract: Studies were made into the process behind the excessive grain growth which is observed in continuous cast slabs of both regular and high permeability oriented 3 Pct Si-Fe during reheating from 1230 °C to 1400 °C. These large grains are undesirable because of the greater difficulty incurred in obtaining the suitably uniform and fine primary grain size desired prior to the final high temperature anneal during which the (110) [001] texture is developed. It was found that the driving force for the growth is the subgrain structure which develops due to the strains of solidification and cooling during continuous casting; however, the temperature at which growth initiates is related to the austenite-ferrite phase relationship. The grain growth begins when the austenite which forms during slab reheating decomposes to form highly perfect ferrite which then grows by consuming the strained preexisting (as-cast) ferrite matrix. Data summarizing studies into the energy storage and recrystallization processes which occur with the use of slab breakdown (or prerolling) prior to reheating from 1230° to 1400 °C are also discussed. © 1986 The Metallurgical of Society of AIME.
Index Keywords: IRON AND STEEL METALLOGRAPHY - Grain Growth; ROLLING MILL PRACTICE - Hot Rolling; ELECTRICAL STEEL; GOSS TEXTURE; RECRYSTALLIZATION; SLAB REHEATING; SOLIDIFICATION; Silicon steel

Authors: Kamke W., Kamke B., Kiefl H.U., Wang Z., Hertel I.V.
Title: Intramolecular penning ionization in organic molecule-rare gas clusters
Affiliations: Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kamke, W., Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Kamke, B., Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Kiefl, H.U., Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Wang, Z., Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Hertel, I.V., Institut für Molekülphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimallee 14, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: A supersonic beam of organic molecules (benzonitrile (Bn), toluene (Tol), benzene (Bz) and pyridine (Pyr)) seeded into Ne or Ar was ionized by VUV radiation from the Berlin electron storage ring (BESSY). Photoionization efficiency curves were measured for Bn, Bn·Ne, Bn·Ar, Tol, Tol·Ar, Tol·Ne, Bz, Pyr, Pyr-Ar, and Pyr-Ne. Resonance peaks in these spectra at the positions of the atomic rare gas resonance lines confirm our previous measurements on Bn seeded into Ar and Kr, showing that the excitation energy of the rare gas atom is transferred to the attached organic molecule within a heterogeneous cluster, leading to ionization of the molecule and fragmentation of the cluster. © 1986.

Authors: Hopkins C.C.E., Nyholmen O., Solheim L.
Title: Qualitative and quantitative models relating otolith zone deposition to growth and condition in sexually mature male and female capelin (Mallotus villosus)
Affiliations: Aquatic Biology Group, Institute of Biology and Geology, University of Tromsø, Tromsø, N-9001, Norway; Department of Statistics, Institute of Mathermatical and Physical Sciences, University of Tromsø, Tromsø, N-9001, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Hopkins, C.C.E., Aquatic Biology Group, Institute of Biology and Geology, University of Tromsø, Tromsø, N-9001, Norway; Nyholmen, O., Aquatic Biology Group, Institute of Biology and Geology, University of Tromsø, Tromsø, N-9001, Norway; Solheim, L., Department of Statistics, Institute of Mathermatical and Physical Sciences, University of Tromsø, Tromsø, N-9001, Norway
Abstract: Correspondence analysis (CA) is used to examine the relationship between months, between selected body components/organs and between months and components/organs for male and female capelin from 12 to 37 months of age in Balsfijorden, northern Norway (69°21′N:19°06′E). The CA profiles have been used to quantify condition with regard to age and season. The major features determining the condition of fish depositing hyaline or opaque otolith zones are itemized using CA, and the data modelled by Multiple Regression (MR) using a cosine curve incorporating the chief mass variables with linear age-dependency. The highest proportion of fish having outer opaque zones are found from ca. June to October, whilst the highest proportion with exterior hyaline zones are found from ca. December to May. There is a clear annual cycle in the deposition of opaque and hyaline otolith zones in both sexes, but there is a significant difference in phase of ca. 12 days between the sexes. There is a significant trend for decreasing proportions of fish having outermost opaque otolith zones with increasing age; this trend is similar in both sexes. The mean level and amplitude of the cycles are similar in both sexes. On the other hand, CA shows a 12-month cycle of storage and utilization of body materials with obvious differences between sexes. In the female protein in the fillet plays a more dominant role than lipid in the fillet in accounting for anabolic and catabolic variations in mass, whereas in the male the opposite is true. Sexual maturation is negatively correlated with fillet (somatic) growth. Variations in stomach weight (with contents) and otolith zone deposition are not significantly correlated. Nevertheless, in both sexes there is a clear positive correlation between stomach weight and liver protein and lipid implying an association between stomach weight and feeding activity. In females, however, maximum liver condition is more positively correlated with exponential ovarian growth, probably through mobilization of lipoproteins for eggs. Qualitative (CA) and quantitative (MR) models have related changes in growth and condition to the type of otolith zone deposited. The fillet of capelin is the major somatic growth site. As CA indicates a negative correlation between fillet reserves and gonad maturation, and the best MR models describing the cycle of otolith zone deposition in males and females (accounting for 93% and 70% respectively of the variation) underlined and quantified the interplay between somatic and gonad growth, it is implicit that the energy balance of the fish will be an important determinant of otolith zone deposition in sexually maturing and mature capelin. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: Balsfjorden; capelin; Norway

Title: REVIEW OF SELF-IRRADIATION EFFECTS IN PU-SUBSTITUTED ZIRCONOLITE.
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Clinard Jr., Frank W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Abstract: Self-irradiation effects due to alpha decay in Pu-substituted zirconolite (CaPuTi//2O//7) have been assessed by dilatometry, TEM, microindentation testing, and differential thermal analysis. The crystalline material became metamict as a result of accumulation of alpha recoil tracks, with accompanying swelling, reduction of hardness, and increase in fracture toughness. Storage at elevated temperature partially or wholly suppressed metamicitization. Studies of recovery from the metamict state showed that ease of crystallization depends on extent of prior damage and that heavy damage reduces the amount of stored energy. These results are interpreted in terms of competition between damage accumulation and annealing, variations within the metamict state, and the role of a heterogeneous microstructure.
Index Keywords: DIFFERENTIAL THERMAL ANALYSIS; DILATOMETERS - Applications; RADIATION EFFECTS; ALPHA DECAY; METAMICTIZATION; PU-SUBSTITUTED ZIRCONOLITE; SELF-IRRADIATION EFFECTS; CERAMIC MATERIALS

Authors: Iocca James M., Kelsall Avery C., Potts Robert W.
Title: COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE, AN ALTERNATIVE TO PUMPED HYDRO.
Affiliations: ZEI Inc, USA, ZEI Inc, USA
Authors with affiliations: Iocca, James M., ZEI Inc, USA, ZEI Inc, USA; Kelsall, Avery C., ZEI Inc, USA, ZEI Inc, USA; Potts, Robert W., ZEI Inc, USA, ZEI Inc, USA
Abstract: Between now and the year 2000, it is almost inevitable that electrical utility capacity additions in th United States will employ energy storage cycles to a much greater extent than heretofore. In spite of project cancellations and delays for large base load thermal units, the proportion of such units in the average utility generation mix remains high. As utility peak loads increase some utility companies might consider using compressed air storage systems (CAES) for peak load shaving. This article presents a description of CAES facilities the theory behind CAES, and a comparison to pumped hydro units.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Energy Storage; CASE; COMPLESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE; PUMPED HYDRO; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: NEW MULTIPURPOSE DRY CASK PASSES HEAT AND DOSE RATE TESTS.
Affiliations: Transnuclear Inc, White Plains, NY,, USA, Transnuclear Inc, White Plains, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pennington, Charles W., Transnuclear Inc, White Plains, NY,, USA, Transnuclear Inc, White Plains, NY, USA
Abstract: The Transnuclear TN-24 is a dry storage transport cask designed to provide economical, long-term storage of spent nuclear fuel at an independent storage installation. It is also intended to be the transport packaging for delivering the stored spent nuclear fuel to either the Department of Energy's (DoE) Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) facility or a final respository. It is designed to store and to transport 24 PWR or 52 BWR intact fuel assemblies, with a maximum decay heat of 24kW. Transnuclear has used the TN-24 concept as the basis for the design of two special purpose storage/transport casks for Nuclear Fuel Services Inc. The TN-BRP holds 85 Big Rock Point fuel assemblies, and the TN-REG holds 40 Ginna fuel assemblies.
Index Keywords: CONTAINERS - Steel; NUCLEAR FUELS - Storage; TN-BRP; TN-REG; TRANSNUCLEAR TN-24; INDUSTRIAL WASTES

Title: HEAT TRANSFER IN ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT.
Affiliations: Univ of Kent, Canterbury, Engl, Univ of Kent, Canterbury, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Smith, K.L., Univ of Kent, Canterbury, Engl, Univ of Kent, Canterbury, Engl
Abstract: Active devices in electronic systems handle energy flows at various rates. In these processes, the efficiencies of power conversion into the wanted form never reach 100% and the 'losses' appear as low-grade heat energy. Efficiency can be defined in these systems as the fraction of the power input appearing in the wanted form at the output. Engineers attempt to raise the efficiency by using switching methods in power supplies, instead of dissipative control in the linear versions. Whichever design techniques are employed, such as those used to increase the efficiency, or whether dissipation is deliberately tolerated, removing the thermal energy produced is important. If heat is not removed quickly, the associated temperature rise could soon destroy the devices. In any event, increases in the operating temperature, or even high storage temperatures, will reduce the reliability of components, although they are below the burn-out point. Heat sinks, thermal conduction, convection and radiant heat loss are considered.
Index Keywords: HEAT SINKS; ACTIVE DEVICES; ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT

Title: ALUMINIUM AND ELECTROCHEMICAL ENERGY CONVERSION.
Affiliations: Univ of Belgrade, Belgrade, Yogosl, Univ of Belgrade, Belgrade, Yogosl
Authors with affiliations: Despic, A.R., Univ of Belgrade, Belgrade, Yogosl, Univ of Belgrade, Belgrade, Yogosl
Abstract: A review is presented of the developments in the use of aluminium in electrochemical power sources. In combination with an air-electrode, aluminium constitutes a fuel-cell or a mechanically rechargeable secondary battery. Two basic lines of research are followed with respect to the electrolyte: alkaline and saline. The alkaline aluminium-air cell is being developed into a large power battery for electric vehicle propulsion, based on the wedge-cell principle. Saline batteries using special low alloyed aluminium are suitable for many small-power applications. They are ecologically acceptable without restraint and hazardless for a common user. They have large energy density (350 Wh kg** minus **1) and give relatively cheap power. The simplest model delivers 250 h of light on periodical replacements of salt water.
Index Keywords: ALUMINUM AND ALLOYS - Applications; ELECTROLYTES - Materials; FUEL CELLS; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES - Equipment; ALUMINUM AIR CELL; ENERGY DENSITY; WEDGE-CELL PRINCIPLE; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: CEA Research and Development in Support of the Fuel Cycle Industry. [LA R&D AU CEA, SUPPORT DE L'INDUSTRIE DU CYCLE DES COMBUSTIBLES.]
Affiliations: CEA, Fr, CEA, Fr

Abstract: Since its creation, the French Atomic Energy Commissariat (CEA) which had been given the responsibility to create the means necessary to master atomic energy, has developed simultaneously reactors and cycle industry. Cycle means mining and ore processing, fuel fabrication, reprocessing and plutonium production, enrichment and waste conditioning and storage. The article discusses some aspects of the cycle, namely reprocessing and fuel fabrication, concerning mainly Cogema (manufacturer, covering the complete fuel cycle) and CEA (research establishment concerned partly with nuclear R&D).

Title: Interaction of vinyl chloride with poly(vinyl chloride) by inverse gas chromatography: effect of monomer concentration, plasticizer content and temperature
Affiliations: Laboratory of Food Chemistry, Dept. of Chemistry, University of Ioannina, Ioannina, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Demertzis, P.G., Laboratory of Food Chemistry, Dept. of Chemistry, University of Ioannina, Ioannina, Greece; Kontominas, M.G., Laboratory of Food Chemistry, Dept. of Chemistry, University of Ioannina, Ioannina, Greece
Abstract: The interaction of vinyl chloride (VC) with poly(vinyl)chloride) (PVC) has been studied by inverse gas chromatography (IGC). The present work focusses on the effect of monomer concentration, temperature and plasticizer content. Values for thermodynamic parameters such as free energy (ΔGs), excess free energy (ΔGxss), enthalphy (ΔHs), entropy (Δs) and activity coefficient (γs) corresponding to sorption of the monomer (VCM) by the polymer, have been calculated using chromatographic data. It was found that retention of VC by PVC is favored at lower monomer concentrations. Increase in temperature resulted in increase of ΔGsΔGxss, and γs values corresponding to a less spontaneous process or a weaker interaction between VC and PVC. An increase in plasticizer content of the polymer resulted in an increase of degree of binding of the monomer. Data support the hypothesis that at significantly low concentrations of residual monomer, low storage temperatures and high concentrations of plasticizer, in the polymer, the probability of migration of VC from a plastics packaging material into a food contacting phase is markedly reduced. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: plasticizer; polyvinyl derivative; polyvinylchloride; vinyl chloride; vinyl derivative; article; gas chromatography; temperature; Chromatography, Gas; Plasticizers; Polyvinyl Chloride; Polyvinyls; Temperature; Vinyl Chloride; Vinyl Compounds

Title: ANALYSIS OF MINI-COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE PLANTS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: A compressed-air energy storage (CAES) plant uses off-peak power to compress air into an underground reservoir. During periods of intermediate and peak demand, the air is heated and directed into an expansion turbine to produce electricity. A project was undertaken in order to evaluate and optimize turbomachinery equipment for 25- and 50-Mw CAES modular plants that use salt caverns, rock caverns, and aquifer reservoirs to store the compressed air. This evaluation, based on manufacturers' technical and cost proposals, shows that such plants are economically attractive, have short construction lead times, and use components available from U. S. and foreign manufacturers.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; TURBOMACHINERY; COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE PLANTS; EPRI; MODULAR PLANTS; OFF-PEAK POWER; PEAK DEMAND; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS

Authors: Babiak R., Leonardi E., Reizes J.A.
Title: USE OF OFF-PEAK ELECTRICITY FOR COOLING OF MULTISTOREY BUILDINGS IN SYDNEY.
Source title: Australian refrigeration, Air conditioning and heating
Affiliations: Dep of Housing & Construction, Sydney, Aust, Dep of Housing & Construction, Sydney, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Babiak, R., Dep of Housing & Construction, Sydney, Aust, Dep of Housing & Construction, Sydney, Aust; Leonardi, E., Dep of Housing & Construction, Sydney, Aust, Dep of Housing & Construction, Sydney, Aust; Reizes, J.A., Dep of Housing & Construction, Sydney, Aust, Dep of Housing & Construction, Sydney, Aust
Abstract: The application of off-peak electricity in air conditioning has significant potential for energy management. In this paper, a theoretical study of an energy-efficient air conditioning installation is presented. Ice storage is an integral part of this system which uses a standard heat pump for cooling in a typical office building in Sydney. It is shown that such an arrangement is at present not feasible but could be economical in special circumstances.

Title: Giant polarization in high polymers
Affiliations: National Magnet Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Building NW-14, Cambridge, 02139, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pohl, H.A., National Magnet Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Building NW-14, Cambridge, 02139, MA, United States
Abstract: In the course of studying the properties of highly conjugated polymers we found that long range orbital delocalization conferred unexpected properties. The presence of giant electronic orbitals made these materials electroactive yet very stable. A new mode of electronic polarizability resulted, a giant nomadic polarization, making these organic polymers among the most polarizable materials ever encountered. In addition, yet other attributes could be found, such as remanent magnetization, or metallic conductivity, or unusual pressure sensitivity. The giant orbital concept opens up new vistas of materials properties. We note that one can tailor giant orbital polymers to produce pure and highly stable super-dielectrics with high dielectric constants, from 6 to 100,000. Such materials will be useful in the electric power control, as in large motor starting capacitors and in power factor correction. They will doubtless also be useful in low visibility coatings, in obscuration, in EMP shielding, in microcircuitry, in transducers, and in parametric circuits. It remains to be proven if this new molecular mode, nomadic polarization, proves superior in energy storage and loss to that of the conventional "dipole orientation" mode. Preliminary results indicate an advantage for the new giant orbital materials. © 1986 The Metallurgical of Society of AIME.
Author Keywords: electroactive polymers; high dielectric constant materials; superdielectrics

Authors: Lunan W.E., Sferrazza M.J., Franzen R.G., May W.D.
Title: CURL-SETTING DURING STORAGE OF THERMOMECHANICAL PULP AT HIGH CONSISTENCY.
Source title: Journal of Pulp and Paper Science
Affiliations: Abitibi-Price Inc, Jonquiere, Que,, Can, Abitibi-Price Inc, Jonquiere, Que, Can
Authors with affiliations: Lunan, W.E., Abitibi-Price Inc, Jonquiere, Que,, Can, Abitibi-Price Inc, Jonquiere, Que, Can; Sferrazza, M.J., Abitibi-Price Inc, Jonquiere, Que,, Can, Abitibi-Price Inc, Jonquiere, Que, Can; Franzen, R.G., Abitibi-Price Inc, Jonquiere, Que,, Can, Abitibi-Price Inc, Jonquiere, Que, Can; May, W.D., Abitibi-Price Inc, Jonquiere, Que,, Can, Abitibi-Price Inc, Jonquiere, Que, Can
Abstract: The effect of storing hot thermomechanical pulp at high consistency directly after the refiners has been investigated. Experiments showed that the latency took several times as long to remove in a disintegrator after the pulp had been stored. Pulp stored above 65 degree C also developed a residual latency which could not be removed even after a long period of disintegration. The residual latency was attributed to curl-setting in the fibers. It was usually accompanied by a loss in brightness which was attributed to accelerated aging of the pulp. An activation energy was derived for the changes in pulp properties, which may allow the effects of storage under any conditions to be predicted.
Index Keywords: OPTICAL PROPERTIES; PAPERMAKING; PULP MANUFACTURE - Thermomechanical Process; THERMAL EFFECTS; CURL-SETTING; LATENCY; PULP AGING; PULP PROPERTIES; THERMOMECHANICAL PULP STORAGE; PULP

Title: MARKET CONSTRAINTS FOR RESIDENTIAL COOL STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Cool storage is becoming widely accepted for comfort cooling of commercial buildings, but improvements in the technology are needed to realize similar opportunities in the residential market. As this study points out, the residential cool storage are likely to exceed the expected cost of equipment. A simplified method to assess the value of residential cool storage was developed and presented during a workshop hosted by the Salt River Project in March 1984. The participants discussed engineering issues associated with developing a viable residential system and adopted the method with minor modifications. Twenty-one utilities used a microcomputer version of the simplified assessment methodology to derive results for their service areas. An additional eight utilities supplied information to allow estimation of minimum system benefits.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Energy Storage; ECONOMICS; HOUSES - Energy Storage; ICE - Cold Storage; REFRIGERATION; COMFORT COOLING; COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS; RESIDENTIAL COOL STORAGE; UTILITIES; AIR CONDITIONING

Title: UTILITIES EMPLOY ENERGY STORAGE FOR LOAD MANAGEMENT.
Affiliations: Power Engineering, Barrington, IL,, USA, Power Engineering, Barrington, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Smith, Douglas J., Power Engineering, Barrington, IL,, USA, Power Engineering, Barrington, IL, USA
Abstract: Load management and conservation programs allow utilities to reduce their power system losses, and postpone the construction of new generation, transmission, and distribution facilities, resulting in reduced generation production costs. Utility companies and their customers can save money by utlilizing off-peak heating and cooling storage systems. A utility saves by deferring construction of new plants and operating its existing equipment more efficiently. Utility customers can save money by taking advantage of lower off-peak or time-of-day rates. The author discusses the use of chilled-water and ice storage systems as off-peak cooling systems to meet demands during peak-load summer periods in the United States and compressed-air energy storage systems for meeting peak power demands. Finally, he describes research being done in the field of battery storage using some advanced designs.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: AC POWER TRAINS FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLES.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Both ac and dc power trains have progressed significantly since 1979, but ac systems may soon overtake the dc systems. In particular, the report identifies a Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) ac power train as potentially the lightest and least-expensive ac system now under development. That system, begun by DOE and continuing in EPRI project RP2861, promises cost and weight reductions of more than 60% from the 1979 dc system used as a benchmark in the study. In an electric fleet van, the JPL power train could cut initial costs by 10-12% and life-cycle costs by approximately 6% without loss of range or performance. Though the main components of the JPL power train - the ac inverter and induction motor - have tested well, the system is incomplete. Integration into the system of such auxiliaries as dashboard instrumentation, a battery charger, and a battery management subsystem is still needed.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILES - Electric; ELECTRIC INVERTERS; ELECTRIC MOTORS, AC - Applications; PROPULSION - Electric Energy; VEHICLES - Electric Drive; AC POWER TRAINS; DC SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; WEIGHT REDUCTION; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Title: ULTRAHIGH HEAD PUMP/TURBINE DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The commercial availability of an ultrahigh head pump/turbine whose output can be regulated makes underground and ultrahigh head-pumped storage creditable options for utility use by reducing construction costs and plant complexity. This new turbine operates at double the head of existing equipment yet uses commercial materials, proven design concepts, and manageable manufacturing techniques. The regulated ultrahigh head pump/turbine is a two-stage unit with two sets of wicket gates to rapidly regulate output. On the basis of a project concept involving a 1500-m head and machine output in the range of 600 MW, a design evolved with a speed of 720 rpm. The resulting pump/turbine provides 655 mw at maximum head and 610 mw at minimum head, with discharges of 53 m**3/s and 52 m**3/s, respectively. An eight-volume report describes the progress of the development program. Volume 1 presents an overall summary of the work.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HYDRAULIC TURBINES; PUMPS, TURBINE; ULTRAHIGH HEAD PUMP/TURBINE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Authors: Anikeev V.I., Parmon V.N., Aristov Yu.I., Zheivot V.I., Kirillov V.A., Zamaraev K.I.
Title: THERMOCATALYTIC SOLAR-TO-CHEMICAL ENERGY TRANSDUCER WITH A HIGH ENERGY-STORAGE COEFFICIENT.
Authors with affiliations: Anikeev, V.I.; Parmon, V.N.; Aristov, Yu.I.; Zheivot, V.I.; Kirillov, V.A.; Zamaraev, K.I.
Abstract: This paper presents the results of an experimental study of the efficiency of thermochemical transformation of solar energy by the conversion of saturated hydrocarbons. In addition to reaction (1), where carbon dioxide gas was needed, the authors have studied processes for the conversion of methane and a propane-butane mixture with steam that are apparently even more promising for the transformation and storage of solar energy.

Authors: Vijayamohanan K., Shukla A.K., Sathyanarayana S.
Title: STATISTICAL OPTIMIZATION OF IRON ELECTRODES FOR ALKALINE STORAGE BATTERIES.
Affiliations: Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India, Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Vijayamohanan, K., Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India, Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India; Shukla, A.K., Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India, Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India; Sathyanarayana, S., Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India, Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India
Abstract: A pressed-plate iron electrode for alkaline storage batteries, designed using a statistical method (fractional factorial technique), is described. Parameters such as the configuration of the base grid, electrode compaction temperature and pressure, binder composition, mixing time, etc. have been optimized using this method. The optimized electrodes have a capacity of 300 plus or minus 5 mAh/g of active material (mixture of iron and magnetite) at 7h rate to a cut-off voltage of minus 0. 86 V vs Hg/HgO, OH** minus .

Title: LIGNITE GRINDING AND FIRING EQUIPMENT FOR TA-LUANG FACTORY OF THE SIAM CEMENT CO. , LTD. (THAILAND).
Affiliations: IHI, Tokyo, Jpn, IHI, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Kobayashi, Toshihiro, IHI, Tokyo, Jpn, IHI, Tokyo, Jpn; Egami, Kenji, IHI, Tokyo, Jpn, IHI, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: An installation for firing lignite procurable at a low price in Thailand in a calcining furnace incorporated into two 4,000 t/d cement kilns at a plant of the Siam Cement Co. , Ltd. was recently completed. The lignite, however, contains high moisture, has a wide variation in quality, and is subject to strong weathering. A lignite storage furnished with an IHI stacker-reclaimer has provided a sufficiently homogenizing effect, and a dry-grinding system composed of an IHI vertical dryer and an IHI-MBF roller mill was proved to be highly safe in operation and to insure considerable energy savings. With lignite firing, two kilns revealed an increase in heat consumption by approx. 1 to 1. 5% as compared with an exclusive oil firing, but they enable considerable production cost savings.
Index Keywords: COAL PREPARATION - Grinding; KILNS - Process Heating; LIGNITE - Grinding; LIGNITE FIRING INSTALLATION; LIGNITE STACKER; LIGNITE STORAGE; CEMENT PLANTS

Title: MICRONISED COAL FOR OIL-TO-COAL CONVERSIONS.
Affiliations: Stordy Combustion Engineering Ltd, Wolverhampton, Engl, Stordy Combustion Engineering Ltd, Wolverhampton, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D., Stordy Combustion Engineering Ltd, Wolverhampton, Engl, Stordy Combustion Engineering Ltd, Wolverhampton, Engl
Abstract: With falling oil prices, the incentive to convert oil-fired boiler plant to coal firing is less urgent than it has been for many years. However, it remains an option which should be considered by energy managers. An article in the July/August 1985 issue of CME discussed a system which ground coal to 98% less than 40 microns in a steam mill. The following article describes a similar system using a different type of mill. Since particle sizes are comparable, burn-out time and profile, ash particle size, burner ratings, etc. , are also comparable.

Authors: Forty A.J., El-Mashri S.M., Jones R.G., Dupree R., Farnan I.
Title: SURFACE EXAFS AND MAGIC ANGLE SPINNING NMR STUDIES OF ANODICALLY FORMED OXIDE FILMS ON ALUMINIUM.
Affiliations: Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl, Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Forty, A.J., Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl, Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl; El-Mashri, S.M., Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl, Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl; Jones, R.G., Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl, Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl; Dupree, R., Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl, Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl; Farnan, I., Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl, Univ of Warwick, Coventry, Engl
Abstract: The techniques of electron yield-EXAFS and magic angle spinning-NMR have been used to derive information about the different structures of amorphous films, formed anodically on pure aluminum in various electrolyte solutions (tartaric, oxalic, boric, phosphoric and chromic acids). The electron yield from the oxidized surfaces were measured to obtain EXAFS spectra over a range of incident x-ray energies extending from 1500 ev (to include the Al K-edge absorption) up to about 2000 ev. This was carried out using the ACO storage ring and double-crystal soft x-ray monochromator operated at the National Scientific Research Centre, Orsay Laboratory (France). The analysis of these EXAFS data was carried out by the Fourier transform method. It has been found that the uniform non-porous (barrier type) oxide films which are formed in neutralized sodium tartrate or sodium borate electrolytes are amorphous and have an average Al-O bondlength of 0. 19 nm.
Index Keywords: ALUMINUM AND ALLOYS; NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE; SPECTROSCOPY, X-RAY; ABSTRACT ONLY; ALUMINUM OXIDE FILMS; ANODIC OXIDATION; EXAFS SPECTRA; MAGIC ANGLE SPINNING NMR STUDIES; SURFACES

Authors: Itaya Yoshinori, Arai Norio, Hasatani Masanobu
Title: CHARACTERISTICS OF RADIATIVE ENERGY COLLECTION BY A FINE-PARTICLE SEMITRANSPARENT SUSPENSION (FPSS) USED AS A VEHICLE AND STORAGE MEDIUM OF A 'VOLUME HEAT-TRAP' TYPE SOLAR COLLECTOR.
Affiliations: Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Itaya, Yoshinori, Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn; Arai, Norio, Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn; Hasatani, Masanobu, Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn
Abstract: The effects of suspension concentration, depth of layer and boundary optical condition on the rate and efficiency of radiative energy collection of a volume heat-trap type solar collector in which a FPSS is used as a heat vehicle and storage medium were studied experimentally and theoretically. Experiments were conducted for the stagnant layer of a graphite-diethylphthalate suspension, heated stepwise by a Xe-lamp from the upper side. The theoretically calculated results were in satisfactory agreement with the experimental data, and it was shown that the efficiency of radiative energy collection in this type of solar collector could surpass easily that in the surface heat-trap collector.
Index Keywords: TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; SOLAR COLLECTOR EFFICIENCY; SUSPENSION CONCENTRATION; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: Point charge passing a resonator with beam tubes
Affiliations: CERN, Genève 23, CH-1211, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Henke, H., CERN, Genève 23, CH-1211, Switzerland
Abstract: Charged particle beams interact with the surroundings because of the co-travelling electromagnetic fields. This interaction limits the beam. One of the most interesting cases is a point charge travelling with arbitrary velocity along the axis of a cylindrical resonator with two semi-infinite tubes. Without the cylindrical wall of the resonator, the structure consists of two tubes connected by an infinite radial line. In the tube region the fields are given by the source fields plus a continuous spectrum of waveguide modes. In the resonator region a discrete set of modes is used. Matching the fields at the common interface yields a system of linear equations for the expansion coefficients. The occurring integrals contain fractions of the Bessel function and its derivative, which were expanded into algebraic series of Bessel function zeros, and are solved by means of the residuum calculus. Numerical results are given for the coupling impedance between charge and structure and for the energy loss of a Gaussian charge distribution. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS; ELECTRON BEAMS; ELECTRON TUBES, KLYSTRON; ELECTRON TUBES, TRAVELING WAVE; RESONATORS; BEAMS OF CHARGED PARTICLES; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; HIGH-CURRENT ACCELERATORS; STORAGE RINGS; CHARGED PARTICLES
