Authors: Summers D.P., Leach S., Frese Jr. K.W.
Title: The electrochemical reduction of aqueous carbon dioxide to methanol at molybdenum electrodes with low overpotentials
Affiliations: Materials Research Laboratory, SRI International, 333 Ravenswood Ave, Menlo Park, CA 94025, United States
Authors with affiliations: Summers, D.P., Materials Research Laboratory, SRI International, 333 Ravenswood Ave, Menlo Park, CA 94025, United States; Leach, S., Materials Research Laboratory, SRI International, 333 Ravenswood Ave, Menlo Park, CA 94025, United States; Frese Jr., K.W., Materials Research Laboratory, SRI International, 333 Ravenswood Ave, Menlo Park, CA 94025, United States
Abstract: Electrolysis using molybdenum electrodes in a pH 4.2, 0.2 M Na2SO4 carbon dioxide saturated solution produces methanol as the major carbon-containing product. The reduction proceeds at room temperature and -0.7 to -0.8 V vs. SCE with faradaic efficiencies of ≥ 50% (efficiencies of near 100% have been measured in some cases). These potentials represent electrolysis at only 160 mV negative of the standard potential corrected for pH. Methanol can also be obtained with good efficiency in 0.05 M H2SO4 at -0.57 to -0.67 V vs. SCE. Electrolysis also produces small amounts of carbon monoxide and traces of methane. No more than a trace of methane was produced even at 52°C. Extended electrolysis of molybdenum electrodes indicates that even over several days the production of methanol does not cease but the faradaic efficiency does increase. Molybdenum will reduce carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide at open circuit. Cyclic voltammetry implicates corrosion of molybdenum metal to molybdenum dioxide as the source of electrons for open circuit reduction of carbon dioxide. Analysis of the solution after electrolysis shows no molybdenum and cyclic voltammetry indicates no detectable molybdenum dioxide on the surface indicating that the electrodes are cathodically protected during electrolysis. If the electrode are cycled between -1.2 and +0.2 V vs. SCE before electrolysis, greater than 100% faradaic efficiencies are observed. The extent of cyclic is critical with yields reaching a maximum with cycling time and extended cycling leading to total passivation of the electrode. These efficiencies involve, at least in part, corrosion of the molybdenum metal. Cycled electrodes will also produce methanol at a low rate at open circuit. © 1986.
Index Keywords: CARBON DIOXIDE - Reduction; METHANOL - Manufacture; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; CYCLIC VOLTAMMETRY; MOLYBDENUM DIOXIDE; MOLYBDENUM ELECTRODE; ELECTROCHEMISTRY

Abstract: The design and performance of several experimental configurations of alexandrite laser pumped intracavity raman lasers are described. These lasers combine the high energy storage of alexandrite with the high gain of the raman medium. They can produce short high-energy pulses of broadly tunable, raman shifted light. © 1986 SPIE.

Authors: Claassen H.C., Reddy M.M., Halm D.R.
Title: Use of the chloride ion in determining hydrologic-basin water budgets - A 3-year case study in the San Juan Mountains, Colorado, U.S.A.
Affiliations: U.S. Geological Survey MS-416, Denver Federal Center, Denver, CO 80225 U.S.A., United States
Authors with affiliations: Claassen, H.C., U.S. Geological Survey MS-416, Denver Federal Center, Denver, CO 80225 U.S.A., United States; Reddy, M.M., U.S. Geological Survey MS-416, Denver Federal Center, Denver, CO 80225 U.S.A., United States; Halm, D.R., U.S. Geological Survey MS-416, Denver Federal Center, Denver, CO 80225 U.S.A., United States
Abstract: Measurement of chloride concentration and water equivalent in precipitation and recharge at a site can be extrapolated to determine available moisture in a nearby basin. This method also may be extrapolated to a basin with similar climatic characteristics if precipitation, vegetation, and topographic data are available. The average accuracy of the total of evaporation, recharge, and runoff (assuming no storage) was about 10% of total precipitation. Soil-moisture measurements indicate the entire 10% error in moisture balance can be attributed to annual changes in storage. Data requirements for the method are considerably less than data requirements for energy-budget methods to determine available moisture. Potential applications of the method to hydrologic problem-solving are: 1. (1) Estimating total available moisture from chloride concentrations in groundwater or surface water or both. 2. (2) Modeling paleoclimate scenarios and evaluating their correctness by comparison with paleo-groundwater chloride concentrations. 3. (3) Providing an independent comparison for water budgets obtained by energy-budget methods. Obviously the method cannot be applied readily to systems with a lithologic source of chloride. Most systems primarily consisting of tuff, intrusive volcanic rock, nonmarine sediments, quartzite, and other metamorphic rocks will be suitable for application of the model. © 1986.
Index Keywords: CHLORINE COMPOUNDS - Trace Analysis; FLOW OF WATER - Porous Materials; METEOROLOGY - Atmospheric Precipitation; SOILS - Moisture; WATER, UNDERGROUND; CHLORIDE ION; HYDROLOGIC-BASIN WATER BUDGETS; WATERSHEDS

Title: Increasing the energy of SLC by transient wake field

Abstract: This paper describes a way to make use of the field excited by the beam in the disk-loaded waveguide combined with the rf field in phase, to increase the output energy of the linear accelerator at the expense of beam duty cycle. Actually, the whole facility can be operated with both a Linac and storage rings. © 1986.

Title: Soft X-ray emission studies of metal-hydrogen bonding states in zirconium-based laves phase hydrides
Affiliations: Institute for Materials' Science Problems, Ukrainian S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Krzyzhanovskii Str. 3, 252180, KievU.S.S.R.
Authors with affiliations: Porutsky, S.G., Institute for Materials' Science Problems, Ukrainian S.S.R. Academy of Sciences, Krzyzhanovskii Str. 3, 252180, KievU.S.S.R.
Abstract: Parameters of X-ray L emission spectra of all transition metals in the system of Laves phase hydrides ZrVMeHx (Me ≡ Cr, Fe, Co, Cu) have been analysed. The analysis shows unequal participation of valence d states of intermetallic components in metal-hydrogen bonding. Different energy positions of hydrogen atoms in tetrahedral interstitial sites formed by different sets of metal atoms cause splitting of the hydride subband of Zr Lβ2.15 emission spectra. A correlation between characteristics of Zr Lβ2.15 emission and hydride thermal stability is found. Valence d states of vanadium take part in metal-hydrogen bonding to a lesser extent than those of zirconium. The d states of chromium, iron, cobalt and copper participate still less in bonding with hydrogen. © 1986.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN INORGANIC COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN STORAGE MATERIALS; LAVES PHASE HYDRIDES; ZIRCONIUM COMPOUNDS

Title: Application of Optical Instrumentation in Medicine XIV and Picture Archiving and Communication Systems
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Abstract: The proceedings contain 100 papers. The topics discussed include: acoustic nuclear magnetic resonance in biological tissue; perfluorocarbon compounds: applications in diagnostic imaging; a statistical approach to an expert diagnostic ultrasonic system; pet imaging of the chemistry of the brain; dual energy imaging in projection radiography; principal components analysis in medical imaging; application of digital fluoroscopic image data in radiation dosimetry; sources of noise in high-resolution screen-film radiography; storage phosphor system for computed radiography: destructive scanning; and storage phosphor system for computed radiography: screen optics.

Title: A thermoanalytical study of the decomposition of a double-base propellant
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Ingegneria Chimica, Dei Materiali, Delle Materie Prime e Metallurgia, Via del Castro Laurenziano 7, Roma Italy
Authors with affiliations: Rodante, F., Dipartimento di Ingegneria Chimica, Dei Materiali, Delle Materie Prime e Metallurgia, Via del Castro Laurenziano 7, Roma Italy
Abstract: The thermal decomposition of a double-base propellant was investigated by isothermal and dynamic DSC and by dynamic TG. In addition the rate constant and the order of the reaction of the decomposition process were determined by DSC analysis. The kinetic parameters (activation energy E and Arrhenius pre-exponential term A) for the thermal decomposition were confirmed by half-life test. Thus they can be used as a screening technique to predict potential explosive hazards due to self-heating during storage at lower temperatures than those of the peak temperatures. An attempt has been made to compare the behaviour of the double-base propellant with those of the two components. It is suggested that the thermal combustion of nitroglycerin is the driving kinetic process of the overall thermal decomposition. © 1986.

Title: Lipid composition of twenty-two species of Antarctic midwater zooplankton and fish
Affiliations: Department of Marine Science, University of South Florida, 140 Seventh Avenue South, St. Petersburg, 33701, Florida, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reinhardt, S.B., Department of Marine Science, University of South Florida, 140 Seventh Avenue South, St. Petersburg, 33701, Florida, United States; Van Vleet, E.S., Department of Marine Science, University of South Florida, 140 Seventh Avenue South, St. Petersburg, 33701, Florida, United States
Abstract: Total lipids, hydrocarbons, wax esters, triacylglycerols, and phospholipids were determined for 22 major biomass species of zooplankton and fish in an Antarctic mesopelagic community that were collected in 1982 and 1983. Lipid levels were similar to levels in more temperate mesopelagic species. Total lipid concentration was depth related, with all lipid-rich species being collected at depths greater than 230 m. Wax ester content in copepods (60 to 70% of the total lipid) was generally higher than in subtropical species. Lipids indicated three predator-prey relationships (Parandania boecki-Atolla wyvillei, Thysanoessa macrura-Calanoides acutus and Eurythenes gryllus-Atolla wyvillei). These were confirmed by gut content analyses. The mesopelagic fish Bathylagus antarcticus, Pleuragramma antarcticum, and Protomyctophum bolini stored most lipid intramuscularly, whereas Electrona antarctica and Gymnoscopelus nicholsi contained extensive stores in subcutaneous lipid sacs. The intramuscular lipids in P. antarcticum and the subcutaneous lipid sacs of E. antarctica were primarily wax esters, possibly used for increased buoyancy or long-term energy storage. Unlike the odd-carbon preference of aliphatic hydrocarbons which typifies terrestrial plants and temperate marine organisms, even-carbon chain-length paraffins predominate in 80% of the Antarctic species analyzed. Although the source of these even-carbon n-alkanes cannot be determined from our data, their dominance in the species analyzed suggests that an unusual biochemical pathway may be responsible for their synthesis in this ecosystem. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.

Title: POTENTIAL FOR THE AIR-CONDITIONING OF OFFICE BUILDINGS WITHOUT MECHANICAL REFRIGERATION.
Affiliations: van Aarle & Herman Consulting, Engineers, Johannesburg, S Afr, van Aarle & Herman Consulting Engineers, Johannesburg, S Afr
Authors with affiliations: van Aarle, Gijbertus, van Aarle & Herman Consulting, Engineers, Johannesburg, S Afr, van Aarle & Herman Consulting Engineers, Johannesburg, S Afr; Herman, Toon, van Aarle & Herman Consulting, Engineers, Johannesburg, S Afr, van Aarle & Herman Consulting Engineers, Johannesburg, S Afr
Abstract: Mechanical refrigeration has always been accepted as an essential part of an air-conditioning system. It is complex and expensive to own and operate. The possibility of providing acceptable space conditions, using cool night air for precooling the building structure at night is explored in South Africa. Guidelines are provided to the building designer towards achieving the objective of making the building the major climate modifier and using the ventilation system as the refining element only. The ventilation strategy should be based on supplying as much outside air as possible during those periods when the outside air can contribute to the cooling of the building, and reducing the amount of air to the minimum required for ventilation and air movement during the rest of the day. This can be done by thermostat or by hand, and may be zoned if required, using speed controlled fans or multiple fans.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Design; FANS - Applications; METEOROLOGY - Climatology; REFRIGERATION; VENTILATION - Energy Conservation; COOL NIGHT AIR UTILIZATION; MECHANICAL REFRIGERATION; OUTSIDE AIR VENTILATION; ROCK BEDS; THERMAL STORAGE; OFFICE BUILDINGS

Title: HEAT STORAGE IN SALT GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS.
Source title: Journal of the Institution of Engineers (India), Part IDP: Interdisciplinary Panels
Affiliations: Natl Research Cent, Cairo, Egypt, Natl Research Cent, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Helwa, N.H., Natl Research Cent, Cairo, Egypt, Natl Research Cent, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: The amount of heat absorbed by the solar ponds depends on the portion of the solar radiation absorbed at the lower convective zone (LCZ), from which heat can be extracted. The one dimensional, time dependent equation of heat conduction has been solved using an equation of the thermal conductivity of the saline water as a function of the salinity and temperature. The time dependent equation of the diffusion of solute (NaCl) through a solvent has also been solved to find the form of variation of the salinity with the depth and the time.
Index Keywords: SODIUM CHLORIDE - Solutions; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Solar Ponds; SALINE WATER; SALT GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR INTENSITY; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: CONSUMER PREFERENCES FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLES.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: A project was undertaken to conduct a consumer survey of various conventional and EV choices for a second car, and to apply an econometric model to the survey results as a basis for estimating future demand for EVs. Based on resulting data, it is argued that a small-sample survey of consumer preferences for a second car - featuring both conventional and electric vehicle choices - indicates a proelectric bias. The potential of electric cars in the utility market largely depends on dramatic improvements in battery technology and the right mix of electricity and gasoline prices.
Index Keywords: STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES - Energy Conservation; CONSUMER PREFERENCES; CONSUMER SURVEY; ECONOMETRIC MODEL; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; SECOND CAR; AUTOMOBILES

Title: ENERGY CONSUMPTION IN THE TRANSPORTATION SERVICES SECTOR.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: A project is reported in order to develop a framework for analyzing the dynamics of the transportation sector and for projecting long-term energy consumption by transportation services. An econometric model was developed which allows analysts to forecast long-term trends in the use of various forms of energy for transportation. Incorporating both supply and demand decisions, utilities may also find the methodology helpful in assessing trends in electric transportation.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILES - Electric; ENERGY UTILIZATION; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; ECONOMETRIC MODEL; ELECTRIC TRANSPORTATION; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; LONG-TERM TRENDS; TRANSPORTATION SERVICES SECTOR; TRANSPORTATION

Title: REDOX BATTERIES - A REVIEW.
Affiliations: Central Electrochemical Research, Inst, Karaikudi, India, Central Electrochemical Research Inst, Karaikudi, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhatt, D.P., Central Electrochemical Research, Inst, Karaikudi, India, Central Electrochemical Research Inst, Karaikudi, India; Mathur, P.B., Central Electrochemical Research, Inst, Karaikudi, India, Central Electrochemical Research Inst, Karaikudi, India
Abstract: There are only a few battery systems which appear suitable for storage of large quantities of electrical energy on the consideration of their cost, limited maintenance and simplicity of operation. Redox battery is one system which can meet all these requirements. The load levelling, storage of solar energy, wind-energy etc. are some of the major utilities of this battery system. Various developments which have taken place on Redox batteries, are reviewed in the present article. Technical problems faced in the development of Iron-Chromium, Iron-Titanium and Iron-Iron batteries in particular, are also surveyed. Occurrence of polarisation of anodes which seems to be a serious problem in the development efforts of any Redox battery has been discussed.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Redox; ENERGY STORAGE; IRON-CHROMIUM REDOX BATTERY; IRON-IRON REDOX BATTERY; IRON-TITANIUM REDOX BATTERY; REDOX BATTERIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: ENERGY STORAGE ON THE SUPPLY SIDE OR THE DEMAND SIDE.
Source title: Research and Development Report - Canadian Electrical Association
Affiliations: Acres Int Ltd, Niagara Falls, Ont,, Can, Acres Int Ltd, Niagara Falls, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Codrington, J.B., Acres Int Ltd, Niagara Falls, Ont,, Can, Acres Int Ltd, Niagara Falls, Ont, Can; Smith, C., Acres Int Ltd, Niagara Falls, Ont,, Can, Acres Int Ltd, Niagara Falls, Ont, Can
Abstract: Traditional large-scale supply side electrical energy storage methods are compared with demand side energy storage methods that may now be economic because of recent electric utility changes or because of recent development work. The characteristics of various energy storage methods are summarized. Promising options are identified: residential thermal energy storage for space heating; commercial thermal energy storage for comfort conditioning; battery and thermochemical energy storage. Actions to expedite use of these options are proposed.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Heat Storage; DEMAND SIDE ENERGY STORAGE; SUPPLY SIDE ENERGY STORAGE; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; THERMOCHEMICAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Guzman A.M., Bauer C.L., Silvain J.-F., Kryder M.H.
Title: The irradiation effects of ion implantation on magnetic garnets
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Authors with affiliations: Guzman, A.M., Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States; Bauer, C.L., Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States; Silvain, J.-F., Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States; Kryder, M.H., Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Abstract: The microstructure of epitaxially grown garnets, used for magnetic bubble memory devices, has been examined prior and subsequent to implantation with high-energy ions by transmission electron microscopy, incorporating a special cross-section technique. In this particular investigation, thin films of (SmYGdTm)3 Ga0.4Fe4.6O12 have been produced by liquid phase epitaxy on (111) substrates of gadolinium gallium garnet and subsequently exposed to various doses of oxygen and/or deuterium ions. At moderate implantation doses (5×1015 D+2 cm2 and/or 1×1014 O+ cm2), magnetic properties are favo larger doses, isolated amorphous regions nucleate and grow into a continuous layer, thereby degrading desirable magnetic properties. Implantation-induced changes of the garnet crystal structure near the unimplanted/implanted boundary are described. Relationships between these microstructural features and concomitant magnetic properties are suggested. © 1986.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE UNITS - Materials; SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS - Ion Implantation; AMORPHIZATION; GADOLINIUM-GALLIUM GARNET; MAGNETIC BUBBLE MEMORY DEVICES; GARNETS

Title: Reliable timing systems for computer controlled accelerators
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Knott, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Nettleton, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Over the past decade the use of computers has set new standards for control systems of accelerators with ever increasing complexity coupled with stringent reliability criteria. In fact, with very slow cycling machines or storage rings any erratic operation or timing pulse will cause the loss of precious particles and waste hours of time and effort of preparation. Thus, for the CERN linac and LEAR (Low Energy Antiproton Ring) timing system reliability becomes a crucial factor in the sense that all components must operate practically without fault for very long periods compared to the effective machine cycle. This has been achieved by careful selection of components and design well below thermal and electrical limits, using error detection and correction where possible, as well as developing "safe" decoding techniques for serial data trains. Further, consistent structuring had to be applied in order to obtain simple and flexible modular configurations with very few components on critical paths and to minimize the exchange of information to synchronize accelerators. In addition, this structuring allows the development of efficient strategies for on-line and off-line fault diagnostics. As a result, the timing system for Linac 2 has, so far, been operating without fault for three years, the one for LEAR more than one year since its final debugging. © 1986.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Computer Applications; CERN; COMPUTER CONTROLLED TIMING SYSTEMS; LEAR; TIMING DEVICES

Title: Seasonal changes in pyloric caecum and gonad indices during the annual reproductive cycle in the seastar Asterias forbesi
Affiliations: Biology Department, Brooklyn College, City University of New York, Brooklyn, 11210, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Franz, D.R., Biology Department, Brooklyn College, City University of New York, Brooklyn, 11210, New York, United States
Abstract: Seasonal changes in pyloric caecum and gonad indices were studied in a population of the seastar Asterias forbesi (Desor) from East Rockaway Inlet (Long Island, New York) during two annual cycles (1980/81, 1982/83). Pyloric caeca indices increased during fall, reached a maximum about April, and declined sharply to a minimum in mid-summer. Gonad indices increased during fall and winter and reached a maximum about May. Judging from gonad size analysis, spawning occurred in late June to early July, at bottom temperatures of 16° to 18°C. There was no long-term inverse relationship between pyloric caecum and gonad indices. Since nutrients and energy ingested during the important fall feeding period are utilized simultaneously for body growth and gonad development, it is unnecessary for the pyloric caeca to store nutrients over long periods as occurs in A. rubens and many other species. The specific caeca-gonad relationship is probably an adaptation to the extreme seasonal thermal fluctuations of the NW Atlantic, which constrain the feeding activity of A. forbesi and limit the possibility of long-term storage. In this population, most individuals grow rapidly in their first year (including first two summers) and spawn in their third summer. Few seastars survive to spawn again in their fourth summer. However, gametogenesis may take place in some individuals in their second summer. Year-to-year variability in mean size at spawning may reflect temporal variation in environmental conditions (weather, food availability) at this site. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Production of carbon monoxide by direct thermal splitting of carbon dioxide at high temperature
Source title: Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan
Affiliations: Research Institute for Scientific Measurements, Tohoku University, Sendai, 980, Japan; Centre de Recherches sur la Physique des Hautes Temperatures CNRS, Orleans Cedex, 45045, France
Authors with affiliations: Nigara, Y., Research Institute for Scientific Measurements, Tohoku University, Sendai, 980, Japan; Cales, B., Research Institute for Scientific Measurements, Tohoku University, Sendai, 980, Japan, Centre de Recherches sur la Physique des Hautes Temperatures CNRS, Orleans Cedex, 45045, France
Abstract: The direct thermal decomposition of carbon dioxide C02 to produce carbon monoxide CO have been studied as a mean of conversion and storage of a thermal energy, such as the solar heat, into a gaseous fuel. The process under investigation consists to displace the dissociation equilibrium of carbon dioxide by a selective pumping of oxygen at high temperature through a semipermeable membrane. Large amounts of carbon monoxide have been produced after the extraction of the oxygen arising from the C02 dissociation with the aid of a membrane made of calcia-stabilized zirconia. The variations of the flow of CO evolved from the reactor vs. temperature and oxygen partial pressure are in good agreement with the theoretical variations that may be deduced from the general equations of electrochemical transport in stabilized zirconia. Thereby, the efficiency of this process appears to be directly limited by the low oxygen permeation rate through the material used as oxygen selective membrane. © 1986 The Chemical Society of Japan.
Index Keywords: Carbon monoxide; Decomposition; Dissociation; Fuel storage; Oxygen; Zirconia; Calcia-stabilized zirconias; Direct thermal Decomposition; Dissociation equilibria; General equations; Oxygen partial pressure; Oxygen selective membranes; Semi-permeable membranes; Stabilized zirconia; Carbon dioxide

Title: Experimental data on the thermal kinetics of organic peroxides
Affiliations: Prins Maurits Laboratorium TNO, P.O. Box 45, 2280 AA Rijswijk, Netherlands; Research Centre Deventer, Akzo Chemie, P.O. Box 10, 7400 AA Deventer, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Hordijk, A.C., Prins Maurits Laboratorium TNO, P.O. Box 45, 2280 AA Rijswijk, Netherlands; De Groot, J.J., Research Centre Deventer, Akzo Chemie, P.O. Box 10, 7400 AA Deventer, Netherlands
Abstract: The heat effects from the exothermic decomposition of concentrated organic peroxides have been investigated experimentally for three peroxy esters (tert-butyl peroxy benzoate, tert-butyl peroxy 2-ethyl hexanoate and tert-butyl peroxy pivalate). Four different calorimetric instruments were used: adiabatic and isothermal storage tests, differential thermal analysis and the low pressure autoclave. The heat generation values which could be measured with these instruments vary from 10-2 to 10-4 W kg-1 (Watt per kilogram of peroxide). From the experimental data the following thermal kinetic information was obtained: total heat of decomposition, activation energy, heat generation factor, and the occurrence of induced decomposition. The storage/control temperatures and run-away data were calculated with these parameters. The calculated values agree with the experimental data for peroxides directly determined in the industrial 30-1 container. The advantage of the computation by means of parameters is that the thermal conditions of practical situations as met, e.g., in production units can also be calculated. These thermal conditions can hardly be determined by direct experiments. © 1986.

Authors: Tolman C.J., Kanodia S., Roberts M.F., Daniels L.
Title: 31P-NMR spectra of methanogens: 2,3-cyclopyrophosphoglycerate is detectable only in methanobacteria strains.
Authors with affiliations: Tolman, C.J.; Kanodia, S.; Roberts, M.F.; Daniels, L.
Abstract: The unique compound 2,3-cyclopyrophosphoglycerate occurs at a detectable concentration in the genera Methanobacterium and Methanobrevibacter but not in Methanococcus, Methanospirillum and Methanosarcina, as shown by a 31P-NMR survey of several different methanogens. Metabolic poisons (carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenylhydrazone and valinomycin) do not decrease the level of the cyclic pyrophosphate in Methanobacterium thermoautotrophicum; therefore, it cannot be a phosphagen, i.e., an energy storage material. 13CO2 is rapidly incorporated into this cyclic compound which represents the major soluble carbon as well as the phosphorus component of this methanobacteria. 13C-NMR analysis demonstrates that the pKa of the 2,3-cyclopyrophosphoglycerate carboxyl group is 2.55. The unusual pseudomurein cell wall structure of methano- and methanobrevibacteria necessitates a high demand on carbohydrate metabolism. For this reason, and the fact that when its concentration is decreased no new phosphorus resonances appear in the high resolution spectra, it is suggested that 2,3-cyclopyrophosphoglycerate has a function in carbohydrate metabolism.
Index Keywords: carbonyl cyanide chlorophenylhydrazone; Carbonyl Cyanide m Chlorophenyl Hydrazone; cyclic 2,3 diphosphoglyceric acid; cyclic-2,3-diphosphoglycerate; mesoxalonitrile; nitrile; oligomycin; organophosphorus compound; valinomycin; anaerobic growth; article; cell wall; comparative study; drug effect; metabolism; Methanobacteriales; nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy; species difference; Anaerobiosis; Carbonyl Cyanide m-Chlorophenyl Hydrazone; Cell Wall; Comparative Study; Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy; Methanogens; Nitriles; Oligomycins; Organophosphorus Compounds; Species Specificity; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.; Valinomycin

Abstract: The unique compound 2,3-cyclopyrophosphoglycerate occurs at a detectable concentration in the genera Methanobacterium and Methanobrevibacter but not in Methanococcus, Methanospirillum and Methanosarcina, as shown by a 31P-NMR survey of several different methanogens. Authors: Jang T.H., Han J.I., Jai-Young L.
Title: Effect of substitution of titanium by zirconium in TiFe on hydrogenation properties
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 131, Cheongryang Seoul,, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Jang, T.H., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 131, Cheongryang Seoul,, South Korea; Han, J.I., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 131, Cheongryang Seoul,, South Korea; Jai-Young, L., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 131, Cheongryang Seoul,, South Korea
Abstract: The influence of partial substitution of titanium by zirconium in the intermetallic compound TiFe on the hydrogenation characteristics was investigated. The compositions of the alloys correspond to the formula Ti1-xZrxFe with x = 0, 0.01, 0.04, 0.07, 0.1 and 0.2. X-ray analysis showed that the lattice parameters of the alloys increased with an increase in zirconium content. Activation properties were largely enhanced with an increase in zirconium content. It was found that the absorption of hydrogen by the zirconium-containing compounds reached saturation earlier than in the case of pure TiFe as the absorption-desorption cycle for activation was continued. The pressure-composition isotherms revealed that the thermodynamic properties of the alloys were different. The hydrogen storage capacity was drastically reduced and the γ phase disappeared. The plateau was inclined and the plateau pressure of the zirconium-containing compounds was lower than that of pure TiFe. The ΔH, ΔS, ΔG values were obtained from the plot of In P versus 1 T by the van't Hoff relation. The hysteresis energy loss was nearly constant with varying zirconium content. © 1986.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN - Storage; TITANIUM IRON ALLOYS - Hydrogenation; TITANIUM IRON ZIRCONIUM ALLOYS - Applications; ZIRCONIUM AND ALLOYS; ABSORPTION CURVES; HYDRIDE FORMATION; PRESSURE-COMPOSITION ISOTHERMS; INTERMETALLICS

Title: A compact plane crystal spectrometer for the energy range between 500 eV and 5000 eV
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A

Authors with affiliations: Tegeler, E., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2-12, D-1000 Berlin, Germany
Abstract: A compact Bragg spectrometer with only one crystal has been built for use with synchrotron radiation of the storage ring BESSY. It is shown that this simple instrument can be used instead of a double crystal monochromator for applications like the transmittance measurement of materials which are relevant to X-ray lithography. Measurements were done on the stability of crystals for the longer wavelength region when exposed to synchrotron radiation. © 1986.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Storage Rings; CRYSTALS; BESSY; BRAGG SPECTROMETER; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; SPECTROMETERS

Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A

Authors with affiliations: Heckenkamp, Ch., Fritz-Haber-Institut der MPG, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany, Fakultät für Physik der Universität Bielefeld, D-4800 Bielefeld 1, Germany; Eyers, A., Fritz-Haber-Institut der MPG, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany, Fakultät für Physik der Universität Bielefeld, D-4800 Bielefeld 1, Germany; Schäfers, F., Fritz-Haber-Institut der MPG, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany, Fakultät für Physik der Universität Bielefeld, D-4800 Bielefeld 1, Germany, BESSY, Lentzeallee 100, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Schöhense, G., Fritz-Haber-Institut der MPG, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany, Fakultät für Physik der Universität Bielefeld, D-4800 Bielefeld 1, Germany; Heinzmann, U., Fritz-Haber-Institut der MPG, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany, Fakultät für Physik der Universität Bielefeld, D-4800 Bielefeld 1, Germany
Abstract: An electron-optical system is described which has been especially designed for spin- and angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy with circularly polarized synchrotron radiation. One hv- and one uhv-type of this system (for studies at atoms/molecules and solids/adsorbates, respectively) are in operation at the storage ring BESSY. The system employs, thus, a light source and an electron spin detector (high energy Mott detector) both fixed in space. This is realized by a rotatable electron spectrometer and a 90° deflector by which the electron beam is directed along the axis of rotation of the spectrometer, independent of the emission angle chosen. © 1986.

Abstract: A Bragg polarimeter-monochromator combination for synchrotron radiation at the 800 MeV storage ring BESSY is described. It utilizes a combination of a Bragg crystal and absorber foils which are matched to the energy dependent synchrotron radiation spectrum of BESSY. The instrument is presently used for measurements of both polarization components of the angular distribution of the synchrotron radiation at photon energies of 1.1, 1.43 and 2.78 keV in order to investigate the current dependent size and divergence of the electron beam of BESSY. © 1986.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Storage Rings; BESSY; BRAGG POLARIMETER-MONOCHROMATOR; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; POLARIMETERS

Title: Subnanosecond time resolved measurements of synchrotron X-ray pulses using photoconductive detectors

Abstract: We have employed fast photoconductive detector (InP:Fe) and a sampling oscilloscope to time resolve the X-ray emission from the SPEAR storage ring. The detector and recording system had a response time (fwhm) of less than 200 ps. For photon energies between 1000 and 3000 eV we observed a Gaussian shaped pulse with a fwhm of 560 ps. © 1986.

Title: Performance of the flipper monochromator at the wiggler/undulator at HASYLAB
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A

Abstract: After almost ten years of successful operation at a bending magnet beamline of HASYLAB, the Flipper monochromator was transferred to a 32-pole wiggler/undulator. With new grazing incidence optics the original energy range of 15-450 eV could be extended to more than 1500 eV. The gain in intensity is approximately two orders of magnitude. Undulator effects are observed between 36 and 900 eV and contribute considerably to this intensity gain. Monochromators of the Flipper type are ideally matching the emission characteristics of undulators. The main problem with wigglers at high energy storage rings is the heat load on the optical elements. © 1986.

Abstract: First operation of a new extended range monochromator on the 1 GeV storage ring Aladdin is described. Curves are given of output flux as a function of photon energy for the 2 m and for the 5 m gratings as measured with an NBS diode. Relatively low background and flux up to 1500 eV is obtained using a 1200 line/mm 5 m holographic grating. Highly reproducible scans were obtained of the transmission of thin films including the carbon K and titanium L edges. This reproducibility and high throughput is in large part due to the small beam size and excellent stability of Aladdin. © 1986.

Authors: Rowen M., Waldhauer A., Pianetta P.
Title: Crystal heating on the JUMBO double crystal monochromator at SSRL
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rowen, M., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Waldhauer, A., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Pianetta, P., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: Heating by intense synchrotron radiation causes the lattice of the first crystal in the JUMBO double crystal monochromator at SSRL to expand. Because the two crystals no longer have the same lattice spacing, they diffract X-rays of the same wavelength at different angles. This causes shifts in energy calibration and beam movement at the sample with change in photon energy or as the current in the storage ring decays. A simple thermal model that predicts the change in wavelength and angle of the monochromatic beam is described. These shifts are proportional to I sin θ tan θ, where I is the SPEAR ring current and θ is the angle of the beam incident on the first crystal. Heating experiments were conducted with Ge(111), quartz(1010, and InSb(111) crystals. Bragg angle shifts of up to 0.25° were measured with high precision encoders mounted directly on the crystal goniometers. Photon energy calibration shifts of up to 3.5 eV (at 1700 eV) were measured. Preliminary results show good agreement with the model for Ge and quartz crystals, but not for InSb crystals. Further study is needed to refine the model for Ge and quartz crystals and to determine a better one for InSb. © 1986.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Accessories; MONOCHROMATORS; OPTICS; BEAMLINE; DOUBLE CRYSTAL MONOCHROMATOR; JUMBO; STANFORD SYNCHROTRON RADIATION LABORATORY; CRYSTALS

Authors: Müller P., Riehle F., Tegeler E., Wende B.
Title: Measurement of the spectral efficiency of energy dispersive Si(Li) detectors below 5 keV photon energy using BESSY as a standard source
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2-12, D-1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Müller, P., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2-12, D-1000 Berlin 10, Germany; Riehle, F., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2-12, D-1000 Berlin 10, Germany; Tegeler, E., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2-12, D-1000 Berlin 10, Germany; Wende, B., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2-12, D-1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Abstract: A method is presented for the measurement of the spectral efficiency of a Si(Li) detector in the spectral range below 5 keV using BESSY as a standard radiation source of extremely low photon flux (1 photon (eV s)-1 and below). The detector was irradiated with white synchrotron radiation when the storage ring was running with about 10 electrons stored. Good agreement was found between the spectral efficiency measured and the one calculated using a simple model. © 1986.

Title: Using the circularly polarized components of synchrotron radiation for circular dichroism measurements between 400 and 3500 Å
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Physikalisches Institut der Universität Bonn, Nussallee 12, D 5300 Bonn 1, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schiller, J., Physikalisches Institut der Universität Bonn, Nussallee 12, D 5300 Bonn 1, Germany; Hormes, J., Physikalisches Institut der Universität Bonn, Nussallee 12, D 5300 Bonn 1, Germany
Abstract: The out of plane components of synchrotron radiation are circularly polarized to a high degree. This property offers the possibility to overcome the energy limitation of about 9 eV for circular dichroism (CD) and magnetic circular dichroism (MCD) measurements which is set by the optical components normally used to produce circularly polarized light. We report the first CD spectra which were taken using the circularly polarized components of synchrotron radiation. The light source was the Bonn 2.5 GeV synchrotron and a special monochromator constructed to monochromatize the off plane components of the radiation. Our experiments reveal several problems which make CD measurements very difficult. Some of these problems which we discuss in detail arise from the intrinsic properties of a synchrotron as compared to a storage ring but most are more general and have to be considered for further work on monochromators for the circularly polarized components of synchrotron radiation. © 1986.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Applications; PHYSICS - Atomic; CIRCULAR DICHROISM; MAGNETIC CIRCULAR DICHROISM; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; LIGHT

Title: The high energy plane grating monochromators at BESSY
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH (BESSY), Lentzeallee 1000, D-100 Berlin 33, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Petersen, H., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH (BESSY), Lentzeallee 1000, D-100 Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: Two plane grating grazing incidence monochromators based on the author's solution of the plane grating focussing term are described. The instruments continuously cover the soft X-ray spectral range up to 2 keV. Source size limited spectral resolution can be obtained when the influence of the too high tangent error of the present focussing mirror is eliminated through aperture reduction. Higher orders can be suppressed by varying the cutoff angle at the plane premirror. The stray light content of the spectrum is very low and allows an edge-jump of 1:2.5 at the silicon K-edge. © 1986.

Abstract: The use of gradient magnets for a low emittance electron storage ring is discussed and a magnetic lattice for a 6 GeV electron energy synchrotron radiation source adopting this feature is presented. © 1986.

Authors: Takacs P.Z., Melendez J., Colbert J.
Title: Synchrotron radiation damage observations in normal incidence copper mirrors
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Instrumentation Division, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973-5000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Takacs, P.Z., Instrumentation Division, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973-5000, United States; Melendez, J., Instrumentation Division, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973-5000, United States; Colbert, J., Instrumentation Division, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973-5000, United States
Abstract: Water-cooled copper mirrors used at near-normal incidence on two beamlines at the NSLS are observed to undergo severe degradation upon exposure to the direct SR beam. These mirrors are used on beam lines designed to utilize radiation in the wavelength regions longer than 100 nm and are coated with a UV reflection-enhancing coating, consisting of one or more bilayers of aluminum with a MgF2 overcoat. Beamline performance degrades very rapidly following installation of a new set of mirrors. Analysis of the mirror surfaces by various non-destructive techniques indicates severe degradation of the coating and surface along the central strip where most of the X-ray power is absorbed from the beam. In one case where the mirror had three bilayer coatings, the outer coating layer has disappeared along the central strip. Rutherford backscatter measurements indicate compositional changes between layers and confirm the existence of a carbon deposit on the surface. Thermal modeling suggests that most of the damage is caused by direct photon interaction, since the temperature rise in the energy deposition region is small. © 1986.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Storage Rings; BEAMLINE; COPPER MIRRORS; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; MIRRORS

Title: Energy storage during DNA girase activity
Affiliations: Departamento de Biofisica, Facultad de Medicina and Departamento de Fisica, Facultad de Humanidades y Ciencias, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay, Uruguay; Department of Physics, Washington College, Chestertown, MD 21620, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mizraji, E., Departamento de Biofisica, Facultad de Medicina and Departamento de Fisica, Facultad de Humanidades y Ciencias, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay, Uruguay; Lin, J., Department of Physics, Washington College, Chestertown, MD 21620, United States
Abstract: In this work, we develop a minimal two-cycle model for the action of DNA girase. One of the cycles describes the ATP dependent chemicomechanical transduction performed by the enzyme. The other cycle describes the relaxing activity exhibited by girase on supercoiled DNA in the absence of substrates. Supercoiling of DNA is described as a random walk on a topological index. The mechanical energy storage in DNA is manifested in the fact that in general, the kinetic constants for the cycles do not satisfy Wegscheider relations. Finally, a connection is established between the degree of DNA supercoiling and the hydrolysis of ATP. © 1986 Academic Press Inc. (London) Ltd All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; dna topoisomerase (atp hydrolysing); dna supercoiling; energy; hydrolysis; methodology; nonhuman; Adenosine Triphosphate; DNA Topoisomerases, Type II; DNA, Superhelical; Energy Metabolism; Escherichia coli; Kinetics; Models, Biological; Thermodynamics

Authors: Misra Ajay K., Whittenberger John D.
Title: ESTIMATED HEATS OF FUSION OF FLUORIDE SALT MIXTURES SUITABLE FOR THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Misra, Ajay K., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Whittenberger, John D., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The heats of fusion of several fluoride salt mixtures with melting points greater than 973 K have been estimated from coupled analysis of thermodynamic data and phase diagrams. Simple binary eutectic systems with and without terminal solid solutions, binary eutectics with congruent melting intermediate phases, and ternary eutectic systems were considered. The eutectics LiF-22CaF//2 and NaF-6OMgF//2 which melt at 1039 and 1273 K, respectively, possess relatively high heats of fusion/gm ( greater than 0. 7 kj/g). Such systems would be candidates for light weight, high energy storage media required in advanced solar dynamic power systems for future space missions.
Index Keywords: CALCIUM COMPOUNDS - Applications; ENERGY STORAGE - Materials; LITHIUM COMPOUNDS - Applications; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS - Applications; SODIUM COMPOUNDS - Applications; FLUORIDE SALTS; HEAT OF FUSION; LITHIUM FLUORIDE-CALCIUM FLUORIDE; SODIUM FLUORIDE-MAGNESIUM FLUORIDE; SPACE APPLICATIONS; SALTS

Title: HARVESTING AND HANDLING AGRICULTURAL RESIDUES FOR ENERGY.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Univ of California-Davis, Davis, CA,, USA, Univ of California-Davis, Davis, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jenkins, B.M., Univ of California-Davis, Davis, CA,, USA, Univ of California-Davis, Davis, CA, USA; Sumner, H.R., Univ of California-Davis, Davis, CA,, USA, Univ of California-Davis, Davis, CA, USA
Abstract: Recommendations are made for research to integrate residue collection and handling systems into general agricultural practices through the development of multi-use equipment and total harvest systems; improve methods for routine evaluation of agricultural residue resources, possibly through remote sensing and image processing; analyze biomass properties to obtain detailed data relevant to engineering design and analysis; evaluate long-term environmental, social, and agronomic impacts of residue collection; develop improved equipment with higher capacities to reduce residue collection and handling costs, with emphasis on optimal design of complete systems including collection, transportation, processing, storage, and utilization; and produce standard forms of biomass fuels or products to enhance material handling and expand biomass markets through improved reliability and automatic control of biomass conversion and other utilization systems.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERING; ENERGY RESOURCES - Waste Utilization; AGRICULTURAL RESIDUES; AGRICULTURAL WASTES

Title: 1985 SURVEY OF UTILITY RESIDENTIAL END-USE PROJECTS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Investigators identified new candidate utility projects and collect up-to-date information both on the new projects and on those previously surveyed. Diverse methods were used to identify the new projects, including contacting equipment manufacturers and representatives of utility industry organizations, reviewing industry trade journals and newsletters, and surveying utilities directly in a broad-based mail inquiry. The surveys focused on the four major areas of residential end-use activity: load control, thermal energy storage and dual-fuel heating, efficient energy use, and end-use solar projects. Using the survey responses, analysts summarized the types and levels of activity in each technology category; the equipment, systems, and techniques in use; the incentives associated with the projects; the project results; and the names of utility contacts and equipment manufacturers.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Load Management; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; DUAL-FUEL HEATING; MAIL INQUIRY; NEW PROJECTS; RESIDENTIAL END-USE PROJECTS; UTILITY PROJECTS; ENERGY UTILIZATION

Title: UNDERGROUND CAVERN EXCAVATION.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The research team reviewed the worldwide literature on undergound construction of large electric power facilities. They investigated the state of the art of underground cavern construction and design, as well as the advantages, unique conditions, and risks encountered. After examining underground construction contracting practices, dispute resolution, and cost control methods, project personnel recommended management approaches and contract mechanisms to reduce the risks and make cost control easier.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Construction; EXCAVATION; ROCK; CAVERN CONSTRUCTION; CONTRACTING PRACTICES; COST CONTROL METHODS; ROCK CAVERNS; UNDERGROUND CAVERN; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: ROCK CAVERN LININGS FOR COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The project team - in consultation with researchers and lining suppliers and manufacturers - reviewed possible approaches and materials such as surface reservoir-type linings, spray-on polymers, and flexible membranes. The researchers established artificial containment requirements as well as specified installation, operation, and safety criteria for candidate linings. Assuming a host rock that was structurally sound but had permeability higher than 10** minus **3 cm/s, they then evaluated three design concepts and calculated the costs of lining a hypothetical cavern of 275,000 yd**3 in each case.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ROCK; ARTIFICIAL CONTAINMENT; COMPRESSED-AIR STORAGE PLANT; LINING SUPPLIERS; ROCK CAVERN; SPRAY-ON POLYMERS; COMPRESSED AIR

Authors with affiliations: Khapov, Yu.I., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Novosibirsk, USSR, Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Novosibirsk, USSR
Abstract: A compact electron accelerator based on a resonant Tesla coil with a double high-voltage storage line with a glycerin dielectric is described. The efficiency of energy conversion at all stages is analyzed. The accelerator, which has an electron energy of 150 kev, a current of 4. 4 ka, and a long life with a pulse repetition frequency of 0. 2 Hz, has been used to excite the gas mixture of excimer lasers.

Title: COMMERCIAL - INNOVATIVE WAYS TO SAVE ENERGY IN NEW BUILDINGS.
Affiliations: Gershon Meckler Associates, New, York, NY, USA, Gershon Meckler Associates, New York, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, Gershon, Gershon Meckler Associates, New, York, NY, USA, Gershon Meckler Associates, New York, NY, USA
Abstract: The ice storage/integrated sprinkler/cogeneration HVAC system designed for Westminster Mall, Colorado eliminates daytime demand charges for HVAC entirely and sharply cuts utility costs by shifting all daytime HVAC electric utility demand to off peak hours or to a cogenerator. The system is described in the article which has a payback on investment of less than 4 years.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING; BUILDINGS - Climate Control; COGENERATION PLANTS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ICE - Storage; COST ANALYSIS; HVAC SYSTEM; INTEGRATED SPRINKLER; NFPA; OFF-PEAK HOURS; ENERGY MANAGEMENT

Title: HOW HIGH-ENERGY RADIATION AFFECTS POLYMERS.
Affiliations: Materials Engineering, Cleveland,, OH, USA, Materials Engineering, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: English, Lawrence K., Materials Engineering, Cleveland,, OH, USA, Materials Engineering, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The advent of gamma sterilization of biomedical products, irradiation of food, radio-pharmaceuticals, increasing reliance on fission power, and the growing number of longer-term space projects are forcing radiation out of the realm of theory and into that of practical design engineering. In many applications, safety factors in long-term use, storage, or transportation of radioactive materials and devices make the effects of high-energy particles on materials a critical design parameter for the selection of coatings, seals and gaskets, adhesives, cable insulation, and structural polymers and composites used in many other key components. This article discusses the subject in terms of the dynamics of degradation, and new performance criteria.
Index Keywords: MATERIALS - Physical Properties; PLASTICS - Degradation; HIGH-ENERGY RADIATION; POLYMERS

Authors: Hwang I.H., Lee J.H., Lee M.H.
Title: A long-pulse amplifier for solar-pumped iodine lasers
Affiliations: NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA 23665-5225, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hwang, I.H., NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA 23665-5225, United States; Lee, J.H., NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA 23665-5225, United States; Lee, M.H., NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA 23665-5225, United States
Abstract: The characteristics of a long-pulse iodine photodissociation laser amplifier were investigated in order to evaluate the adaptability of an oscillator-amplifier chain as a high-energy solar-pumped laser system. The long storage time and the substantial gain observed experimentally confirm that developing such a system is indeed feasible. © 1986.

Authors: Scudder G.G.E., Moore L.V., Isman M.B.
Title: Sequestration of cardenolides in Oncopeltus fasciatus: Morphological and physiological adaptations
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, Canada; Department of Plant Science, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Scudder, G.G.E., Department of Zoology, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, Canada; Moore, L.V., Department of Zoology, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, Canada; Isman, M.B., Department of Plant Science, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, Canada
Abstract: The morphological and physiological adaptations associated with sequestration of cardenolides by the lygaeid Oncopeltus fasciatus are summarized and discussed. Cardenolides are efficiently accumulated in O. fasciatus; however, the insect does not appear to suffer any physiological cost as a result of handling large amounts of these plant toxins. Morphological adaptations of the insect include a modified integument composed of a double layered epidermis with an inner layer (the dorsolateral space) specialized for cardenolide storage. Special weak areas of the cuticle are found on both the thorax and abdomen, which rupture when the insect is squeezed, resulting in the cardenolide-rich contents of the inner epidermal layer being released onto the body surface in the form of discrete spherical droplets. Physiological adaptations include selective sequestration of food plant cardenolides, concentration of cardenolides in the dorsolateral space, passive uptake of cardenolides at the gut and dorsolateral space requiring little energy output, reabsorption of secreted cardenolides by the Malpighian tubules, high in vivo tolerance to cardenolides, and the presence of cardenolide-resistant Na,K-ATPases. © 1986 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Author Keywords: Asclepiadaceae; cardenolides; Hemiptera Heteroptera; Lygaeidae; morphological adaptations; Oncopeltus fasciatus; physiological adaptations; sequestration

Abstract: This experiment has been performed at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings to study the direct formation of charmonium states in antiproton-proton annihilations. The experimental program has partly been devoted to an inclusive scan for pp → J/ψ + X in the range 3520-3530 MeV/c2. A cluster of five events has been observed in a narrow energy band, centred on the centre of gravity of the 3PJ states where the 1P1 is expected to be. When interpreted as a new resonace, these data yield a mass m = 3525.4±0.8 MeV/c2. © 1986.

Title: Memory and dynamic imaging in a conducting PRIZ
Affiliations: Air Force Institute of Technology (AU), Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH 45433-6583, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nilius, M.E., Air Force Institute of Technology (AU), Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH 45433-6583, United States; Luke, T.E., Air Force Institute of Technology (AU), Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, OH 45433-6583, United States
Abstract: The conducting PRIZ spatial light modulator, which uses transparent electrodes deposited directly onto the surface of a photorefractive crystal, has information storage times which are a strong function of the incident write-beam energy density. The memory or storage time has been found to be a monotonically decreasing function of the incident write-beam energy density. At low energy densities, the memory time is of the order of 0.5 h. However, at sufficiently high write-beam energy densities, the device acts as a differentiator and exhibits dynamic image selection. The optical output of the device, which depends upon the transverse electro-optic effect, peaks at moderate energy levels. © 1986.
Index Keywords: IMAGE PROCESSING; DYNAMIC IMAGING; IMAGE TRANSFORMER; SPATIAL LIGHT MODULATOR; STORAGE TIME; TRANSPARENT ELECTRODES; LIGHT

Title: TL dating of malan loess in gansu province
Affiliations: Institute of Geochemistry, Academia Sinica, China; Institute of Archaeology, the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, China
Authors with affiliations: Lu, L., Institute of Geochemistry, Academia Sinica, China; Li, H., Institute of Archaeology, the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, China
Abstract: TL dating technique is of great advantage for determining the initial time of storing energy (T0) in an object to be analyzed. The sample is required to have undergone at least one thermal event, permitting all the residual storage to release. As a result, TL dating technique has found wide application in geochronology of pottery. The determination of T0 of loess is mainly based on the fact that fine particles of which loess is composed will lose their storage in the process of transportation by wind. In our experiment TL dating technique was adopted to determine the ages of fine quartz grains, and the results were corrected for those of shine-fading experiment. TL dating of Malan loess specimens from Mt. Gaolanshan, Liugouhe near Lanzhou, Mt. Qijiadashan in Jingning and Baichaoyuan in Huining gave the age values of 2.6±0.1, 3.6±0,3. 4.7±0.5 and 10.0±0.6×104 yr, respectively. The values indicate that the Malan loess began depositing in Late Pleisotocene, but the initial time and acumulation rate are different under different morphological conditions from place to place. © 1986 Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences.

Title: APPLICATION OF A FULL-TEXT STORAGE AND RETRIEVAL SYSTEM FOR RECORDS MANAGEMENT.
Source title: The Journal of information and image management
Affiliations: US Nuclear Regulatory Commission, USA, US Nuclear Regulatory Commission, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bender, Avi, US Nuclear Regulatory Commission, USA, US Nuclear Regulatory Commission, USA
Abstract: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is required under Section 114(d)(2) of the Nuclear Waste Policy Act to review The Department of Energy's license application for constructing a high-level waste repository. The purpose of this paper is to describe a full-text storage and retrieval system pilot project at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Experience gained to date shows that implementing a full-text system no longer poses many of the problems which made it an unattractive alternative in the past. NRC's current pilot project seeks to evaluate the process of capturing documents electronically and making them available on a full-text storage and retrieval system. The practical application of the full-text system is being demonstrated to address both NWPA- and NRC-wide record management needs.
Index Keywords: MANAGEMENT - Information Systems; FULL-TEXT STORAGE AND RETRIEVAL; LICENSE APPLICATION REVIEW; NUCLEAR REGULATORY COMMISSION (NRC); INFORMATION RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS

Title: EFFECTS OF OUTSIDE STORAGE ON THE ENERGY POTENTIAL OF HARDWOOD PARTICULATE FUELS: PART III. SPECIFIC GRAVITY, ASH CONTENT, AND pH OF WATER SOLUBLES.
Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Blacksburg, VA, USA, Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State Univ, Blacksburg, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: White, M.S., Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Blacksburg, VA, USA, Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State Univ, Blacksburg, VA, USA; Argent, R.M., Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Blacksburg, VA, USA, Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State Univ, Blacksburg, VA, USA; Sarles, R.L., Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Blacksburg, VA, USA, Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State Univ, Blacksburg, VA, USA
Abstract: Approximately 150 tons of green, hardwood wholetree fuel chips were stored outdoors in a 20-foot-high, conical pile at Blacksburg, Va. The pile was monitored for 1 year to determine the effect of outside storage on the rate of fiber loss, the level of noncombustibles in the fuel, and the pH of water-soluble matter. At ambient temperatures above 20 degree C wood substance loss occurred at a uniform rate of 1. 5 percent per month. Ash content increased by 0. 23 percentage points per month after the first 4 months of storage. This increased ash content may burden fly ash and grate ash disposal systems unless they are properly designed. Water-soluble fractions of wood and bark were highly acidic and changed little over the yearlong study period. Uncontrolled, the leachate from storage piles may be harmful to the environment.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; FUELS - Calorific Value; MATERIALS - Physical Properties; WOOD PRODUCTS - Storage; ENERGY POTENTIAL; HARDWOOD PARTICULATE FUELS; OUTSIDE STORAGE; WOOD

Title: LITHIUM BATTERY IS RECHARGEABLE.
Affiliations: Design News, Newton, MA, USA, Design News, Newton, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bak, David J., Design News, Newton, MA, USA, Design News, Newton, MA, USA
Abstract: Lithium, the lightest known metal, and a phenomena called intercalation, give this energy storage system several advantages over conventional batteries. A flashlight-size C-cell weights about 10 grams less than a similar nickel-cadmium (NiCd) cell. Power density, reportedly, is three times greater; shelf life eight years or more. Charge, moreover, can be determined simply by measuring voltage. 'Molicels' a product of Moli Energy Ltd. , incorporates a positive electrode (cathode), negative electrode (anode), and separator. Lithium foil forms the anode; molybdenum disulfide powder, bound to a substrate, makes up the cathode. A porous film saturated with an electrolyte solution separates the two.
Index Keywords: ELECTRODES, ELECTROCHEMICAL; LITHIUM AND ALLOYS - Electric Properties; ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM; RECHARGEABLE BATTERIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: HIGH FREQUENCY, HIGH AMPLITUDE AND LOW ENERGY EARTHQUAKE STUDY AT V. C. SUMMER NUCLEAR STATION.
Affiliations: South Carolina Electric & Gas, Co, Columbia, SC, USA, South Carolina Electric & Gas Co, Columbia, SC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Whorton, Robert B., South Carolina Electric & Gas, Co, Columbia, SC, USA, South Carolina Electric & Gas Co, Columbia, SC, USA
Abstract: The impoundment of Monticello Reservoir, adjacent to the Virgil C. Summer Nuclear Station, produced a large number of small earthquakes in the near-field. Several of these earthquakes were recorded by a USGS strong motion accelerometer located on an earthen dam abutment approximately 1 mile from the nuclear station. The recorded earthquakes contained high frequency, high amplitude (maximum horizontal acceleration of 0. 36 g), and low energy. To resolve Atomic Safety & Licensing Board (ASLB) and Advisory Committee on Reactor Safeguards (ACRS) concerns relative to these earthquakes, the utility was requested to compare the response spectra of the recorded earthquakes to the plant design response spectra to verify that adequate safety margins exist for plant components necessary for shutdown and residual heat removal.

Title: PERFORMANCE OF A CAPACITIVE COOLING SYSTEM FOR DRY COOLING.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, Coal Combustion Systems Division, (Report) EPRI CS
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This work has demonstrated a capacitive cooling system (CCS) that can augment an all-dry heat rejection system for a steam turbine during periods of peak load and maximum ambient temperature. The CCS consumes no water by evaporation and operates in a zero discharge mode, offering sizable siting and environmental advantages compared with wet-dry supplementary cooling systems. This system includes a 750,000 gal water tank that serves as a thermal capacitor, storing heat during periods of high ambient temperature and rejecting it during the night. Water from the CCS cools an auxiliary steam condenser operated in parallel with the primary (ammonia-cooled) condenser. The heated water is stored above the remaining cold water in the tank, and at night a heat pump transfers heat from the hot water layer to the primary dry-cooling tower.
Index Keywords: COOLING TOWERS; ENERGY CONSERVATION; STEAM CONDENSERS; STEAM POWER PLANTS - Energy Storage; WATER TANKS AND TOWERS - Energy Storage; ALL-DRY HEAT RESECTION SYSTEM; CAPACITIVE COOLING SYSTEM; STRATIFIED STORAGE OF HEATED WATER; STEAM TURBINES

Authors: Vybornov O.Yu., Snegirev N.N., Statsenko I.V., Dovbysh N.G.
Title: DIFFUSION COEFFICIENTS OF POTASSIUM HYDROXIDE AND ZINCATE IN MEMBRANES (SEPARATORS) BASED ON GRAFT POLYETHYLENE.
Source title: Journal of applied chemistry of the USSR
Affiliations: All-Union Scientific-Research Inst, of Storge Batteries, USSR, All-Union Scientific-Research Inst of Storge Batteries, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Vybornov, O.Yu., All-Union Scientific-Research Inst, of Storge Batteries, USSR, All-Union Scientific-Research Inst of Storge Batteries, USSR; Snegirev, N.N., All-Union Scientific-Research Inst, of Storge Batteries, USSR, All-Union Scientific-Research Inst of Storge Batteries, USSR; Statsenko, I.V., All-Union Scientific-Research Inst, of Storge Batteries, USSR, All-Union Scientific-Research Inst of Storge Batteries, USSR; Dovbysh, N.G., All-Union Scientific-Research Inst, of Storge Batteries, USSR, All-Union Scientific-Research Inst of Storge Batteries, USSR
Abstract: Short-circuiting of the electrodes and failure of the cells may occur during charging of storage batteries. This undesirable effect is caused by growth of filamentary dendrites within the separator channels and not by mechanical puncture. Dendrite growth is proportional to the 'solubility' and rate of ion diffusion within the separators. The purpose of this work is to study these processes. The diffusion coefficients of potassium hydroxide and zincate in separators made of polyethylene with grafted acrylic acid were measured. Correlations were established between the relative electrical conductivities of separator membranes and the diffusion coefficients, standard free energy, enthalpy, and entropy of activation of diffusion of the electrolytes KOH and K//2 left bracket ZN (OH)//4 right bracket . It is shown that ions move through separator channels by two mechanisms. The contribution of the cooperative mechanism increases with increase of the relative electrical resistance of the separator membranes. Mechanisms of ion diffusion in membranes are postulated.
Index Keywords: ELECTROLYTES; IONS - Diffusion; POLYETHYLENES - Applications; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS - Diffusion; SEPARATORS - Materials; ACTIVATION ENERGY; POTASSIUM HYDROXIDE; POTASSIUM ZINCATE; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: BLACKENING AT ROOM TEMPERATURE.
Affiliations: Birchwood Casey, Eden Prairie, MN,, USA, Birchwood Casey, Eden Prairie, MN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ruhland, Mark A., Birchwood Casey, Eden Prairie, MN,, USA, Birchwood Casey, Eden Prairie, MN, USA
Abstract: Over the years, black-oxide finishes have served the metalworking industry well, making it possible for manufacturers of steel parts of all descriptions to achieve a finish that satisfies the following requirements: Good corrosion resistance; properly applied, the black finish retards rust in service or in storage. Esthetic appeal; many manufactured parts require an attractive yet durable black finish for 'sales appeal. ' No dimensional change; machined parts often are manufactured to tight dimensional specifications. As such, they are not good candidates for electroplating or painting, since these coatings change dimensions more than is tolerable. Low cost; blackening generally can be done for less money than other types of finishing. While blackening remains very popular today, over the past ten years the processes for blackening have had to respond to changes in world economics, and to a number of government regulations. Manufacturers have increasingly sought processes that save energy, lessen environmental pollution, increase productivity and improve worker safety.
Index Keywords: METALS AND ALLOYS - Oxidation; OXIDES; BLACK-OXIDE FINISHES; BLACKENING; RINSES; PROTECTIVE COATINGS

Authors with affiliations: Hochdahl, O.
Abstract: Various fuels and their utilization in the cement industry are covered. Some of the aspects discussed are handling, preparation, storage, controlled feeding of primary and waste-derived fuels, firing systems, burners, and energy recovery. Some of the fuels are covered, including coal and alternative fuels.

Title: VOLTAGE REGULATOR HAVING COUPLED FILTER FOR FAST LOAD TRANSIENT RESPONSE.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: In a conventional forward-averaging output of a switching supply, the filtering is done at the voltage and current levels of the output. For low voltage, high current outputs, this filtering becomes unwieldy because (1) capacitive energy storage at low voltage requires large capacitor values and (2) use of large inductances at high currents results in physically large structures, and slows the supply's speed of response to changes in load current. It is shown how the need for output filtering at the supply voltage and current can be reduced.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC FILTERS; ELECTRIC POWER SUPPLIES TO APPARATUS - Switching; COUPLED FILTER; FAST LOAD; FORWARD-AVERAGING OUTPUT; OUTPUT FILTERING; TRANSIENT RESPONSE; VOLTAGE REGULATORS

Title: FLUORESCENT MONITOR SAVES MONEY FOR MAJOR MEDICAL DISTRIBUTOR.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: By upgrading their expanding warehouse lighting system with fluorescent monitors, a Mississippi medical distributor will cut lighting energy and maintenance costs approximately 23,000 a year. Installed without disrupting normal operations, the inexpensive monitors can double the life of tubes and ballasts while reducing energy costs 30 to 50 percent. The monitor tunes and balances the whole fluorescent system, including lamps, ballasts, and powee supply; it precisely regulates both the voltage and the current on an ongoing basis to establish and hold the system at optimum performance level; and protects the whole fluorescent system with special safety circuits.
