Authors: Cooper A., Dixon S.F., Tsuda M.
Title: Photoenergetics of octopus rhodopsin - Convergent evolution of biological photon counters?
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Glasgow University, Glasgow, G128QQ, United Kingdom; Department of Physics, Sapporo Medical College, Sapporo, 060, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Cooper, A., Department of Chemistry, Glasgow University, Glasgow, G128QQ, United Kingdom; Dixon, S.F., Department of Chemistry, Glasgow University, Glasgow, G128QQ, United Kingdom; Tsuda, M., Department of Physics, Sapporo Medical College, Sapporo, 060, Japan
Abstract: The enthalpy changes associated with each of the major steps in the photoconversion of octopus rhodopsin have been measured by direct photocalorimetry. Formation of the primary photoproduct (bathorhodopsin) involves energy uptake of about 130 kJ/mol, corresponding to storage of over 50% of the exciting photon energy, and is comparable to the energy storage previously observed in bovine rhodopsin. Subsequent intermediates involve the step-wise dissipation of this energy to give the physiological end-product (acid metarhodopsin) at a level only slightly above the parent rhodopsin. No significant differences in energetics are observed between rhodopsin in microvilli membrane suspensions or detergent dispersions. Use of different buffer systems in the calorimetric experiments shows that conversion of rhodopsin to acid metarhodopsin involves no light-induced protonation change, whereas alkali metarhodopsin photoproduction occurs with the release of one proton per molecule and an additional enthalpy increase of about 50 kJ/mol. Van't Hoff analysis of the effect of temperature on the reversible metarhodopsin equilibrium gives an enthalpy for the acid → alkali transition consistent with this calorimetric result, and the proton release is confirmed by direct observation of light-induced pH changes. Acid-base titration of metarhodopsin yields an apparent pK of 9.5 for this transition, though the pH profile deviates slightly from ideal titration behaviour. We suggest that a high energy primary photoproduct is an obligatory feature of efficient biological photodetectors, as opposed to photon energy transducers, and that the similarity at this stage between cephalopod and vertebrate rhodopsins represents either convergent evolution at the molecular level or strong conservation of a crucial functional characteristic. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: calorimetry; energetics; rhodopsin; vision
Index Keywords: rhodopsin; enthalpy; methodology; nonhuman; octopus; Animal; Calorimetry; Darkness; Light; Microvilli; Octopus; Retinal Pigments; Rhodopsin; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Thermodynamics

Title: Portsmouth dockyard: An industrial archaeological overview
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Portsmout Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Riley, R.C., Department of Geography, Portsmout Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: A chronological framework is employed to trace the evolution since the 1690s of surviving artefacts in the Dockyard. Emphasis is placed upon the docks and basins, not only because they are of crucial importance, but also since they have to date been the subject of scant attention by researchers. Unlike the docks and basins, most of the pre-1914 production shops have lost their function, but fortunately are to be retained as stores in the current reorganisation plan. The requirement for storage space has ensured the survival of many eighteenth century storehouses. The paper concludes with a review of energy supplies and the Dockyard's internal transport system. © 1986 Maney Publishing.

Title: Results of 8-year continuous measurements of aerosol profiles in the stratosphere with discussion of the importance of stratospheric aerosols to an estimate of effects on the global climate
Affiliations: Fritz-Müllerstrasse 54, Garmisch-Partenkirchen, D-8100, Germany; Fraunhofer-Institut für Atmosphärische Umweltforschung, Kreuzeckbahnstrasse 19, Garmisch-Partenkirchen, D-8100, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Reiter, R., Fritz-Müllerstrasse 54, Garmisch-Partenkirchen, D-8100, Germany; Jäger, H., Fraunhofer-Institut für Atmosphärische Umweltforschung, Kreuzeckbahnstrasse 19, Garmisch-Partenkirchen, D-8100, Germany
Abstract: After a short description of the measuring technique used the results of an efficient lidar system to determine stratospheric aerosol profiles up to 30 km altitude are reported in detail. Technical data of the lidar system: 100 megawatt trasmitter energy, 20 n sec pulse length, 1/sec pulse repetition, 694 nm wavelength, single photon counting with use of a chopper for suppressing fluorescence of the laser crystal after the shot, fully-automated control of the measuring procedure and storage of data by computer. Shown as examples are first individual profiles of the stratospheric aerosol distribution after the most violent eruption of the recent past (El Chichon 1982). These profiles reveal the rapid variations of the profile structure caused by the different flow conditions as a function of season. The results make clear that the fastest possible sequence of lidar measurements is required to obtain significant and application-oriented data. The integrated backscattering is presented from the beginning of 1977 to the end of 1984. Its variations, resulting from a whole series of volcanic events during this period, are discussed in comparison with the back-ground conditions 1977/78. The residence time of stratospheric aerosols is derived for different layers of the stratosphere with an estimate of the mean residence time of particles<0.5 μm diameter at the respective level. The dramatic variation of the stratospheric aerosol distribution in 47o northern latitude shortly before and immediately after the El Chichon eruption and continuously until summer 1984 is shown by means of three-dimensional diagrams. The different temporal trends in the behavior of the stratospheric aerosol in midlatitudes as a function of the latitude of volcanic eruptions are discussed by means of examples. Our results of measurements are compared with those of other groups. Calculations of the optical depth are shown from early 1982 to late 1984 and are compared with background conditions from 1978. The stratospheric aerosol mass in the column above the unit surface is grphically plotted as a function of time. In several passages it is pointed out that not only volcano El Chichon as the last - even though extreme volcanic event - has to be considered but also minor volcanic eruptions which took place in different countries in late summer and fall 1983. Special sections give an overview of the available literature concerning the question of an impact on climate, especially on the northern hemispheric temperature by stratospheric turbidity, and conclusions are drawn as to the practical application of our measurement results. Based on reliable data from the literature, a volcanically-induced cooling of the order of about 0.5 K is to be expected from the turn of the year 1984/85 on, followed by a gradual normalization (provided: no new major volcanic eruptions). © 1986 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Organ preservation: Current and future perspectives
Affiliations: Department of Surgery, Section of Transplantation, Mount Carmel Mercy Hospital, Detroit, MI 48235, United States
Authors with affiliations: Toledo-Pereyra, L.H., Department of Surgery, Section of Transplantation, Mount Carmel Mercy Hospital, Detroit, MI 48235, United States
Abstract: In theory, two approaches may be used to keep an organ alive in the ex vivo setting. Either the tissue metabolism may be reduced enough so that oxygen and energy carriers are unnecessary or one may attempt to meet as many of the requirements of normal metabolism as possible in the preservation setting. Since it was found to be difficult to maintain and meet normal metabolic requirements, the use of hypothermia as a means of reducing these needs has developed as a main principle of preservation. It has been found, for example, that the oxygen consumption of the kidney at 7 degree C is 3-6% of that at normal body temperatures. Currently in clinical organ preservation, both hypothermic storage and hypothermic pulsatile perfusion methods are used. This paper presents the current status of each of these techniques and presents the new areas of work to improve organ preservation. Preservation of the non-renal organs, liver, heart, and pancreas is discussed specifically.

Title: CATCHING THE FAST ACTION - TIME RESOLUTION IN HIGH-ENERGY X-RAY STUDIES.
Affiliations: Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mills, Dennis M., Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA, Cornell Univ, Ithaca, NY, USA
Abstract: In studies of the temporal evolution of fast processes, investigators have had to rely mainly on techniques other than x-ray diffraction and spectroscopy because of the inherent weakness of conventional x-ray sources. Within the last decade, however, a new source of intense radiation has become available: high-energy storage rings. The Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source (CHESS), operated in conjunction with the Cornell Electron Storage Ring (CESR), is providing new impetus for time-resolved studies. This article investigates the intrinsic properties of synchrotron radiation and its applications. The most straightforward application is the use of the high flux available from storage rings to decrease data-collection time. In other techniques, both the high flux and the continuous spectrum of radiation are utilized. And in some experiments the pulsed nature of the emitted radiation provides ways of looking at processes with very short time scales.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON; MATERIALS - Radiation Effects; HIGH ENERGY RESEARCH; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; TIME RESOLUTION; X-RAYS

Title: ULTRAVIOLET DEGRADATION OF CORRUGATED PLASTIC TUBING.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Desmond, E.D., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA; Schwab, G.O., Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA
Abstract: The embrittlement rates of corrugated plastic tubing (CPT) resulting from two accelerated ultraviolet (UV) exposure methods were compared with that of natural sunlight exposure in Ohio. CPT storage shelf life predictions were based on the effect of UV light exposure. Fourteen average months of Ohio exposure, or 5600 MJ/m**2 of solar energy, is the maximum recommended shelf life for storage of CPT. Shelf life tests can be made by accelerated exposure of 450 MJ/m**2 of concentrated sunlight or by 800 Weatherometer hours of exposure both followed by a flat plate impact of 30 J. Protection from UV embrittlement during the recommended shelf life is adequate if all samples exposed on accelerated machines pass the impact test.

Title: PART-LOAD PROBLEM.
Affiliations: Univ of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks,, AK, USA, Univ of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, Ronald A., Univ of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks,, AK, USA, Univ of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK, USA; Malosh, James B., Univ of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks,, AK, USA, Univ of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK, USA; Leonard, Leroy E., Univ of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks,, AK, USA, Univ of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK, USA; Bubendorf, Sandra L., Univ of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks,, AK, USA, Univ of Alaska-Fairbanks, Fairbanks, AK, USA
Abstract: The task of improving the part-load efficiency of a diesel-electric generator is a twofold problem, but some solutions to one aspect of the problem also improve the other. The first part of the problem concerns the reduced efficiency of the diesel engine when it is operated at low loads. The second aspect concerns modifications of the engine so that it can operate at less than 60 percent capacity without suffering mechanical failures. A review of the literature reveals the possibility of modifying diesel-electric generators by adding a radiator-mounted load band with resistive heat recovery, by using acoustically tuned, aerodynamically efficient intake and exhaust systems, or by parallel operation of smaller generating units.

Zajc, W.A., University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, 19104, PA, United States
Abstract: We present stdies of events triggered on two high-pT jets, produced in pp collisions at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings (ISR) at {Mathematical expression}=63 GeV, using a large solid angle calorimeter. The cross-section for producing two jets is measured in the dijet mass range 17-50 GeV/c2. A high-statistics sample of dijet events, where each jet has transverse energy above 10 GeV, is used to study the structure of jets and the associated event. We find the longitudinal fragmentation function to be similar to that of jets emerging from e+e- collisions but considerably harder than that observed at the Super Proton Synchrotron (SPS) {Mathematical expression} Collider. A steepening of the fragmentation function is observed when increasing the jet energy. Studies of the charge distribution in jets show that these predominantly originate from fragmenting valence quarks. The transverse energy and particle flows are presented as functions of the azimuthal distance from the jet axis. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.

Abstract: We report a study of the decay τ-→τ-τ+τ-vτ using the ARGUS detector at the DORIS II storage ring. Tau pairs were produced by e+e- annihilation at centre-of-mass energies near 10 GeV. We have observed about 1,700 events, corresponding to a branching ratio for τ-→τ-τ+τ-vτ of (5.6±0.7)%. The dominant mode for this decay is observed to be ρ0π- in a Jp=1+ spin state. The ρ0π- mass spectrum shows a broad enhancement near 1.10 GeV/c2, which has the properties expected for the A1. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Future of large tandems plus boosters
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Hahn-Meitner-Institut für Kernforschung Berlin GmbH, Bereich Kern - und Strahlenphysik, Glienicker Str. 100, D-1000 Berlin 39, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ziegler, K., Hahn-Meitner-Institut für Kernforschung Berlin GmbH, Bereich Kern - und Strahlenphysik, Glienicker Str. 100, D-1000 Berlin 39, Germany
Abstract: The future of existing large tandem facilities lies firstly in the application of developments to achieve higher terminal voltages, secondly in the addition of a suitable booster, and thirdly in the use of the tandem as injector for a large synchrotron or storage ring. The development of the Vivitron in Strasbourg might well be the prototype for one or two more machines in the range of terminal voltages between 35 MV and 50 MV. The field of large tandems and boosters is very much alive and we can expect a series of improvements and even new developments in the next ten years. © 1986.
Index Keywords: ELECTROSTATIC DEVICES; BOOSTERS; ENERGY-MASS DIAGRAM; INJECTORS; VICKSI-GROUP; ACCELERATORS

Title: The self-association of insulin: Determinations based on a differential gel adsorption procedure
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, WA 6009, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Helmerhorst, E., Department of Biochemistry, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, WA 6009, Australia; Stokes, G.B., Department of Biochemistry, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, WA 6009, Australia
Abstract: Self-association properties of zinc-insulin were investigated using a differential gel adsorption procedure based on the microcentrifuge desalting method of E. Helmerhorst and G. B. Stokes (1980, Anal. Biochem. 104, 130-135). This differential gel adsorption procedure offered a quick semiquantitative method for examining insulin association under a wide range of different conditions using simple equipment. Nonspecific adsorption effects with the gel matrix at low insulin concentrations were minimized by the presence of 0.1% bovine serum albumin. This procedure was based on the observation that the monomer species of insulin was separated from insulin aggregates due to its interaction with the devoided gel matrix of Sephadex G-25 and remained on the column following centrifugation. A residue with an apparent pK of 11.1 ± 0.1 was shown to be critically responsible for the adsorption of monomer insulin to the gel matrix, thus implicating the tyrosyl residue(s) of insulin in this interaction. The proportion of monomer was simply computed from the recovery of insulin off the gel using [125I]monoiodoinsulin to monitor recovery. Insulin association was studied over the range of insulin concentrations from physiologically circulating levels (nm) to storage concentrations (mm). Our data are in agreement with monomer being the predominant form of the hormone in vivo. Our estimates for the Gibbs free energy change, enthalpy, and entropy for the formation of dimers and the effects of pH, ionic strength, and temperature on the equilibrium constant for the formation of dimers were in good agreement with the literature. This differential gel adsorption procedure may have application to other protein-associating systems with suitable adsorption characteristics. © 1986.
Index Keywords: albumin; insulin; insulin i 125; radioisotope; drug binding; nonhuman; priority journal; protein assembly; Centrifugation; Computers; Hydrogen-Ion Concentration; Insulin; Macromolecular Systems; Mathematics; Microchemistry; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Thermodynamics

Title: FUTURE FUEL PRICES AND COMPETITIVENESS TO THE YEAR 2005.
Source title: Technical Note TN - BSRIA (Building Services Research and Information Association)
Authors with affiliations: Gregory, D.P.
Abstract: A consensus of opinion was obtained from fuel supply planners in late 1985 about the likely future costs of various fuels and electricity for the next 20 years. These price escalation projections are applied to current domestic and commercial tariffs, and are then adjusted for the likely system efficiencies expected for oil, coal, gas and propane boilers, electric resistance and storage heating, and gas and electric heat pumps. Off-peak electricity becomes competitive with oil and solid fuel in both the commercial and domestic markets and begins to approach the running cost of a gas boiler by 2005. Attention is drawn to the advantages to be gained with electric heating by introducing sufficient thermal storage to allow about 30% of the operating time to be at night, when significant running cost savings are achieved. The average cost of electricity is shown as a function of the ratio of day to night operation. The report concludes that in future, more attention must be paid to systems carefully designed to make optimum use of stored energy and off-peak electric tariffs as the price of electricity becomes more competitive with the fossil fuels.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER UTILIZATION - Economics; ENERGY STORAGE - Efficiency; TECHNOLOGICAL FORECASTING - Analysis; ELECTRICITY COST DECLINE; OIL PRICE TRENDS; FUELS

Authors: Hendricks Robert C., Simoneau Robert J., Dunning Jr. John W.
Title: HEAT TRANSFER IN SPACE POWER AND PROPULSION SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hendricks, Robert C., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Simoneau, Robert J., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA; Dunning Jr., John W., NASA, Lewis Research Cent,, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: The current administration in Washington has set as a national goal the establishment of a space station by 1992. In order to meet this deadline, various heat transfer problems encountered in space power and aerospace propulsion systems will have to be solved. The space station, operating as a NASA laboratory, presents numerous heat transfer problems-in orbital power systems, transfer-vehicle propulsion, orbital propellant supply, and the design of hypersonic vehicles. This paper discusses possible solutions.

Title: Investigations on hydrophilic and hydrophobic silicon (100) wafer surfaces by X-ray photoelectron and high-resolution electron energy loss-spectroscopy
Source title: Applied Physics A Solids and Surfaces
Affiliations: Research Center, Wacker-Chemitronic, Burghausen, D-8263, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Grundner, M., Research Center, Wacker-Chemitronic, Burghausen, D-8263, Germany; Jacob, H., Research Center, Wacker-Chemitronic, Burghausen, D-8263, Germany
Abstract: The paper reports on surface spectroscopy measurements of silicon single-crystal wafers which have been treated in order to obtain hydrophilic and hydrophobic surfaces, respectively. The wafers are characterized in terms of the oxidation behaviour in air ("native oxides"), their surface chemical composition and the chemical bonds involved. It is shown that the oxide on hydrophilic wafers mainly grows in the cleaning agent and consists of hydrated SiO2 through all stages of the growth. On a hydrophobic surface, however, the oxidation begins with the formation of a lower oxidation state which turns into SiO2 on storage in air. The thickness of the oxides on both surface types reaches 1.4-1.5 nm. Both the chemical shift in photoelectron spectroscopy and the frequency of the asymmetric Si-O-Si vibration in electron energy loss spectroscopy support the assumption of a reduced bonding angle of the oxygen bridge. Hydrophilicity is caused by singular and associated OH groups on the surface. Singular groups could be detected up to 700 K. There are hints that OH groups stabilize the oxide during heating. The hydrophobic state is mainly characterized by Si-H and Si-CHx groups on the surface, whereas Si-F exists only in minor quantities. Si-H groups were stable up to approximately 900 K in UHV. Si-CHx dehydrogenizes at temperatures between 500 and 700 K leaving SiC on the surface. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Oxidation; SPECTROSCOPY, ELECTRON - Applications; HIGH-RESOLUTION ELECTRON ENERGY LOSS-SPECTROSCOPY; HYDROPHILIC SILICON; HYDROPHOBIC SILICON; X-RAY PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY; SEMICONDUCTING SILICON

Title: SOLID PARTICLE CENTRAL RECEIVER FOR SOLAR ENERGY.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Solid Particle, Receiver Program, Livermore, CA, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Solid Particle Receiver Program, Livermore, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hruby, J.M., Sandia Natl Lab, Solid Particle, Receiver Program, Livermore, CA, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Solid Particle Receiver Program, Livermore, CA, USA; Steele, B.R., Sandia Natl Lab, Solid Particle, Receiver Program, Livermore, CA, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Solid Particle Receiver Program, Livermore, CA, USA
Abstract: A novel concept for a central receiver currently being examined employs sand-size refractory particles that free-fall in a cavity receiver. A conceptual design of a solid particle receiver is shown. The solid particle central receiver is being evaluated for high-temperature (greater than 550 degree C) applications of solar energy. The advantages of a solid particle receiver over traditional fluid-in-tube receivers are: the particles can directly absorb solar radiation and the particles maintain their integrity at high temperatures. These advantages, coupled with the possibility that the particles can serve as the storage medium, could provide a cost-effective means of high-temperature solar energy utilization.
Index Keywords: CENTRAL RECEIVER; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: What the hen can tell about her eggs: egg development on the basis of energy budgets
Affiliations: Netherlands Organization for Applied Scientific Research, TNO, P.O. Box 217, AE Delft, 2600, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kooijman, S.A.L.M., Netherlands Organization for Applied Scientific Research, TNO, P.O. Box 217, AE Delft, 2600, Netherlands
Abstract: By a simple model involving the state variables size and storage, it is possible to describe a wide variety of observations on the feeding, growth, energy storage and reproduction of animals. The model is based on the assumption that reproduction, growth as well as maintenance depend on the stored energy only and not directly on feeding. If an egg is thought of as a non-feeding animal, the model predicts the respiration ontogeny and growth of the embryo inside the egg. These predictions seem to hold well for published data on the development of eggs of fish and ratite, precocial and altricial birds. The latter two are known to follow different respiration ontogenies, but both are described well, differing only in one (compound) parameter value. The model explains why the incubation times of eggs of different species tend to increase linearly with egg size to the power 1/4, and why kiwis and petrels, which lay relatively large eggs, have to brood them much longer than larger birds with eggs of the same size. Conversely, it explains why the small eggs of the (parasitic) European cuckoo, hatch earlier than the still smaller eggs of their tiny hosts. Furthermore, it has been shown how the maintenance rate constant, which frequently appears in the microbial literature, can be obtained from measurements on the respiration and weight ontogeny in embryos, so linking independent lines of research. Application of the model shows an increase of the maintenance rate constant from bacteria, crustaceans, up to fish and birds, and a decrease from bacteria to green algae, suggesting lines of evolutionary development. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Adult-egg relation; Egg respiration; Maintenance rate constant; Scaling relations

Authors: van Dorssen R.J., Gerola P.D., Olson J.M., Amesz J.
Title: Optical and structural properties of chlorosomes of the photosynthetic green sulfur bacterium Chlorobium limicola
Affiliations: Department of Biophysics, Huygens Laboratory, the State University, P.O. Box 9504, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands; Institute of Biochemistry, Odense University, Campusvej 55, 5230 Odense M, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: van Dorssen, R.J., Department of Biophysics, Huygens Laboratory, the State University, P.O. Box 9504, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands; Gerola, P.D., Institute of Biochemistry, Odense University, Campusvej 55, 5230 Odense M, Denmark; Olson, J.M., Institute of Biochemistry, Odense University, Campusvej 55, 5230 Odense M, Denmark; Amesz, J., Department of Biophysics, Huygens Laboratory, the State University, P.O. Box 9504, 2300 RA Leiden, Netherlands
Abstract: Isolated chlorosomes of the photosynthetic green sulfur bacterium Chorobium limicola upon cooling to 4 K showed, in addition to the near-infrared absorption band at 753 nm due to bacteriochlorophyll c, a weak band near 800 nm that could be attributed to bacteriochlorophyll a. The emission spectrum showed bands of bacteriochlorophyll c and a at 788 and 828 nm, respectively. The fluorescence excitation spectrum indicated a high efficiency of energy transfer from bacteriochlorophyll c to bacteriochlorophyll a. When all bacteriochlorophyll c absorption had been lost upon storage, no appreciable change in the optical properties of the bacteriochlorophyll a contained in these 'depleted chlorosomes' was observed. The fluorescence and absorption spectra of the chlorosomal bacteriochlorophyll a were clearly different from those of the soluble bacteriochlorophyll a protein present in these bacteria. The results provide strong evidence that bacteriochlorophyll a, although present in a small amount, is an integral constituent of the chlorosome. It presumably functions in the transfer of energy from the chlorosome to the photosynthetic membrane; its spectral properties and the orientation of its near-infrared optical transitions as determined by linear dichroism are such as to favor this energy transfer. © 1986.
Author Keywords: (Green sulfur bacterium); Bacteriochlorophyll a; Bacteriochlorophyll c; Chlorosome; Energy transfer
Index Keywords: bacteriochlorophyll; bacterium; cell inclusion; chlorobium; nonhuman; photosynthesis; priority journal

Title: High transverse energy and high transverse momentum events in pp and pp interactions at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, United States; Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Angelis, A.L.S., Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Basini, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Besch, H.-J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Breedon, R.E., Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Camilleri, L., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Chapin, T.J., Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Cox, P.T., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Von Gagern, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Grosso-Pilcher, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Hanna, D.S., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Humphries, B.M., Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, United States; Linnemann, J.T., Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, United States, Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Newman-Holmes, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Nickerson, R.B., Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Phinney, N., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Pope, B.G., Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, United States; Pordes, S.H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Powell, K.J., Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Rusack, R.W., Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Salgado, C.W., Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, United States; Segar, A.M., Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Stampke, S.R., Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, United States; Tannenbaum, M.J., Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Yelton, J.M., Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: A comparison between pp and pp interactions at √s = 52.7 GeV is presented for a total neutral transverse energy (ETo) trigger and for a high transverse momentum (pT) neutral cluster trigger. The rate of production of events in the range 6<ETo<20 GeV is observed to be 10% higher in pp collisions than in pp collisions. A study of the structure of the events shows this excess to be due to more isotropic events being produced in pp collisions. The ratio of the production cross section for single neutral clusters in pp and pp interactions in the range 1.25<pT<10 GeV/c does not significantly differ from unity. © 1986.

Title: Heavy ions in the CELSIUS storage ring in Uppsala
Affiliations: Tandem Accelerator Laboratory, Box 533, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Westerberg, L., Tandem Accelerator Laboratory, Box 533, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: The CELSIUS storage ring facility will include electron cooling, acceleration and internal targets. It is presently under construction adjacent to its injector machine, the rebuilt synchrocyclotron of the Gustaf Werner Institute. The maximum energy for protons will be 1.16 GeV and for heavy ions 388 MeV/A for ions with Q/A=0.5. © 1986.

Title: A heat pump incorporating thermochemical energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Riffat, S.B.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: Tek M.R., Coleman D.D., Parker J.M.
Title: Huntsman and west engelland fields, cheyenne county, Nebraska: A case history of technical lessons from a legal conflict
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: U. of New South Wales, United States; Consulting Geochemist, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tek, M.R., U. of New South Wales, United States; Coleman, D.D., Consulting Geochemist, United States; Parker, J.M., Consulting Geochemist, United States
Abstract: During the years 1982-85, a lengthy litigation took place between KN Energy and Marathon Oil Corp. The case involved performance of two fields on structures adjacent to a common saddle and suspected migration of storage gas into the gas cap of a producing oil field. After some 3 years of extensive study, discovery proceedings and preparations, the case came to trial in U.S. District Court in Lincoln, Nebraska, 8 Duly 1985. After nearly a month in court, agreement was reached between the parties to settle the case on 6 August 1985. The purpose of this paper is not to redress and reargue the legal controversy. Rather, it is to share in the technical forum of gas technology, the lessons learned from the synergistic study leading to a forensic conclusion. The case history is unique and significant because it relates to extensive data from 2 fields and provides insight helpful to understanding major geological and operational factors affecting migration, exchange and mixing of mobile fluids underground. The paper, written from the perspectives of applied reservoir engineering, geology and geochemistry, includes methodologies applicable to other similar situations - often suspected but not sufficiently investigated. Application and calculations involving inventory verification methods, production-pressure trends, study of well records, gas-water, gas-oil contacts, computer simulation by finite element method, and identification of resident gas by isotope chemistry are among areas highlighted by specific examples. © 1986, Society of Petroleum Engineers.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Geology; Laws and legislation; Oil fields; Gas technologies; Gas-oil contacts; Inventory verifications; Legal conflicts; Operational factors; Pressure trends; Reservoir engineering; Technical forums; Gases

Title: ACID CORROSION IN A CAES RECUPERATOR.
Affiliations: Encotech Inc, Encotech Inc
Authors with affiliations: Lukas, Holger, Encotech Inc, Encotech Inc; Mehta, Bhupen, Encotech Inc, Encotech Inc
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: Ambrose J.H., Chow L.C., Beam J.E.
Title: TRANSIENT HEAT PIPE RESPONSE AND REWETTING BEHAVIOR.
Affiliations: Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA, Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ambrose, J.H., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA, Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA; Chow, L.C., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA, Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA; Beam, J.E., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA, Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, KY, USA
Abstract: This paper describes the results of an investigation of pulsed heat pipe start up. Two types of pulsed start up of a copper and water heat pipe are examined. In the first, the mean temperature of the transport section is nearly constant with time. In the second, the entire heat pipe is increasing in temperature, so thermal energy storage is significant. Dryout of the wick at the evaporator is found to occur only for heat transport rates greater than the capillary limit. A transient heat pipe model is used to qualitatively explain the dryout and rewetting of the wick in the second type of pulsed start up.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Convection; DRYOUT; REWETTING; START UP; Heat pipes

Title: EXTENDED ABSTRACTS OF THE FIRST INTERNATIONAL WORKSHOP ON BATTERY TESTING.
Abstract: Proceedings includes 43 papers that are grouped into seven sessions dealing with: general testing procedures, international overview, testing of special battery systems, accelerated life cycle tests, instrumentation, hardware, equipment, post-test analyses, thermal management, field testing and correlating laboratory tests with on-board EV (electric vehicle) tests. Topics considered include: electrolytes, electrodes, lead-acid batteries, testing facilities in West Germany, Australia, Canada, United States, Great Britain, and Japan, the Natl Battery Test Laboratory (NBTC), energy storage, sodium-sulfide traction batteries, beta alumina ceramics, sodium-sulfur cells, computer-aided testing and data acquisition, aqueous batteries, in-vehicle testing, and urban-traffic aspects.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILES - Electric; DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; ELECTROLYTES; ENERGY STORAGE; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; EIREV; ELECTRIC VEHICLES (EV); LEAD-ACID BATTERIES; SODIUM-SULFUR CELLS; TESTING LABORATORIES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: SOLID-PHASE (GELATINIZED) STORAGE SYSTEM OF WAXY CRUDE OIL.
Source title: Transactions of the Iron and Steel Institute of Japan
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Some of the high pour-point (H. P. P. ) crude oil, such as Daqing (China) and Minas (indonesia), have a high wax content, and their pour-point is often above 30 degree C. Because of these characteristics, H. P. P. crude oil is usually heated to about 50 to 60 degree C to maintain fluidity during storage, at considerable expense and at some risk to safety. To solve those difficulties, Nippon Steel Corporation has developed a new storage system for H. P. P. crude oil, called the solid-phase (gelatinized) storage system, in collaboration with Japan National Oil Corporation, a corporation under the control of Agency of National Resources and Energy.
Index Keywords: OIL FUEL - Heating; OIL TANKS - Heaters; HIGH POUR POINT/HPP; SOLID PHASE (GELATINIZED) STORAGE SYSTEM; WAXY RUDE OIL; Petroleum, Crude

Title: Survey of hydropower potential for large regions.
Authors with affiliations: Hildebrand, H.; Kern, K.
Abstract: Energy planning in industrial countries, as well as in developing countries, can only be carried out efficiently on the basis of an inventory of the available energy resources. In this context, hydropower as a renewable source of energy is of special importance. The potential water power resources of a country, a region or a catchment area can be determined by means of the area and the line potential. The area potential calculated from precipitation or specific discharge represents the hydropower resources which can be utilized by storage power plants and run of the river plants. The line potential can be used to estimate the water power resources in fluvial systems and to identify reaches with high energy potential. Presented as a band with varying width according to the specific power output, the line potential gives a useful tool to define adequate power plant sites.
Index Keywords: Hydroelectric power

Title: Analysis of a stand-alone power system for remote-site applications.
Authors with affiliations: Thacker, J.R.
Abstract: The U.S. Coast Guard has over forty automated remote lighthouses which are powered by a continuously run Diesel/electric generator. Continuous operation of a Diesel generator increases maintenance requirements as well as fuel costs. Previous studies have indicated that maintenance and operational costs at remote, automated lighthouses could be substantially reduced by incorporating a hybrid energy management system. Such a 120 volt system was designed, developed and built and includes the following major components: Diesel/electric generator; wind turbine generator; battery storage; inverter; system controller and lighthouse load. This paper discusses the system design, the chronological record of events; conclusions and recommendations of over three months of continuous data collection and system operation. Additionally, each major system component is discussed in detail.

Title: Thermal stresses in a large packed bed regenerative thermal energy store.
Issue: (eds.), Washington, U.S.A., Hemisphere Publishing Corp., 1986, p.143-156. (ISBN 0-89116-565-7)
Authors with affiliations: Atthey, D.E.; O'Reilly, M.P.
Abstract: In an advanced form of compressed air energy storage, cooling of the air during the compression phase and its subsequent reheating can be achieved at least in part by a thermal energy store. A previous detailed design study considered a number of variations of this energy storage scheme. Good thermal performance can be achieved for a low capital cost by using a direct contact packed bed made up of a large volume of almost spherical particles. The particles are made up of fireclay, iron oxide or cast iron and operate at temperatures up to 900DEGREESC or 500DEGREESC, depending on plant design. In an effort to evaluate the maximum stress levels to which bed particles and vessel wall are subjected to the stress/strain behaviour of a sample of the packed bed material under repeated cyclic loading was examined in detail. A theoretical model for the stress/strain behaviour of an idealized material is also described.

Title: Hydraulic accumulator energy storage in a city bus.
Authors with affiliations: Vaughan, N.D.; Dorey, R.E.
Abstract: This paper is concerned with the sizing and selection of an hydraulic accumulator system for regenerative braking in a city bus and with an evaluation by computer simulation of alternatives for its integration in the vehicle drive line. Earlier work published by the authors is reviewed. The accumulator system is considered in conjunction with both conventional and hydrostatic split power transmissions and the effect upon bus performance determine for operation over a typical route.

Authors: Holbrook J.H., Collings E.W., Cialone H.J., Drauglis E.J.
Title: Hydrogen degradation of pipeline steels: Final report.
Authors with affiliations: Holbrook, J.H.; Collings, E.W.; Cialone, H.J.; Drauglis, E.J.
Abstract: Purpose of investigations conducted by Battelle Columbus Laboratories was to develop a research data base applicable to the problem of hydrogen degradation in pipeline steels. The findings would provide pipeline designers and operators with insight for developing specifications and procedures in the event available natural gas transmission/distribution systems are used for hydrogen transport. Fundamental investigations and data derived from sophisticated analytical and test procedures have been equated to practical field conditions and experiences as may be encountered should the hydrogen energy storage/transport option become an economic reality. (A)

Title: The Corps of Engineers' new hydropower manual.
Issue: (ed.), New York, U.S.A., Am. Soc. Civ. Engrs., 1986, p.797-804. (ISBN 0-87262-536-2)
Authors with affiliations: Clowes, B.W.; Mittelstadt, R.L.
Abstract: The Corps of Engineers has recently completed a new Engineering Manual (EM), which outlines procedures used for the evaluation of hydropower projects. It will serve as the basic Corps reference document on hydropower planning and design for all levels of study. It covers a variety of topics, including hydrologic data requirements, estimating energy potential, powerplant sizing, pumped storage hydro, need for hydropower, and economic analysis. (A)

Title: Longterm performance modelling of a wind/Diesel system with hydraulic accumulator storage.
Authors with affiliations: Slack, G.; Musgrove, P.J.
Abstract: The use of hydraulic accumlator storage as a small capacity, high power, energy store to improve operation of a wind/Diesel system was validated by tests on a prototype system at Reading. Although measured data has made possible the formulation of a computer model which accurately represents the performance in the short term, assessment of the long term performance and economics causes difficulty due to the large amount of computer time required. This paper describes a fast and flexible method of combining energy buffer performance parameters derived from fast frequency wind data so as to provide an assessment of the long term performance and economic potential, for a wide variety of system configurations and operating conditions. (A)

Title: Applied wind generation in small isolated electricity systems.
Authors with affiliations: Somerville, W.M.
Abstract: Some problems in the operation of small electricity supply systems for isolated communities are discussed in relation to the application of wind energy. The choice of aerogenerator, the use of load management techniques to balance supply and demand and possible benefits of energy storage systems are examined. The importance of community involvement in load control is stressed and some results given. (A)

Authors: Rygh J.E., Wium R., Carlstrom B.
Title: A novel approach to control of remote subsea templates: the autonomous subsea control system.
Authors with affiliations: Rygh, J.E.; Wium, R.; Carlstrom, B.
Abstract: The autonomous control system is fully self contained and is only dependent on communication with the control centre to be operated. It was designed as a system reliable enough to avoid retrieval of the subsea modules within the regular maintenance periods for the production system. Autonomous systems are based on local power generation and storage; closed hydraulic system including hydraulic pumps and accumulators; and wireless data communication to each production module. The main features of the hydraulic systems and the data communication are described. An example of the energy demand for an autonomous control pod with Christmas tree and seven values is quoted. Generation of electric power is via batteries, radio isotope thermal electric generator and direct thermal electric devices.

Title: Estimating and avoiding waterhammer - a practical guide.
Authors with affiliations: Lewinsky-Kesslitz, H.P.
Abstract: The fundamentals are introduced for estimating procedures and graphic methods for a typical transient condition e.g. closing of valves, shutdown of centrifugal pumps, applicable to simplified systems. Ten methods for protecting pipeline systems for waterhammer are reviewed using a variety of design principles e.g. energy storage, over pressure or under pressure protecting valving and rupture discs. Their functions in a pipeline system are discussed, advantages as well as disadvantages are reviewed and sizing criteria are presented. (from author's abstract)

Authors: Anand D.K., Kirk J.A., Bangham M.L.
Title: Simulation, design and construction of a flywheel magnetic bearing.
Authors with affiliations: Anand, D.K.; Kirk, J.A.; Bangham, M.L.
Abstract: The work presented in this paper covers the design and construction of a magnetic bearing assembly for flywheel energy storage applications. A pancake magnetic bearing is described and the geometry of the bearing, which governs the radial weight carrying capacity and the size of permanent magnets and electromagnets, is presented. A design model for magnetic force computation is developed, based on the use of an equivalent electric circuit for the magnetic system, and results of applying the model are presented. The bearing control system is analyzed by simulating its response to perturbations. A linear model of the plant is used for the simulation, and to establish bounds on stability. The perturbation analysis determines the corrective flux requirements for a 2-g radial acceleration, and the real time simulation is used to analyze the effect of changes in the control system feedback loop on bearing impulse response. The results of the analysis determine the parametric design of a 300 Watt-Hour (108 kJ) energy storage flywheel system. In addition to the magnetic bearing design, a complete mechanical package, incorporating a motor/generator and back up mechanical bearings, is presented. (A)

Title: Energy: a conceptual approach.
Authors with affiliations: Van Koevering, T.E.; Sell, N.J.
Abstract: This book discusses energy sources in general, from solar energy, to natural gas and nuclear power. Chapter 13 concentrates on wind power, looking first at wind patterns all over the world, regionally and locally. Principles of wind energy devices are discussed, plus the application of windmills and energy storage systems. (R.I.H.)

Title: The development of a new non-pressurized in-line surge arrestor.
Authors with affiliations: Ayres, W.D.; Dement, R.B.
Abstract: The engineering mechanics and development of a device which has been designed for absorbing the excessive pressure buildup and shock waves produced in piping systems are presented. The surge arrestor moderates pulsations and minimizes hydraulic shock. The flexible tubular member of the device is known as the absorber element and is made of a synthetic elastomeric material; it functions as a kinetic energy storage/dissipator. Specifications of the absorber element are presented and its operation is explained with diagrams. Wave form effects and the testing of a 2 inch pipeline with a reflux valve are described. (A.J.)

Title: The development and testing of a regenerative Diesel-hydraulic power train for the urban bus.
Authors with affiliations: Heggie, W.S.; Davies, A.S.
Abstract: A retrofit package to hybridize the urban bus comprising hydropneumatic energy storage and controlled by a custom designed electronic processor control system was constructed and tested under average city operating conditions. The optimum accumulator designs in terms of stored energy per unit volume is shown to be less than ideal when considering the complete system. When this is compromised a well developed flow and control philosophy is shown to be capable of approximating theoretical predictions of improved fuel mileage, etc. with good driveability. (A)

Authors: Wu F.H.Y., Leung T.C.F., Tzong T.J.
Title: A hydraulic wave power system.
Issue: (Brighton, U.K.: May 14-16, 1986), Cranfield, U.K., BHRA, 1986, Paper 30, p.397-409. (ISBN 0-947711-
Authors with affiliations: Wu, F.H.Y.; Leung, T.C.F.; Tzong, T.J.
Abstract: Describes a wave energy convertor comprising a hydraulic float/pump/reservoir system. The system consists a buoy, double action pump, pipes, valves, elevated storage tank, hydraulic turbine and generator. Analyzes the dynamics of the heave motion of the float and describes combination of the computer model derived with a wave power calculation program for irregular wave conditions. Describes the experiments set up (1:40 scale model) for simulation of the dynamic behaviour and for provision of verification data. Presents calculated time histories and proposes a caisson design for the supporting structure, to provide a resonant chamber. (C.J.U.)

Authors: Arinze E.A., Schoenau G.J., Besant R.W.
Title: Experimental and computer performance evaluation of a movable thermal insulation for energy conservation in greenhouses
Affiliations: Department of Agricultural Engineering, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Arinze, E.A., Department of Agricultural Engineering, Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, Nigeria; Schoenau, G.J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada; Besant, R.W., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada
Abstract: In recent years internal night curtains or thermal screens have appeared to be useful in reducing heat losses in greenhouses during cold weather. Most of the curtains used consisted of single-layer thin plastic materials, and lack of storage space inside the greenhouse may prevent use of thicker sections. The difficulty with thermal screens operating on the outside of the structure is that they are exposed to the weather. This paper describes the construction and experimental evaluation of a greenhouse thermal screen system where heavily insulated and relatively thick screens operate in-between the glazings of a double-glazed greenhouse. The thermal screen system was evaluated on a commercial size, arch (semi-circular) greenhouse with inflated outer polythylene and inner fibreglass glazings. A computer program was developed to predict the thermal performance of the shutter system in reducing greenhouse energy consumption. The comparisons between the experimental and computer results showed a high degree of correlation, and these results indicated that under average climatic conditions the heating requirements of a double-glazed greenhouse using the thermal screens could be reduced by as much as 60 to 80% © 1986, The British Society for Research in Agricultural Engineering. All rights reserved.

Authors: Ohsawa Y., Miyauchi H., Hayashi M.
Title: Stabilizing Control for Long Distance Longitudinal Power System by Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage
Source title: IEEJ Transactions on Power and Energy
Affiliations: Institute of Engineering Mechanics, University of Tsukuba, Japan; Department of Electrical Engineering, Kyoto University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohsawa, Y., Institute of Engineering Mechanics, University of Tsukuba, Japan; Miyauchi, H., Department of Electrical Engineering, Kyoto University, Japan; Hayashi, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Kyoto University, Japan

Authors: Lee S.K., Matsuda H., Hasatani M.
Title: Fundamental Studies of CaSO4(1/2)H2O/CaSO4Thermochemical Reaction Cycle for Thermal Energy Storage by Means of Chemical Reaction
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., Nagoya,464, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lee, S.K., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., Nagoya,464, Japan; Matsuda, H., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., Nagoya,464, Japan; Hasatani, M., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., Nagoya,464, Japan
Abstract: For the purpose of thermal energy storage at relatively low temperature around 373 K, the following gas-solid reaction cycle in which both an exothermic (hydration) and an endothermic (dehydration) process are involved was chosen and was studied from a fundamental point of view concerning its reaction equilibrium and reaction kinetics by using a microthermobalance equipped with a steam generator. (formula omitted) The grain model was applied in order to determine the reaction kinetic parameters such as the reaction rate constants by considering a complex reaction scheme during the course of the hydration of CaSO4and the dehydration of CaSO4.1/2H2O. As a result, it was found that the reaction order with respect to the steam pressure was 1.0 for both the hydration and the dehydration, and that the reaction rate constant for the hydration of CaSO4took a maximum value at about 380 K. Further, it was observed that the reaction activity remained almost constant, independently of the repetition of the reaction cycle between hydration and dehydration within the experimental conditions employed. Consequently, it is considered that the CaSO4.1/2H2O/CaSO4thermochemical reaction cycle might be usable for thermal energy storage between 293.2 and 473.2 K, despite its relatively low value of reaction heat among several kinds of reaction candidates. © 1986, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Calcium Sulphate; Complex Reaction; Gas Solid Reaction; Thermal Energy Storage; Thermochemical Reaction

Authors: Binz E.F., Grosskopf W.J., Hallinan G.J.
Title: Recent advances in solar dynamic power for space
Source title: AIAA Space Station in the 21st Century, 1986
Affiliations: Rockwell International, Canoga Park, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Binz, E.F., Rockwell International, Canoga Park, CA, United States; Grosskopf, W.J., Rockwell International, Canoga Park, CA, United States; Hallinan, G.J., Rockwell International, Canoga Park, CA, United States
Abstract: The most common method used up to now to provide power to spacecraft having long life (greater than a few weeks) has been photovoltaic (Pγ) arrays. These devices have commonly been used on communication satellites, which operate in geosynchronous orbits where there is little or no time spent in the eclipse of the earth and where less than 5 kW of power is required. With space systems requiring 70 to 400 kW in low earth orbits (LEO), new power generation devices are required to avoid the extremely large Pγ arrays that would result from the high power requirement and their inherent low efficiency. Energy storage systems are also required to provide power during -30% of the orbit in eclipse. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. All right reserved.
Index Keywords: Communication satellites; Earth (planet); Orbits; Space stations; Energy storage systems; Geosynchronous orbits; High power; Low earth orbit(LEO); Photovoltaic; Power generation devices; Solar dynamic; SPACE system; Space power generation

Authors: GERSCHENSON L.N., ALZAMORA S.M., CHIRIFE J.
Title: Technical note: Kinetics of sorbic acid loss during storage of peaches preserved by combined factors
Source title: International Journal of Food Science & Technology
Affiliations: PROIPA (CONICET-FCEyN), Departamento de Industrias, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, 1428, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: GERSCHENSON, L.N., PROIPA (CONICET-FCEyN), Departamento de Industrias, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, 1428, Argentina; ALZAMORA, S.M., PROIPA (CONICET-FCEyN), Departamento de Industrias, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, 1428, Argentina; CHIRIFE, J., PROIPA (CONICET-FCEyN), Departamento de Industrias, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, 1428, Argentina
Abstract: It was found that the loss of sorbic acid in stored peaches preserved by combined factors (water activity, pH, additives) followed first order reaction kinetics. Rate constants and activation energy (14 kcal/mol) were almost identical to those previously reported for sorbic acid loss in concentrated glucose solutions of identical water activity and pH. Copyright © 1986, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Water Thermal Storage Type Solar Greenhouse: (1) Thermal Performance of a System for Hydroponic Culture
Affiliations: Biology Laboratory, CRIEPI, 1646 Abiko-city, Chiba, 270-11, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Okano, T., Biology Laboratory, CRIEPI, 1646 Abiko-city, Chiba, 270-11, Japan; Yamamoto, Y., Biology Laboratory, CRIEPI, 1646 Abiko-city, Chiba, 270-11, Japan
Abstract: The thermal performance of a solar heating greenhouse designed for a hydroponic system was studied. The system was constructed with an air-water heat exchanger and heat storage tanks that were combined with hydroponic water beds. The heat exchanger had been designed for a moderate heat source. To achieve a reasonable price and a compact heat exchanger, the heat transfer surface is made of a polyethylene film shaped into a bag; many poly-bags are installed into a casing in parallel and close to each other. The heat transfer is accomplished as follows: Water flows down inside the bags in a thin layer, and air flows outside the bags. The water tanks to store solar heat were separated into two parts with a polyethylene film. The upper parts were filled with hydroponic water used for the plant growth bed, and the lower parts were filled with fresh water. The fresh water was circulated into the heat exchanger to recover the solar heat inside the greenhouse and to release the heat for heating. The system was designed in 3.6m x 9.0m greenhouse equipped with an interior curtain. The total heat transfer surface in the heat exchanger was 28m2 and the heat transfer rate was 16 kcal/ m2h°C. The two water tanks (6m long, 0.6m wide and 0.5m deep) were installed and filled with 0.8m3 of hydroponic water and 2.8m3 of fresh water. The tanks were buried 0.35m deep under the ground to keep favorable working conditions. A 2.08 kW electric water heater was installed into the tank for auxiliary heating. Cucumbers were grown and the data were collected through seventy days from Jan. 5 in 1983. The averaged minimum air temperature inside the greenhouse was maintained at 11.4°C, the solar heat storage efficiency was 0.18 and solar heat provided 77% of the total heat for heating through seventy days. The solar heat storage efficiency depended on outside insolation. When outside insolation was less than 1000 kcal/m2day, the solar heat storage efficiency was zero, and was 0.32 when outside insolation was over 3000 kcal/m2day. The highest COP of the system (the heat released from the heat storage tank/the energy consumption to store and release the solar heat) was 6.6 and the averaged COP was 4.1. The COP was also in proportion to outside insolation. In the days when the COP was over 4.1, the heating was achieved with only the solar heat storage. The hydroponic water temperature was maintained at 24—15°C by the heat from the fresh water, high enough to grow cucumbers. Therefore, it was not necessary to apply another heat source to heat the hydroponic water. The cucumbers grew well and the system appeared to be able to supply 77% of heating energy from solar heat. It would be necessary for further research to optimize carbon dioxide and humidity levels without deteriorating the capability of solar heating for practical use. © 1986, The Society of Agricultural Meteorology of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Lee S.K., Matsuda H., Hasatani M.
Title: Rate Enhancement of the Dehydration of Ca(OH)2 under Reduced Pressures
Affiliations: Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., Nagoya 464, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Lee, S.K., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., Nagoya 464, Japan; Matsuda, H., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., Nagoya 464, Japan; Hasatani, M., Dept. of Chem. Eng., Nagoya Univ., Nagoya 464, Japan
Abstract: For rate enhancement of thermal energy storage by means of Ca(OH)2/CaO reversible thermochemical reaction, the dehydration behaviour of Ca(OH)2 was studied under reduced pressure conditions (2.33-101.3 KPa). It was found that the initiation temperature of the dehydration of Ca(OH)2 was lowered by reducing the pressure in the reaction system and that the dehydration rate increased in inverse proportion to the pressure in the system. The overall reaction rate expression under static conditions was obtained by non-isothermal reaction analysis at various constant heating rates. The reaction orders with respect to a solid reactant and to water vapour pressure were found to be 0th and 0.5th, respectively. The apparent rate constant determined was relatively well correlated with the total pressure in the reaction system within the experimental conditions employed in the present study. The enhancement of the dehydration of Ca(OH)2 by reducing the pressure in the reaction system was quantitatively estimated. © 1986, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Calcium Hydroxide; Calcium Oxide; Chemical Heat Pump; Chemical Heat Storage; Gas Solid Reaction

Title: An autonomous power system test bed
Affiliations: Boeing Aerospace Company, Seattle, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barton, J.R., Boeing Aerospace Company, Seattle, WA, United States
Abstract: An autonomous power system test bed has been developed for testing and evaluating electrical power system autonomous control functions. The test bed architecture includes an expert system to manage the power system, a control system to operate the power system, and specific hardware control functions to protect the power system against catastrophic transient conditions. Also, a fault network is incorporated into the test bed for the purpose of testing expert system and control system response to specific failure modes. Expert system functions include load management, energy storage management, maintenance management, performance monitoring, fault diagnosis, and fault recovery. Control system functions include command and data processing, status checking, charge control, fault detection, and safe haven. The power system has a 2800 watt capability with six solar array segments, four nickel cadmium batteries, various control elements, and 20 loads ranging from 50 watts to 600 watts, including constant power, constant current, and resistive loads. Experience to date has led us to believe that a sophisticated autonomous control system can be developed with state-of-the-art programming capabilities. © American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., 1986.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Data handling; Digital storage; Electric power systems; Equipment testing; Expert systems; Fault detection; Maintenance; Nickel cadmium batteries; Power control; Solar cell arrays; Storage management; Testing; Transfer functions; Autonomous control; Autonomous control systems; Autonomous power system; Electrical power system; Maintenance management; Performance monitoring; Specific hardware; Transient conditions; Electric power system control

Authors: Binz E.F., Grosskopf W.J., Hallinan G.J.
Title: Recent advances in solar dynamic power for space
Authors with affiliations: Binz, E.F.; Grosskopf, W.J.; Hallinan, G.J.
Abstract: The prevailing means to provide power to spacecraft having long life (greater than a few weeks) has been photovoltaic (PV) arrays. These devices have commonly been used on communication satellites, which operate in geosynchronous orbits where there is little or no time spent in the eclipse of the earth and where less than 5 kW of power is required. With space systems requiring 70 to 400 kW in low earth orbits (LEO), new power generation devices are required to avoid the extremely large PV arrays that would result from the high power requirement and their inherent low efficiency. Energy storage systems are also required to provide power during ~30% of the orbit in eclipse. Solar dynamic (SD) power generation systems have been used for many years to provide electrical energy for terrestrial applications. Their use in a space application offers the potential for significantly higher efficiency with a threefold reduction in projected area as compared with a planar PV array and a substantial life cycle cost (LCC) reduction. Dynamic engines [closed Brayton cycle (CBC) and organic Rankine cycle (ORC)] in the size required for space have been operated for many years. Recently, extensive demonstrations have been conducted to verify the ability to convert the intermittent sunlight attendant to an LEO and convert it to the constant energy stream needed to operate the candidate dynamic engines. The approach utilizes a heat receiver that absorbs concentrated sunlight from a parabolic dish and stores the energy in a phase-change material (PCM) for use by the engine when in the earth eclipse. Technical issues such as containment material corrosion, PCM behavior, and heat transfer to the heat receiver have been addressed theoretically, in the laboratory, and in large-scale system tests. The behavior of PCM has been characterized for both ORC and CBC. LiOH [MP of 470°C (878°F)] has been found to be an appropriate PCM for the ORC. Its heat of fusion, 877 kJ/kg (377 Btu/lb), is high enough to minimize storage mass. LiOH may be contained with nickel and nickel-chromium alloys. Eutectic mixtures of MgF2-LiF or CaF2-LiF are both candidate salts for a moderate temperature, 704°C (1300°F) CBC. Both mixtures can be contained with nickel-chromium and cobalt base alloys. Large-scale system tests with PCM in cylindrical canisters within a heat exchanger were performed using a parabolic concentrator to characterize thermodynamic performance in an environment typical of LEO. The performance of the PCM indicated that the intermittent sunlight characteristic of LEO could be converted to the constant energy stream necessary for dynamic engine operation. © 1986, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Brayton cycle; Chromium; Chromium alloys; Communication satellites; Diffusers (optical); Earth (planet); Engines; Heat exchangers; Heat transfer; Large scale systems; Life cycle; Mixtures; Nickel; Nickel alloys; Orbits; Phase change materials; Photovoltaic cells; Rankine cycle; Concentrated sunlights; Energy storage systems; Organic Rankine Cycle(ORC); Parabolic concentrators; Power generation devices; Power generation systems; Terrestrial application; Thermodynamic performance; Space power generation

Authors: Hartmann D.L., Ramanathan V., Berroir A., Hunt G.E.
Title: Earth Radiation Budget data and climate research
Authors with affiliations: Hartmann, D.L.; Ramanathan, V.; Berroir, A.; Hunt, G.E.
Abstract: An overview is presented of the uses of top of the atmosphere radiation budget measurements in studies of climate. The net radiative energy flux at the top of the atmosphere must be balanced by local heat storage in the earth‐atmosphere column or by horizontal transport in the atmosphere and ocean. Regional variations in the components of the radiation balance are significant and place important constraints on regional and global climate. If suitable time averaging is applied, regional net radiation can be used to infer horizontal transport of energy in the atmosphere and ocean. Estimates of equator‐to‐pole transport in the atmosphere and ocean based upon currently available top‐of‐atmosphere radiation budget measurements contain unacceptably large uncertainties associated with uncertainties in the radiation budget measurements themselves. Diurnal and interannual variations in regional radiation balances are large and important but have not yet been properly sampled with broadband instruments. Both have the potential for providing important insights into climate. The role of cloudiness in climate sensitivity remains one of the major uncertainties in quantitative estimates of climate changes associated with particular perturbing influences. Radiation budget data can be used to estimate the effects of actual cloudiness on the top‐of‐atmosphere heat balance and the dependence of these effects on location and season. The observational studies of the effect of cloudiness on the radiation balance at the top of the atmosphere that have been completed to date all suffer from one or more of three fundamental problems. These are that the parameters of the cloudiness are not accurately known, the radiation budget data are not based on measurements whose frequency response is unbiased in relation to the emissions of the sun and the earth, and the diurnal sampling of the measurements is not complete. The uncertainties associated with each of these problems are expected to be reduced as a result of analyses based on data from the Earth Radiation Budget Experiment. In order that quantitative estimates of climate change be as accurate as possible the general circulation models (GCMs) which produce these forecasts must be critically evaluated with observed data. Many of the most important mechanisms for perturbing climate (e.g., CO2, volcanic aerosols, surface albedo changes) and many of the most important feedback processes (e.g., relative humidity feedback, cloud feedback, ice‐albedo feedback) directly involve the radiation balance at the top of the atmosphere and its relation to surface climate. Since the radiation balance at the top of the atmosphere can, in principle, be measured very accurately from space, it is natural that the simulation of top‐of‐atmosphere energy fluxes by GCMs should be carefully validated against observations. Because of the complexities introduced by clouds, a complete validation of the radiation budget of a GCM is a long and difficult task. A strategy is suggested here in which the clear‐sky fluxes of the model are first compared with a clear‐sky radiation budget climatology derived from observations. The radiation budgets with clouds included can then also be compared. This procedure should isolate problems not associated with cloudiness and indicate whether, in the grossest sense, the model clouds are correctly influencing the radiation balance. Comparisons between instantaneous synoptic maps of the radiation budget components and numerical forecasts can also be used to diagnose the performance of models. Copyright 1986 by the American Geophysical Union.

Title: Assimilation and deposition of dietary fatty alcohols in Leach's storm petrel, Oceanodroma leucorhoa
Affiliations: Department of Biology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 19104, United States
Authors with affiliations: Place, A.R., Department of Biology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 19104, United States; Roby, D.D., Department of Biology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 19104, United States
Abstract: The diet of Leach's storm petrel (Oceanodroma leucorhoa) chicks has a high lipid content (up to 60% of fresh mass), and, for certain populations, much of the dietary lipids are wax esters (up to 70% of total lipid). In order to determine the metabolic fate of dietary wax esters, we fed chicks [1‐14C]cetyl oleate in either a low wax (20%, w/w) or a high wax (80%, w/w) mixture of wax ester and triacylglycerols. Wax ester in the stomach remained unhydrolyzed for extended periods, with up to 38% of the label still unassimilated after 36 hr. Hydrolysis occured principally in the duodenum, where the fatty alcohol product was rapidly oxidized to fatty acid, apparently at the intestinal epithelia. Assimilated label was primarily metabolized and respired as carbon dioxide, with most of the remainder incorporated into triacylglycerols and deposited in storage fat depots. Hydrolysis of wax ester and assimilation of the fatty alcohol moiety were extremely efficient, with less than 0.2% of ingested label excreted. Assimilation efficiencies for label in low wax and high wax meals were statistically indistinguishable. Chicks fed 20% (w/w) [1‐14C]cetyl alcohol in triacylglycerols had similar assimilation efficiencies as those fed labeled wax ester, indicating that hydrolysis of the ester linkage does not limit wax ester assimilation. This study suggests that sea birds can possess an efficient means for metabolizing wax esters, an abundant energy source in the marine environment, which have previously been thought to be difficult to assimilate. Copyright © 1986 Wiley‐Liss, Inc., A Wiley Company

Authors: Roby D.D., Place A.R., Ricklefs R.E.
Title: Assimilation and deposition of wax esters in planktivorous seabirds
Affiliations: Department of Biology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 19104, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roby, D.D., Department of Biology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 19104, United States; Place, A.R., Department of Biology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 19104, United States; Ricklefs, R.E., Department of Biology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 19104, United States
Abstract: We have analyzed the lipid composition of meals fed to chicks and determined the ability of chicks to assimilate wax esters in four species of high latitude, plankton‐feeding seabirds: one alcid (Aethia pusilla; Alcidae: Charadriiformes) and three petrels (Pelecanoides urinatrix, P. georgicus, and Pachyptila desolata; Procellariiformes). Up to 63% of the estimated digestible energy in chick meals consists of wax esters. Using 14C‐labeled cetyl palmitate, we have shown that chicks of the four study species efficiently hydrolyze wax esters, with less than 1% of the ingested label excreted in most cases. Labeled fatty acids were assimilated and deposited primarily as triacylglycerols in storage fat depots. The one study species known to store lipids in the proventriculus retained much of the labeled wax ester unhydrolyzed in stomach oils. However, the capacity to store stomach oils was not a requisite for efficient assimilation of wax esters. This study provides the first direct evidence that seabirds have the inherent ability to digest and assimilate wax esters efficiently. Copyright © 1986 Wiley‐Liss, Inc., A Wiley Company

Title: Mechanical design of hedgehog spines and porcupine quills
Affiliations: Biomechanics Group, University of Reading, PO Box 228, Reading, RG6 2AJ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Vincent, J.F.V., Biomechanics Group, University of Reading, PO Box 228, Reading, RG6 2AJ, United Kingdom; Owers, P., Biomechanics Group, University of Reading, PO Box 228, Reading, RG6 2AJ, United Kingdom
Abstract: The spines or quills of hedgehogs and porcupines are morphologically and mechanically different. In simple terms, it seems that the quills of porcupines are proportioned to be as long as possible without bending too easily when loaded axially. By contrast, the spines of the hedgehog are as short as possible while still able to bend when loaded axially. In addition, the hedgehog spines have an internal morphology which delays the onset of local buckling under these loads, thus enabling the spines to absorb larger amounts of mechanical energy. By contrast, the quills of Hystrix are designed to break at the tip. Thus, whilst the quills of the porcupine seem to be well adapted for keeping an enemy as far away as possible, the spines of the hedgehog probably have this as an incidental function. Their main function is much more likely to be that of a shock absorber or storage of impact energy when the animal falls from a height, a behavioural attribute which is reportedly common. 1986 The Zoological Society of London

Title: Coordinative Planning of Energy Storage System in Optimal Generation Mix
Source title: IEEJ Transactions on Power and Energy
Affiliations: Tohoku University, Japan; Tohoku Electric Power Company, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Toyoda, J., Tohoku University, Japan; Kohno, M., Tohoku Electric Power Company, Japan
