Authors: Cooper Jr. J.A., Melloch M.R., Qian Q-D
Title: DEVELOPMENT OF A ONE TRANSISTOR DYNAMIC RAM FOR THE AlGaAs/GaAs HIGFET TECHNOLOGY.
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cooper Jr., J.A., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Melloch, M.R., Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA; Qian, Q-D, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, IN, USA
Abstract: The long-term retention of minority carriers in potential wells at the AlGaAs/GaAs interface have been studied. Using a deep depletion capacitance-voltage (C-V) technique, the storage time of holes at the AlAs interface in the dark has been measured as a function of temperature from 175 K to 77 K. Storage times are thermally activated, with an activation energy of 0. 37 eV. At 77 K, the storage time is greater than 220 hours, or 9 days. Using an AlAs-GaAs superlattice barrier, an activation energy of 0. 17 eV and a storage time at 77 K of 34 hours were measured. These times are far in excess of what is needed to construct a one-transfer dynamic RAM for the GaAs HIGFET technology.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Random Access; Semiconducting aluminum compounds; SEMICONDUCTING GALLIUM ARSENIDE - Charge Carriers; ALUMINUM-ARSENIC INTERFACE; DEEP DEPLETION CAPACITANCE-VOLTAGE TECHNIQUE; DYNAMIC RANDOM ACCESS MEMORY (RAM); LONG-TERM MINORITY CARRIER RETENTION; THERMALLY-ACTIVATED STORAGE TIMES; Transistors

Authors: Tateishi H., Komuro K., Nomura H., Onishi T.
Title: BIPOLAR SWEEP TEST OF A 3 MJ PULSED SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNET.
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Tateishi, H., Electrotechnical Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Komuro, K., Electrotechnical Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Nomura, H., Electrotechnical Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn; Onishi, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn, Electrotechnical Lab, Tsukuba, Jpn
Abstract: The first bipolar operational test of an MJ-class pulsed superconducting magnet was successfully carried out in energy transfer experiments between a 3 MJ magnet (load magnet) and a 4 MJ magnet (energy storage magnet) using a chopper-type energy transfer equipment. The test goal was to confirm the technical feasibility of operating an ohmic heating coil for a tokamak-type fusion reactor. A 3 MJ magnet was first charged to 4510 amperes in 1. 5 seconds. It was discharged to 0 ampere in 1. 5 seconds and at once was re-charged to minus 4510 amperes in 1. 5 seconds. It was again discharged in 1. 5 seconds. The maximum field and the stored energy were 5. 4 T and 2. 1 MJ, respectively. During this bipolar sweep test, the magnet was quite stable during charge. Instability phenomena were not observed when the direction of the current was reversed. We also found that there was no mechanical instability during operation from the results of dynamic strain measurement. Thus it can be concluded that there is no technical problem in the bipolar sweep of an MJ-class pulsed superconducting magnet.
Index Keywords: CHOPPERS - Design; ELECTROMAGNETS - Energy Storage; TOKAMAK DEVICES - Design; ENERGY STOPPAGE MAGNETS; ENERGY TRANSFER SYSTEM; LOAD MAGNET; PLASMA IGNITION; PULSED SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNET; Superconducting magnets

Title: CENTRAL RECEIVER SYSTEM (CRS) OF THE SSPS PROJECT: SUBSYSTEM AND SYSTEM PERFORMANCES.
Affiliations: DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger, DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Grasse, Wilfried, DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger, DFVLR, Cologne, West Ger
Abstract: The Small Solar Power Systems Project (SSPS) is one of the joint tasks of the member countries of the International Energy Agency (IEA). As part of the SSPS-CRS, two different sodium receivers were designed and manufactured, following different designs. A total plant efficiency of 8% was measured. With improvements possible and as demonstrated in special tests a representative SSPS-CRS overall plant efficiency of 17% (gross) or 14% (net) would be achievable. Extrapolation of these values for a total year would depend only on a corresponding solar multiple and storage capacity. Taking the SSPS data and assuming a 'normal operational day' as defined for the SSPS Project, costs for the solar primary energy (i. e. , concentrated solar radiation in front of the receiver tubes) can be calculated with reasonable confidence on the basis of measured data.

Abstract: This paper summarizes the results of performance monitoring of a simple hybrid solar heating system of the active charge/passive discharge type. Conventional active hydronic flat plate solar collectors charge a massive radiant panel slab. Solar energy is stored and released to the building in a passive manner by radiation and conduction. The performance monitoring has demonstrated that this simple low cost hybrid solar heating system offers significant advantages in system efficiency overall performance, comfort and architectural flexibility.

Title: FIVE-YEAR PROGRESS REPORT ON A SUCCESSFUL SOLAR/GEOTHERMAL HEATING AND COOLING SYSTEM FOR A COMMERCIAL OFFICE BUILDING IN BURLINGTON, MASSACHUSETTS.

Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to present: 1) a description of a solar/geothermal heating and cooling system that has been in successful operation in a commercial office building for over five years; and 2) to present technical and cost operational results that indicate a total annual energy consumption of approximately 25,000 Btu/sq ft/ year. The paper includes a general description of the three-story multi-tenant office building located in Burlington, Massachusetts, its energy efficient design features, its active solar space heating and hot water system, its solar/geothermal heat pump back-up heating system and its geothermal cooling system. A description of the solar/geothermal system is presented including the liquid flat plate collectors, storage tanks, heat exchangers, heat pump, heat transfer fluid, control system, operational modes and the energy monitoring system.

Title: ELECTROCHEMICAL SOLAR PONDS. HYBRID THERMAL AND ELECTRIC STORAGE.

Abstract: A hybrid thermal and electric energy collection and storage system for solar applications is proposed. Hybrid storage is achieved transforming a conventional solar pond into a secondary activity cell where the inert electrolyte (NaCl solution) has been partially replaced by active ones totally soluble on both oxidated and reduced phases which produce highly reversible reactions. The system has been designed for static operation and large storage capacity. Changing the solar pond into an electrical accumulator improves thermal efficiency and does not increase building expenses. High temperature is advantageous for the accumulator operation.

Title: SOLAR/WIND POWER PLANTS.
Affiliations: Lavalin Inc, Montreal, Que, Can, Lavalin Inc, Montreal, Que, Can
Authors with affiliations: Quraeshi, S., Lavalin Inc, Montreal, Que, Can, Lavalin Inc, Montreal, Que, Can
Abstract: Solar/wind power plants convert solar radiation into electrical energy by combining the principles of the solar energy collection system, the thermal storage system, the stack system and the wind turbine generator system. This paper discusses the background, theory, design, construction, costs and economics of solar/wind power plants and provides a brief description of the 50 kW plant which has been built in Spain to demonstrate the feasibility of the concept and to verify the theoretical work. The work done to date gives confidence in technical and economic viability of large MW scale installations in sunny regions of the world with arid or semi-arid conditions.

Authors: Burns P.R., Mitchell J.W., Beckman W.A.
Title: SOLAR HYBRID DESICCANT COOLING SYSTEMS IN SUPERMARKET APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Burns, P.R., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA; Mitchell, J.W., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA; Beckman, W.A., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison,, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: The use of standard vapor compression cycles for air conditioning supermarkets is inefficient due to the cooling provided by the open refrigerated food cases. The high latent load ratios found in supermarkets provide an ideal application for hybrid desiccant cooling systems. Such systems can reduce air conditioning energy costs between 50% and 70%. Solar collectors with no storage capacity can reduce the auxiliary heat requirements of hybrid desiccant cycles by another 50%, and further reductions occur with the use of storage. The value of the savings do not offset the additional cost of the solar system. The required installed capacity of the vapor compression unit is decreased 80% with the use of hybrid systems. This results in reduced peak demands charges and lower initial costs. The reduction in initial cost offsets the additional cost of the desiccant equipment and may produce immediate paybacks.

Abstract: In December, 1984 the SEGS I solar electric plant was placed in service on the electric grid in southern California. This plant generates close to 15 MWe gross power at design conditions, utilizing almost 72,000 square meters of parabolic troughs to deliver energy to the Rankine steam cycle. Natural gas is used to superheat the steam and thermal storage allows shifting the electric production to on-peak electricity hours. After five months of startup operation, the plant is routinely operating at turbine design capacity. The daily output, while achieving expectations for the start-up period, is still below final design values.

Title: PRACTICAL EXPERIENCES FROM A PILOT TEST FACILITY FOR SOLAR HEATING SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: TNO Inst of Applied Physics, Delft, Neth, TNO Inst of Applied Physics, Delft, Neth
Authors with affiliations: van Galen, E., TNO Inst of Applied Physics, Delft, Neth, TNO Inst of Applied Physics, Delft, Neth
Abstract: Research carried out at solar heating systems in a Pilot Test Facility shows that the use of such facilities is essential for solar energy R&D. The choice of sensor locations is extremely important for proper evaluation of the system performance. An evaluation technique is being developed to detect weak spots in the system design based on measurement output. The study focussed on the solar energy installation and the operation of the auxiliary heating. An ideal interaction between the installation and the auxiliary heating was assumed. A detailed monitoring programme was carried out to study the behaviour of the solar system components. It was concluded that characterization of system components should be carried out with special test facilities and according to standard test procedures, in particular for the main components in a solar heating system: the solar collector, the heat storage system and the auxiliary heater.

Title: THERMAL STRATIFICATION IN WATER VESSELS FOR ENERGY STORAGE.

Authors with affiliations: Hoogendoorn, C.J., Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Neth, Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Neth; Bakker, R.G., Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Neth, Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Neth; Herweijer, E.J.J., Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Neth, Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Neth; Plokker, W., Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Neth, Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Neth
Abstract: An experimental study has been made on the stratification in hot water thermal energy storage vessels for solar- and district-heating systems. In a large 300 m**3 vessel the thermal dispersion turned out to be 30 to 180 times that by conduction alone, depending on the average water velocity. Small scale tests using flow visualization showed that improvement can be obtained by using a well designed inlet. However even for the large vessel the number of mixing zones in series always far exceeded the required minimum of 10 to get an optimum system operation.

Title: COMPUTER SIMULATION OF THE THERMAL PERFORMANCE OF COLLECTOR STORAGE WALLS, ATTACHED SUNSPACES AND DIRECT GAIN SYSTEMS IN TEMPERATE AUSTRALIA.
Affiliations: CSIRO, Highett, Aust, CSIRO, Highett, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Sheridan, J., CSIRO, Highett, Aust, CSIRO, Highett, Aust; Delsante, A.E., CSIRO, Highett, Aust, CSIRO, Highett, Aust
Abstract: This paper gives some results of computer simulations of the thermal performance of three types of passive solar systems - direct gain, collector storage wall and attached sunspace - in three locations of temperate Australia. The heat transfer processes that occur in these systems have been incorporated into ZSTEP3, a program for dynamically simulating the thermal performance of multizone buildings, based on the total-zone response factor method. The systems are simulated as part of a compact three-bedroom house that has auxiliary intermittent heating to the living zone only, and no artificial cooling, typical for temperate Australia. Evaluation is in terms of annual living zone energy requirements and degree of overheating in summer. The results show that all three systems can perform well in winter and summer, provided that they are well-shaded.

Abstract: Four mixtures containing magnesium and calcium salt hydrates added with NH//4NO//3 and KNO//3 are described as promising thermal heat storage materials suitable for active and passive solar heating applications covering the temperature range 15-55 degree C. Title: SOLIDIFICATION (MELTING) IN FINITE EXTENT PCM BODIES.
Affiliations: Ben Gurion Univ of the Negev, Isr, Ben Gurion Univ of the Negev, Isr
Authors with affiliations: Charach, Ch., Ben Gurion Univ of the Negev, Isr, Ben Gurion Univ of the Negev, Isr
Abstract: The design of the latent heat storage systems requires quantitative information on the heat transfer in phase-changing materials (PCM). Due to the nonlinearity of the heat transfer problems with moving boundaries, exact analytic solutions are known only for few particular cases. The aim of the present work is to develop an approximate analytic model that accounts for the combined effect of a finite thickness of the PCM slab and initial overheating (subcooling). We consider the case of sufficiently small Stefan numbers, which are parameters that characterize the ratio of sensible to latent heat in liquid and solid phases. This is usually the case in the passive solar energy applications of the PCM systems. Simple analytic expressions for the total solidification time are derived.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Mathematical Models; SALTS - Phase Transitions; ANALYTIC MODEL; LATENT HEAT STORAGE SYSTEMS; PASSIVE SOLAR ENERGY; PHASE-CHANGING MATERIALS; STEFAN NUMBERS; Solar energy

Abstract: This work describes an analytical model for battery storage in a photovoltaic system which takes into account the frequency of occurrence of radiation input and load values. Introduction of the correlation time of the input affects the probability distribution of the battery charging level in the neighborhood of the two end points (empty and full). These end regions determine the amount of required back-up energy as well as energy dumping and loss-of-power probability. The method is applicable to other storage devices such as water reservoirs.

Authors: Laporte Francois, Maranda Michel, Rheault Fernand
Title: MONITORING AND ANALYSIS OF SEASONAL SOLAR DOMESTIC HOT WATER (SDHW) SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Univ du Quebec, Varennes, Que, Can, Univ du Quebec, Varennes, Que, Can
Authors with affiliations: Laporte, Francois, Univ du Quebec, Varennes, Que, Can, Univ du Quebec, Varennes, Que, Can; Maranda, Michel, Univ du Quebec, Varennes, Que, Can, Univ du Quebec, Varennes, Que, Can; Rheault, Fernand, Univ du Quebec, Varennes, Que, Can, Univ du Quebec, Varennes, Que, Can
Abstract: Five Canadian seasonal thermosiphon systems were monitored during part of their normal operating season in the summer of 1984. Three of these systems are standard flat plate exchangerless systems, one is a flat plate with tank in tank heat exchanger and the last one has a heat pipe evacuated tube collector. Measured system efficiencies and solar fraction vary considerably from one to another but all of them show measured performances consistently lower than the one obtained from the SYPHON simulation model. In most instances these discrepancies are attributed to system malfunctions (uneven collector flow distribution, cold water withdrawal through the collectors) or from uncorrect specification of component characteristics. A parametric study using the SYPHON model shows that the physical characteristics (pipe diameter, collector to tank distance) of the collector storage and loop pipe arrangement has in a usual range of variation very little effect on thermal performances. However, pipe and preheat tank insulation may have an important impact on the economy of the overall system.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Monitoring; HOT WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS - Computer Simulation; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Algorithms; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; FLAT PLATE EXCHANGERLESS SYSTEMS; SEASONAL THERMOSIPHON SYSTEMS; SIMULATION PROGRAMS; SYPHON MODEL; THERMAL PERFORMANCES; THERMOSIPHONS; Heating

Title: RESULTS OF CESA-1 PLANT.
Affiliations: IER-CIEMAT, IER-CIEMAT

Abstract: The CESA-1 Project, an enterprise of the Spanish Ministry of Industry and Energy consists of the design, construction, operation and evaluation of a 1. 2 Mwe Experiments Central Receiver Solar Power System. The CESA-1 plant, located within the boundaries of 'Platforma Solar' in Tabernas (Almeria), includes a collector field of 300 heliostats, a water/steam cooled cavity-type receiver, dual admission steam turbine, molten salt heat storage as well as the associated controls and auxiliary subsystem. This paper presents an overview of the results obtained during the first phase of evaluation of the plant which covers a period of 15 months, from October 1983 to the beginning of 1985. During 1985 and the first half of 1986 the plant was dedicated to performing the tests of the GAST Technological Program that is the purpose of this paper.

Title: MONITORED PERFORMANCE OF A SOLAR HEATING SYSTEM WITH ANNUAL HEAT STORAGE - THE AYLMER SENIOR CITIZENS' APARTMENT.
Affiliations: Enermodal Engineering Ltd, Waterloo,, Ont, Can, Enermodal Engineering Ltd, Waterloo, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Carpenter, Stephen C., Enermodal Engineering Ltd, Waterloo,, Ont, Can, Enermodal Engineering Ltd, Waterloo, Ont, Can; Sibbitt, Bruce, Enermodal Engineering Ltd, Waterloo,, Ont, Can, Enermodal Engineering Ltd, Waterloo, Ont, Can
Abstract: The monitored performance of a solar space and water heating system incorporating annual heat storage is presented. Comparisons are made between design estimates and monitored results, with reasons given for any discrepancies. The system was found to deliver 18% less energy than the design estimate. The lower performance was largely caused by the method of heat delivery which results in the storage tank operating at a higher temperature than necessary for optimum system performance.

Title: COMPARISON OF SOLAR LOAD RATIO PREDICTIONS WITH PERFORMANCE OF FIVE PASSIVE SOLAR BUILDINGS.
Affiliations: Colorado Mountain Coll, Glenwood, Springs, CO, USA, Colorado Mountain Coll, Glenwood Springs, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Olson, Kenneth R., Colorado Mountain Coll, Glenwood, Springs, CO, USA, Colorado Mountain Coll, Glenwood Springs, CO, USA
Abstract: The Solar Load Ratio (SLR) method of passive solar design analysis, developed at Los Alamos National Laboratory, is evaluated for accuracy in predicting performance within the 10-15% range claimed by its authors. SLR predictions of auxiliary heating requirements, as performed on an Apple II Computer, are compared with actual performances of five passive solar residences in the Roaring Fork Valley of Colorado. The residences were monitored for Class C (non-instrumented) data which is of similar accuracy to the information available to a designer using SLR. Thermal performance of designs including direct gain, thermal storage wall, sunspace and mixed systems are evaluated. It is concluded that a designer using SLR cannot expect accuracy within the 10-15% range because sufficiently accurate input data is not available during the design process.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Heating; ENERGY UTILIZATION - Monitoring; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Utilization; CLASS-C MONITORING; PASSIVE SOLAR BUILDINGS; SOLAR LOAD RATIO; THERMAL PERFORMANCE; Heating

Title: SOLAR AIR CONDITIONING WITH SOLID ADSORBENTS IN OPEN SYSTEMS.

Authors with affiliations: Jung, D., Ludwig Maximilians Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Ludwig Maximilians Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger; Khelifa, N., Ludwig Maximilians Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Ludwig Maximilians Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger; Laevemann, E., Ludwig Maximilians Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Ludwig Maximilians Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger; Sizmann, R., Ludwig Maximilians Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger, Ludwig Maximilians Univ Muenchen, Munich, West Ger
Abstract: We report on a solar-driven air conditioning system based on an open air loop in which air is dried by solid adsorbents such as zeolites or silica gel and is cooled by adiabatic water evaporation. The dessicants are regenerated by hot air supplied by inexpensive air-heating solar collectors. Dry adsorbents provide storable cooling capacity for periods of low irradiance. Equilibrium isosteres of water vapor with various adsorbents have been measured. Based on these data the coefficient of performance (COP), mass flows and output temperatures have been calculated for equilibrium and steady state conditions. Output temperatures have been verified in a laboratory scale pilot plant. At present a thermal COP of about 0. 4 seems attainable. Desorption temperatures of 70 to 90 degree C are sufficient for operation.
Index Keywords: Adsorption; Evaporation; Silica gel; Zeolites; AIR HEATING SOLAR COLLECTORS; COOLING ENERGY STORAGE; DESICCANTS; SOLAR AIR CONDITIONING; SOLID ADSORBENTS; Air conditioning

Title: EFFECT OF IMMOBILIZED PHOTOSENSITIZERS ON PHOTOISOMERIZATION OF NORBORNADIENE.
Affiliations: Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Hayakawa, K., Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn; Taoda, H., Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn; Kawase, K., Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn; Tazawa, M., Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn; Yamakita, H., Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn, Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Jpn
Abstract: Novel immobilized photosensitizers were prepared and the effect of them on the photoisomerization of norbornadiene (NBD) to quadricyclene (QC) was studied in the heterogeneous phase. Photochemical isomerization of NBD to QC is regarded as one of the most promising reactions for the permanent storage of solar energy in the form of chemical energy. However, for practical systems using substances like NBD which have no corresponding absorption bands to sunlight, the immobilized insoluble photosensitizers should be utilized in the irradiation cell to avoid undesirable contamination causing deactivation of the catalyst for reversing exothermic reaction. Such immobilization techniques are also desirable for saving the quantities of photosensitizers and for ease in handling.

Abstract: The results of operating a submerged plastic tube heat exchanger in the 1080 m**2 Research Salt Gradient Solar Pond at Argonne National Laboratory are presented. The heat exchange system simulates grain drying in which the temperature of the ambient air is raised 8-15 degree C when it passes through a liquid-to-air heat exchanger that is coupled to the submerged heat exchanger. Approximately 1. 0 multiplied by 10**1**1 J (100 MMBtu) were extracted from the pond. The operation had no adverse effects on the stability of the salt gradient.

Abstract: An approach for designing an integrated renewable energy system based on loss of power supply probability is presented and discussed with the aid of a numerical example. Five renewable energy resources are considered - solar radiation, solar heat, wind, biomass (primarily animal and agricultural wastes), and falling water (natural or dedicated water storage). A typical village situated in a remote rural area of a developing country is considered.

Authors: Jørgensen C.K., Reisfeld R., Eyal M.
Title: Fluoride glasses as optimized materials for lanthanide luminescence and energy storage in manganese(II)
Affiliations: Département de Chimie Minérale, Analytique et Appliquée, Université de Genève, CH 1211 Geneva 4, Switzerland; Department of Inorganic Chemistry, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Jørgensen, C.K., Département de Chimie Minérale, Analytique et Appliquée, Université de Genève, CH 1211 Geneva 4, Switzerland; Reisfeld, R., Department of Inorganic Chemistry, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel; Eyal, M., Department of Inorganic Chemistry, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel
Abstract: Fluoride glasses of basic composition of 55.75ZrF4:33.75BaF2:4.5LaF3: 4AlF3 (ZBLA) and 27.5ThF4:27ZnF2:27YF3:9BaF2:6ZrF4:5NaF:3LiF reveal luminescence of 8 J levels of holmium(III) and 3 J levels of neodymium(III). The multiphonon relaxation in these glasses is very low and quantum efficiencies high because of the large number of phonons per energy gap between the emitting to lower levels. The simultaneous presence of manganese(II) allows the lowest quartet state of manganese(II) (showing a lifetime of 14 ms in the absence of lanthanides) to store energy which may be considered as an important property for laser material. Energy transfer from 1 mol.% MnF2 to 1 mol.% NdF3 in ZBLA glass was observed as manifested by an increase in the lifetime of neodymium(III) from 0.34 ms to 1.45 ms accompanied by a decrease in the lifetime of manganese(II). The specific properties of fluoride glass may be related to the very high energy of the electron transfer bands and the relatively weak nephelauxetic effect. © 1986.
Index Keywords: HOLMIUM - Optical Properties; LUMINESCENCE; MANGANESE AND ALLOYS; NEODYMIUM AND ALLOYS - Optical Properties; FLUORIDE GLASSES; LANTHANIDES; MULTIPHONON RELAXATION; GLASS

Title: Thermal energy storage studies in the Lower Greensand aquifer in Cambridgeshire.
Affiliations: British Geological Survey, Maclean Building, Crowmarsh Gifford, Wallingford, Oxon OX10 8BB, UK.
Authors with affiliations: Kitching, R., British Geological Survey, Maclean Building, Crowmarsh Gifford, Wallingford, Oxon OX10 8BB, UK.; Adams, B., British Geological Survey, Maclean Building, Crowmarsh Gifford, Wallingford, Oxon OX10 8BB, UK.
Abstract: Approximately 1500 m3 of water at approx 60oC was injected into the Lower Greensand over a period of 78 days, and after storage for 105 days the heat was abstracted over a period of 97 days. Over this single cycle of operation, 33% of the injected energy was recovered. This proportion could probably be increased significantly with further cycles and/or with greater amounts of heat injected. Computer modelling suggests energy recovery factors of 66% appear to be feasible. -R.A.H.

Title: The role and economics of different types of energy storage
Source title: Tunnelling and Underground Space Technology incorporating Trenchless
Authors with affiliations: Margen, P.
Abstract: The value of heat storage for space heating systems ranging in size from individual multi-residential buildings to large district heating systems is examined for various time scales of storage-daily, intermediate and seasonal-and for various types of base-load plants for charging the stores. The cost of different types of storage-steel vessels, earth pits, rock caverns, clay stores, drilled rock stores and aquifers-are examined for built, tendered and designed projects, and are expressed as simplified cost equations. A comparison between the value and cost storage is used to discuss which types of stores are best suited for different tasks. Payback time and net savings achievable for various applications are derived. Payback times between less than two years and seven years are often attainable where conditions are suitable. While the numerical results are evaluated for Swedish conditions, comments on applicability elsewhere are included. © 1986.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS - Analysis; ENERGY STORAGE - Equipment; BASE-LOAD PRODUCTION SOURCES; CO-GENERATION PLANTS; DISTRICT HEATING SYSTEMS; INDUSTRIAL WASTE HEAT; PAYBACK TIMES; HEATING

Authors: LaWhite Leif E., Schlecht Martin F.
Title: ACTIVE FILTERS FOR 1 MHZ POWER CIRCUITS WITH STRICT INPUT/OUTPUT RIPPLE REQUIREMENTS.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: LaWhite, Leif E., MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA; Schlecht, Martin F., MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
Abstract: As the switching frequency of a dc-dc converter is raised from 100 kHz to 1 MHz, one would expect the energy storage elements of the circuit to be correspondingly reduced in size. If the circuit must meet input and output ripple requirements of the nature of MIL-STD-461B CEO3, however, the advantage of a higher switching frequency is significantly offset by the higher filter attenuation levels required. The use of active filters, in conjunction with minimal passive filters, to achieve the required ripple levels with a much smaller overall volume is discussed. Working active filters with gains in excess of 100 at 1 MHz are also presented.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE - Switching; MILITARY EQUIPMENT - Standards; INDUCTOR AND CAPACITOR ENHANCING CIRCUITS; INPUT AND OUTPUT RIPPLE LEVELS; MIL-STD 461B CEO3; SWITCHING FREQUENCY; Electric filters, Active

Authors: Ferrieux Jean-Paul, Toutain Emmanuel, Le-Huy Hoang
Title: MULTIFUNCTION DC-DC CONVERTER AS VERSATILE POWER CONDITIONER.
Affiliations: ENSIEG, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St., -Martin-d'Heres, Fr, ENSIEG, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. -Martin-d'Heres, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Ferrieux, Jean-Paul, ENSIEG, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St., -Martin-d'Heres, Fr, ENSIEG, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. -Martin-d'Heres, Fr; Toutain, Emmanuel, ENSIEG, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St., -Martin-d'Heres, Fr, ENSIEG, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. -Martin-d'Heres, Fr; Le-Huy, Hoang, ENSIEG, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St., -Martin-d'Heres, Fr, ENSIEG, Lab d'Electrotechnique, St. -Martin-d'Heres, Fr
Abstract: A multifunction dc-dc converter is presented that can be used as a single power conditioner connecting the source, the storage, and the load in solar or wind energy systems. The proposed converter is basically of a capacitive storage-type using a single transistor as a power switch. The configuration and function of the converter can be modified by an appropriate combination of three contactors. In each configuration the energy flow is controlled by the duty cycle of the power switch. Four possible configurations of the multifunction converter are considered, and operation is analyzed for each configuration. Static and dynamic characteristics are studied using average equivalent circuits. Application of the proposed multifunction converter in low-power solar or wind energy systems is discussed. Experimental results obtained with a prototype circuit are given.
Index Keywords: TRANSISTORS - Switching; CAPACITIVE STORAGE; ENERGY FLOW CONTROL; MULTIFUNCTION CONVERTER; POWER SWITCH; SINGLE POWER CONDITIONER; Electric converters, Power type

Authors: Huang B.K., Toksoy M., Cengel Y.A.
Title: Transient response of latent heat storage in greenhouse solar system
Affiliations: Department of Biological and Agricultural Engineering, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC 27695, United States; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Dokuz Eylul University, Bornova, Izmir, Turkey; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Nevada, Reno, NV 89557, United States

Abstract: A latent heat storage system with two different stacking configurations and air bafflings was designed and constructed as an integrated part of the greenhouse solar system (solar barn). Commercial cylindrical storage rods were used as the primary storage elements. The results showed that the designed latent storage systems demonstrated significantly higher compact storage capacity than water or rock storage and that the ring-baffled storage unit performed better than the cross-baffled storage unit. © 1986.

Title: Cation patterns and information storage.
Source title: Clay Minerals and the Origin of Life
Affiliations: Dept. of Geology, State Univ. of New York, 4240 Ridge Lea, Amherst, NY 14226, USA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Giese, R.F., Dept. of Geology, State Univ. of New York, 4240 Ridge Lea, Amherst, NY 14226, USA., United States
Abstract: The capacity of a structure to store information depends on that structure being, in a restricted sense, unpredictable. Since there is no sure way of observing the pattern of cations in short-range ordered domains, an alternative is to make models of the structure in order to reproduce what may exist in real crystals. One way to do this is to construct a mathematical model of the crystal structure, calculate its energy and then try to minimize the energy by rearranging the substituting cations. Patterns of cations that are found in energetically favourable model structures are likely to occur in nature. Only two studies have tried to examine the short-range ordering patterns in layer silicates (trioctahedral and dioctahedral micas). Each looks at a different aspect of the problem with quite different methods. Both agree that short-range ordering patterns are likely in disordered layer silicates and that the energies of many of these patterns should be similar. -J.M.H.

Authors: Rao M., Acharya S., Samuel A.M., Srivastava O.N.
Title: The electronic behaviour of polytypes. Relevance to energy conversion (I).
Authors with affiliations: Rao, M.; Acharya, S.; Samuel, A.M.; Srivastava, O.N.
Abstract: The relationship between the electronic behaviour (e.g. the electronic band gap) and polytype periodicity/structure is discussed. The case of SnS2/SnSe2 is examined in detail. The results suggest that the polytypes of a compound represent lattice-matched variable band-gap semiconductors. The possible role of polytypes in the storage of energy (hydrogen and electrical energies) is outlined. -R.A.H. Physics Dept., Brooklyn College, City Univ. Brooklyn, NY, USA.

Title: High temperature thermal energy storage: A method of achieving rapid charge and discharge rates
Affiliations: Division of Energy Technology, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization. Highett, Vic., Australia
Authors with affiliations: Close, D.J., Division of Energy Technology, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization. Highett, Vic., Australia; Peck, M.K., Division of Energy Technology, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization. Highett, Vic., Australia
Abstract: Types of thermal energy storage are discussed and a classification introduced where the store type is identified by the pair of fluids used to charge and discharge the store. From studies reported in the literature, the type characterized by the fluid pairs steam and steam, or steam and a high pressure fluid, are identified as requiring further development. To overcome the high costs of pressure containment or heat exchange presently encountered with stores exchanging heat with high pressure fluids, a store geometry is proposed comprising a packed bed with steam or high pressure fluid tubes exchanging heat with it. The packing may be a sensible heat, or encapsulated phase change or thermochemical material. The primary problem is the low effective conductivity of the packing leading to either very large numbers of steam tubes or very long charge and discharge times. A method of achieving high conductivities in packed beds is proposed using a gas vapour mixture in the voids. This mixture is maintained at 1 atmosphere pressure so that the container cost is kept low. Data from an experimental system shows that predicted high conductivities can be achieved in steady state, and that under transient conditions, the approximate theories so far developed are adequate for engineering design purposes. © 1986.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Packed Beds; DISCHARGE RATES; HIGH HEAT TRANSFER RATES; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE COSTS; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: HORIZONTAL NATURAL CONVECTION BOUNDARY LAYER REGIME IN A CLOSED CAVITY.
Source title: Heat Transfer, Proceedings of the International Heat Transfer Conference
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, R., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA; Lauriat, G., Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden,, CO, USA, Solar Energy Research Inst, Golden, CO, USA
Abstract: A series of numerical, experimental, and analytical results have been presented that describe the horizontal boundary layer regime in a closed cavity, which is heated from below and cooled along one vertical wall. The presence of bottom heating produces a well-defined horizontal boundary layer on the floor of the cavity. Due to the presence of bottom heating, the floor boundary layer entrains fluid from the core in addition to entraining fluid from the boundary layer on the cold wall, and has a distinct thermal boundary layer structure that is not present in the flow across the floor of a cavity with differentially heated sides. In spite of the potential destablizing effect of the bottom heating arrangement, experimental observations in a water-filled test cell indicate that the horizontal boundary layer structure persists for flux modified Rayleigh numbers as large as 5 multiplied by 10**1**3 and is not disturbed by the formation of Benard type instabilities or thermal plumes. The results of the numerical calculation have been compared with scaling relationships and heat transfer correlations for horizontal and vertical surfaces in an infinite medium. The vertical cooled surface in the cavity is shown to behave much like a vertical surface in an infinite medium, indicating that the flow past the vertical surface is relatively unaffected by the presence of the heated bottom wall. The same conclusion does not apply to the bottom wall.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; BOTTOM HEATING ARRANGEMENT; CLOSED CAVITY; NATURAL CONVECTION; Heat transfer

Authors with affiliations: Cacciola, G., Istituto CRN, TAE, Via Salita S. Lucia sopra Contesse, 39, 98013 Pistunina, Messina, Italy; Giordano, N., Istituto CRN, TAE, Via Salita S. Lucia sopra Contesse, 39, 98013 Pistunina, Messina, Italy
Abstract: Chemical reaction, adsorption of a gas in a solid, or adsorption of gas in a liquid solvent can be used to solve problems in conservation, storage and transmission of energy. Possible applications of such processes are chemical heat pumps, cooling systems, heat transformers, chemical heat pipes, separation, storage and transmission of hydrogen. In the present paper, the principal chemical processes are described with their applications, advantages and drawbacks. © 1986.

Authors: Breed C.E., McGill K.E., Holt M.T.
Title: Pilot-Plant Production Of A Concentrated Ammonium Polyphosphate Suspension Fertilizer
Source title: Journal of Environmental Science and Health. Part A: Environmental Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Tennessee Valley Authority, National Fertilizer Development Center, Muscle Shoals, Alabama 35660, United States
Authors with affiliations: Breed, C.E., Tennessee Valley Authority, National Fertilizer Development Center, Muscle Shoals, Alabama 35660, United States; McGill, K.E., Tennessee Valley Authority, National Fertilizer Development Center, Muscle Shoals, Alabama 35660, United States; Holt, M.T., Tennessee Valley Authority, National Fertilizer Development Center, Muscle Shoals, Alabama 35660, United States
Abstract: TVA is developing a process for the production of a high-grade ammonium polyphosphate (APP) suspension fertilizer from merchantgrade wet—process phosphoric acid and anhydrous ammonia. The acid is ammoniated in an “enlarged” pipe reactor; the molten APP is dissolved in water and the fluid is cooled to room temperature by evaporative cooling. Attapulgite clay is in the APP fluid to prevent solids from settling during shipment, storage, and use. The process is energy efficient in that hot APP fluid provides all the heat required to preheat the phosphoric acid and vaporize the ammonia. Suspension grade of up to 12-36-0 can be made with 20 to 25% of the P2O5 present as polyphosphate. Lower shipping costs due to the high nutrient content of the suspensions makes it a desirable product. The APP fluid fertilizer can be either applied directly to the soil or used in preparation of mixed suspension products of various ratios. © 1985, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: AMMONIA - Chemical Reactions; AMMONIUM COMPOUNDS - Applications; CLAY - Applications; AMMONIUM POLYPHOSPHATES; PILOT PLANTS; FERTILIZERS

Title: ACTIVE FILTER FOR REACTIVE POWER AND HARMONICS COMPENSATION.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference

Authors with affiliations: Malesani, L., Univ of Padova, Italy, Univ of Padova, Italy; Rossetto, L., Univ of Padova, Italy, Univ of Padova, Italy; Tenti, P., Univ of Padova, Italy, Univ of Padova, Italy
Abstract: A three-phase active filter is described for the compensation of reactive power and current harmonics of a symmetrical load. The filter uses an inductor for energy storage and a two-quadrant PWM bridge coverter. A control system ensuring fast response and good operation even under severe load transients is also described. The converter structure and control scheme are discussed. Simulation of the system is performed, ratings of components are established, and experimental results are reported.

Title: Plans for a demonstration photovoltaic/wind/pumped storage system integrated on an island in Boston Harbor.
Source title: Energy for rural and island communities IV. Proc. 4th international conference, Inverness, 1985
Affiliations: Education and Resources Group, Old City Hall, 45 School Street, Boston, MA 02108, USA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Westgate, M., Education and Resources Group, Old City Hall, 45 School Street, Boston, MA 02108, USA., United States; Bergman, D.A., Education and Resources Group, Old City Hall, 45 School Street, Boston, MA 02108, USA., United States
Abstract: Describes the energy section of the Master Plan for an Island in Boston Harbor. The Island provides an unusual opportunity to demonstrate the viability of various alternative energy systems. Placing emphasis on photovoltaic cells, the plan also utilizes windpower and water pumped storage. Diesel generators are to be installed as backup. Educational displays are to be interactive with the public, demonstrating power availability and use and the value of conservation. Island visitation is projected at 20 000 initially, growing to 200 000 annually. Electrical demand would grow from 28 000 KWH to 250 000 KWH annually. -from Authors

Authors: Ranade S.M., Lee M.-C., Prengle Jr. H.W.
Title: Chemical storage of solar energy-kinetics of heterogeneous NH3 and H2SO4 reactions II. Process and reactor design
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ranade, S.M., Department of Chemical Engineering, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States; Lee, M.-C., Department of Chemical Engineering, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States; Prengle Jr., H.W., Department of Chemical Engineering, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States
Abstract: An important energy recovery step in the ammonium hydrogen sulfate (AHS) cycle is the recombination reaction producing NH4HSO4. It has been determined that the optimum way to accomplish this, and prevent side reactions, is by the heterogeneous gas-liquid reaction of H2SO4 and NH3. A mathematical model is presented and applied to the two reaction zones and a method of numerical solution is discussed. Three horizontal pilot-scale configurations, 0.17 × 106 to 4.2 × 106 kJ/h energy release, are discussed and sizing is presented. The most important conclusion from the work is that the energy can be released most effectively by carrying out the reaction in a double pipe tubular reactor operating in the annular flow regime with both gas and liquid in turbulent flow. © 1986.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Reaction Kinetics; AMMONIUM HYDROGEN SULFATE (AHS) CYCLE; CHEMICAL STORAGE; ENERGY RECOVERY; REACTION ZONES; RECOMBINATION REACTION; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Chemical storage of solar energy-Kinetics of heterogeneous NH3 and H2SO4 reactions I. Analysis of experimental reaction and mass transfer data
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, M.-C., Department of Chemical Engineering, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States; Prengle Jr., H.W., Department of Chemical Engineering, The Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States
Abstract: The exothermic heterogeneous reaction of ammonia vapor and liquid sulfuric acid (H2O + SO3) to produce ammonium hydrogen sulfate and ammonium sulfate is important for the recovery of stored energy in the small molecules, H2O, SO3 and NH3. As the first part of a chemical reaction engineering analysis, literature data on the reaction and mass transfer were analyzed. The reaction rate constant as a function of temperature and the mass transfer coefficient as a function of the dynamical variables in a flow system were determined. The reaction mechanism in concentrated liquid phase is pseudo-second order and the rate is extremely fast. However, for the heterogeneous system with ammonia transferred from the vapor phase the mass transfer is rate controlling. A broad range of mass transfer data, covering packed columns and dispersed phase droplets, was correlated over 15 orders of magnitude by the jD-factor correlation method. © 1986.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Reaction Kinetics; MASS TRANSFER; AMMONIA VAPOR; CHEMICAL REACTION ENGINEERING ANALYSIS; HETEROGENEOUS REACTION; LIQUID SULFURIC ACID; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Analytic modelling of solar radiation: driven temperature variations of outdoor surfaces
Affiliations: Department of Applied Physics, The University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, G4 0NG, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Buchan, G.D., Department of Applied Physics, The University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, G4 0NG, United Kingdom
Abstract: An analytic model is described for the variation of surface temperature T0(t) ofa freely evaporating or totally dry surface exposed to complicated, non-analytic variations of meteorological conditions expressed in (N + 1)-point time series form. Its basis is a parameterized, analytic representation of T0, inserted in linearized equations describing the surface energy balance and the concurrent underlying heat conduction. Applied to diurnal variations (with N = 24) over bare soil, the model reproduces observed temperatures with a typical standard deviation less than 1K, and the daily mean within 0.1 K. The method should find general application in modelling of storage systems subject to complicated, discretely-sampled boundary conditions, where a linear analytic equation links the latter to the storage term. © 1986.
Author Keywords: energy balance; heat storage; solar radiation; surface temperature
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURE; INFRARED IMAGING; INFRARED RADIATION - Remote Sensing; SOILS - Temperature Measurement; SURFACES; ANALYTIC MODELING; ENERGY BALANCE; HEAT STORAGE; OUTDOOR SURFACES; SURFACE TEMPERATURE; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: A method for steady-state simulation of multistage separation columns involving nonideal systems
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. T2N 1N4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wu, J.-S., Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. T2N 1N4, Canada; Bishnoi, P.R., Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. T2N 1N4, Canada
Abstract: A new algorithm is developed for steady-state simulation of multistage separation columns. The algorithm decouples the model equations into two groups. The component-material balance and summation equations are solved simultaneously by the Newton-Raphson method for temperatures and component flow rates in the inner loop. The energy-balance equations are solved in the outer loop to obtain total flow rates. The K-factor is separated into three parts, each representing separately the effect of temperature, composition and apparent volatility. This makes the analytical calculation of the partial derivatives of the K-factors in the Jacobian matrix a simple task. The stability and efficiency of the algorithm is illustrated by solving a variety of problems for distillation, absorber and reboiled absorber columns. The algorithm does not require large storage space. © 1986.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL EQUIPMENT - Computer Simulation; CHEMICAL OPERATIONS - Mathematical Models; MATHEMATICAL PROGRAMMING; MULTICOMPONENT DISTILLATION; MULTISTAGE SEPARATION COLUMNS; MULTISTAGE SEPARATION PROCESS; STEADY-STATE SIMULATION; SEPARATION

Authors: Ohtani Y., Ohta S., Terada A.
Title: Os‐doped γ‐Fe2O3 thin‐film media for perpendicular recording
Source title: Electronics and Communications in Japan (Part II: Electronics)
Affiliations: Ntt Ibaraki Electrical Communication Laboratories, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohtani, Y., Ntt Ibaraki Electrical Communication Laboratories, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan; Ohta, S., Ntt Ibaraki Electrical Communication Laboratories, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan; Terada, A., Ntt Ibaraki Electrical Communication Laboratories, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan
Abstract: Since Os‐doped γ‐Fe2O3 sputtered thin film can be added in perpendicular anisotropy by annealing in the magnetic field perpendicular to the film surface, it has potential as a perpendicular magnetic recording media. Herein we examine both a method to dope Os by reactive sputtering and the causes contributing to the induced magnetic anisotropy. Its performance as a perpendicular magnetic disk has yielded the following results. When Os is solidified during the formation of Fe3O4 film by reactive sputtering, reproducible doping is possible. When γ‐Fe2O3 is formed in atmospheric oxidation, the coercive force increases in proportion to the Os doping (Hc ∝ 500x, x = Os at. %). Magnetic anneal is effective for the γ‐Fe2O3 state, and a large anisotropy can be added when the oxygen partial pressure in the atmosphere is increased. Furthermore, the activation energy for the induced anisotropy was approximately 1.0 eV. The induced anisotropy seems to be related to the vacancies. In the recording reproduction using a thin‐film ring head, the reproduced isolated waveform is dipulse, thereby confirming the recording with a large perpendicular component (dipulse ratio 0.7). Copyright © 1986 Wiley Periodicals, Inc., A Wiley Company
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC - Film; HYSTERESIS; MAGNETIC ANISOTROPY; OS DOPING; PERPENDICULAR MAGNETIC RECORDING; REACTIVE SPUTTERING; MAGNETIC MATERIALS

Title: Autonomous electrical supply systems based on renewable energy sources - results from a simulation model and experiences with a small scale system.

Abstract: By combining today's techniques of energy conversion and storage it is possible in principle to construct energy supply systems based to a high degree on renewable energy sources. We report on simulation calculations for such systems using experimentally validated models for converters and storage devices. In particular the influence of system parameters such as size of different converters and battery capacity on the renewable fraction and the energy pay back time of the whole system is discussed. -Authors

Title: DESIGN OF SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEMS FOR SUPPLYING POWER TO REMOTE COMMUNICATIONS CENTERS.
Affiliations: Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK,, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ashenayi, K., Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK,, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK, USA; Ramakumar, R., Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK,, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, OK, USA
Abstract: Three different load models are evaluated in the context of designing a solar energy system for supplying power to remote communications centers. The loss-of-power-supply probability is used as a measure of performance. The load models range in sophistication from a typical load profile for a communications center based on recorded data to a simple model consisting of just two parameters, namely the maximum and minimum load demands. It is found that the simpler load models are good substitutes for the more sophisticated load model from the design viewpoint. The final design values, based on the loss-of-power-supply probability approach, for a typical solar energy conversion system with energy storage supplying power to a remote communication center are given. The results should be useful to designers of solar energy conversion systems with energy storage.

Authors: Klueh R.L., Gelles D.S., Lechtenberg T.A.
Title: Development of ferritic steels for reduced activation: The US program
Affiliations: Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Westinghouse Hanford Company, Richland, WA, United States; GA Technologies, Inc., San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klueh, R.L., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Gelles, D.S., Westinghouse Hanford Company, Richland, WA, United States; Lechtenberg, T.A., GA Technologies, Inc., San Diego, CA, United States
Abstract: The Cr-Mo ferritic (martensitic) steels are candidates for the structural components of fusion reactors. Irradiation of such steels in a fusion environment produces long-lived radioactive isotopes, which lead to difficult radioactive waste disposal problems once the structure is removed from service. Such problems could be reduced by using steels that contain only elements that produce radioactive isotopes that decay to low levels in a reasonable time (tens of years instead of hundreds or thousands of years). The US Department of Energy has a program to develop steels to meet the criteria for shallow land burial as opposed to deep geologic storage. A review of the alloy development programs indicates that ferritic steels that meet these criteria can be developed. © 1986.
Index Keywords: RADIOACTIVE WASTES - Disposal; STAINLESS STEEL; LOW ACTIVATION ALLOYS; NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR

Authors: William Prengle Jr. H., Lee M.-C.
Title: Chemical storage of solar energy-The Flood-Förland-Lindemann hypotheses and the decomposition of pyrosulfate ions
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, The Energy Laboratory University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States
Authors with affiliations: William Prengle Jr., H., Department of Chemical Engineering, The Energy Laboratory University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States; Lee, M.-C., Department of Chemical Engineering, The Energy Laboratory University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States
Abstract: The endothermic decomposition of metal pyrosulfate in molten phase to produce metal sulfate and sulfur trioxide gas is an important chemical energy storage reaction. A chemical reaction engineering analysis of certain literature data was carried out to obtain a model for the decomposition and the rate constant as a function of temperature. The analysis indicates that the rate controlling reaction event is the cation-anion interaction of K+ and S2O7-2 ions to form KS2O7-1, simultaneously polarizing the latter to weaken the SOS bridge and release SO3. Based on this view transition state theory was applied and yielded an expression for the rate constant in essential agreement with experimental data. A preliminary model for a pilot-scale reactor is presented. © 1986.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Decomposition; CHEMICAL ENERGY STORAGE CYCLE; CHEMICAL REACTORS; PILOT-SCALE REACTOR; PYROSULFATE IONS; SOLAR ENERGY

Abstract: The melting process of an unfixed solid PCM between two heated concentric horizontal and isothermal cylinders was investigated both by experimental techniques and by a combined analytical and numerical method. Abstract: A straightforward analysis of a solar water heating system with n-tanks connected in series has been presented. The long-term performance of the system has also been studied. On the basis of numerical calculations made for four successive days, the following conclusions have been drawn: 1. (1) The fluctuation in temperature variation decreases with increase of the number of tanks connected in series. 2. (2) The variation becomes smooth after the second successive day, which is more desirable from the point of view of users. © 1986.

Abstract: A theoretical analysis is presented for the phase change process occurring in a cylindrical annulus in which rectangular, uniformly spaced axial fins, spanning the annulus, are attached to the inner isothermal tube, while the outer tube is kept adiabatic. The model assumes conduction to be the only mode of heat transfer. The governing equations are solved by finite-difference methods. The time-wise evolution of the interface profile, phase-change fraction and energy stored/discharged and the effect of all the nine prescribable parameters are presented here. Based on the analysis a working formula VF = 1.1275 (Fo Ste Tf)0.624 (N)0.028 (L)-1.385(W)-0.049 is suggested for engineering design purposes. © 1986.

Lucia sopra Contesse, 39, 98013 Pistunina, Messina, Italy; Cacciola, G., Istituto CNR, TAE, Via Salita S. Lucia sopra Contesse, 39, 98013 Pistunina, Messina, Italy
Abstract: The main aim of this work is to make an economic evaluation of solar energy systems applied to the zootechnic field. As a typical application, a cattle-breeding farm was chosen, with the following energy requirements: stable heating during the cold season, heating of washing water, and the drying of hay during harvest. By means of a computer program simulating the hourly operative conditions of the whole system (solar source, storage and thermal load) it was possible to optimize the plant components in order to minimize energy costs. Results are referred to a plant situated in Sicily (Messina). © 1986.
Index Keywords: FARM BUILDINGS - Heating; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; HAY DRYING; STABLE HEATING; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Biogas clean-up and utilization
Affiliations: Companhia de Saneamento Basico do Estado de Sao Paulo, SABESP, 01448 Sao Paulo, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Camargo, E.B., Companhia de Saneamento Basico do Estado de Sao Paulo, SABESP, 01448 Sao Paulo, Brazil
Abstract: The economic use of energy from biogas generated in anaerobic biodigesters installed in the sewage treatment plants owned by SABESP is described in this paper with evaluation of its advantages in vehicular use. The clean-up process and use of biogas were designed based on results obtained from a pilot plant in operation since 1983. The biogas is sweetened through water scrubbing,with reduction of CO2 and humidity, to attain acceptable levels for consumption by vehicular engines. The resulting methane gas is odourized and compressed in cylinders by high pressure compressors. The vehicles are adapted to compressed methane, with installation of high pressure cylinders, pressure reducing valves, methane/air mixers, valves and pressure gauge for maximum operation safety. Filling of vehicles (refuelling) is done in an appropriate station and transfer of methane to the vehicle is by difference of pressure.

Title: The influence of temperature and absorbed water on the fatigue crack propagation in nylon-6,6
Affiliations: Polymer Science and Engineering Program, Materials Research Center, Coxe Lab 32, Bethlehem, PA 18015, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hahn, M.T., Polymer Science and Engineering Program, Materials Research Center, Coxe Lab 32, Bethlehem, PA 18015, United States; Hertzberg, R.W., Polymer Science and Engineering Program, Materials Research Center, Coxe Lab 32, Bethlehem, PA 18015, United States; Manson, J.A., Polymer Science and Engineering Program, Materials Research Center, Coxe Lab 32, Bethlehem, PA 18015, United States; Sperling, L.H., Polymer Science and Engineering Program, Materials Research Center, Coxe Lab 32, Bethlehem, PA 18015, United States
Abstract: The effect of absorbed water on the fatigue crack propagation (FCP) of nylon-6,6 was investigated over a range of test temperatures and is correlated with dynamic mechanical properties. Both the storage modulus, a measure of specimen stiffness, and the loss compliance, a measure of energy dissipation and hysteretic heating, influence FCP response. At a given temperature, fatigue resistance is greatest for a given water content corresponding to an optimum combination of storage modulus, E′, and loss compliance, D″. The use of an empirical shift parameter to normalize the temperature dependence of the FCP behaviour of nylon with various water contents is discussed. © 1986.

Abstract: Operation of a high gain VUV/Soft X-Ray Free Electron Laser (FEL) oscillator on the Stanford X-Ray Center (SXRC) storage ring is investigated. Laser energy and emittance acceptance in the high gain regime for XUV light are examined using the FEL amplifier simulation code FRED. Assuming 50% mirror reflectivity, oscillation is shown to be feasible down to 220 Angstrom with a realizable wiggler magnet placed in the 27 straight section of the 1 GeV SXRC ring. Laser output power and time structure are determined for a 960 Angstrom oscillator operating in both 'cw' and slow pulsed modes.

Authors: Hijikata K., Himeno N., Miyasaka H., Saito K.
Title: LATENT HEAT THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE BY USING BINARY MIXTURE.
Source title: Heat Transfer, Proceedings of the International Heat Transfer Conference
Affiliations: Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Hijikata, K., Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn; Himeno, N., Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn; Miyasaka, H., Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn; Saito, K., Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn, Tokyo Inst of Technology, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: Latent heat thermal energy storage is investigated by using a binary mixture of p-C//6H//4Cl//2 and p-C//6H//4Br//2 as a heat storage material. In solidification of a binary mixture, the melting temperature changes due to the variation of mixing ratio are caused by the segregation. Two solidification models are proposed for a theoretical analysis. In the first model, the solidification increases in the direction of the heat flow. In the other, it is assumed that the segregation grows perpendicularly to the heat flow, which corresponds to a dendritic solidification. The former model can be well applied in the low mixing ratio of p-C//6H//4Cl//2 and the latter can be used in the high mixing ratio. The temperature profile also changes in accordance with the initial mixing ratio of the two materials, however, the variation of the transfered heat from outside with time is quite similar to that of pure material having the same melting temperature. The effect of free convection on heat storage performance is also investigated by changing the direction of the heat input or output.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Convection; LIQUIDS - Freezing; MATERIALS - Phase Transitions; BINARY MIXTURE SOLIDIFICATION; HEAT STORAGE MATERIALS; LATENT HEAT THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SOLIDIFICATION MODEL; Energy storage

Abstract: The development of electric and hybrid vehicles in the Federal Republic of Germany (FRG) is described. Abstract: It is shown that internal low-frequency energy storage can be used to achieve harmonic-free operation and controllable power factors in converters whose desired operations require unequal instantaneous input and output powers, such as in single-phase rectifiers, inverters, cycloconverters, and reactive power generators. A synthesis and analysis technique is developed for such converters. It can be used to find all converters which can be obtained from a given set of network elements. Since this technique includes converter dynamics, it leads to a systematic procedure for the design of converters with minimum component size for given specifications.
